Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- For provisions dealing with weights and measures, see 1942 Miss. Code, § 5132 
et seq.; as to the official who shall keep standards thereof, § 5142. 


Sec. 2-1. - Fiscal year. 
    The fiscal year of the city shall begin on the 1st day of October, in each year. 
(Code 1922, § 191) 
Cross reference- For assessments required for personal and real property each year, § 18-1. 


Sec. 2-2. - Social security and state retirement for officers and employees. 
(a)	Policy declared. It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the city to extend the provisions 
of Articles I and II, Senate Bill No. 273, Regular Session, Mississippi Legislature of 1952, as 
amended by chapter 346, laws of 1956, chapter 547, laws of 1958 and chapters 453 and 454, laws 
of 1960, which provide Social Security and State Retirement to eligible employees and officers of the 
city. In pursuance of said policy, and for that purpose, the officers of the city shall take such action as 
may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(b)	Agreement authorized. The mayor and clerk of the city are hereby authorized and directed to 
execute an agreement with the Public Employees' Retirement System of Mississippi to secure 
coverage of eligible employees as provided in subsection (a) hereof. 
(c)	Withholdings from earnings authorized. Withholdings from salaries or wages of employees for the 
purpose provided in subsection (a) hereof are hereby authorized to be made in the amounts and at 
such times as may be required by applicable state and federal laws and regulations, and shall be 
paid over to the state agency in such amounts and at such times as are designated by state laws 
and regulations. 
(d)	Employer contributions and administrative expense. Employer contributions and administrative 
expense shall be paid to the state agency in accordance with applicable state laws and regulations 
from amounts appropriated for such purposes. 
(e)	Duties of city clerk. The city clerk shall maintain such records and submit such reports as may be 
required by applicable state and federal laws or regulations. 
(Ord. No. 444, §§ 1-5, 9-23-1952) 
State Law reference- For authority to extend such benefits to employees of political 
subdivisions, including municipalities, see 1942 Miss. Code, §§ 7446-01, 7446-02, 7446-05, 
7446-11 and 7446-13. 


Sec. 2-3. - Administrative departments-Established. 
    The duties of the municipal government of the city, shall be divided into three departments. 
    The first department shall include the department of finance, the city clerk's office, the airport 
properties and management, the tax assessor's office, fire department and police department. 
    The second department shall include all departments of streets and structures, including the disposal 
plant under construction at this time and the recreation and playgrounds of the city. 
    The third department shall include the water and light department and public properties of the city. 
(Ord. No. 530, § 1, 6-5-1962; Ord. No. 579, § 1, 7-5-1965) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 579, § 4, enacted July 5, 1965, repealed §§ 2-3-2-5 and enacted 
similar provisions regarding the division of administrative duties into departments, codified as §§ 
2-3-2-5 by the editors, although said ordinance did not specifically amend this Code. 
Cross reference- As to the second department, for provisions regarding fire protection and 
prevention generally, Ch. 8; finances, Ch. 18; airport regulations, Ch. 3. 
State Law reference- For establishment and organization of municipal departments, see 1942 
Miss. Code, § 3374-54. 


Sec. 2-4. - Same-Assignment of officers and employees. 
    The various employees and officers of the city shall be assigned to the appropriate departments as 
set forth in section 2-3 of this chapter as follows: 
First department: City clerk, tax collector, tax assessor, chief of fire department and all firemen; chief of 
police, assistant, or assistants, chief of police, and all policemen; police court, airport and Fletcher Field 
housing engineer. 
Second department: Superintendent of sanitation, including the disposal plant under construction at the 
present time; superintendent of structures and streets; city engineer, building inspector and housing 
officer. 
Third department: Auditorium manager, water and light department and public property. 
(Ord. No. 520, § 1, 7-3-1961; Ord. No. 530, §§ 1, 2, 6-5-1962; Ord. No. 579, § 2, 7-5-1965) 
Editor's note- See note following § 2-3. Various operations were reassigned from one 
department to another to achieve a better functioning of the city government. 
Cross reference- For the powers and duties of the building inspector, see § 6-4; as to creation 
of office of police justice, § 14-63; for duty of tax assessor to make assessments of personal, real 
property, § 18-1. 


Sec. 2-5. - Same-Supervision. 
    The mayor and commissioners to whom each department is hereby assigned shall have control in 
the direction and control of all officers, or employees, assigned or employed in the respective 
departments. It shall be the duty of such mayor and commissioners to see that all ordinances, resolutions 
or orders of the board of mayor and commissioners of the city relating to such departments are properly 
executed and that they shall from time to time recommend to the board of mayor and commissioners of 
said city such matters concerning the department assigned to each of them as he may deem necessary. 
(Ord. No. 520, § 3, 7-3-1961; Ord. No. 579, § 3, 7-5-1969) 
Amendment note- Ord. No. 579, § 3, took the authority for supervision of the various 
departments from the superintendent of said departments and placed it with the mayor and 
commissioners to whom the departments are assigned. See note following § 2-3. 


Sec. 2-6. - Meetings of board of mayor and commissioners. 
(a)	Meeting dates. The board of mayor and commissioners of the City of Clarksdale shall hold its regular 
meetings on the second and fourth Mondays of each month, in the main council chambers, first floor, 
situated in City Hall, 121 Sunflower Avenue, Clarksdale, Mississippi 38613, beginning at 4:00 p.m., 
commencing on the fourth Monday of March, 2003, being March 24, 2003, and on the second and 
fourth Mondays of each month thereafter, excepting legal holidays, at which time, any and all 
business properly coming before the said board of mayor and commissioners may be transacted. 
(b)	Prior actions validated. All actions, transactions, contracts, stipulations, proceedings and actions of 
any kind whatsoever heretofore had and done, are hereby ratified, confirmed, approved and 
adopted, insofar as the date, time and place of the meetings of the said board are concerned, 
whether at the time of any such meeting the time of the convention thereof was fixed and established 
by ordinance, resolution or order. 
(Ord. No. 609, § 1, 7-10-1969; Ord. No. 889, § 1, 6-29-1992; Ord. No. 894, § 1, 1-11-1993; Ord. 
No. 936, § 1, 1-21-1997; Ord. No. 940, § 1, 5-27-1997; Ord. No. 991, § 1, 2-17-2003) 
Amendment note- Ord. No. 609, § 3, repealed Ord. No. 524 of Nov. 14, 1961, Ord. No. 531 of 
June 18, 1962, and Ord. No. 580 of July 6, 1965, from which § 2-6 was derived. Section 1 of 
Ord. No. 609 enacted § 2-6 to read as herein set out. Prior to amendment § 2-6 consisted of 
subsections (a)-(d). Subsection (a) provided for monthly meetings; subsection (b) provided for 
weekly meetings; subsection (c) provided for monthly meetings in lieu of weekly meetings; and 
subsection (d) consisted of the provisions now designated as subsection (c). Ord. No. 991 of 
February 17, 2003, amended subsection (a), establishing meeting dates. 
Charter reference- Meeting dates designated, § 5. 
State Law reference- For authority to designate time of meetings, see Miss. Code 1942, § 
3374-51. 


Sec. 2-7. - Elections-To conform to state law. 
    All municipal elections shall be conducted and governed by the election laws of the State of 
Mississippi, as far as applicable, except as herein otherwise directed. The commissioners, inspectors and 
managers, of elections shall perform all the duties in respect to municipal elections which are prescribed 
by law. 
(Code 1922, § 189) 
State Law reference- For provisions governing municipal elections, see Miss Code 1942, § 
3374-60 to § 3374-69.7, inclusive. 


Sec. 2-8. - Same-Voting precinct and polling place established; alphabetical classification of voters. 
(a)	Authority. This section is adopted by authority of House Bill 522 of the 1948 Session of the 
Mississippi Legislature. [2] 
(b)	Precincts established. A city plan dividing the city into four single-member districts, or wards, from 
which four commissioners will be elected, one commissioner to be elected from each ward, with the 
mayor to be elected at large, is hereby adopted and approved. A map of said ward plan is on file in 
the office of the city clerk, and reference is made thereto as if fully set forth herein. 
(c)	Voting places designated. There are hereby established, for all municipal primary, general and 
special elections of the city, the following voting places: 
(1)	Ward One: Lee Drive Fire Station. 
(2)	Ward Two: Clarksdale Civic Auditorium. 
(3)	Ward Three: Riverton School. 
(4)	Ward Four: National Guard Armory. 
(d)	Alphabetical classification of voters. The qualified electors of the city are hereby divided as to voting 
in all municipal primary, general and special elections of the city into the following alphabetical 
sequence of their surnames: A through K and L through Z. Separate poll books, ballot boxes, tally 
sheets and other supplies used in municipal elections shall be provided and used for each 
subdivision of voters as set out in this subsection. Separate sets of election officials shall be 
appointed for each subdivision of voters as provided in this subsection. 
(Ord. No. 392, §§ 2-7, 3-23-1948; Res. of 4-21-1986) 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- H. B. 522 of the 1948 session appears as Miss. Code 1942, § 3374-69.5. 


Sec. 2-9. - Planning Commission-Created; purposes. 
    In order to make adequate provision for the preparation, adoption and revision of a city plan to guide, 
direct and control the future growth and development of the city in an orderly, efficient, healthful and 
economic manner, there is hereby created a commission to be known as the city planning commission, 
hereinafter referred to as the commission. 
(Ord. No. 409, § 1, 6-3-1949) 
Cross reference- For zoning generally, see Ch. 23; for creation, membership, procedure, 
powers of board of adjustment, see Ch. 23, art. II. 
State Law reference- For creation and powers of planning commission, see 1942 Miss. Code, 
§ 2890.5. 


Sec. 2-10. - Same-Members; appointment, terms, compensation. 
(a)	The planning commission shall consist of nine members, two of whom shall be officers or employees 
of the city, and all of whom shall be appointed to the commission by the board of mayor and 
commissioners. The two officers or employees of the city shall be appointed to serve until the 
expiration of the terms of the members of board of mayor and commissioners who appoint them, and 
the other members of the commission shall be appointed as follows: 
    One shall be appointed for a term of one year; 
    One shall be appointed for a term of two years; 
    One shall be appointed for a term of three years; 
    One shall be appointed for a term of four years; 
    One shall be appointed for a term of five years; 
    One shall be appointed for a term of six years; and 
    One shall be appointed for a term of seven years; 
(b)	The successors of the officers or employees appointed on the commission shall be appointed for 
terms expiring with the terms of the members of the board of mayor and commissioners who appoint 
them and the successors of the members of the commission other than the officers or employees of 
the city shall in all cases be appointed for a term of four years and all appointments to fill vacancies 
shall be for the unexpired term. 
(c)	All members of the commission shall serve without pay. 
(Ord. No. 409, § 2, 6-3-1949; Ord. No. 485, § 1, 8-13-1957) 
Note- See note to § 2-9. 


Sec. 2-11. - Same-Officers; rules of procedure; quorum. 
    The planning commission shall elect from among its members its own chairman, vice-chairman and 
secretary, and from time to time provide such rules and regulations, not inconsistent with the ordinances 
of the city, for its own organization and procedure as it may deem proper; provided, however, that the two 
members who are public officials of the city shall not be eligible to hold any of the offices mentioned in 
this section. Five members of said commission shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(Ord. No. 409, § 3, 6-3-1949) 


Sec. 2-12. - Same-Reports required; employment of personnel; expenses. 
    The planning commission shall make annual reports to the board of mayor and commissioners 
covering their investigations, transactions and recommendations, and such other and further reports 
relative thereto as it may deem proper or as may be required by the board of mayor and commissioners. 
Said commission may employ such city planners, engineers, clerks and other persons as authorized by 
the board of mayor and commissioners. The salaries and compensation of such employees, and other 
necessary expenses of said commission and its members, shall be provided for at the discretion of the 
board of mayor and commissioners by proper appropriations or ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 409, § 4, 6-3-1949) 


Sec. 2-13. - Same-Powers and duties. 
    The planning commission shall have the power, and it shall be its duty, to: 
(a)	Prepare city plan. Prepare a comprehensive city plan for the future development of the city, 
including recommendations relative to the location, length, width and arrangement of the 
streets, alleys, bridges, viaducts, parks, parkways, playgrounds, boulevards or other public 
grounds or improvements, the platting of public property into lots, plots, streets or alleys, the 
location of railroad or street car lines, transportation or other channels for communications of 
any kind, the grouping of public buildings, the design and placing of memorials, works of art, 
power or lighting plants, street lighting standards, telegraph and telephone poles, street name 
signs, billboards or projecting signs, elimination of railroad grade crossings and all other things 
pertaining to the welfare, housing, appearance or beauty of the city or any portion thereof. 
(b)	Interpret change, adjust plan. Make recommendations in connection with the execution and 
detailed interpretation of the city plan, and make such changes and adjustments in the plan as 
may be deemed desirable from time to time. 
(c)	Act upon zoning matters. Act upon any matter relating to zoning regulations of the city which 
may be referred to it by the board of mayor and commissioners, and assume such other related 
duties and responsibilities as may be delegated to it by the board of mayor and commissioners. 
(d)	Recommend regarding subdivisions. Prepare and recommend to the board of mayor and 
commissioners rules controlling the subdivision of land. 
(e)	Act upon plats for subdivisions. Make recommendations regarding the approval or disapproval 
of plats for land subdivision. Such plats shall be referred to the city planning commission before 
the board of mayor and commissioners takes any action. Failure of the city planning 
commission to act within sixty days shall be deemed an approval. 
(f)	Recommend legislation. Recommend from time to time legislation which may be desirable to 
further the purposes of city planning. 
(Ord. No. 409, § 5, 6-3-1949) 
Note- See note to § 2-9. 


Sec. 2-14. - Separate school district continued. 
    The territory which has previously been included in the separate school district of Clarksdale shall 
continue to be included in said separate school district as heretofore. 
(Code, 1922, § 206) 
State Law reference- For authority to reconstitute municipal separate school district, see 1942 
Miss. Code, § 6328-02. 


Sec. 2-15. - Selection of school trustees. 
    There shall be elected by the city commission five trustees for the public schools in the separate 
school district of Clarksdale in accordance with the provisions of 1942 Mississippi Code, section 6328-
07(b). 
(Code, 1922, § 207) 


Sec. 2-16. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2014-02, adopted May 27, 2014, repealed § 2-16 which pertained to 
residence requirements of officers and employees, and derived from Ord. No. 929, § 1, adopted 
April 1, 1996; and Ord. No. 950, § 1, adopted Jan. 12, 1998. 


Sec. 2-17. - Board of trustees of the Delta Blues Museum. 
(a)	Purpose of section. The purpose and intent of the board of mayor and commissioners of the city, by 
its adoption of this section, is to provide for the city and the citizens thereof and visitors and potential 
visitors thereto, all benefits resulting from the creation of a separate board of trustees to develop, 
expand, manage and control the Delta Blues Museum, and to operate the same, and to exercise all 
powers authorized by House Bill 1749 and/or granted by this section. 
(b)	Formation of board of trustees. 
(1)	Creation. The management and control of the Delta Blues Museum shall be vested in a board of 
trustees, comprised of five (5) trustees, who shall be appointed by the board of mayor and 
commissioners of the city. The first appointments shall be for terms of one (1), two (2), three (3), 
four (4) and five (5) years, respectively, and thereafter, a trustee shall be appointed to serve a 
five-year term. 
(2)	Qualifications. Each trustee shall be a resident and qualified elector of the city. After the initial 
term, if the initial term is for less than five (5) years, a trustee shall be limited to two (2) 
consecutive terms of office; provided, however, there shall be no limit on the total number of 
terms which may be served by a trustee. 
(3)	Vacancies. Vacancies of the board of trustees of the Delta Blues Museum shall be filled for 
unexpired terms by action of the board of mayor and commissioners of the city. 
(4)	Removal. Any trustee who shall move from the city or no longer be a qualified elector of the city, 
or who misses three (3) consecutive meetings of the board of trustees, shall be subject to 
removal by the board of mayor and commissioners of the city. 
(5)	Expense reimbursement. No trustee shall receive a salary or other compensation for his or her 
service; provided, however, that all trustees may be reimbursed for their necessary travel 
expenses and mileage incident to their attendance upon the business of the board of trustees, 
as provided by Mississippi Code Annotated, § 25-3-41 (Rev. 1991). 
(c)	Control and management of real and personal property; powers of trustees. 
(1)	Organization. The trustees of the Delta Blues Museum, immediately after their appointment, 
shall meet and organize by the election of such officers as they deem necessary, which may 
include a chairman, one (1) or more vice-chairmen, a secretary and a treasurer. They shall (i) 
adopt such bylaws, rules and regulations for their own guidance in the government of the Delta 
Blues Museum as they deem expedient; (ii) meet at least once in each month, (iii) have the 
supervision, care and custody of all property of the Delta Blues Museum, including the building 
or buildings leased, designated or set apart therefor; (iv) may, in their discretion, employ a 
director, a curator and such other staff as may be necessary, prescribe their duties, fix their 
compensation and remove them, with or without cause; (v) submit annually to the board of 
mayor and commissioners of the city a budget containing estimates of income and expenses for 
the ensuing year; (vi) have exclusive control of the finances of the Delta Blues Museum; (vii) 
accept such gifts of money or property for museum purposes and under such conditions as they 
deem expedient; (viii) purchase exhibits, equipment, insurance, supplies and other items 
incident to the operation, maintenance and control of the Delta Blues Museum as they, in their 
discretion, deem necessary; (ix) dispose of equipment and discarded or surplus museum 
materials as provided in Mississippi Code Annotated § 19-7-5 (Rev. 1995); (x) enter into 
agreements with consultants, architects, engineers, museum designers, public relations, media 
relations, web designers, fundraisers, promoters and such other firms and organizations as the 
trustees deem necessary to design, construct, maintain and promote the Delta Blues Museum; 
and (xi) do all other acts necessary for the orderly and efficient management and control of the 
Delta Blues Museum. However, no expenditure made or contracted by the trustees of the Delta 
Blues Museum shall be binding upon the city so as to require any payment in excess of funds 
made available for Delta Blues Museum purposes by the board of mayor and commissioners of 
the city. 
(2)	Employment of director, curator. The board of trustees of the Delta Blues Museum is authorized 
and empowered to employ a director and/or a curator for the Delta Blues Museum, who shall 
have such educational qualifications as may be prescribed by the board of trustees. The board 
of trustees may, from time to time, combine the positions of director and curator, or may keep 
them separate, as the board of trustees, in its discretion, deems in the best public interest. 
(3)	Staff. The director shall administer and establish procedures according to policies established 
by the board of trustees. His or her duties shall include: (a) recommendations relative to the 
employment of staff, with the final decision and approval to be made by the board of trustees; 
(b) prescription of staff duties; (c) recommendation of removal or discharge of staff, which final 
decision shall be that of the board of trustees; (d) preparation of budgets; (e) financial and 
statistical management; (f) reporting to the board of trustees and to the board of commissioners 
of the city; and (g) other acts necessary for the orderly and efficient administration of the Delta 
Blues Museum. 
(4)	Insurance coverage. The board of trustees is authorized to insure all property exhibited or used 
in the operation of the Delta Blues Museum, including buildings, furniture, exhibits, memorabilia, 
books, records, and the like, against loss by fire, wind, water, theft and other perils commonly 
insured against, and to carry a sufficient amount of employer's liability, worker's compensation 
and other insurance as, in the discretion of the board of trustees, may be deemed proper, and 
to pay the premiums therefor out of the funds available to it, including funds derived from the 
operation of the Delta Blues Museum. 
(5)	Reciprocal agreements. The board of trustees may enter into agreements with other museums, 
individuals, corporations and other business entities, and other governmental entities, for the 
acquisition, display, movement, transfer, location and relocation of exhibits, upon such terms 
and conditions, for such lengths of time and for such consideration as the board of trustees 
may, from time to time, in its discretion, determine to be in the best interests of the Delta Blues 
Museum. 
(6)	Admission fees. The board of trustees may establish an admission fee or charge, and may, at 
its discretion, waive such admission fee or charge to residents of the City of Clarksdale and/or 
Coahoma County, Mississippi. The board of trustees shall have the right, from time to time, to 
modify such admission fees, to provide for group discounts or to waive such fees in their 
entirety, as the board of trustees, in its discretion, deems appropriate and in the best interest of 
the Delta Blues Museum. 
(7)	Special sections. The board of trustees may determine and require reasonable reimbursements 
to be collected for the provision of special museum services. 
(8)	Gifts and donations. The board of trustees may accept, in the name of the Delta Blues Museum, 
gifts or donations of money, real estate, exhibits, music, books, periodicals or other property, 
real, personal or intellectual, for the purpose of promoting the work and mission of the Delta 
Blues Museum, and may accept and administer any funds which might be provided by the state 
or federal government for such purposes. 
(9)	Loans of materials. The board of trustees may also accept loans of exhibits, photographs, 
musical instruments, books, periodicals, memorabilia, collections and other items of interest, to 
be displayed upon such conditions as the board of trustees may deem appropriate, and may 
insure the same and pay the premiums therefor, which shall not be considered as a donation. 
(10)	Bids. The board of trustees of the Delta Blues Museum shall advertise for competitive bids for 
the items and in the manner and form as is required by Mississippi Code Annotated § 31-7-13 
(Rev. 1998). The board of trustees shall not be required to comply with the competitive bid 
requirements of § 31-7-13 relative to the acquisition of museum exhibits and/or for professional 
services. 
(11)	Professional services. The board of trustees may enter into professional services contracts and 
agreements with architects, engineers, museum designers, consultants, media and public 
relations consultants, fundraisers, web and internet designers, providers and consultants, and 
other professional service providers, upon such terms and conditions as the board of trustees, 
in its discretion, may determine to be in the best interests of the Delta Blues Museum. 
(12)	Web activities. The board of trustees may design, publish and maintain an internet website for 
the Delta Blues Museum, and pay the costs incident thereto from its available funds. 
(13)	Books and accounts. The board of trustees shall install and maintain proper books of record 
and account, separate entirely from other records and accounts of the city, in which correct 
entries shall be made of all dealings or transactions of or in relation to the properties, business 
and affairs of the Delta Blues Museum. 
(14)	Gift shop. The board of trustees may cause the operation of a museum gift shop, and acquire, 
purchase and sell, for profit, books, recordings, posters, t-shirts, novelties and similar items. 
(15)	Promotion and events. The board of trustees may, in its discretion, promote the Delta Blues 
Museum by (i) sponsoring live events, concerts or other public performances, (ii) enter into 
contracts with management companies, lighting, stage and sound providers, promoters, public 
relations and media relations companies, and such other service providers as may be 
necessary for such promotions and (iii) to sponsor photographic, art and music exhibits, 
performances, workshops and such other functions as will continue to promote and foster the 
development of the blues. 
(16)	Arts and education component. The board of trustees may, in its discretion, create and offer 
various programs, including, but not limited to, an arts and education component, to teach 
visual, performing and creative arts, music, music appreciation, and to promote a better 
understanding of the blues, and may employ persons specifically for those purposes. 
(17)	Reciprocal agreements. The board of trustees may, in its discretion, enter into agreements with 
other museums, educational institutions or the like, to exchange, display or loan exhibits, and 
may institute and implement satellite museums and/or traveling exhibitions. 
(d)	Reports. 
(1)	Quarterly reports. The board of trustees shall report quarterly to the board of mayor and 
commissioners on all of its actions and transactions of every kind whatsoever, which report shall 
also contain a detailed statement of the financial condition of the Delta Blues Museum. 
(2)	Annual reports. At the close of each year, the board of trustees of the Delta Blues Museum shall 
make its report to the board of mayor and commissioners of the city, showing the condition of 
the trust during the year, the sums of money received for the Delta Blues Museum fund from 
taxes and all other sources, the sums of money expended and the purposes of the 
expenditures, the number of the exhibits on hand, the number added during the year, the 
number disposed of, the number of visitors to the Delta Blues Museum, and such other statistics 
and information, and such suggestions, as the board of trustees deems in the public interest. 
(e)	Powers and authorities of the city. The board of mayor and commissioners of the city was specifically 
granted the power and authority, by House Bill 1749, and hereby reserves unto itself, the power and 
authority: 
(1)	To create the board of trustees of the Delta Blues Museum as specified in subsection (b) above, 
and to appoint the members thereof. 
(2)	To acquire all real property necessary for the development and expansion of the Delta Blues 
Museum, and to erect buildings and structures thereon to house the museum, its exhibits, gift 
shops and related facilities. 
(3)	To create an advisory board, to consist of such number of members as it, in its discretion, 
deems in the best interests of the Delta Blues Museum. Members of the advisory board may 
reside within or without the city and/or the State of Mississippi, and may include a broad cross-
section, including musicians, managers, authors, publishers, members of the business 
community, academics or otherwise, to provide advice to the city and to the board of trustees as 
to the design, operation, promotion, management, finances and future growth of the Delta Blues 
Museum. No person may serve simultaneously as a member of the board of trustees and of the 
advisory board. The board of mayor and commissioners of the city may determine the terms of 
service of members of the advisory board. 
(4)	To develop, construct and promote "Blues Alley" as an entertainment district in which the Delta 
Blues Museum is situated, and to make such rules and regulations relative thereto as may be in 
the best interests of the city. 
(5)	To enter into agreements with other local governments, including, without limitation, the board 
of supervisors of Coahoma County and the Coahoma County Tourism Commission, to provide 
funds, property, buildings, exhibits and other support to the Delta Blues Museum. 
(6)	To lease or furnish space to the Delta Blues Museum, for such period of time as the governing 
authorities determine. The benefit to the city from the operation of such lease may be 
considered as sufficient consideration. The lease may be exercised for a nominal fee, and it 
shall be presumed that such lease shall not amount to a donation of municipal property. The 
consideration for such lease may be adjusted, from time to time, upon agreement of the board 
of mayor and commissioners of the city and the board of trustees of the Delta Blues Museum. 
(7)	To create a Blues Hall of Fame and/or Walk of Fame, honoring substantial contributors to blues 
music, by photograph, bias relief, statue, or such other recognition as the board of mayor and 
commissioners, in its discretion, deems appropriate, and to expend municipal funds therefor. 
The board of mayor and commissioners of the city and the board of trustees of the Delta Blues 
Museum may coordinate such efforts as the respective boards deem appropriate. 
(8)	To adopt such ordinances and resolutions, and to do all things and perform all acts necessary, 
proper or desirable, to effectuate the full intent and purposes of these sections, including the 
authority to borrow money and issue negotiable notes or certificates of indebtedness therefor 
under the provisions hereof. 
(f)	Control of funds. 
(1)	The board of trustees of the Delta Blues Museum shall have full jurisdiction of all funds coming 
into its possession, either by appropriation of the governing authorities of the city, or by gift, or 
by revenue derived from the operation of the Delta Blues Museum, its gift shop or from the sale 
of merchandise, and shall have the authority to make all contracts in relation thereto. 
(2)	The board of trustees of the Delta Blues Museum shall devote all monies derived by 
appropriation from the municipal governing authorities, by gift, by revenue or from any other 
source, for the payment of all maintenance and operational expenses, the operation of the Delta 
Blues Museum, the purchase of equipment, exhibits and artifacts, the reconditioning, repair and 
replacement thereof, and the extension of museum facilities, services and programs for the 
benefit of the citizens and patrons of the Delta Blues Museum. 
(g)	Tax levy. The board of mayor and commissioners of the city was granted the authority, in House Bill 
1749, in its discretion, to levy and collect not more than three (3) mills annually for the purpose of 
constructing, supporting and maintaining the Delta Blues Museum. Such taxes shall be levied 
annually by order of the board of mayor and commissioners as other taxes are levied. The funds so 
collected by said tax shall be used for no purpose except as provided in this section. 
(h)	Bonds. 
(1)	The board of mayor and commissioners of the city was, in House Bill 1749, authorized and 
empowered to, at one (1) time or from time to time, issue general obligation bonds of the city to 
provide funds for construction, repair, remodeling, equipping, furnishing, adding to or improving 
the capital facilities and/or exhibits of the Delta Blues Museum. The issuance of bonds under 
this provision shall be preceded by the adoption of a resolution by the board of mayor and 
commissioners of the city, declaring the necessity for the issuance of general obligation bonds 
under the authority contained in this section. The total outstanding amount of bonds issued 
hereunder shall not exceed two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) at any one (1) time. 
(2)	The proceeds of bonds issued hereunder shall be used solely for the benefit of the Delta Blues 
Museum, including capital improvements, exhibit acquisition and development, and the costs 
incident to the issuance and sale of such bonds. 
(3)	All bonds issued under the Act and this section shall be legal investments for trustees and other 
fiduciaries and for savings banks, trust companies and insurance companies organized under 
the laws of the State of Mississippi, and such bonds shall be legal securities that may be 
deposited with and shall be received by all public officers and bodies of this state and all 
municipalities and political subdivisions for the purpose of securing the deposit of public funds. 
(4)	The bonds authorized under the authority of the Act and this section may be validated in the 
Chancery Court of Coahoma County, Mississippi, in the manner and with the force provided by 
Chapter 13, Title 31, Mississippi Code of 1972 for the validation of municipal and other bonds. A 
notice to taxpayers required by such statutes shall be published in a newspaper published or 
having a general circulation in the city. 
(5)	Bonds issued under the Act and this section, and the income from the bonds, shall be exempt 
from all taxation in the State of Mississippi. 
(6)	The bonds issued under the provisions of the Act and this section are general obligations of the 
city, and for the payment thereof, the full faith and credit of the city may irrevocably be pledged. 
If the funds appropriated by the board of mayor and commissioners of the city are insufficient to 
pay the principal of and the interest on such bonds as they become due, then the deficiency 
shall be paid by the city clerk from any funds in the city treasury not otherwise appropriated. All 
such bonds issued hereunder shall contain recitals on their faces substantially covering the 
provisions of this section. 
(7)	The principal of and interest on the bonds authorized hereunder shall be payable in the manner 
provided in this section and in House Bill 1749. Such bonds shall bear such date or dates, be in 
such denomination or denominations, bear interest at such rate or rates not exceeding the limits 
set forth in Mississippi Code Annotated § 75-17-101 (1972), as amended, be payable at such 
place or places within or without the State of Mississippi, shall mature absolutely at such time or 
times, not to exceed twenty (20) years from the date of issue, be redeemable before maturity at 
such time or times, and upon such terms, with or without premium, shall bear such registration 
privileges, and shall be substantially such form, all as determined by an appropriate resolution 
duly adopted by the board of mayor and commissioners of the city. 
(i)	Disposition, utilization of proceeds. 
(1)	The board of mayor and commissioners of the city is, under the provisions of House Bill 1749, 
authorized and empowered, if it so desires, to sell, lease or otherwise dispose of the municipally 
owned real and personal property utilized or acquired by the Delta Blues Museum, on such 
terms and conditions, and with such safeguards as will best promote and protect the public 
interest. In the event of the sale of real property, the board of mayor and commissioners of the 
city shall comply with the requirements of Mississippi Code Annotated § 21-17-1 (Supp. 1998), 
or as hereafter may be amended. In the event of the sale or disposition of personal property, the 
board of mayor and commissioners of the city may dispose of the same on such terms and 
conditions as it deems in the public interest, including, without limitation, sale, lease or donation; 
provided, however, that any donations shall only be to bona fide not-for-profit entity complying in 
all respects with Section 501(c) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The board of mayor and 
commissioners of the city is specifically authorized to enter into donation agreements with the 
board of trustees of the Carnegie Public Library relative to the disposition of personal property 
utilized in the operation of the Delta Blues Museum. 
(2)	The board of mayor and commissioners of the city, in the event of a sale, may use the proceeds 
of such sale, or any part thereof, for the purpose of retiring and paying off any public debt of the 
municipality incurred by the ownership or operation of the Delta Blues Museum, or may invest 
said funds or any part thereof derived from the sale in such lawful investments as may, from 
time to time, be designated by the Mississippi Legislature for public bodies. 
(j)	Liberal construction. These subsections and this section shall be liberally construed so as to promote 
the efficient maintenance and operation of the Delta Blues Museum to the end that it may result in 
the improvement of the general health, entertainment and welfare of the citizens of the city and of the 
State of Mississippi. 
(k)	Reverse referendum election procedure. At any time before the date the bonds described in 
subsection (i) above are to be issued, a petition signed by twenty (20) percent, the tax described in 
subsection (h), or fifteen hundred (1,500), whichever is less, of the qualified electors residing within 
the city is filed with the board of mayor and commissioners of the city, requesting an election to be 
held within the city upon the proposition, then the board of mayor and commissioners of the city shall 
adopt a resolution calling an election to be held within the city. The election shall be called upon at 
least three (3) weeks' notice by publication of the proposition at least once a week for three (3) 
consecutive weeks in a newspaper having general circulation in the city. 
The election to approve the tax or bonds shall be held, as far as is practicable, in the same manner as 
other elections are held in cities. At the election, all qualified electors who reside in the city may vote. 
When the results of the election have been canvassed by the election commissioners of the city and 
certified by them to the board of mayor and commissioners of the city, it shall be the duty of the board of 
mayor and commissioners to determine and adjudicate whether or not a majority of the qualified electors 
residing in the city who voted in the election voted in favor of the proposition or against the proposition. If 
a majority of the qualified electors residing in the city who voted in the election vote in favor of the 
proposition, then the proposition shall be authorized. 
(l)	Submission to department of justice. House Bill 1749 having been approved by the governor on April 
14, 1999, so requiring, the board of mayor and commissioners of the city shall submit House Bill 
1749 to the Attorney General of the United States or to the United States District Court for the District 
of Columbia, in accordance with the Voting Rights Act of 1965, as amended and extended and under 
the provisions of 28 C.F.R. Part 51., 42 U.S.C. § 1973. 
(m)	Construction and severability. Severability is intended throughout and within the provisions of this 
section. If any provision, including inter alia, any exception, part, phrase or term or the application 
thereof to any person or circumstance is held invalid, the application to other persons or 
circumstances shall not be affected thereby, and the validity of this section in any and all other 
respects shall not be affected thereby. The board of mayor and commissioners of the city does not 
intend a result that is impossible to execute or unreasonable. It is intended that this section be held 
inapplicable in such cases, if any, where its application would be unconstitutional. A constitutional 
construction is intended and shall be given. 
(n)	Section cumulative. This section shall be cumulative and in addition to any other laws in force. 
(Ord. No. 963, 4-19-1999) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 963, adopted April 19, 1999, enacted provisions which were not 
specifically amendatory of the Code. At the editor's discretion, for purposes of classification, 
these provisions have been included herein as a new § 2-17. 


Chapter 3 - AIRCRAFT AND AIRPORTS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- For city wide zoning regulations, see Ch. 28. 
State Law reference- For municipal authority to acquire, equip and maintain airports, see 1942 Miss. 
Code, § 7538; to issue bonds, §§ 7540, 7545-10; to appoint special police, § 7540-05; to lease to private 
concerns, § 7541; to issue rules, regulations, orders for airport, § 7545-08. 


Sec. 3-1. - Definitions of terms. 
    The following terms whenever used or referred to in this chapter shall have the following respective 
meanings, unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context: 
    Aircraft. The term "aircraft" shall mean any contrivance now known or hereafter invented, used or 
designed for navigation of or flight in the air. 
    Airman. The term "airman" shall mean any individual who engages, as a person in command or as a 
pilot, mechanic or member of the crew, in the navigation of aircraft while under way; and any individual 
who is directly in charge of the inspection, maintenance, overhauling or repair of aircraft, aircraft engines, 
propellers or appliances. 
    Airport. The terms "airport," "Clarksdale Airport" or "Fletcher Field" wherever used herein shall mean 
the Clarksdale Municipal Airport. 
    Airport manager. The term "airport manager" shall mean the duly appointed manager of the 
Clarksdale Municipal Airport, or his designated authority. 
    Fixed base operator. The term "fixed base operator" shall mean any person upon the airport in the 
business of the sale of aircraft, the sale of aircraft parts, the sale of gasoline and oil for aircraft at retail, 
the rental of aircraft, the operation of a flying school or the rendition of any service to aircraft or the 
operators thereof for profit. The term shall include persons engaged in any one or more of such 
businesses, but shall not include oil companies renting space on the airport and selling gasoline and oil to 
commercial airlines and to fixed base operators for resale or retail. 
    Local flying. The term "local flying" shall mean any flight within a ten mile radius. 
    Operation of aircraft. The terms "Operation of aircraft" or "operate aircraft" shall mean the use of 
aircraft for the purpose of air navigation. Any person who causes or authorizes the operation of aircraft, 
whether with or without the right of legal control of the aircraft, in the capacity of owner, lessee or 
otherwise, shall be deemed to be engaged in the operation of aircraft within the meaning of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 475, § 1, 9-18-1956) 


Sec. 3-2. - Federal air traffic rules adopted. 
    The air traffic rules as now established by the Civil Aeronautics Administration and the Civil 
Aeronautics Board, and as the same may be hereafter supplemented and modified, are hereby adopted 
by reference and made a part hereof as fully as if the same and each and all of them were set forth herein 
at length. Any violation of such rules shall be a violation of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 475, § 3, 9-18-1956) 
State Law reference- For authority to adopt regulations in order to avoid creation of airport 
hazards, see 1942 Miss. Code, § 7544-03; for authority to make and enforce rules for proper 
control of airports, see 1942 Miss. Code, § 7540. 


Sec. 3-3. - Federal aircraft and operator's certificates required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or cause or authorize to be operated any civil aircraft 
within this state unless such aircraft has an effective certificate, permit or license issued by the United 
States, if such certificate, permit or license is required by the United States. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in aeronautics as an airman in the state unless he has 
an effective airman certificate, permit, rating or license issued by the United States authorizing him to 
engage in the particular class of aeronautics in which he is engaged, if such certificate, permit, rating or 
license is required by the United States. 
(Ord. No. 475, § 3, 9-18-1956) 
State Law reference- For similar provision of state law, see 1942 Miss Code, § 7536-13. 


Sec. 3-4. - Airport manager-Office created; duties. 
    The position of airport manager is hereby created, said position to be filled by appointment by the 
board of mayor and commissioners. The airport manager shall have full administrative authority to carry 
out the provisions of this chapter and the orders, rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto, and to 
give such orders and directions not inconsistent with the terms of this chapter as shall be necessary and 
proper for the policing and protection of the public and public property at the airport. 
Cross reference- For provision placing the office of airport manager within the first 
department of the city, § 2-3. 


Sec. 3-5. - Same-Promulgation of airport rules authorized; limitation; filing. 
(a)	Promulgation of rules. The airport manager, with the approval of the board of mayor and 
commissioners, shall have the power to make, promulgate and amend such reasonable general or 
special rules, regulations and procedures, and to establish such minimum standards consistent with 
the provisions of this chapter, as shall be deemed necessary to carry out the provisions of this 
chapter, which regulations when so made, approved, and published shall have the force and effect of 
law. No such rules, regulations, orders, or standards prescribed by the airport manager shall be 
inconsistent with or contrary to any federal or state laws or rules and regulations. 
(b)	Copies of rules. The airport manager shall keep on file with the city clerk and in the airport manager's 
office a copy of all rules and regulations adopted for public inspection. 
(Ord. No. 475, § 2, 9-18-1956) 
State Law reference- For authority to promulgate essential rules and regulations, see 1942 
Miss. Code, § 7540. 


Sec. 3-6. - Airport manager may restrict operations. 
    The airport manager, or his designated authority, may delay or restrict any flight or other operations 
at the airport and may refuse takeoff clearance to any aircraft for any infraction of airport rules and 
regulations, or in the interest of safety. 
(Ord. No. 475, § 3, 9-18-1956) 


Sec. 3-7. - Registration with airport manager required; exception. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate aircraft from the airport not properly registered in the office of the 
airport manager; provided however, that this shall not apply to regular airline aircraft, United States 
Government or state owned and operated aircraft. 
(Ord. No. 475, § 3, 9-18-1956) 


Sec. 3-8. - Conformity to traffic pattern. 
    All traffic shall be in accordance with the approved traffic pattern now in effect or hereafter adopted, 
and said traffic pattern is made a part of this chapter as fully as though the same were here set forth at 
length. 
(Ord. No. 475, § 3, 9-18-1956) 


Sec. 3-9. - Reckless operation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate an aircraft in the air or on the ground or water while 
under the influence of intoxicating liquor, narcotics or other habit-forming drug, or to operate an aircraft in 
the air or on the ground or water, in a careless or reckless manner so as to endanger the life or property 
of another. In any proceeding charging careless or reckless operation of aircraft in violation of this 
section, the police justice in determining whether the operation was careless or reckless shall consider 
the standards for safe operation of aircraft prescribed by federal statutes or regulations governing 
aeronautics. 
(Ord. No. 475, § 3, 9-18-1956) 
State Law reference- For similar provisions of state law, see Miss. Code 1942, § 7536-12. 


Sec. 3-9.1. - Flying over area within corporate limits. 
    It shall be unlawful for any aircraft to fly or pass over any area within the corporate limits of the City 
of Clarksdale, Mississippi at an altitude less than the minimum altitude established by the Federal 
Aviation Administration or any other federal or state agency having jurisdiction over aircraft and flight for 
each such type of aircraft and/or category of flight. 
(Ord. No. 666, § 1, 9-18-1972; Ord. No. 905, 3-21-1994) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 666 did not expressly amend this Code, hence codification of § 1 as § 
3-9.1 was at the discretion of the editors. 


Sec. 3-9.2. - Aircraft and parachute landings. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to ascend or land any aircraft, including gliders, balloons, 
helicopters and parachutes, within the corporate limits of the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi. This 
proscription shall not apply to emergency landings, military or National Guard personnel, medical 
helicopters nor landings at any established airport. 
(Ord. No. 905, 3-21-1994) 


Sec. 3-9.3. - Penalties for violations. 
    The pilot of any aircraft or any person violating this section shall be deemed to be guilty of a violation 
of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi, and subject to punishment as set forth 
therein. 
(Ord. No. 905, 3-21-1994) 


Sec. 3-10. - Permit required for commercial activities at airport. 
    No person shall use the airport for revenue-producing commercial activities without securing an 
appropriate permit for such activities from the airport manager and paying the rates and charges lawfully 
prescribed for such use. 
(Ord. No. 475, § 4, 9-18-1956) 


Sec. 3-11. - Violators may be ejected from airport. 
    In addition to penalties otherwise provided for violations of this Code, any person violating this 
chapter or the rules and regulations adopted by authority of this chapter, or refusing to comply therewith, 
may promptly be removed or ejected from the airport. 
(Ord. No. 475, § 4, 9-18-1956) 


Chapter 4 - ANIMALS AND FOWL[1] 

Footnotes:

34-4-39 and derived from the 1962 Code, §§ 9-15, and the following ordinances:
