whether owned for rental purposes, shall place or cause to be placed on all openings such as doors, 
windows, etc., of such dwellings and residences, proper screens, not larger than number sixteen 
screen wire, which is to say, not less than sixteen mesh to the square inch, each way, of said screen 
wire. 
(b)	Enforcement. It shall be the duty of the county health officer to inspect residences and dwelling 
houses in the city. If any residence or dwelling house is found not screened in accordance with the 
terms of this section, the owner of the same and the property shall be proceeded against as a 
nuisance. 
(c)	Penalty. Any person owning property and failing to comply with the terms of this section shall be 
fined in a sum not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each parcel of property unscreened 
in accordance with the terms of this section, in addition to the penalty provided in subsection (b). 
(Ord. No. 248, §§ 1-3, 4-16-1929) 


Sec. 11-6. - Screening of hotels, food establishments. 
    Hotels, restaurants, lunch counters, soda fountains, bottling factories, ice cream companies, candy 
kitchens, bakeries, meat markets, slaughterhouses, dairy barns and milk houses and all places where 
fruits, vegetables and unwrapped groceries are offered for sale shall be effectively screened at all outside 
openings with screen of not less than sixteen meshes to the square inch, each way, and all such 
screening shall be kept in good repair at all times. 
(Code, 1922, § 106) 


Sec. 11-7. - Sanitary regulations for hotels, restaurants. 
(a)	Hotel defined. A hotel within the meaning of this section is any inn or lodginghouse of three or more 
rooms where transient guests are fed or lodged for pay. 
(b)	Application to lunch rooms. The term restaurant as used in this section shall also include lunch 
counters. 
(c)	Lighting, ventilation, general cleanliness. All hotels, restaurants and lunch counters shall be lighted 
and ventilated and shall be kept at all times clean and in a sanitary condition. 
(d)	Animals prohibited. Cats and dogs and other domestic animals shall not be kept in the kitchen or 
dining room of any hotel or restaurant. 
(e)	Health certificate. No person shall be employed in any hotel or restaurant unless he shall have a 
health certificate, duly issued and currently effective. 
(f)	Where cuspidors prohibited. Cuspidors are not permitted in the dining room or other place where 
food is served in any hotel or restaurant. 
(g)	Common drinking cups. Common drinking cups are prohibited in any hotel or restaurant. 
(h)	Garbage disposal. All garbage of all kinds in restaurants and hotels must be kept in containers which 
are securely covered and which are emptied daily. 
(Code 1922, § 108) 
Cross reference- For food and food handlers, generally, see Ch. 9. 


Sec. 11-8. - Sanitary regulations for meat markets. 
(a)	Lighting, ventilation, general cleanliness. Meat markets shall be well lighted, ventilated, and kept at 
all times clean and in sanitary condition. 
(b)	Disposal of waste. Scraps of meats, offal, bones, or other organic matter shall not be exposed but 
shall be kept in a closed receptacle, which must be emptied at least once a day. 
(c)	Cleanliness of fixtures, utensils. The refrigerators, meat hooks, cutting blocks, scales, counters, 
floors and all utensils must be kept clean. 
(d)	Spitting. Spitting upon the floor, walls or other places in a meat market other than in a cuspidor 
provided with some disinfectant solution is prohibited. 
(f)	Application to fish markets. A fish market shall be governed by the same rules as a meat market. 
(Code of 1922, § 108) 
Cross reference- For meat and meat products, §§ 9-19-9-29. 


Sec. 11-9. - Sanitary regulations for barbershops. 
    All barbershops shall be well screened, lighted and ventilated, and the floors, walls and partitions 
kept clean and in sanitary condition. All mugs, shaving brushes and razors shall be sterilized by 
immersion in boiling water or in sixty per cent alcohol, after each separate use thereof. A separate clean 
towel shall be used for each person served. The roller towel and the common drinking cup are prohibited. 
Alum sticks or other caustic sticks used for stopping the flow of blood shall not be used. The use of 
powder puffs and sponges is prohibited. No barbershop shall be used as a bedroom. Every barbershop 
shall be provided with hot and cold water. Every barber shall clean his hands thoroughly before serving 
each customer. 
(Code, 1922, § 113) 


Sec. 11-10. - Keeping animals on premises. 
    It shall be the duty of all persons occupying or using premises within the city, or entitled to the use or 
occupancy thereof, who have and maintain upon such premises stables, hog pens, coops or other places 
for the keeping of animals or fowl, to maintain the premises so used in a condition that shall not be 
offensive or prejudicial to the health of the city and its inhabitants. When a condition hazardous to public 
health arises as a result of violation of this section, the health officer shall require the owner or occupant 
of the subject premises to remove and abate the condition at his own expense within such time as said 
health officer may deem the public health to require. 
Cross reference- Provision regulating the keeping of hogs in the city, § 4-34. 
State Law reference- For authority to prevent, abate nuisances, see 1942 Miss. Code, § 3374-
116. 


Sec. 11-11. - Notice of unsanitary conditions to nonresident; duty to correct; correction by city 
authorized; collecting costs. 
(a)	When any person owns property within the city and is a nonresident of the city, or cannot be found 
therein, and the premises and property of such owner shall not be in such situation and condition as 
may be required by this Code or any ordinances of the city, or the rules and regulations of the state 
board of heath, such property owner shall be notified thereof by the municipal authorities by posting 
a written notice thereof upon some place upon the property or premises last aforesaid, and by 
mailing a written copy of such notice to such property owner addressed to him postage prepaid at his 
last known post office address, if such address be known, giving such property owner notice of the 
particulars wherein such property owner has failed to comply with the sanitary ordinances and 
regulations of said city. 
(b)	Said notice shall be given for five days, and if at the expiration of such time such person shall not 
comply with the sanitary rules and regulations of the city in respect to said property as required by 
the above mentioned notice, then the proper city authorities, shall cause said premises to be put in 
sanitary condition, as called for by said notice and shall charge the actual cost of all such work 
against such property. 
(c)	If such property owner shall not within ten days after such work shall be finished, discharge the cost 
of the sanitary work, as above stated, then the city shall institute a summary proceeding by attaching 
or other proper process for the collection of all such costs and when collected the same shall be paid 
over to the treasurer of the city, as other sums are required to be paid to him. 
(Code, 1922, § 204) 
Cross reference- As to authority of city to abate a nuisance, § 14-26. 


Sec. 11-12. - Removal of dead animals required; transporting through, placing on streets. 
(a)	No person shall suffer any dead animal which belonged to him to remain in the city limits nor to throw 
dead animals or fowl into the streets or alleys, but all persons shall be required to remove all such 
objectionable matter at once beyond the city limits under the direction of the superintendent of the 
sanitary department or other health officer. 
(b)	It shall be unlawful for any person to drag through the streets of the city the dead body or carcass of 
any animal unless the same when transported through or about the city be carried in a covered 
wagon so as to prevent the spreading of disease through flies and other insects and, the 
dissemination of foul odors. 
(c)	Any violation of this section shall constitute and be a misdemeanor; and any person found guilty shall 
be fined the sum of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than fifty dollars ($50.00) or be 
imprisoned for the space of not more than fifteen days, or both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Code 1922, §§ 96, 205) 


Sec. 11-13. - Duty of sanitary officer, police officers. 
    The sanitary officer and the police officers of the city are hereby charged with the duty of carrying out 
and enforcing the provisions of this chapter and are hereby empowered to make arrests for violation 
thereof. 
(Ord. No. 529, § 10, 5-28-1962) 


Sec. 11-14. - Junk automobile bodies, etc.; notice to remove; removal by city; penalty for section 
violation; exceptions; term defined. 
(a)	Junk automobile bodies, etc. No firm, person or corporation in the city shall place or keep materials 
or objects, junk automobile bodies, rubbish, refuse, weeds, grass or garbage (other than in garbage 
containers) on any lot or lots within the said city which will cause unsanitary or unsightly conditions. 
(b)	Reserved. 
(c)	Penalty for violation of section. The violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine not 
exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00) or imprisonment for a term not exceeding thirty (30) days, 
with each day of said violation constituting a separate offense. In addition to the above penalty, any 
conditions caused or permitted to exist in violation of this section shall be deemed a public nuisance 
and may be enjoyed by the city as provided by law for other nuisances. 
(d)	Exceptions. This section shall not be applicable to licensed operators of junkyards or dealers in 
scrap materials as those terms are ordinarily defined. 
(e)	Definition. The term "junk" means any property (except land) that: (a) is not able to be used in the 
manner or the purposes for which it was designed or constructed, or (b) is inoperative, or (c) is in a 
state of disrepair, or (d) scrap metal, or (e) is discarded, or (f) is no longer useful in its original form, 
or (g) old or scrap copper, brass, rope, rags, batteries, paper, trash, rubber debris, waste, or 
dismantled or wrecked motor vehicles, or parts thereof, iron, steel, and other old or scrap metals, or 
(h) a motor vehicle (including, but not limited to cars, trucks, four wheelers, three wheelers and 
motorcycles) that is incapable of being moved under its own power or rendered inoperative by 
reason of a lack of any essential parts such as wheels, tires, motor, radiator, or other essential 
components. 
(Ord. No. 596, §§ 1-4, 12-18-1967; Ord. No. 1017, § 1, 4-24-2006; Ord. No. 1023, § 1, 6-11-
2007; Ord, No. 2016-02, § 1, 7-25-2016) 
Editor's note- Section 11-14 is derived from Ord. No. 596, §§ 1-4, adopted Dec. 18, 1967. 
This ordinance, nonamendatory of this Code, was codified as said section in the discretion of the 
editors. Subsection (e) is derived from Ord. No. 1017, adopted April 24, 2006. 
Cross reference- Garbage, trash and weeds, §§ 11-19 et seq.; junkyards, fencing requirements, 
§ 11-16.1. 


Secs. 11-15-11-18. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE II. - GARBAGE, TRASH, WEEDS AND LITTER[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Provision declaring the keeping of trash upon vacant lots to be a misdemeanor, § 14-
25. 
State Law reference- Authority to compel or regulate removal of garbage and filth, 1942 Miss. Code, § 
3374-116. 


DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Sections 11-27 and 11-28, as derived from the Code of 1922, §§ 116, 117, 218 and Ord. 
No. 604, § 1, enacted Dec. 3, 1968, were renumbered as 11-19 and 11-20 in the composition of Div. 1. 


Sec. 11-19. - Duty to keep grass and weeds mowed and debris removed. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful for any owner of property, or the tenant or user thereof, whether said property is 
vacant or occupied, or the holder of any rights-of-way or easements, to allow weeds, Johnson grass, 
or other grasses to grow to such a height as to create a hazard to motorist traffic, or to allow such 
weeds, grasses or any debris to be on said property, or rights-of-way, or easements, in such a 
manner as to be unsightly, or to create a health hazard within the limits of the City of Clarksdale, 
Mississippi, and to keep the grass and weeds well mowed in the alleys adjacent thereto, and on the 
streets as far as the curb. 
(b)	The violation of this section shall constitute a misdemeanor and shall be punishable by a fine of no 
more than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each day of its violation, and such prohibition of said 
allowance of growth of such weeds and grasses and placing of such debris may be enjoined in the 
Chancery Court of Coahoma County, Mississippi. 
(Code 1922, §§ 116, 117; Ord. No. 604, § 1, 12-3-1968) 
State Law reference- Authority to require cutting of weeds, 1942 Miss. Code, § 3374-171. 


Sec. 11-20. - Duty to keep sidewalks, alleys free from weeds. 
(a)	Sidewalks abutting occupied property. It shall be the duty of all persons occupying or using any 
enclosed property within the city to keep the full space set apart for sidewalks in front of the property 
so occupied free from all weeds and other noxious growths; but this shall not prohibit said occupants 
from maintaining on the said sidewalks a sod of grass kept closely cut or trimmed. 
(b)	Alleys abutting occupied property. In all cases where the property occupied as set out in subsection 
(a) hereof extends to, or opens out upon an alley it shall be the duty of the occupants of such 
property, to keep the alley back of their premises free from weeds and other noxious growth to the 
center line of the alley bordering the premises occupied by them. 
(c)	Sidewalks, alleys abutting vacant property. The owners and occupants of all vacant lots and other 
vacant property in the city shall keep said property and the sidewalk in front and the alleys in the rear 
thereof, free from weeds and like noxious growth. 
(d)	Penalty. All persons who should fall, neglect or refuse to comply with the provisions of this section 
shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined for each offense not more than twenty-five dollars 
($25.00), and each day or part of a day during which any person should fail, neglect or refuse to 
comply with the provisions of this chapter shall be taken and held for a separate and distinct offense, 
and he shall be punished therefor as such. 
(Code 1922, § 218) 


Secs. 11-21-11-29. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 2. - REFUSE COLLECTION[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Sections 11-19-11-26 and 11-29-11-30 of the Code pertaining to garbage and trash, 
as previously derived from the Code of 1922, §§ 83, 116, 117, 218; Ord. No. 432, §§ 1, 3-12, enacted 
Oct. 30, 1951; Ord. No. 529, §§ 1, 2, 4, 9, 11; enacted May 28, 1962; Ord. No. 545, § 1, enacted Jan. 22, 
1963; Ord. No. 603, §§ 1, 2, enacted Oct. 28, 1968; and Ord. No. 604, § 1, enacted Dec. 3 1968, were 
repealed by Ord. No. 725, § 10, enacted Aug. 28, 1978. Sections 1-8 of said Ord. No. 725 are herein set 
out as Div. 2, §§ 11-30-11-34.8 of the Code at the editor's discretion. 


Sec. 11-30. - Short title. 
    This division shall be known and may be cited as the "Municipal Refuse Collections Service 
Ordinance of the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi." 
(Ord. No. 725, § 1, 8-28-78) 


Sec. 11-31. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this division the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations shall have 
the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense 
include the future, words in the plural number include the singular number, and words in the singular 
number include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
(1)	Ashes is the residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke, or other combustible materials. 
(2)	City is the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi. 
(3)	Director of public works or director is the director of public works of the City of Clarksdale. 
(4)	Garbage is putrescible animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, 
cooking, and consumption of food. 
(5)	Person is any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of 
any kind. 
(6)	Point of collection is a place which is not in the traveled right-of-way of a street, alley or 
sidewalk and is accessible to and not more than five (5) feet from the side of the streets or alley 
from which a scheduled collection is made. 
(7)	Refuse is all putrescible and nonputrescible solid wastes (except body wastes), including 
garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals, abandoned automobiles, yard waste 
and solid market and industrial waste. Hazardous wastes are specifically excluded from the 
definition hereof, and may not be collected or disposed of by the city. 
(8)	Rubbish is nonputrescible solid wastes (excluding ashes), consisting of both combustible and 
noncombustible wastes, such as paper, cardboard, tin cans, glass, bedding, crockery, white 
goods and similar materials, but excluding yard waste. 
(9)	Scheduled collection is the regularly scheduled date of collection, or the next business day, if 
the scheduled collection day falls on a holiday, as established and published by the Director of 
Public Works. 
(10)	Yard waste shall include wood (but not lumber, construction materials or other commercially 
produced wood), shrubs, yard clippings, leaves, tree trimmings, garden debris, brush and 
similar matter. This term shall not include stumps or roots. 
(Ord. No. 919, §§ 1-3, 3-6-1995; Ord. No. 1016, § 4, 4-24-2006) 


Sec. 11-32. - Collection by city. 
    All refuse accumulated in the city shall be collected, conveyed and disposed of by the city. No 
person shall collect, convey over any of the streets or alleys of the city, or dispose of, any refuse 
accumulated in the city. 
(a)	Exception for actual producers. This division shall not prohibit the actual producers of refuse, or 
the owners of premises upon which refuse has accumulated, from personally collecting, 
conveying and disposing of such refuse, provided such producers or owners comply with the 
provisions of this division and with any other governing law or ordinances. 
(b)	Exception for outside collectors. This division shall not prohibit collectors of refuse from outside 
of the city from hauling such refuse over city streets, provided such collectors comply with the 
provisions of this division and with any other governing law or ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 725, § 3, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 11-33. - Collection supervised by director of public works; appeals. 
(a)	All refuse accumulated in the city shall be collected, conveyed and disposed of by the city under the 
supervision of the director of public works. The director shall have the authority to make regulations 
concerning the days of collection, type and location of waste containers and such other matters 
pertaining to the collections, conveyance and disposal as he shall find necessary, and to modify the 
same after notice as required by law, provided that such regulations are not contrary to the 
provisions hereof. 
(b)	Any person aggrieved by a regulation of, or fee charged by, the director shall have the right of appeal 
to the board of mayor and commissioners who shall have the authority to confirm, modify or revoke 
any such regulation or fee. 
(Ord. No. 725, § 4, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 11-34. - Placement for collection; containers; removal of construction debris. 
(A)	Preparation of yard waste. Yard waste, including leaves, grass clippings, garden debris, weeds and 
the like, shall be placed in plastic or waterproof paper trash bags, commonly known as "garbage 
bags," to be placed curbside for collection as required hereinafter. Tree trimmings, hedge clippings 
and similar material shall be cut to a length not to exceed four (4) feet, and be of such size and 
weight, not to exceed fifty (50) pounds, as can be handled by one (1) person. 
(1)	Placement and notification of city. All owners, tenants, lessees or occupants of the premises 
upon which such acceptable refuse and/or yard clippings has accumulated or been produced, 
shall place or cause the same to be placed in refuse containers provided by the city, or, for yard 
waste, bagged and bundled as required hereinabove and placed in neat, orderly piles at the 
curb or in the street immediately in front of such premises in such a manner so that the same 
will not interfere with the traffic, for the purposes of removal thereof by the city. Immediately 
after placing or causing refuse to be placed in such orderly piles, the owner, tenant, lessee or 
occupant of such premises shall notify the director, or such other person or department of the 
city as the director may specify, of the existence of refuse, other than yard waste, so that the 
same may be removed as soon as practical. Yard waste shall be collected by the city on a 
regular schedule once each week in accordance with the schedule adopted by the director. 
(B)	Refuse containers. 
(1)	Duty to provide and maintain in sanitary condition. Refuse containers shall be provided by the 
owner, tenant, lessee, or occupant of the premises. Refuse containers shall be maintained in 
good condition. Any container that does not conform to the provisions of this section or that may 
have ragged or sharp edges or any other defect liable to hamper or injure the person collecting 
the contents thereof shall be promptly replaced upon notice. The director shall have the 
authority to refuse collection services for failure to comply herewith. 
(2)	Containers. Refuse containers shall be made of metal, plastic or other suitable material, 
equipped with suitable handles and tight fitting covers, and shall be water tight: 
(a)	Capacity. Refuse containers shall have a capacity of not more than thirty (30) gallons, and 
shall be of such weight that they can be handled by one man; 
(b)	Sanitation. Refuse containers shall be of a type approved by the director and shall be kept 
in a clean, neat and sanitary condition at all times. 
(C)	Containers furnished by city. The city in its discretion may make available for refuse collection refuse 
containers for the mechanical collection of refuse or for such other similar system of collection and 
disposal of refuse without charge for the cost of such container to any person required to or agreeing 
to use such container. Said refuse containers shall remain the property of the city and shall be 
maintained in good condition by the person to whom furnished. Said person shall be responsible to 
and shall pay to the city the amount of any damage to said container or containers, except ordinary 
wear and tear while said container is in the possession of said person. The director shall have the 
authority to refuse collection services for failure to comply herewith. 
(D)	Storing of refuse. 
(1)	Public places. No person shall place or cause to be placed any refuse, except yard waste as 
provided in section 11-34(A) herein, in any street, alley or other public place, or upon any 
private property, whether owned by such person or not, within the city, except it be in proper 
containers for collection or under express approval granted by the director. No person shall 
throw or deposit any refuse in any stream or other body of water within the city. 
(a)	Unauthorized accumulation. Any unauthorized accumulation of refuse, including yard 
waste, on any premises is hereby declared to be a nuisance and is prohibited. Failure to 
remove any existing accumulation of refuse within thirty (30) days after the effective date of 
this section shall be deemed a violation hereof. Each day upon which such accumulation 
continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(b)	Unauthorized placement of yard waste. Any person who shall place or cause to be placed 
yard waste in or upon the alleys, rights-of-way or other public places within the city, or 
upon any private property therein, whether owned by such person or not, except that it be 
placed in proper form, bagged and bundled, on the curb or in the street immediately in front 
of and adjacent to the property upon which the same was generated in accordance with 
the provisions of section 11-34(A) hereof, is hereby declared to be a violation of this 
section, and prohibited by law. Allowing any accumulation in the alleys immediately 
adjacent to the property upon which the same was generated, or failing to remove any 
existing accumulation of yard waste within thirty (30) days after the effective date hereof 
shall be deemed to be a violation of this section. Each day upon which such accumulation 
continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(c)	Scattering of refuse and yard waste. No person shall cast, place, sweep or deposit 
anywhere within the city any refuse, including yard waste, in such a manner that it may be 
carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk, alley, sewer, storm sewer, 
parkway or other public place, or into any occupied premises within the city, except that 
yard waste may be placed at the curb or in the street, properly bagged and bundled, in 
accordance with the provisions hereof. 
(d)	Penalties. Any person who shall violate any provision of this subsection shall, upon 
conviction, be punished in accordance with the provisions of section 11-34.3 of the Code of 
Ordinances. 
(E)	Points collection. Refuse containers shall be placed for collection at ground level on the property, not 
within the travelled right-of-way of a street or alley, and accessible to and not more than five (5) feet 
from the side of the street or alley from which collection is made, provided that containers may be 
placed for collection at other than ground level and at a distance of more than five (5) feet when 
approved by the director and an additional payment for the extra service is agreed upon by both 
parties. 
(F)	Removal of construction debris. 
(1)	All debris or rubbish generated from construction, reconstruction, repairs, remodeling and/or 
replacement of any building or other structure within the city, including roofing and/or roof repair 
or replacement and including waste generated from materials used in tar or asphalt 
applications, including but not limited to wood, metal, concrete, dirt, shingles, insulation, nails 
and other fasteners, sheathing, decking materials, felt, empty cans or containers, and plastic 
sheeting (hereinafter, "construction debris") shall be disposed of by immediately hauling the 
same to any licensed sanitary landfill or, in the case of hazardous wastes, to any licensed 
disposal facility approved for such hazardous wastes, and properly disposing of the same. The 
responsibility for removing and disposing of all construction debris shall be upon the owner 
upon whose property the construction, reconstruction, repair, remodeling, replacement, roofing, 
reroofing or other construction activity has occurred. The owner shall also be responsible for 
payment of the applicable fees charged by the operator of the licensed waste disposal facility or 
sanitary landfill. 
(2)	It shall be unlawful for any person to allow any construction debris as defined hereinabove upon 
his or her property, and/or to fail to properly dispose of the same. 
(3)	It shall be unlawful for any person to place or cause to be placed any construction debris as 
defined hereinabove upon any public street, alley, right-of-way or other public place within the 
city. 
(4)	Any person who shall violate any provision of this subsection (F) shall, upon conviction, be 
punished in accordance with the provisions of section 11-34.3 of this Code. 
(5)	The director of public works or his designee shall have the authority to cause any construction 
debris so placed upon any public street, alley, right-of-way or other public place within the 
corporate limits of the city to be removed and properly disposed of, and shall charge the actual 
cost of the cleaning thereof, plus an additional penalty of twenty-five (25) percent of the cost, to 
the owner of the property upon which the construction debris is placed, and the city may collect 
the same by any method authorized by law, including the abatement of a nuisance under the 
provisions of this Code. This provision shall be in addition to the criminal penalties set forth in 
subsection (f)(4) above. 
(6)	This subsection (F) shall not be construed to alter or amend any requirements presently 
contained in any other ordinance, building code, fire prevention code, permit regulations or 
other applicable regulations of the city, but shall be in addition to such other requirements, 
ordinances, codes and regulations. 
(G)	Limitations. 
(1)	City employees will not go upon private property to collect refuse, except areas that are open to 
the public, or by special order of the director, as in the event of garbage collection for 
handicapped citizens under the provisions of regulations duly adopted by the director and 
approved by the board of mayor and commissioners of the city. 
(2)	The following items will not be collected by the city, and must be properly disposed of by the 
owner thereof: 
(a)	Motor vehicles; 
(b)	Waste from the remodeling, demolition, destruction, burning or disposal of buildings; 
(c)	Large household appliances, including, without limitation, stoves, refrigerators, washing 
machines, dryers, freezers and other appliances commonly known as "white goods"; 
(d)	Concrete; 
(e)	Large limbs; tree trunks, tree roots; 
(f)	Tree trimmings produced by any person other than the owner, tenant, lessee or occupant 
of the premises, and specifically including those generated by commercial contractors; 
(g)	Items weighing more [than] fifty (50) pounds or twenty-seven (27) kilograms; 
(h)	Construction debris, which must be disposed of in accordance with the provisions of 
section 11-34(F) hereof. 
(3)	Newspapers must be tied in bundles. 
(4)	Cardboard boxes must be broken down and bundled. 
(5)	Refuse or garbage, including yard waste, may not be put out for collection more than forty-eight 
(48) hours prior to the scheduled pickup time. 
(6)	Yard waste not capable of being bundled in accordance with the provisions of section 11-34(A) 
shall be placed in standard size (not to exceed thirty-five (35) gallons or one hundred thirty-two 
(132) liters) plastic or waterproof paper trash bags, which must be tied and be sturdy enough so 
that they can be handled without breaking or tearing. 
(H)	Responsibilities of persons placing refuse for collection. 
(1)	No person placing or causing to be placed refuse in receptacles or appropriately bagged and 
bundled yard waste or for the purpose of having the same collected at a scheduled collection 
day, shall do so before sunset of the day prior to such scheduled collection, nor shall such 
person allow such receptacle to remain at the point of collection after the end of the day of such 
scheduled collection. 
(2)	No person shall place refuse in a receptacle unless the refuse is placed in a bag or container 
which would prevent the refuse from being loose and subject to being blown by the wind or 
otherwise become separated from the remaining refuse and be scattered when being collected 
by the City, its employees or its authorized agent or authorized refuse collector. 
(3)	Notice and penalties. 
(a)	If a person fails to comply with the provisions of this subsection (H), a notice of violation 
shall be placed on the front door of the residence, advising the person(s) of this provision. 
It is not necessary that the person be personally served with this notice. 
(b)	If the person, after the placement of the notice provided for in Section 3(a) above, fails to 
comply with this ordinance, the person shall be personally served with a citation advising of 
the violation and giving the person a court date to appear. The person may pay a fine of 
fifty dollars ($50), plus court costs, in full at City Hall on or before the scheduled time for 
court, in lieu of personally appearing in court. The fine for a second or subsequent violation 
shall be one hundred dollars ($100) plus court costs. 
(c)	If a person fails to pay the fine and court costs or fails to appear for court, the court may 
proceed as it does with other matters when a person fails to appear. 
(Ord. No. 725, § 5, 8-28-1978; Ord. No. 589, §§ 1-6, 4-2-1990; Ord. No. 919, §§ 4-6, 3-6-
1995; Ord. No. 1016, §§ 1, 2, 4-24-2006) 
Editor's note- Section 11-34(H) was established by Ord. No. 1016, adopted April 24, 2006. 


Sec. 11-34.1. - Collection practices. 
(a)	Frequency of collection. 
(1)	Residential. 
a.	Garbage generated or accumulated by residents shall be collected at least once each 
week in accordance with the system of collection adopted by the city. The method of 
garbage collection, frequency, routing and other elements of the garbage collection system 
may, from time to time, be modified by action of the board of mayor and commissioners. 
b.	Refuse consisting of rubbish and yard waste as provided in section 11-34(A) generated or 
accumulated by residents shall be collected as provided therein at least once each week in 
accordance with the system of collection adopted by the city. The method of refuse 
collection, including frequency, routing, and other elements of the refuse collection system 
may be modified, from time to time, by action of the board of mayor and commissioners. 
c.	For the purposes of the collection yard waste, "residential" shall include such multifamily 
housing complexes as shall pay such additional fees for the collection and disposal of yard 
waste as may be established from time to time under the provisions of section 11-34.2 of 
the Code of Ordinances. 
(2)	Commercial. Hotels, restaurants and such other businesses and institutions as deem it 
necessary may enter into an agreement for a greater frequency of collection. Where necessary 
to protect the public health, the director shall have the authority to require that more frequent 
collection be made. 
(b)	Limitation on quantity: 
(1)	Residential. The director shall collect a reasonable accumulation of refuse of each family during 
a collection period for the standard charge; 
(2)	Commercial. The director shall collect a reasonable accumulation of refuse of hotels, 
restaurants and other businesses and institutions during the collection period at a fair charge 
based upon the average weight or volume. The director shall have the authority to refuse to 
collect unreasonable amounts or to make an additional charge for such amounts. 
(c)	Special refuse problems: 
(1)	Contagious disease refuse. The removal of wearing, bedding or other refuse from homes or 
other places where highly infectious or contagious diseases have prevailed should be 
performed under the supervision and direction of the director. Such refuse shall not be placed in 
containers for regular collections. 
(2)	Inflammable, hazardous or explosive refuse. Highly inflammable, hazardous or explosive 
materials shall not be placed in containers for regular collection but shall be disposed of as 
directed by the director at the expense of the owner or possessor thereof. 
(d)	Collection by actual producers and outside collectors: 
(1)	Requirements for vehicles. The actual producers of refuse or the owners of premises upon 
which refuse is accumulated who desire personally to collect and dispose of such refuse, 
persons who desire to dispose of waste material not included in the definition of refuse and 
collectors of refuse from outside of the city who desire to haul over the streets of the city, shall 
use a watertight vehicle provided with a tight cover and so operated as to prevent offensive 
odors escaping therefrom and refuse from being blown, dropped or spilled; 
(2)	Disposal. Disposal of refuse by persons so permitted under subsection (1) above shall be made 
outside the city limits; unless otherwise specifically authorized by the director. The director shall 
have the authority to permit the disposal of such material in the city dump provided the charge 
as provided in section 11-36 is paid; 
(3)	Rules and regulations. The director shall have the authority to make such other reasonable 
regulations concerning individual collection and disposal and relating to the hauling of refuse 
over city streets by outside collectors as he shall find necessary, subject to the right of appeal 
as set forth in section 11-33 hereof. 
(e)	Refuse property of city. Ownership of refuse material set out for collection or deposited on the city 
dump shall be vested in the city. 
(Ord. No. 725, § 6, 8-28-1978; Ord. No. 919, § 7, 3-6-1995) 


Sec. 11-34.2. - Fees. 
(a)	Ground level; Within five (5) Feet. The city shall charge fees for the collection and disposal of 
acceptable solid waste, trash or other acceptable refuse, which shall be placed for collection at 
ground level and not more than five (5) feet distance from the side of the street from which collection 
is made, and which is appropriately containerized, bagged and bundled in accordance with these 
ordinances and with the rules and regulations adopted by the public works director, and for litter 
control and street sweeping, as follows: 
(1)	One-or two-family residence. For single-family or two-family residences: twenty-six and 50/100 
Dollars ($26.50) per month per family. 
(2)	Commercial and multifamily dwellings. For hotels, restaurants and other businesses and 
institutions, and for dwellings of three (3) units or more, the fees shall be based upon the 
average amount of refuse material and the frequency of collection, and shall be fixed by the 
director subject to the right of appeal to the board of mayor and commissioners. The owners, 
and not the tenants, lessees or occupants of such premises shall be responsible for payment of 
such fees. 
(b)	Other than ground level; more than five (5) feet. Where the collection of refuse from other than 
ground level or from more than five (5) feet from the side of the street or alley is accepted by the 
director, the fee shall be that of subsection (a) above plus a fee set by the director, subject to appeal 
to the board of mayor and commissioners, which shall be deemed by him to cover the cost of the 
extra service rendered. 
(c)	Delinquent accounts. All accounts shall be considered delinquent if not paid by the due date 
designated by the board of mayor and commissioners. All delinquent accounts are subject to 
stoppage of service, after proper notice for the opportunity of a due process hearing. If a delinquent 
account is not paid within thirty (30) days, the director shall cease all refuse collection for that 
account unless otherwise directed by the board of mayor and commissioners. Service shall be 
resumed thereafter only on payment of the accumulated fees for the period of collection and the 
period of noncollection plus a penalty of five dollars ($5.00) unless the board of mayor and 
commissioners specifically directs otherwise. 
(1)	Legal remedy. The stoppage of services hereinbefore authorized for nonpayment of collection 
charges shall be in addition to the right of the city to proceed for the collection of such unpaid 
charges in a manner provided by law for the collection of a municipal claim. 
(d)	Use of city dump. Any person having permission of the director to use the city dump for the disposal 
of refuse shall pay a fee to be fixed by the director, subject to appeal to the board of mayor and 
commissioners, to be paid to the city for every load or part thereof. 
(Ord. No. 725, § 7, 8-28-1978; Ord. No. 764, § 1, 8-31-1981; Ord. No. 819, § 1, 9-30-1985; Ord. 
No. 828, § 1, 9-29-1986; Ord. No. 845, § 1, 8-22-1988; Ord. No. 865, § 1, 9-24-1990; Ord. No. 
901, § 1, 8-30-1993; Ord. No. 942, § 1, 9-15-1997; Ord. No. 990, § 1, 1-27-2003; Ord. No. 1031, 
§ 1, 11-23-2009; Ord. No. 2015-03, 8-24-2015) 


Sec. 11-34.3. - Penalties. 
(a)	Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this division shall be deemed guilty 
of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof, shall be fined in an amount not exceeding one 
thousand dollars ($1,000) or be imprisoned in the city jail for a period not exceeding ninety (90) days, 
or be both fined and imprisoned. Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall 
constitute a separate offense and be punishable as such hereunder. 
(b)	The director shall have the authority to cause any refuse placed upon any alley, right-of-way or other 
public place within the corporate limits of the city not designated as a proper place for the placement 
thereof, to be removed and properly disposed of, and shall charge the actual cost of the cleaning 
thereof, plus an additional penalty of twenty (25) percent of the cost, to the owner of the property 
upon which the refuse is placed or from which it is generated. The city may collect the same by any 
method authorized by law, including specifically the abatement of a nuisance under the provisions of 
this Code. This provision shall be in addition to the criminal penalties set forth in subsection (a) 
above. 
(Ord. No. 725, § 8, 8-28-1978; Ord. No. 919, § 8, 3-6-1995) 


DIVISION 3. - LITTER[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 726, §§ 1-22, enacted Aug. 28, 1978, is nonamendatory of the Code and is 
inserted as Div. 3, §§ 11-34.4-11-34.25, of the Code, at the editor's discretion. 


Sec. 11-34.4. - Short title. 
    This division shall be known and may be cited as the "Clarksdale Anti-Litter Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 726, § 1, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 11-34.5. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this division the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations shall have 
the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense 
include the future, words used in the plural number include the singular number, and words used in the 
singular number include the plural number. The word shall is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
(1)	Aircraft is any contrivance now known or hereafter invented, used or designed for navigation or 
for flight in the air. The word "aircraft" shall include helicopters and lighter than air dirigibles and 
balloons. 
(2)	Authorized private receptacle is a litter storage and collection receptacle as required and 
authorized in the "Municipal Refuse Collection Service Ordinance of the City of Clarksdale, 
Mississippi." 
(3)	City is the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi. 
(4)	Commercial handbill is any printed or written matter, any sample or device, dodger, circular, 
leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet, or any printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of 
any matter of literature: 
(a)	Which advertises for sale any merchandise, product, commodity, or thing; or 
(b)	Which directs attention to any business or mercantile or commercial establishment, or 
other activity, for the purpose of either directly or indirectly promoting the interest thereof by 
sales; or 
(c)	Which directs attention to or advertises any meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition, or 
event of any kind, for which an admission fee is charged for the purpose of private gain or 
profit; but the terms of this clause shall not apply where an admission fee is charged or a 
collection is taken up for the purpose of defraying the expenses incident to such meeting, 
theatrical performance, exhibition, or event of any kind, when either of the same is held, 
given or takes place in connection with the dissemination of information which is not 
restricted under the ordinary rules of decency, good morals, public peace, safety and good 
order; provided, that nothing contained in this clause shall be deemed to authorize the 
holding, giving or taking place of any meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition, or event 
of any kind, without a license, where such license is or may be required by any law of this 
state, or under any ordinance of this city; or 
(d)	Which, while containing reading matter other than advertising matter, is predominantly and 
essentially an advertisement, and is distributed or circulated for advertising purposes, or for 
the private benefit and gain of any person so engaged as advertiser or distributor. 
(5)	Garbage is putrescible animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, 
cooking and consumption of food. 
(6)	Litter is garbage, refuse, and rubbish as defined herein and all other waste material which, if 
thrown or deposited as herein prohibited, tends to create a danger to public health, safety and 
welfare. 
(7)	Newspaper is any newspaper of general circulation as defined by general law, any newspaper 
duly entered with the Post Office Department of the United States, in accordance with federal 
statute or regulation, and any newspaper filed and recorded with any recording officer as 
provided by general law; and, in addition thereto, shall mean and include any periodical or 
current magazine regularly published with not less than four (4) issues per year, and sold to the 
public. 
(8)	Noncommercial handbill is any printed or written matter, any sample, or device, dodger, circular, 
leaflet, pamphlet, newspaper, magazine, paper, booklet, or any other printed or otherwise 
reproduced original or copies of any matter of literature not included in the aforesaid definitions 
of a commercial handbill or newspaper. 
(9)	Park is a park, reservation, playground, beach, recreation center or any other public area in the 
city, owned or used by the city and devoted to active or passive recreation. 
(10)	Person is any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of 
any kind. 
(11)	Private premises is any dwelling, house, building or other structure, designed or used either 
wholly or in part for private residential purposes, whether inhabited or temporarily or 
continuously uninhabited or vacant, and shall include any yard, grounds, walk, driveway, porch, 
steps, vestibule or mailbox belonging or appurtenant to such dwelling, house, building, or other 
structure. 
(12)	Public place is any and all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys or other public ways and any 
and all public parks, squares, spaces, grounds, and buildings. 
(13)	Refuse is all putrescible and nonputrescible, solid wastes (except body wastes), including 
garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals, abandoned automobiles, and solid 
market and industrial wastes. 
(14)	Rubbish is nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of both combustible and noncombustible 
wastes, such as paper, wrappings, cigarettes, cardboard, tin cans, yard clippings, leaves, wood, 
glass, bedding, crockery and similar materials. 
(15)	Vehicle is every device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or 
drawn upon a highway, including devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Ord. No. 726, § 2, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 11-34.6. - Litter in public places. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter in or upon any street, sidewalk or other public place within the 
city except in public receptacles, in authorized private receptacles for collection, or in official city dumps. 
(Ord. No. 726, § 3, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 11-34.7. - Placement of litter in receptacles so as to prevent scattering. 
    Persons placing litter in public receptacles or in authorized private receptacles shall do so in such a 
manner as to prevent it from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or 
other public place or upon private property. 
(Ord. No. 726, § 4, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 11-34.8. - Sweeping litter into gutters prohibited. 
    No person shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street or other public place within the city the 
accumulation of litter from any building or lot or from any public or private sidewalk or driveway. Persons 
owning or occupying property shall keep the sidewalk in front of their premises free of litter. 
(Ord. No. 726, § 5, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 11-34.9. - Merchants' duty to keep sidewalks free of litter. 
    No person owning or occupying a place of business shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street 
or other public place within the city the accumulation of litter from any building or lot or from any public or 
private sidewalk or driveway. Persons owning or occupying places of business within the city shall keep 
the sidewalk in front of their business premises free of litter. 
(Ord. No. 726, § 6, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 11-34.10. - Litter thrown by persons in vehicles. 
    No person, while a driver or passenger in a vehicle, shall throw or deposit litter upon any street or 
other public place within the city, or upon private property. 
(Ord. No. 726, § 7, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 11-34.11. - Truck loads causing litter. 
    No person shall drive or move any truck or other vehicle within the city unless such vehicle is so 
constructed or loaded as to prevent any load, contents or litter from being blown or deposited upon any 
street, alley or other public place. Nor shall any person drive or move any vehicle or truck within the city, 
the wheels or tires of which carry onto or deposit any street, alley or other public place, mud, dirt, sticky 
substances, litter or foreign matter of any kind. 
(Ord. No. 726, § 8, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 11-34.12. - Litter in parks. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter in any park within the city except in public receptacles and in 
such a manner that the litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any 
part of the park or upon any street or other public place. Where public receptacles are not provided, all 
such litter shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for its presence and properly 
disposed of elsewhere as provided therein. 
(Ord. No. 726, § 9, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 11-34.13. - Litter in lakes and fountains. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter in any fountain, pond, lake, stream, bay or any other body of 
water in a park or elsewhere within the city. 
(Ord. No. 726, § 10, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 11-34.14. - Throwing or distributing commercial handbills in public places. 
    No person shall throw or deposit any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon any sidewalk, 
street or other public place within the city. Nor shall any person hand out or distribute or sell any 
commercial handbill in any public place. Provided, however, that it shall not be unlawful on any sidewalk, 
street, or other public place within the city for any person to hand out or distribute, without charge to the 
receiver thereof, any noncommercial handbill to any person willing to accept it. 
(Ord. No. 726, § 11, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 11-34.15. - Placing commercial and noncommercial handbills on vehicles. 
    No person shall throw or deposit any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon any vehicle. 
Provided, however, that it shall not be unlawful in any public place for a person to hand out or distribute 
without charge to the receiver thereof, a noncommercial handbill to any occupant of a vehicle who is 
willing to accept it. 
(Ord. No. 726, § 12, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 11-34.16. - Depositing commercial and noncommercial handbills on uninhabited or vacant 
premises. 
    No person shall throw or deposit any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon any private 
premises which are temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant. 
(Ord. No. 726, § 13, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 11-34.17. - Prohibiting distribution of handbills where properly posted. 
    No person shall throw, deposit or distribute any commercial or noncommercial handbill upon any 
private premises, if requested by anyone thereon not to do so, or if there is placed on said premises in a 
conspicuous position near the entrance thereof, a sign bearing the words: "No Trespassing," "No 
Peddlers or Agents," "No Advertisement," or any similar notice, indicating in any matter that the 
occupants of said premises do not desire to be molested or have their right of privacy disturbed, or to 
have any such handbills left upon such premises. 
(Ord. No. 726, § 14, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 11-34.18. - Distributing commercial and noncommercial handbills at inhabited private premises; 
exemption for mail and newspapers. 
(a)	No person shall throw, deposit or distribute any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon 
private premises which are inhabited, except by handing or transmitting any such handbill directly to 
the owner, occupant, or other person when present in or upon such private premises. Provided, 
however, that in case of inhabited private premises which are not posted, as provided in this division, 
such person, unless requested by anyone upon such premises not to do so, may place or deposit 
any such handbill in or upon such inhabited private premises, if such handbill is so placed or 
deposited as to secure or prevent such handbill from being blown or drifted about such premises or 
sidewalks, streets, or other public places, and except that mailboxes may not be so used when so 
prohibited by federal postal law or regulations. 
(b)	The provisions of this section shall not apply to the distribution of mail by the United States, nor to 
newspapers (as defined herein) except that newspapers shall be placed on private property in such 
a manner as to prevent their being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or 
other public place or upon private property. 
(Ord. No. 726, § 15, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 11-34.19. - Dropping litter from aircraft. 
    No person in an aircraft shall throw out, drop or deposit within the city any litter, handbill or any other 
object. 
(Ord. No. 726, § 16, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 11-34.20. - Posting notices prohibited. 
    No person shall post or affix any notice poster or other paper or device, calculated to attract the 
attention of the public, to any lamp post, public utility pole or shade tree, or upon any public structure or 
building, except as may be authorized or required by law. 
(Ord. No. 726, § 17, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 11-34.21. - Litter on occupied private property. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter on any occupied private property within the city, whether 
owned by such person or not, except that the owner or person in control of private property may maintain 
authorized private receptacles for collection in such a manner that litter will be prevented from being 
carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon any private 
property. 
(Ord. No. 726, § 18, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 11-34.22. - Owner to maintain premises free of litter. 
    The owner or person in control of any private property shall at all times maintain the premises free of 
litter. Provided, however, that this section shall not prohibit the storage of litter in authorized private 
receptacles for collection. 
(Ord. No. 726, § 19, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 11-34.23. - Litter on vacant lots. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter on any open or vacant private property within the city whether 
owned by such person or not. 
(Ord. No. 726, § 20, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 11-34.24. - Clearing of litter, dilapidated buildings and other debris from private property by city. 
    All of the provisions of Section 21-19-11 of the Mississippi Code of 1972, which section relates to the 
cleaning of private property by the city, and all amendments to said section, which are applicable and 
adapted to the city are incorporated herein and adopted as a part hereof, as fully as if the same were set 
forth at length. 
(Ord. No. 726, § 21, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 11-34.25. - Penalties. 
(a)	Any person violating any of the provisions of the anti-litter ordinance shall be deemed guilty of a 
misdemeanor, and upon conviction, shall be fined in an amount not exceeding one thousand dollars 
($1,000.00) or imprisoned for a period not exceeding one hundred eighty (180) days, or be both so 
fined and imprisoned. Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute 
a separate offense and be punishable as such hereunder. 
(b)	Any person arrested for a violation of any provision of the anti-litter ordinance shall be released upon 
proper bail being furnished as required by the city Code and/or the laws of the State of Mississippi. 
The shift commander may, in the absence of a municipal judge, prescribe the amount of bail or bond 
in each instance. Provided that any arrested person may, at his or her own request, have the amount 
of such bond set by a magistrate or judge as provided by statute. 
(c)	For violations of this division, a Clarksdale police officer, after making note of the name of the 
offender, the license number of the vehicle, if a violation occurs from a moving vehicle, and obtaining 
the other information requested hereby, may issue a citation or ticket, notifying the offender to 
appear in court at the time designated for hearing cases involving violations of the city Code. Such 
officer may sign a complaint for the issuance of a warrant if the offender does not appear at the time 
and place so specified. The police chief, or his designee, shall design the form of citation, which shall 
include all relevant information, including the names and addresses of the person so charged, the 
offense charged, and the time when and place where such person shall appear in court, which time 
specified in the notice, unless waived by the arrested person, shall be at least five (5) days after the 
arrest. The place specified in the notice shall be the court of the municipal judge before whom the 
person would be taken if the requirement of taking an arrested person before a judge were complied 
with, or shall be an officer authorized by such court to receive a deposit of bail. The officer shall 
deliver one (1) copy of the citation and notice to appear to the arrested person, and the arrested 
person, in order to secure his or her release, shall give his or her written promise to appear in court 
by signing the duplicate notice, which shall be retained by the officer. Thereupon, the arresting officer 
shall forthwith release the person charged from custody. The officer shall, as soon as practicable, file 
the duplicate notice with the municipal court clerk and a copy with the records department of the 
police department. No warrant shall issue on such charge for the arrest of a person who has given 
such written promise to appear in court, unless or until he or she has violated such promise or has 
failed to appear for a trial or judgment, or to comply with the terms and provisions of the judgment, as 
required by law. 
(d)	In lieu of, or as a part of and in addition to the other penalties specified herein, any person convicted 
of a violation of the anti-litter ordinance may be required to perform community service as prescribed 
by the court, based upon the following minimum requirements: 
(1)	The offender shall perform not less than ten (10) nor more than forty (40) hours of community 
service for each violation. 
(2)	The entire period of community service shall be performed under the supervision of a 
community service provider approved by the chief of police. 
(3)	Reasonable effort shall be made to assign the offender to a type of community service that is 
reasonably expected to have the most rehabilitative effect, including community service that 
involves litter pickup, graffiti removal or the like. 
(Ord. No. 726, § 22, 8-28-1978; Ord. No. 953, § 1, 4-27-1998) 


ARTICLE III. - DISEASES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- For requirement that those employed in the handling of food have health certificates, 
§§ 9-2, 9-5; requirement that persons employed by hotels, restaurants have health certificate, § 11-7. 
State Law reference- For authority to make regulations to prevent introduction and spread of diseases, 
see 1942 Miss. Code, § 3374-132; authority to appropriate for suppression of diseases, § 7088. 


Sec. 11-35. - Persons entering city after exposure to disease. 
    Anyone being within the corporate limits of the city and being suspected of coming from an infected 
locality where any contagious disease prevails shall at once leave the city upon being requested to do so 
by the authorities of the city or any one of them, or by the county health officer. Any person refusing or 
failing to comply with the said request shall be fined not more than twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(Code 1922, § 100) 


Sec. 11-36. - Venereal diseases-Defined, declared dangerous. 
    Venereal diseases are hereby defined to be syphilis, gonorrhea and chancroid and are hereby 
declared to be contagious, infectious, communicable and dangerous to the public health. 
(Code 1922, § 118) 


Sec. 11-37. - Same-Report to county health officer of arrests for morals violations, vagrancy. 
    Whenever any person charged with the violation of any ordinance relating to prostitution, lewdness, 
the keeping or setting up of a house of ill fame, brothel or bawdy house, street-walking or soliciting for 
prostitution or for any immoral purposes, pandering or vagrancy, is arrested, it shall be the duty of the 
person making the arrest to immediately report in writing the name, address and charge made against 
such person arrested to the county health officer. 
(Code 1922, § 118) 
Cross reference- Prostitutes congregating prohibited, § 14-31; vagrancy, § 14-39. 


Sec. 11-38. - Same-Morals offenders, vagrants to be examined; confinement, treatment if infected. 
(a)	Examination. The county board of health shall have full power and authority to subject such person 
so arrested and so charged to an examination for determining whether or not such person is infected 
with a venereal disease. 
(b)	Confinement, treatment. Should the examination of such person disclose the existence of a venereal 
disease, such person shall be isolated and confined in a suitable place to be provided therefor by the 
city and treated in such manner as may be required to cure such disease and shall be held in 
confinement therein until the county health officer shall deem it safe to the public that such person be 
discharged. 
(c)	Notice, trial. Immediately upon the isolation and confinement of such person a written notice thereof, 
signed by the county health officer shall be given to the police justice before whom such charge was 
made, and thereupon the trial of such charge (if said trial be not already concluded) shall be 
suspended or deferred until such person shall have been discharged by the said board of health as 
above provided. Upon the discharge of such person written notice thereof signed by the county 
health officer shall be given to the police justice, and the trial of such charge shall be had and 
proceeded with according to law. 
(Code 1922, § 119) 


Sec. 11-39. - Same-Enforcement by board of health; right of entry. 
    The county board of health is hereby invested with the authority and charged with the duty to enforce 
all the provisions of sections 11-35 through 11-38 and to prosecute all persons charged with violating 
same, and to that end, its officers, agents, employees, inspectors and appointees shall have the right to 
enter any premises or place in the city for the purpose of inspection for violation thereof. 
(Code 1922, § 121) 


Sec. 11-40. - Same-Infected prisoners to be isolated. 
    Any person convicted of violating any of the provisions of this chapter or any ordinance and 
sentenced to be punished by imprisonment shall, if infected with a venereal disease, be isolated during 
the term of such imprisonment. 
(Code 1922, § 122) 


Sec. 11-41. - Same-Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of sections 11-35 and 11-37 through 11-39, who refuses to submit 
himself to the examination, confinement and treatment prescribed, shall be punished by a fine of not less 
than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than fifty dollars ($50.00) for such refusal, or in default of payment of 
such fine, by imprisonment for not less than five days nor more than thirty days, or by both such fine and 
imprisonment, at the discretion of the police justice. 
(Code 1922, § 121) 


Secs. 11-42-11-47. - Reserved. 


Article IV. - CITY SMOKING BAN[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 735, § 13, enacted Dec. 19, 1979, repealed §§ 11-48-11-55 which formerly 
comprised Art. IV pertaining to disposal of excreta. Former §§ 11-48-11-55 were derived from Ord. No. 
324, §§ 1-5 and 7-10, enacted Sept. 14, 1937. 


Sec. 11-48. - Title. 
    This article shall be known as the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi Smoking Ban Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2014-04, § 1, 8-11-2014) 


Sec. 11-49. - Intent. 
    The mayor and board of commissioners find and declare that the purposes of this article are: 
(1)	to protect the public health and welfare by prohibiting smoking in public places and places of 
employment; 
(2)	to guarantee the right of nonsmokers to breathe smoke free air; and, 
(3)	to recognize that the need to breathe smoke free air shall have priority over the desire to 
smoke. 
(Ord. No. 2014-04, § 2, 8-11-2014) 


Sec. 11-50. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, whenever used in this article, shall be construed as defined in this 
section: 
    Bar means an establishment that is devoted to the serving of beer and light wine and other alcoholic 
beverages for consumption by guests on the premises and in which the serving of food is only incidental 
to the consumption of those beverages, including but not limited to, taverns, nightclubs, cocktail lounges 
and cabarets. 
    Business means a sole proprietorship, partnership, joint venture, corporation, or other business 
entity, either for-profit or not-for-profit, including retail establishments where goods or services are sold; 
professional corporations and other entities where legal, medical, dental, engineering, architectural or 
other professional services are delivered; and private clubs. 
    Employee means a person who is employed by an employer in consideration for direct or indirect 
monetary wages or profit, and a person who volunteers his or her services for a non-profit entity. 
    Employer means a person, business, partnership, association, corporation, including a municipal 
corporation, trust or non-profit entity that employs the services of one (1) or more individual persons. 
    Enclosed area means all space between a floor and ceiling that is enclosed on all sides by solid 
walls or windows (exclusive of doorways), which extend from the floor to the ceiling. 
    Health care facility means an office or institution providing care or treatment of diseases, whether 
physical, mental, or emotional, or other medical, physiological conditions, including but not limited to, 
hospitals, rehabilitation hospitals or other clinics, including weight control clinics, nursing homes, long-
term care facilities, homes for the aging or chronically ill, laboratories and offices of surgeons, 
chiropractors, physical therapists, physicians, psychiatrists, dentists and all specialists within these 
professions. This definition shall include all waiting rooms, hallways, private rooms, semi-private rooms 
and wards within health care facilities. 
    Place of employment means an area under the control of a public or private employer that 
employees normally frequent [in] the course of employment, including, but not limited to, work areas, 
private offices, employee lounges, restrooms, conference rooms, meeting rooms, classrooms, employee 
cafeterias, hallways and vehicles. A private residence is not a "place of employment" unless it is used as 
childcare, adult day care or health care facility. 
    Private club means an organization, whether incorporated or not, which is the owner, lessee or 
occupant of a building or portion thereof used exclusively for club purposes at all times, which is operated 
solely for a recreational, fraternal, social, patriotic, political, benevolent or athletic purpose, but not for 
pecuniary gain, and which only sells alcoholic beverages incidental to its operation. The affairs and 
management of the organization are conducted by a board of directors, executive committee or similar 
body chosen by the members at an annual meeting. The organization has established bylaws and/or a 
constitution to govern its activities. The organization has been granted an exemption from the payment of 
federal income tax as a club under 26 U.S.C. Section 501. 
    Public place means an enclosed area to which the public is invited or in which the public is permitted, 
including but not limited to, banks, bars, educational facilities, gaming facilities, health care facilities, 
hotels and motels, laundromats, public transportation facilities, reception areas, restaurants, retail food 
production and marketing establishments, retail service establishments, retail stores, shopping malls, 
sports arenas, theaters and waiting rooms. A private club is a "public place" when being used for a 
function to which the general public is invited. A private residence is not a "public place" unless it is used 
as a childcare, adult day care or health care facility. 
    Restaurant means an eating establishment, including but not limited to, coffee shops, cafeterias, 
sandwich stands and private and public school cafeterias, which gives or offers for sale food to the public, 
guests or employees, as well as kitchens and catering facilities in which food is prepared on the premises 
for serving elsewhere. The term "restaurant" shall include a bar area within the restaurant. 
    Service line means an indoor line in which one (1) or more persons are waiting for or receiving 
service of any kind, whether or not the service involves the exchange of money. 
    Shopping mall means an enclosed walkway or hall area that serves to connect retail or professional 
establishments. 
    Smoking means inhaling, exhaling, burning or carrying any lighted cigar, cigarette, pipe or other 
lighted tobacco product in any manner or in any form. 
    Sports arena means sports pavilions, stadiums, health spas, boxing arenas, swimming pools, roller 
and ice rinks, bowling alleys and other similar places where members of the general public assemble to 
engage in physical exercise, participate in athletic competition or witness sports or other events. 
(Ord. No. 2014-04, § 3, 8-11-2014) 


Sec. 11-51. - Prohibition of smoking in enclosed public places. 
    Smoking shall be prohibited in all enclosed public places within the city, including but not limited to, 
the following places: 
(1)	Aquariums, galleries, libraries and museums. 
(2)	Areas available to and customarily used by the general public in business and non-profit entities 
patronized by the public, including but not limited to, banks, laundromats, professional offices 
and retail service establishments. 
(3)	Bars. 
(4)	Bingo facilities. 
(5)	Childcare and adult day care facilities. 
(6)	Convention facilities. 
(7)	Educational facilities, both public and private. 
(8)	Elevators. 
(9)	Gaming facilities. 
(10)	Health care facilities. 
(11)	Hotels and motels, including at least eighty (80) percent of rooms that are rented to guests. 
(12)	Lobbies, hallways and other common areas in apartment buildings, condominiums, trailer parks, 
retirement facilities, nursing homes and other multiple-unit residential facilities. 
(13)	Polling places. 
(14)	Private clubs when being used for a function to which the general public is invited. 
(15)	Public transportation facilities, including buses and taxicabs, under the authority of the city, and 
ticket, boarding and waiting areas of public transit depots. 
(16)	Restaurants. 
(17)	Restrooms, lobbies, reception areas, hallways and other common-use areas. 
(18)	Retail stores. 
(19)	Rooms, chambers, places of meeting or public assembly, including school buildings, under 
control of an agency, board, commission, committee or council of the city or a political 
subdivision of the state, to the extent the place is subject to the jurisdiction of the city. 
(20)	Service lines. 
(21)	Shopping malls. 
(22)	Sports arenas, including enclosed places in outdoor arenas. 
(23)	Theaters and other facilities primarily used for exhibiting motion pictures, stage dramas, 
lectures, musical recitals or other similar performances. 
(Ord. No. 2014-04, § 4, 8-11-2014) 


Sec. 11-52. - Prohibition of smoking in places of employment. 
(a)	Smoking shall be prohibited in all enclosed facilities within places of employment without exception. 
This includes common work areas, auditoriums, classrooms, conference and meeting rooms, private 
offices, elevators, hallways, medical facilities, cafeterias, employee lounges, stairs, restrooms, 
vehicles and all other enclosed facilities. 
(b)	This prohibition on smoking shall be communicated by the business owner to all existing employees 
by the effective date of the ordinance from which this article derives and to all prospective employees 
upon their application for employment. 
(Ord. No. 2014-04, § 5, 8-11-2014) 


Sec. 11-53. - Prohibition of smoking in outdoor areas. 
    Smoking shall be prohibited in the following outdoor places: 
(1)	Within a reasonable distance of twenty (20) feet outside entrances, operable windows, and 
ventilation systems of enclosed areas where smoking is prohibited, so as to ensure that tobacco 
smoke does not enter those areas. 
(2)	In outdoor seating or serving areas of restaurants, however, smoking is allowed in an area 
which constitutes no more than fifty (50) percent of the outdoor seating capacity. Ingress and 
egress to the restaurant cannot go through the outdoor smoking area. 
(3)	In all outdoor arenas, stadiums and amphitheaters, except in designated smoking areas, which 
may be established only in perimeter areas at least twenty (20) feet from any seating areas or 
concession stands. Smoking shall also be prohibited in, and within twenty (20) feet of, bleachers 
and grandstands for use by spectators at sporting and other public events. 
(4)	In all public transit stations, platforms and shelters under the authority of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2014-04, § 6, 8-11-2014) 


Sec. 11-54. - Where smoking not regulated. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this article to the contrary, the following areas shall be exempt 
from the provisions of sections 11-52 and 11-53: 
(1)	Private residences, except when used as a childcare, adult day care or health care facility. 
(2)	Not more than twenty (20) percent of hotel and motel rooms rented to guests and designated as 
smoking rooms. All smoking rooms on the same floor must be contiguous and smoke from 
these rooms must not infiltrate into areas where smoking is prohibited under the provisions of 
this article. The status of rooms as smoking or nonsmoking may not be changed, except to add 
additional nonsmoking rooms. 
(3)	Private clubs that have no employees, except when being used for a function to which the 
general public is invited; provided that smoke from such clubs does not infiltrate into areas 
where smoking is prohibited under the provisions of this article. This exemption shall not apply 
to any organization that is established for the purpose of avoiding compliance with this article. 
(4)	Outdoor areas of places of employment except those covered by the provisions of section 11-
53. 
(Ord. No. 2014-04, § 7, 8-11-2014) 


Sec. 11-55. - Declaration of establishment as nonsmoking 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, an owner, manager or other person in control of 
an establishment, facility or outdoor area may declare that entire establishment, facility or outdoor area as 
a nonsmoking place. Smoking shall be prohibited in any place in which a sign conforming to the 
requirements of Section 10(A) is posted. 
(Ord. No. 2014-04, § 8, 8-11-2014) 


Sec. 11-55.1. - Posting of signs 
(a)	"No Smoking" signs or the international "No Smoking" symbol (consisting of a pictorial representation 
of a burning cigarette enclosed in a red circle with a red bar across it) shall be clearly and 
conspicuously posted in every public place and place of employment where smoking is prohibited by 
this article, by the owner, operator, manager or other person in control of that place. 
(b)	Every public place and place of employment where smoking is prohibited by this article shall have 
posted at every entrance a conspicuous sign clearly stating that smoking is prohibited. Every vehicle 
that constitutes a place of employment under this article shall have at least one (1) conspicuous sign, 
visible from the exterior of the vehicle, clearly stating that smoking is prohibited. 
(c)	All ashtrays shall be removed from any area where smoking is prohibited by this article by the owner, 
operator, manager or other person having control of the area. 
(Ord. No. 2014-04, § 9, 8-11-2014) 


Sec. 11-55.2 - Enforcement 
(a)	This article shall be enforced by the chief of police or an authorized designee. 
(b)	Notice of the provisions of this article shall be given to all applicants for a business license in the city. 
(c)	Any citizen who desires to register a complaint under this article may initiate enforcement with the 
police department. 
(d)	The public works department, fire department or their designees shall, while an establishment is 
undergoing otherwise mandated inspections, inspect for compliance with this article. 
(e)	An owner, manager, operator or employee of an establishment regulated by this article shall inform 
persons violating this article of the appropriate provisions thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2014-04, § 10, 8-11-2014) 


Sec. 11-55.3. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)	A person who smokes in an area where smoking is prohibited by the provisions of this article shall be 
guilty of an infraction, punishable by a fine not exceeding fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(b)	Except as otherwise provided in section (a), above, a person who owns, manages, operates or 
otherwise controls a public place or place of employment and who fails to comply with the provisions 
of this article shall be guilty of an infraction, punishable by: 
(1)	A fine not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00) for a first violation 
(2)	A fine not exceeding two hundred dollars ($200.00) for a second violation within one (1) year. 
(3)	A fine not exceeding five hundred ($500.00) for each additional violation within one (1) year.
