    A good faith effort to prevent smoking will be a complete defense to this offense. 
(c)	In addition of the fines established by this section, violation of this article by a person who owns, 
manages, operates or otherwise controls a public place or place of employment may result in the 
suspension or revocation of any permit or license issued to the person for the premises on which the 
violation occurred. 
(d)	Violation of this article is hereby declared to be a public nuisance, which may be abated by the police 
department by restraining order, preliminary and permanent injunction, or other means provided for 
by law, and the city may take action to recover the costs of the nuisance abatement. 
(e)	Each day on which a violation of this article occurs shall be considered a separate and distinct 
violation. 
(Ord. No. 2014-04, § 11, 8-11-2014) 


Sec. 11-55.4. - Public education. 
    The mayor shall engage in a continuing program to explain and clarify the purposes and 
requirements of this article to citizens affected by it, and to guide owners, operators and managers in their 
compliance with it. The program may include publication of a brochure for affected businesses and 
individuals explaining the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2014-04, § 12, 8-11-2014) 


Sec. 11-55.5. - Governmental agency cooperation. 
    The mayor shall annually request other governmental and educational agencies having facilities 
within the city to establish local operating procedures in cooperation and compliance with this article. This 
includes urging all federal, state, county and school district agencies to update their existing smoking 
control regulations to be consistent with the current health findings regarding secondhand smoke. 
(Ord. No. 2014-04, § 13, 8-11-2014) 


Sec. 11-55.6. - Other applicable laws. 
    This article shall not be interpreted or construed to permit smoking where it is otherwise restricted by 
other applicable laws. 
(Ord. No. 2014-04, § 14, 8-11-2014) 


Sec. 11-55.7. - Liberal construction. 
    This article shall be liberally construed so as to further its purposes. 
(Ord. No. 2014-04, § 15, 8-11-2014) 


ARTICLE V. - MOSQUITO CONTROL AND ABATEMENT[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 958, §§ 1-15, adopted December 14, 1998, enacted provisions which were not 
specifically amendatory of the Code. At the editor's discretion, and for purposes of classification, these 
provisions were included herein as a new Art. V, §§ 11-56-11-70. 


Sec. 11-56. - Title. 
    This article may be called the "City of Clarksdale Mosquito Control and Abatement Ordinance" or the 
"mosquito control ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 958, § 1, 12-14-1998) 


Sec. 11-57. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to provide more effective mosquito control and abatement services 
within the corporate limits of the city and the surrounding buffer zone, and will, therefore, lead to a safer, 
more sanitary city, by reducing or eliminating mosquitos and the diseases carried by mosquitos, and by 
the elimination or reduction of standing water, tires and other breeding grounds for mosquitos within the 
city. 
(Ord. No. 958, § 2, 12-14-1998) 


Sec. 11-58. - Scope. 
(a)	This article is enacted pursuant to the authority granted to the city under Mississippi Code Annotated 
§§ 21-17-5 21-19-1 and 21-19-3; and other applicable statutes and the provisions thereof affecting 
Mississippi municipalities, as duly adopted by Mississippi Legislature. 
(b)	This article applies to the control and abatement of mosquitos, including larvae and adult mosquitos, 
and breeding places for mosquitos within the corporate limits of the city and within the buffer zone 
thereof. 
(c)	This article proscribes definitions, regulations, standards, costs and the method of payment, and also 
provides for penalties for violations. 
(d)	This article shall apply to all areas inside the corporate limits of the city as the same now exist, or 
may hereafter be expanded by annexation. The city recognizes that it may not enforce this article 
outside the corporate limits of the city, but expresses its intent to control, to the maximum extent 
feasible, mosquito control and abatement, including breeding sites, within the surrounding buffer 
zone. 
(Ord. No. 958, § 3, 12-14-1998) 


Sec. 11-59. - Definitions. 
    Terms not defined herein shall have the usual and ordinary meanings ascribed to them, unless the 
context hereof requires otherwise. The determination in respect to any ambiguity or question regarding 
the definition of any defined term by the city board shall be conclusive. 
    City or Clarksdale shall mean the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi, a municipal corporation domiciled in 
Coahoma County, Mississippi whose mailing address is Post Office Box 940, Clarksdale, Mississippi 
38614. 
    City board shall mean the duly elected, qualified and acting board of mayor and commissioners of 
the city. 
    City clerk shall mean the duly appointed, qualified and acting city clerk of the City of Clarksdale, 
Mississippi. 
    County shall mean Coahoma County, Mississippi, a body politic whose mailing address is Post 
Office Box 98, Clarksdale, Mississippi 38614. 
    County board shall mean the duly elected, qualified and acting Board of Supervisors of Coahoma 
County, Mississippi. 
    Clarksdale Public Utilities Commission or public utilities commission shall mean the Clarksdale 
Public Utilities Commission, as created by Ordinance No. 854, duly adopted by the board of mayor and 
commissioners of the city on July 20, 1989, codified as sections 20-81 et seq. of this Code, and whose 
mailing address is Post Office Box 70, Clarksdale, Mississippi 38614. 
    Customer or sewer customer shall mean any person, firm, corporation, partnership, limited liability 
company or other legal entity which shall have any residential, commercial or industrial sewer meter 
connection to the sewage collection, disposal and treatment facilities of the city, as managed by the 
Clarksdale Public Utilities Commission. 
    Person shall mean any individual, firm, partnership, limited partnership, corporation, limited liability 
company or other form of business entity, or any combination thereof. 
    Public works director shall mean the duly appointed, qualified and acting public works director of the 
City of Clarksdale, Mississippi or his designee. 
    Service or mosquito service or mosquito control and abatement service shall mean and include the 
(i) surveillance and inspection of larvae breeding sites, (ii) monitoring adult mosquito populations and 
plotting densities, (iii) application of chemical and biological larvicides, chemical and biological adulticides 
and (iv) such other actions as may be necessary to control mosquito populations within the service area. 
    Service area shall mean the current corporate limits of the city, as the same now exist or may 
hereafter be expanded, plus a buffer zone of at least one (1) mile surrounding the corporate limits of the 
city. The buffer zone may be modified from time to time by action duly adopted by the city board. 
    Vector or VDC shall mean Vector Disease Control, Inc., an Arkansas corporation duly qualified to do 
business in the State of Mississippi, whose mailing address is Post Office Box 566, Dewitt, Arkansas 
72049. 
    Work shall mean the service as defined in section (j) above. 
(Ord. No. 958, § 4, 12-14-1998) 


Sec. 11-60. - Breeding sites. 
    The city shall have the power to control and eliminate all breeding and producing places of 
mosquitos within the city, and to do and perform all acts and to carry out all plans which, in the opinion 
and judgment of the city board, may be necessary or proper for the survey and elimination of breeding 
and producing places of mosquitos, or which will tend to exterminate mosquitos within said city, including 
private property within the city. 
(Ord. No. 958, § 5, 12-14-1998) 


Sec. 11-61. - Rates established. 
    There shall be and is hereby established rates and charges to be paid by customers for the mosquito 
services to be provided by the city. Such rates or charges shall be based upon the actual cost of the 
provision of such services. Each residential, commercial or industrial customer who now or hereafter 
receives sewer services from the public utilities commission and/or the city shall be charged the sum of 
two dollars ($2.00) per month for mosquito services. These rates are based upon the contract by and 
between the city and Vector for mosquito services for the calendar year 1999, and take into account the 
agreement of the county board of supervisors to pay one-half (1/2) of the cost of mosquito services within 
the city directly to the city. 
(Ord. No. 958, § 6, 12-14-1998; Ord. No. 985, § 1, 9-17-2001) 


Sec. 11-62. - Modifications of rates. 
    The rates to be charged for mosquito services may be modified from time to time by the board of 
mayor and commissioners of the city by resolution duly adopted and spread upon its minutes. In the 
event the county board causes its subsidizing of the mosquito service by discontinuing or reducing its 
payment to the city of one-half (1/2) of the cost of mosquito services within the city, the rates may 
immediately be adjusted to provide that the customers pay all of the costs of such service. 
(Ord. No. 958, § 7, 12-14-1998) 


Sec. 11-63. - Manner of collection. 
    The charges herein imposed shall be collected by the public utilities commission, and shall be 
included upon the combined utility bills of each sewer customer. Any failure to pay the same within the 
time provided for by the rules and regulations of the public utilities commission shall result in 
discontinuance of water and/or sewer services, as the case may be, at the time provided in said rules and 
regulations, after proper notice and the opportunity for a due process hearing. Water and sewer services 
shall be resumed thereafter only upon payment of all of the accumulated fees for the period of service, 
including mosquito services, and the period of non-service, plus such penalty as may be, from time to 
time, established by the public utilities commission. Upon collection by the public utilities commission, the 
monies specified for mosquito services shall be remitted by the public utilities commission to the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 958, § 8, 12-14-1998) 


Sec. 11-64. - Advance payment. 
    The public utilities commission may offer an option to any customer to prepay mosquito services in 
advance for such periods of time as the board of mayor and commissioners may from time to time 
determine, but not less than quarterly nor more than annually. 
(Ord. No. 958, § 9, 12-14-1998) 


Sec. 11-65. - Lien. 
    In the event that the charges for mosquito services are not paid within thirty (30) days after the 
rendition of the bill for such services or such earlier time as may be specified by the public utilities 
commission, such charges shall be deemed and are hereby declared to be delinquent. In addition to the 
other collection methodologies specified herein or in this Code, such delinquency shall constitute a lien 
upon the real estate for which such service is supplied, and the city clerk is authorized and empowered to 
file sworn statements showing such delinquencies in the office of the chancery clerk of Coahoma County, 
Mississippi, and the filing of such statements shall be deemed notice of the lien of charges for such 
service. In addition, the city clerk may take such other actions, including collection procedures and court 
actions on delinquent accounts as are authorized under Mississippi law. 
(Ord. No. 958, § 10, 12-14-1998) 


Sec. 11-66. - Person responsible for payment. 
    The rates and charges herein established shall be collected from the owners, occupants and users 
of the premises which are connected to the city sewer system within the city on or from and after the 
effective date of this article. 
(Ord. No. 958, § 11, 12-14-1998) 


Sec. 11-67. - Mosquito breeding sites unlawful. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit or permit to be deposited on public or private 
property within the city, or any area under the jurisdiction of the city, cesspools, tire piles, artificial 
containers, septic ponds, rainwater pools and other mosquito larvae breeding sites. 
(Ord. No. 958, § 12, 12-14-1998) 


Sec. 11-68. - Abatement of mosquito breeding sites. 
    The public works director may, from time to time, issue written notice to the owner or occupant of 
property upon which such mosquito breeding sites have been allowed to accumulate, by certified mail, 
return receipt requested, giving notice of the observed mosquito breeding site(s), and a period of time of 
not less than five (5) nor more than fifteen (15) days within which to abate the mosquito breeding sites. 
Such mosquito breeding sites are hereby declared to be nuisances, and may be abated as provided in 
section 14-26 of this Code or under the provisions of Mississippi Code Annotated § 21-19-11 (Rev. 1990) 
for cesspools and standing water nuisances, at the discretion of the public works director. Failure of the 
owner or occupant to abate the mosquito breeding sites as directed by the public works director or his or 
her designee shall be deemed to be a violation hereof, and punishable in accordance with the provisions 
of section 11-69 below. 
(Ord. No. 958, § 13, 12-14-1998) 


Sec. 11-69. - Penalties for violation. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and may, upon 
conviction, be fined an amount not exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or be imprisoned in the 
city jail for a period not exceeding ninety (90) days, or be both so fined and imprisoned. Each day that a 
separate violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense, and shall be 
punishable as such. 
(Ord. No. 958, § 14, 12-14-1998) 


Sec. 11-70. - Costs of abatement. 
    In addition to the penalties provided in section 11-69 above, the actual costs of abating such 
nuisance may be assessed against the property, and shall become a lien thereon. 
(Ord. No. 958, § 15, 12-14-1998) 


Chapter 11A - HISTORIC PRESERVATION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- This chapter was established by Ord. No. 988, adopted October 28, 2002. 


Sec. 11A-1. - Short title. 
    This Ordinance shall be known and may be cited as the "Clarksdale Historic Preservation 
Ordinance" or the "Historic Preservation Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 988, § 1, 10-28-2002) 


Sec. 11A-2. - Purposes and findings. 
(a)	The Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi hereby recognizes that 
the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi is known for its extensive and concentrated collection of southern 
vernacular houses, southern mansions and historic landmarks, particularly as are related to 
playwright Tennessee Williams, and the unique position of the City of Clarksdale as the "Birthplace 
of the Blues", including a historical African American commercial district and related buildings and 
sites. The City of Clarksdale's unique qualities have proven increasingly attractive to residents, 
business interests and particularly, tourists, specifically including tourists interested in the Blues and 
in Tennessee Williams. 
(b)	As a matter of public policy the City of Clarksdale aims to preserve, enhance, and perpetuate those 
aspects of the City having historical, cultural, architectural, and archaeological merit. The Board of 
Mayor and Commissioners hereby finds and determines that such historic activities will promote and 
protect the health, safety, prosperity, education and general welfare of the people living in and 
visiting the City of Clarksdale. 
(c)	More specifically, this Historic Preservation Ordinance is designed to achieve the following goals: 
(1)	To protect, enhance and perpetuate resources which represent distinctive and significant 
elements of the City of Clarksdale's historical, cultural, social, economic, political, 
archaeological and architectural identity; 
(2)	To ensure the harmonious, orderly and efficient growth and development of the City; 
(3)	To strengthen civic pride and cultural stability through neighborhood conservation; 
(4)	To stabilize the economy of the City of Clarksdale through the continued use, preservation, and 
revitalization of its resources; 
(5)	To protect and enhance the City of Clarksdale's attractions to tourists and visitors and the 
support and stimulus to business and industry thereby provided; 
(6)	To promote the use of resources for the education, pleasure and welfare of the people of the 
City of Clarksdale; and 
(7)	To provide a review process for the preservation and appropriate development of the City of 
Clarksdale's resources. 
(Ord. No. 988, § 2, 10-28-2002) 


Sec. 11A-3. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this Historic Preservation Ordinance, and unless specifically noted otherwise, 
the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given herein. When not 
inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future tense, words in the plural 
number include the singular number, and words in the singular number include the plural number. The 
masculine gender shall include the feminine gender, and the feminine shall include the masculine. The 
word "shall" is always mandatory and is not merely directory. 
    Alteration means any change in the exterior appearance or materials of a landmark or a structure 
within a historic district or on a landmark site. 
    Applicant means the owner of record of a resource; the lessee thereof with the approval of the owner 
of record in notarized form; or a person holding a bona fide contract to purchase a resource. 
    Appurtenance means an accessory to a building, structure, object, or site, including, but not limited 
to, landscaping features, walls, fences, light fixtures, steps, paving, sidewalks, shutters, awnings, solar 
panels, satellite dishes and signs. 
    Board means the Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi, its 
governing authority. 
    Building means a structure created to shelter any form of human activity, including, but not limited to 
a house, garage, barn, church, hotel, museum, theater or similar structure. 
    Certificate of appropriateness means an official signed and dated governmental document issued by 
the Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi, to permit specific work in a 
historic district or at a landmark site or landmark which has been reviewed and approved. 
    Certified Local Government (CLG) means a federal program authorized by the National Historic 
Preservation Act, 16 USC 470 et seq., that provides for the participation of local governments in a 
federal/state/local government preservation partnership. The federal law directs the State Historic 
Preservation Officer of Mississippi and the Secretary of the Interior to certify local governments to 
participate in this partnership. Specific Mississippi requirements for the program are published in "State of 
Mississippi, Procedures for the Certified Local Government Program." 
    City means the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi, a municipal corporation, domiciled in Coahoma 
County, Mississippi, with its offices located at City Hall, 121 Sunflower Avenue, Post Office Box 940, 
Clarksdale, Mississippi 38614. 
    City Attorney means the duly appointed, qualified and acting City Attorney for the City of Clarksdale, 
Mississippi. In the event of the designation by the City of Clarksdale of a firm as City Attorneys, a member 
of the firm assigned to perform the duties of City Attorney. 
    Construction means work which is neither alteration nor demolition. Essentially, construction is the 
erection of a new structure which did not previously exist, even if such a structure is partially joined to an 
existing structure. 
    Demolition means the intentional removal of a structure within a local historic district or on a 
landmark site or which has been designated as a landmark. 
    Demolition by neglect means substantial deterioration of a historic structure that results from 
improper maintenance or a lack of maintenance. 
    Design Review Guidelines, as adopted by the Clarksdale Historic Preservation Commission, shall be 
in a written form designed to inform local property owners regarding historical architectural styles 
prevalent in the community, to recommend preferred treatments and to discourage treatments that would 
compromise the architectural integrity of structures in a historic district or on a landmark site or 
individually designated as landmarks. 
    Exterior features or resources means and includes, but shall not be limited to, the color, kind, and 
texture of the building material and the type and style of all windows, doors, and appurtenances. 
    Historic district or historic preservation district means a group of two (2) or more tax parcels and their 
structures, which may be an entire neighborhood of structures linked by historical association or historical 
development. It is not necessary that all structures within a historic district share the same primary 
architectural style or be from the same primary historical period. A historic district may also include both 
commercial and residential structures, and may include structures covered by two (2) or more zoning 
classifications. A historic district may include both contributing and noncontributing structures. A historic 
district is designated by the Historic Preservation Commission and approved by the Board of Mayor and 
Commissioners of the City through an ordinance. 
    Historic landmark means a structure of exceptional individual significance, and its historically 
associated land, which typically could not be included within a local historic district or other appropriate 
setting, A historic landmark is designated by the Historic Preservation Commission and approved by the 
Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City through an ordinance. 
    Historic preservation commission or commission means a local historic preservation commission 
established pursuant to the provisions of Miss. Code Ann. § 19-13-3 (Rev. 2001), to advise the Board of 
Mayor and Commissioners of the City on matters relating to historic preservation, including the 
designation of historic districts, landmarks and landmark sites, and which may be empowered to review 
applications for permits for alteration, construction, demolition, relocation or subdivision for structures in 
designated historic districts or on landmark sites or designated as landmarks. 
    Improvement means additions to or new construction on landmarks or landmark sites, including, but 
not limited to, buildings, structures, objects, landscape features, and manufactured units, including, but 
not limited to mobile homes, carports and storage and accessory buildings. 
    Landmark site means a location where a primary architectural or historical resource formerly stood or 
a significant historic event took place, or where an important archeological resource remains. For the 
purposes of this Ordinance, a Landmark Site encompasses prehistoric or historic sites on unimproved or 
improved land. A historic Landmark Site is designated by the Historic Preservation Commission and 
approved by the Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City through an ordinance. 
    Landscape means any improvement or vegetation including, but not limited to: shrubbery, trees, 
plantings, outbuildings, walls, courtyards, fences, swimming pools, planters, gates, street furniture, 
exterior lighting and site improvements, including but not limited to, subsurface alterations, site regrading, 
fill depositing and paving. 
    Mississippi Department of Archives and History means the state agency created by the Mississippi 
Legislature pursuant to the authority contained in Miss. Code Ann. § 39-5-1 et seq. (Supp. 2001), which 
includes, as its duties and responsibilities, the encouragement of historical work and research and the 
determination of the location of places of historical interests throughout the State of Mississippi. The 
Mississippi Department of Archives and History is sometimes abbreviated in this Ordinance as the 
"MDAH." 
    Mississippi Local Government Historic Preservation Law of 1978 means the Mississippi Local 
Government Historic Preservation Law of 1978, as adopted by the Mississippi Legislature on April 4, 
1978, and codified as Miss. Code Ann. § 39-13-1 et seq. (Rev. 2002). 
    National Historic Landmark means a district, site, building, structure, and/or object that has been 
formally designated as a National Historic Landmark by the Secretary of the Interior and possesses 
exceptional value or quality in illustrating or interpreting the heritage of the United States in history, 
architecture, archaeology, engineering and culture and that possesses a high degree of integrity of 
location, design, setting, materials, workmanship, feeling and association. National Historic Landmarks 
are automatically listed in the National Register. 
    National Register of Historic Places means a federal list of cultural resources worthy of preservation, 
authorized under the National Historic Preservation Act of 1966 as part of a national program to 
coordinate and support public and private efforts to identify, evaluate, and protect the nation's historic and 
archaeological resources. The National Register Program is administered by the Historic Preservation 
Commission, by the State Historic Preservation Office and by the National Park Service under the 
Department of the Interior. Significant federal benefits may accrue to owners of properties listed or 
determined eligible for listing in the National Register. 
    Object means a material thing of functional, cultural, historical or scientific value that may be, by 
nature or design, movable, yet related to a specific setting or environment. 
    Ordinary repair or maintenance means work done to prevent deterioration of a resource or any part 
thereof by returning the resource as nearly as practical to its condition prior to such deterioration, decay 
or damage. 
    Owner of record means the owner of a parcel of land, improved or unimproved situated within a 
Historic Preservation District, as reflected on the Coahoma County deed records and/or tax rolls. 
    Period of greatest historic significance for a Landmark means the time period during which the 
Landmark had been essentially completed but not yet altered. It is also the period during which the style 
of architecture of the Landmark was commonplace or typical. If a Landmark also achieved historical 
importance in part because of designed landscape features, the period of greatest historic significance 
includes the time period during which such landscape features were maintained. 
    Relocation means the moving of a structure to a new location on its tax parcel or the relocation of 
such a structure to a new tax parcel. 
    Resource means parcels located within Historic Districts, individual Landmarks and Landmark sites, 
regardless of whether such sites are presently improved or unimproved. Resources can be both separate 
buildings, districts, structures, sites and objects and related groups thereof. 
    Secretary of the Interior's Standards for Rehabilitation and Guidelines for Rehabilitating Historic 
Buildings means the federal document which sets forth the standards and guidelines for the appropriate 
rehabilitation and preservation of historic buildings. 
    Site means the location of a significant event, a prehistoric or historic occupation or activity or a 
building or structure, whether standing, ruined or vanished, where the location itself maintains historical or 
archaeological value regardless of the value of any existing buildings or objects. 
    State Historic Preservation Office means the Historic Preservation Division of the Mississippi 
Department of Archives and History. 
    State Historic Preservation Officer means the director of the Mississippi Department of Archives and 
History. 
    Structure means a manmade object and typically will be visible because of portions which exist 
above grade. Structures built during the historic period, circa 1700 forward, may in some instances not be 
visible above grade if they are cellars, cisterns, icehouses or similar objects which by their nature are 
intended to be built into the ground. A Structure includes both interior components and visible exterior 
surfaces, as well as attached elements such as signs and related features such as walks, walls, fences 
and other nearby secondary structures or landmark features. 
    Subdistricts means discrete areas within a larger Historic District within which separate design 
guidelines are appropriate and that may be created to recognize different zoning classifications or historic 
development patterns which have caused adjacent historic areas to develop at different times. 
    Subdivision means any change in the boundaries of a single tax parcel, whether the change results 
in expansion or reduction or a boundary relocation. 
    Substantial deterioration means structural degradation of such a nature that water penetration into a 
historic structure can no longer be prevented, or structural degradation that causes stress or strain on 
structural members when supports collapse or warp, evidence of which includes defective roofing 
materials, broken window coverings and visible interior decay. 
    Survey of resources means the documentation, by historical research or a photographic record, of 
structures of historical interest within a specified area or jurisdiction or of existing structures within a 
proposed Historic District. 
    Unauthorized demolition means the deliberate demolition of a historic structure without prior review 
and approval by the Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City of Clarksdale, to which the Historic 
Preservation Commission has made a recommendation. 
    Unreasonable economic hardship shall have the definition under constitutional standards used to 
determine whether a "taking" exists. 
(Ord. No. 988, § 3, 10-28-2002) 


Sec. 11A-4. - Clarksdale Historic Preservation Commission; composition, and terms. 
(a)	Purpose. By virtue of the Mississippi Local Government Historic Preservation Law of 1978, and 
specifically Miss. Code Ann. §§ 39-13-5, 39-15-7 and 39-13-9 (Rev. 2001), the City of Clarksdale is 
authorized to establish the Historic Preservation Commission to preserve, promote and develop the 
City's historical resources and to advise the Board of the City on the designation of historic districts, 
landmarks and landmark sites, and to perform such other functions as may be provided by law. 
(b)	Appointments. All members of the Historic Preservation Commission are appointed by the Board of 
Mayor and Commissioners of the City, and shall serve at the will and pleasure of the City. The 
Historic Preservation Commission shall consist of five (5) members, each of whom shall be residents 
of the City of Clarksdale. 
(c)	Terms. All members of the Historic Preservation Commission shall serve for terms established by the 
City and shall be eligible for reappointment as provided herein. All Historic Preservation Commission 
members shall have a demonstrated knowledge of or interest, competence, or expertise in historic 
preservation. 
(d)	Qualifications of Members. To the extent available in the community, the City Board shall consider 
appointment of professional members from the primary historic preservation-related disciplines such 
as urban planning, American studies, American civilization, cultural geography, cultural 
anthropology, interior design, law and related fields. In conformity with the "State of Mississippi, 
Procedures for the Certified Local Government Program", the City shall document a "good faith 
effort" to locate professionals to serve on the Historic Preservation Commission before appointing lay 
members. Also the City shall document its "good faith effort" to locate residents of the municipality to 
serve on the commission before appointing individuals who own property within the boundary of the 
municipality or are in the service of an employer located within the boundary of the municipality. 
(e)	The City shall publish at least one notice in the Clarksdale Press Register, a newspaper published 
and having general circulation in the City of Clarksdale, to solicit responses from citizens who are 
professionals in the related fields of historic preservation and who are interested in serving on the 
Historic Preservation Commission. The City may contact known professionals and interested lay 
persons, and invite the submission of their qualifications in written resume form. 
(f)	The City shall provide at least three (3) weeks (15 working days) for responses. Respondents shall 
submit, in written resume form, information concerning their demonstrated interest, competence, 
knowledge, or expertise. Such information should include, but is not limited to, educational and 
professional background, membership in appropriate preservation organizations, subscriptions to 
suitable professional publications, volunteer work, attendance at workshops and seminars and other 
relevant experience. 
(g)	When the City has collected adequate information concerning the potential appointees to the Historic 
Preservation Commission, the Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City shall decide, which 
candidates can be considered professionals and thereby qualified for appointment to the Historic 
Preservation Commission. 
(Ord. No. 988, § 4, 10-28-2002) 


Sec. 11A-5. - Powers of the commission. 
    In order to preserve, promote and develop the distinctive appearance and the historic resources of 
the City of Clarksdale and to accomplish the purposes set forth in Miss. Code Ann. § 39-13-5 (Rev. 2001) 
and in this Ordinance: 
A.	The Historic Preservation Commission shall conduct or cause to be conducted a continuing 
study and survey of resources within the City of Clarksdale. 
B.	The Historic Preservation Commission shall recommend to the Board of Mayor and 
Commissioners of the City the adoption of ordinances designating historic districts, landmarks 
and landmark sites. 
C.	The Historic Preservation Commission may, in its discretion, recommend that the City recognize 
subdistricts within any historic district, in order that the Historic Preservation Commission may 
adopt specific guidelines for the regulation of properties within such subdistrict. 
D.	The Historic Preservation Commission shall review applications proposing construction, 
alteration, demolition or relocation of any resource as defined in section 11A-3. 
E.	The Historic Preservation Commission shall recommend to the Board of Mayor and 
Commissioners that it grant or deny Certificates of Appropriateness, and may recommend the 
grant of Certificates of Appropriateness contingent upon the acceptance by the applicant of 
specified conditions. The final decision as to the grant or denial of a Certificate of 
Appropriateness shall rest with the Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City and the 
recommendation of the Historic Preservation Commissioners shall be advisory only and 
nonbinding. 
F.	The Historic Preservation Commission shall not consider interior arrangements of buildings and 
structures, except that it may, when requested by the MDAH, advise the MDAH on questions 
relating to the interiors of publicly-owned historic buildings. Interior arrangements which are not 
to be considered by the Historic Preservation Commission shall include floor plans, architectural 
details and finishes, but the Commission may consider interior structural elements visible 
through doors or windows if they become deteriorated because of demolition by neglect. Such 
interior structural elements may include walls, floors and ceilings, as well as other supporting 
elements of a composite structure. 
G.	The Historic Preservation Commission, subject to the consent of and the requirements of the 
City, may apply for, receive, hold and spend funds from private and public sources, in addition 
to appropriations made by the City, if any, for the purpose for carrying out the provisions of this 
ordinance. The Historic Preservation Commission shall obtain prior consent of the Board of 
Mayor and Commissioners before submitting a grant application, provide documentation to 
include, but not limited to, a proposed budget for the project, the availability of matching funds if 
any, required under any grant application, include a copy of the terms and conditions of a grant, 
give notice to the Mayor and the City Clerk of grant approval and of any action required by the 
City to accept the grant. The Historic Preservation Commission may not commit funds of the 
City of Clarksdale to any project without the prior consent of the Board of Mayor and 
Commissioners as spread upon its minutes. The Historic Preservation Commission may not 
encumber any property owned by the City of Clarksdale or make any pledge against any 
revenues, including the general taxing authority of the City, or issue any type of bonds on behalf 
of the City. 
H.	The Historic Preservation Commission, subject to the consent of and requirements of the City 
Board, may employ such staff or contract with technical experts or other persons as may be 
required for the performance of its duties and may obtain the equipment, supplies, and other 
materials necessary for its effective operation. 
I.	The Historic Preservation Commission may, solely in the performance of its official duties and 
only at reasonable times, enter upon private land for the examination or survey thereof. No 
member, employee, or agent of the Historic Preservation Commission shall enter any private 
dwelling or structure without the express consent of the owner of record or occupant thereof. 
J.	Changes in the exterior color of a structure within a designated historic district are hereby 
specifically determined to be outside the jurisdiction of the Historic Preservation Commission, 
and no submission or application to or recommendation by the Historic Preservation 
Commission or approval by the Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City shall be required 
for an owner to make such exterior color changes as he may deem desirable or appropriate. 
K.	The Historic Preservation Commission may not recommend denial of a Certificate of 
Appropriateness for demolition if denial of such a certificate would cause unreasonable 
economic hardship to an owner, pursuant to the requirements of Miss. Code Ann. § 39-13-5(d) 
(Rev. 2001). 
(Ord. No. 988, § 5, 10-28-2002) 


Sec. 11A-6. - Rules of procedure. 
    To fulfill the purposes of this ordinance and to carry out the provisions contained therein: 
A.	The Historic Preservation Commission annually shall elect from its membership a chairman and 
vice-chairman. It shall select a secretary from its membership or its staff. If neither the chairman 
nor the vice-chairman is in attendance at a particular meeting, the remaining members shall 
select an acting chairman from the members in attendance at such meeting. 
B.	Three (3) out of the five (5) members of the Historic Preservation Commission shall constitute a 
quorum. A quorum of the members shall be required to conduct any business. 
C.	The Historic Preservation Commission shall, as soon as possible, develop and adopt proposed 
rules of procedure which shall govern the conduct of its business, and which shall be submitted 
to the Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City for its approval. Such rules of procedure 
shall be a matter of public record. 
D.	The Historic Preservation Commission shall develop design review guidelines for determining 
appropriateness as generally set forth in section 11A-7. Such criteria shall, insofar as possible, 
be consistent with local, state and federal guidelines and regulations, including, but not limited 
to, building safety and fire codes and the Secretary of the Interior's Standards For 
Rehabilitation. 
E.	The Historic Preservation Commission shall keep minutes and records of all meetings and 
proceedings including voting records, attendance, resolutions, findings, determinations and 
decisions. All such material shall be a matter of public record. 
F.	The Historic Preservation Commission shall be subject to the requirements of the Mississippi 
Open Meetings Law, Miss. Code Ann. § 25-41-1 et seq. (Rev. 1999). 
G.	The Historic Preservation Commission shall establish its own regular meeting day and time; 
however, the first meeting shall be held within thirty (30) days of the establishment of the 
Commission by the Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City and regular meetings shall 
be scheduled at least once every three (3) months. The chairman or any two (2) members may 
call a special meeting for any lawful purpose. 
(Ord. No. 988, § 6, 10-28-2002) 


Sec. 11A-7. - Designation of landmarks, landmark sites, and historic districts. 
    By ordinance, the City of Clarksdale, acting through its Board of Mayor and Commissioners, may 
establish landmarks, landmark sites, and historic districts within the area of its jurisdiction. Such 
landmarks, landmark sites, or historic districts shall be designated following the criteria as specified in 
Section 11A-3 above. 
A.	The Historic Preservation Commission shall initiate a continuing and thorough investigation of 
the archaeological, architectural, cultural, and historic significance of the City of Clarksdale's 
resources. The findings shall be collected in a cohesive format, made a matter of public record, 
and made available for public inspection. The Historic Preservation Commission will work 
toward providing complete documentation for locally designated historic districts, which will 
normally include: 
1.	An inventory of all property within the boundary of the historic district, with photographs of 
each building and an evaluation of its significance to the historic district. Building 
evaluations are to be used only as a reference or guide, and shall not be used as the 
determining factor for issuing or denying a Certificate of Appropriateness. 
2.	An inventory which would be in format consistent with the statewide inventory format of the 
Historic Preservation Division of the Mississippi Department of Archives and History 
(SHPO). 
B.	The Historic Preservation Commission shall advise the Board of Mayor and Commissioners of 
the City on the designation of historic districts, landmarks or landmark sites, and submit or 
cause to be prepared proposed ordinances making such designations. 
C.	A resource or resources may be nominated for designation upon motion of at least two 
members of the Historic Preservation Commission, or by an organization interested in historic 
preservation or by an owner of the property being nominated. A nomination shall contain 
information as specified by the Historic Preservation Commission. The Historic Preservation 
Commission must reach a decision on whether to recommend a proposed nomination to the 
Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City within six months in the case of a historic 
district, and three months in the case of either a landmark or landmark site. 
D.	If the Historic Preservation Commission votes to recommend to the Board of Mayor and 
Commissioners of the City the designation of a proposed resource, it shall promptly forward to 
the City its recommendation, in writing, together with an accompanying file. 
E.	The Historic Preservation Commission's recommendations to the City for the designation of a 
historic district shall be accompanied by appropriate data, including, but not limited to: 
1.	A map of the historic district that clearly delineates the boundaries thereof. 
2.	A verbal boundary description. 
3.	A written justification as to the proposed boundaries. 
4.	A written statement of the significance of the proposed historic district and the reasons 
therefor. 
5.	Such other information, in writing, including photographs, which will assist the Board of 
Mayor and Commissioners of the City in its evaluation of the proposed historic district. 
F.	After the nomination of a resource to the Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City by the 
Historic Preservation Commission for possible local designation, the resource shall be fully 
protected by the provisions of this ordinance for a period of six months, as if it were already 
designated. 
G.	Any property designated under any previous city ordinance shall remain designated. 
H.	No historic district or districts shall be designated until the MDAH has been notified by certified 
letter by the City and invited to make recommendations and comments concerning the 
proposed district boundaries. The MDAH may comment by letter, telephone, e-mail or in person 
through designated staff. The City shall provide to the MDAH the dates of the next two (2) public 
meetings at which action on the designation of such historic district might be taken so that the 
MDAH may comment in a timely manner. Failure of the MDAH to comment by the date of the 
second such meeting relieves the City of any responsibility for awaiting and responding to such 
analysis, and the City may, at any time thereafter, take such action as it deems necessary and 
appropriate to create the proposed historic district or to decline to create the proposed historic 
district as the Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City, in its sole discretion, deems 
appropriate and in the best interests of the City of Clarksdale. 
I.	If a proposed ordinance is to designate a landmark or landmark site, it may be presented to the 
Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City with the recommendation of the Historic 
Preservation Commission that it be adopted without submission to the MDAH. 
J.	The Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City shall conduct a public hearing, after proper 
notice, to discuss the proposed designation and boundaries thereof. Written notice of the public 
hearing shall be published once a week for at least three (3) consecutive weeks in the 
Clarksdale Press Register, a newspaper published and having general circulation in the City of 
Clarksdale, which is authorized to publish legal notices in accordance with law, weekly for three 
(3) consecutive weeks. The first publication of such notice of public hearing shall be made not 
less than twenty-one (21) days prior to the date of the public hearing and the last publication not 
more than seven (7) days prior to such date. 
K.	The Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City must taken action on the proposed 
designation within sixty (60) days of the public hearing, either to adopt a designating ordinance 
or to reject the proposed designation. 
L.	The Historic Preservation Commission shall, as soon as is reasonably possible, notify other 
municipal agencies and any appropriate county or state agencies, including MDAH, of the 
designation of a historic district, landmarks or landmark site. 
M.	The Historic Preservation Commission shall maintain, in its official files, an updated list and map 
of local designations, and will provide copies of such map(s) to other governmental agencies, 
specifically including the Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City, within one (1) week of 
the preparation of a new version of such map. 
(Ord. No. 988, § 7, 10-28-2002) 


Sec. 11A-8. - Certificates of appropriateness. 
A.	No exterior feature, including exterior colors, of any resource shall be altered, relocated, or 
demolished until an application for a certificate of appropriateness of such work has been submitted 
to the Historic Preservation Commission and the Historic Preservation Commission has 
recommended to the Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City the approval thereof, if the 
Historic Preservation Commission finds and determines that a proposed construction, alteration, 
demolition, subdivision or relation is consistent with the design review guidelines established by the 
Historic Preservation Commission and a specific finding that the proposed construction alteration, 
demolition, subdivision or relocation would be compatible with the character of a historic district or 
landmark or landmark site, and does not compromise the historic and architectural integrity of the 
historic district, landmark or landmark site. 
B.	The Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City may require that a property owner post a bond in 
such amount as the Historic Preservation Commission recommends to guaranty satisfactory 
completion of a relocation project. 
C.	No construction, alteration, demolition, subdivision or relocation of a resource or which affects a 
resource shall be undertaken without the owner thereof having first obtained a certificate of 
appropriateness. 
D.	The Historic Preservation Commission, whenever it recommends denial of a certificate of 
appropriateness, must state, in writing, the reasons for such recommendation of a denial. The Board 
of Mayor and Commissioners of the City shall consider the same in determining whether to issue a 
certificate of appropriateness. In the event of the denial of a certificate of appropriateness, an 
applicant may resubmit a new application at any time, accept that a applicant must wait six (6) 
months whenever an application for a certification of appropriateness is denied for a landmark 
property of statewide or national significance and notice of any second or subsequent application 
shall be sent to MDAH as well as to the Historic Preservation Commission. 
E.	The denial of a certification of appropriateness shall be binding upon local building inspectors and 
the Public Works Department, the agency responsible for issuing building permits, and shall prevent 
the issuance of other building permits for the same parcel until a certificate of appropriateness is 
approved. A certification of appropriateness shall be required for work which does not otherwise 
require a building permit. A certificate of appropriateness may be evidence by either a written and 
dated letter to an owner or applicant or such a letter accompanied by a signed and dated stamp on 
the face of any and all architectural project drawings prepared for a project. 
F.	A certificate of appropriateness shall expire at the end of six (6) months, if work has not been begun 
and substantially completed within said time frame. 
G.	The Historic Preservation Commission shall serve as a review body with the power to recommend to 
the Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City the approval or denial of all applications for 
certificates of appropriateness. 
H.	In recommending whether to approve and deny any applications for certificates of appropriateness, 
the Historic Preservation Commission shall seek to accomplish the purposes of this ordinance and 
the Mississippi Local Government Historic Preservation Law of 1978, Miss. Code Ann. § 39-13-1 et 
seq. (Rev. 2001). 
I.	A certification of appropriateness shall not be required for work deemed by the Historic Preservation 
Commission to be ordinary maintenance or repair of any resource. 
J.	All proceedings, decisions and recommendations of the Historic Preservation Commission shall be in 
writing and shall state the findings of the Historic Preservation Commission, its recommendations 
and the reasons therefore. 
(Ord. No. 988, § 8, 10-28-2002) 


Sec. 11A-9. - Criteria for issuance of certificates of appropriateness. 
    The Historic Preservation Commission shall consider the following criteria recommending, and the 
Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City shall use the following criteria in granting or denying 
certificates of appropriateness: 
A.	General Factors: 
1.	Architectural design of existing building, structure, or appurtenance and proposed 
alteration. 
2.	Historical significance of the resource. 
3.	General appearance of the resource. 
4.	Condition of the resource. 
5.	Materials composing the resource. 
6.	Size of the resource. 
7.	The relationship of the above factors to, and their effect upon the immediate surroundings 
and, if within a historic district, upon the district as a whole, and its architectural and 
historical character and integrity. 
B.	New construction: 
1.	In advance of new construction, steps shall be taken to insure evaluation of possible 
archaeological resources, as set forth in the Mississippi Antiquities Act. 
2.	The following aspects of new construction shall be visually compatible with the buildings 
and environment with which the new construction is visually related, including but not 
limited to: (a) the height, (b) the gross volume, (c) the proportion between width and height 
of the facade(s), (d) the proportions and relationship between doors and windows, (e) the 
rhythm of solids, to voids created by openings in the facade, (f) the materials, (g) the 
textures, (h) the colors, (i) the patterns, (j) the trims and (k) the design of the roof. 
3.	Existing rhythm created by existing building masses and spaces between them shall be 
preserved insofar as feasible. 
4.	The landscape plan shall be compatible with the resource, and visually compatible with the 
environment with which it is visually related. Landscaping shall also not prove detrimental 
to the fabric of a resource, or adjacent public or private improvements like sidewalks and 
walls. 
5.	No specific architectural style shall be required. 
C.	Exterior alteration: 
1.	All exterior alterations to a building, structure, object, site, or landscape feature shall be 
compatible with the resource itself and other resources with which it is related, as is 
provided in this subsections A and B, and the original design of a building, structure, 
object, or landscape feature shall be considered in applying these standards. 
2.	Exterior alterations shall not affect the architectural character or historic quality of a 
landmark nor destroy the significance of landmark sites. 
D.	In considering an application for the demolition of a landmark or a resource within a historic 
district, the following shall be considered: 
1.	The individual architectural, cultural and/or historical significance of the resource. 
2.	The importance or contribution of the resource to the architectural character of the historic 
district. 
3.	The importance or contribution of the resource to neighboring property values. 
4.	The difficulty or impossibility of reproducing such a resource because of its texture, design, 
material, or detail. 
5.	Following recommendation for approval of demolition, the applicant must seek approval of 
replacement plans under the criteria set forth in subsection B prior to receiving a demolition 
permit and other permits. Replacement plans, for this purpose, shall include but shall not 
be restricted to, project concept, preliminary elevations and site plans, and completed 
working drawings for at least the foundation plan to enable the applicant to receive a permit 
for foundation construction. 
6.	Applicants who received a recommendation for demolition shall be permitted to receive 
such demolition permit without additional action by the Historic Preservation Commission 
of the City on demolition, following the Commission's recommendation of a permit for new 
construction. Permits for demolition and construction may be issued simultaneously if 
requirements of subsection B, are met, and the applicant provides financial proof of his 
ability to complete the project. 
7.	When the commission recommends approval of demolition of a resource, a permit shall not 
be issued until all plans for the site have received approval from the Public Works 
Department or the Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City, as applicable. 
(Ord. No. 988, § 9, 10-28-2002) 


Sec. 11A-10. - Procedures for issuance of certificates of appropriateness. 
A.	Anyone desiring to take any action which requires a certificate of appropriateness concerning a 
resource for which a permit, variance, or other authorization from either the City Building Official or 
the City is also required, shall make application therefore in the form and manner required by the 
applicable City code section or ordinance. Any such application shall also be considered an 
application for a certificate of appropriateness, and shall include such additional information as may 
be required by the Historic Preservation Commission or this Ordinance. After receipt of any such 
application, the City Building Official shall assure himself that the application is proper and complete. 
B.	No building permit shall be issued by the City Building Official which affects a resource without a 
certificate of appropriateness. In the event that a building permit need not be obtained for a building, 
structure or object to be erected within a historic district or on a landmark or landmark site, a 
certificate of appropriateness is nevertheless required before such building, structure or object may 
be erected. 
C.	Each application shall be reviewed in accordance with the following procedure: 
1.	When any such application is filed, the City Building Official shall immediately notify the Historic 
Preservation Commission Chairman or Vice-Chairman, if the Chairman is unavailable, that an 
application has been filed. 
2.	If, at the time of filing of an application, there is not a Historic Preservation Commission meeting 
already scheduled within thirty (30) days of the filing, the Chairman or Vice-Chairman may set a 
time and date, which shall be not later than fifteen (15) days after the filing of the application, for 
a hearing by the Historic Planning Commission, and the City Building Official shall be so 
informed. 
3.	The applicant shall, upon request, have the right to a preliminary conference with the Historic 
Preservation Commission staff, if any, and/or the City Building Official for the purpose of making 
any changes or adjustments to the application which might be more consistent with the Historic 
Preservation Commission's and the City's standards as set forth in the Historic Preservation 
Commission's rules and regulations and in this Ordinance. 
4.	Not later than eight (8) calendar days before the date set for the said hearing, the City Building 
Official shall mail notice thereof by regular U. S. first class mail postage prepaid, to the applicant 
at the address in the application, and to all members of the Historic Preservation Commission. 
5.	Notice of the time and place of said hearing may, in the discretion of the Historic Preservation 
Commission, be given by publication in the Clarksdale Press Register, a newspaper published 
and having general circulation in the City at least ten (10) days before such hearing and by 
posting such notice on the main bulletin board in the lobby of City Hall, 121 Sunflower Avenue, 
Clarksdale, Mississippi 38614. 
6.	At such hearing, the applicant for a certificate of appropriateness shall have the right to present 
any relevant evidence in support of the application. Likewise, the City shall have the right to 
present any additional relevant evidence in support of or opposition to the application. 
7.	The Historic Preservation Commission shall have the right to recommend additional changes 
and modifications to enable the applicant to meet the requirements of the Commission. 
Compliance by the applicant with such recommendations may be made a condition precedent 
to the issuance of the certificate of appropriateness. 
8.	Within twenty-one (21) days after the adjournment of the hearing on an application, the Historic 
Preservation Commission shall act upon it, either recommending its approval or denial to the 
Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City, or the Historic Preservation Commission may, 
for good cause, defer action until the next meeting of the Historic Preservation Commission, 
giving consideration to the factors set forth in Section IX hereof. The Historic Preservation 
Commission shall makes its findings of fact and its recommendations to the Board of Mayor and 
Commissioners in writing within five (5) working days following the meeting at which its decision 
is made. The Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City will ordinarily act upon the 
recommendation of the Historic Preservation Commission at its next regular weekly meeting 
following receipt of the decision of the Historic Preservation Commission. The Historic 
Preservation Commission shall forward a copy of its findings and recommendations to the 
applicant and the City Building Official. Whenever the Historic Preservation Commission 
recommends denial of the certificate of appropriateness, it must state the reasons for such 
denial in writing. Likewise, whenever the Board of Mayor and Commissioners accepts and 
approves the recommendation of the Historic Preservation Commission and denies the 
issuance of the certificate of appropriateness, the City Board must state its reasons for such 
denial in writing, which may include reliance upon the findings and recommendations of the 
Historic Preservation Commission. Thereafter, an applicant may resubmit a new application at 
any time, except that an applicant must wait six (6) months whenever an application for a 
certificate of appropriateness is denied for a landmark property of statewide or national 
significance and notice of any second or subsequent application must be sent to the Mississippi 
Department of Archives and History as well as to the local historic preservation commission. 
9.	In all cases of applications affecting National Historic Landmarks, at least two-thirds of the 
members of the Historic Preservation Commission must affirmatively recommend the approval 
of a certificate of appropriateness in order that it be granted. A majority vote of the Board of 
Mayor and Commissioners of the City approving the issuance of a certificate of appropriateness 
in such event shall be sufficient. 
10.	The issuance of a certificate of appropriateness shall not relieve an applicant for a building 
permit, special use permit, variance, or other authorization from compliance with any and all 
other requirements or provisions of the laws and ordinances of the City concerning zoning, land 
use, subdivision rules and regulations, construction, repair or demolition. 
11.	Denial of a certificate of appropriateness by the Board of Mayor and Commissioners shall be 
binding upon the City Building Inspector or the Public Works Department, the agency 
responsible for issuing building permits, and shall prevent the issuance of other building permits 
for the same parcel until a certificate of appropriateness is approved and issued. A certificate of 
appropriateness may be required for work which does not require a building permit. A certificate 
of appropriateness may be evidenced by either a written and dated letter to an owner or 
applicant or such a letter accompanied by a signed and dated stamp on the face of any and all 
architectural or project drawings prepared for a project. 
12.	A certificate of appropriateness shall expire, without further action on the part of the City, after 
six (6) months if work has not begun on the resource. 
13.	The Historic Preservation Commission may recommend, and the Board of Mayor and 
Commissioners of the City may adopt a reasonable schedule of fees to cover the Historic 
Preservation Commission's and the City's administrative and other costs in the application and 
approval process, including the costs of publication of any notices of public hearings, 
inspections, photographs or similar costs. 
14.	The Historic Preservation Commission shall comply with the provisions of the Mississippi Open 
Meetings Law, Miss. Code Ann. § 25-41-1 et seq. (Rev. 1999) regarding notice of special 
meetings and otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 988, § 10, 10-28-2002) 


Sec. 11A-11. - Unreasonable economic hardship. 
A.	When a claim of unreasonable economic hardship is made as a result of the effect of this ordinance, 
the owner of record must present evidence sufficient to prove that, as a result of the Historic 
Preservation Commission's action, he is unable to obtain a reasonable return or a reasonable 
beneficial use. The owner of record shall submit, by affidavit, to the Historic Preservation 
Commission for its review at a minimum the following information: 
1.	The date the property was acquired by its current owner. 
2.	The price paid for the property (if acquired by purchase), and the relationship (if any) between 
the buyer and the seller of the property. 
3.	The mortgage history of the property, including any current mortgage. 
4.	The current fair market value of the property. 
5.	The equity in current use and in alternative uses. 
6.	The past and current income and expense statements for a two-year period. 
7.	The past capital expenditures during ownership of current owner. 
8.	The appraisals of the property obtained within the previous two years. 
9.	The income and property tax factors affecting the property. 
10.	Any other information reasonably required by the Historic Preservation Commission. 
B.	The Historic Preservation Commission may require that an applicant furnish additional information 
relevant to the determination of unreasonable economic hardship. 
C.	The Historic Preservation Commission may receive and consider studies and economic analyses 
from other city agencies and from private organizations relating to the property in question. 
D.	Should the Historic Preservation Commission determine that the owner's present return is not 
reasonable, it must consider whether there are other uses currently allowed that would provide a 
reasonable return, and whether such a return could be obtained through investment in the property 
for rehabilitation purposes. 
E.	Should the applicant satisfy the Historic Preservation Commission that he will suffer an unreasonable 
economic hardship if a certificate of appropriateness is not approved, the Historic Preservation 
Commission shall recommend the approval of such certificate to the Board of Mayor and 
Commissioners of the City. 
(Ord. No. 988, § 11, 10-28-2002) 


Sec. 11A-12. - Appeals. 
A.	An applicant who is aggrieved by any final decision of the Historic Preservation Commission may 
appeal the decision of the Historic Preservation Commission to the Board of Mayor and 
Commissioners of the City by filing his notice with the City Clerk of the City within ten (10) days from 
the date of such decision. 
B.	If a property owner in a historic district, or the owner of the historic landmark or property site is 
denied a Certificate of Appropriateness, the property owner may appeal directly to the Chancery 
Court of Coahoma County, Mississippi, in accordance with the provisions of Section 39-13-19 (Rev. 
2001). Any such appeal shall be reviewed upon the record established before the Historic 
Preservation Commission. 
C.	Any local property owner or organization aggrieved or damages by such a decision may appeal in 
the same manner, in accordance with the law. 
(Ord. No. 988, § 12, 10-28-2002) 


Sec. 11A-13. - Minimum maintenance requirements. 
    In order to insure the protective maintenance of resources, the exterior features of such properties 
shall be maintained so as to meet at least the minimum requirements of the City's building and housing 
codes. 
(Ord. No. 988, § 13, 10-28-2002) 


Sec. 11A-14. - Demolition by neglect. 
A.	Any resource which is a landmark and all resources within a historic district shall be preserved by the 
owner or such other person or persons as may have the legal custody or control thereof against 
decay and deterioration and free from unreasonable structural defects. The owner or other person 
having legal custody and control thereof shall repair such resource if it is found to have one or more 
of the following defects: 
1.	Deterioration to the extent that it creates or permits a hazardous or unsafe condition as 
determined by the City's Building Inspector. 
2.	Deterioration, as determined by the City's Building Inspector, of a building characterized by one 
or more of the following: 
a.	Those buildings which have parts thereof which are so attached that they may fall and 
injure persons or property. 
b.	Deteriorated or inadequate foundations. 
c.	Defective or deteriorated floor supports or floor supports inefficient to carry imposed loads 
with safety. 
d.	Members of walls or other vertical supports that split, lean, list or buckle due to defective 
material, workmanship or deterioration. 
e.	Members of walls or other vertical supports that are insufficient to carry imposed loads with 
safety. 
f.	Members of ceilings, roofs, ceiling and roof supports, or other horizontal members which 
sag, split or buckle due to defective material, workmanship or deterioration. 
g.	Members of ceilings, roofs, ceiling and roof supports, or other horizontal members that are 
insufficient to carry imposed loads with safety. 
h.	Fireplaces or chimneys which list, bulge, or settle due to defective material, workmanship 
or deterioration. 
i.	Any fault, defect, or condition in the building which renders the same structurally unsafe or 
not properly watertight. 
B.	If the Historic Preservation commission makes a preliminary determination that a resource is being 
demolished by neglect, it shall direct the City's Building Inspector to notify the owner or owners of the 
resource of this preliminary determination, stating the reasons therefore, and shall give the owner of 
record thirty (30) days from the date of mailing of such notice or the posting thereof on the property, 
whichever comes later, to commence work to correct the specific defects as determined by the 
Historic Preservation Commission. Said notice shall be given as follows: 
1.	By certified mail, return receipt requested, restricted delivery, mailed to the last known address 
of the record owner or owners as listed on the tax rolls of Coahoma County, Mississippi on file 
in the Coahoma County Tax Assessor's office; or 
2.	If the mailing procedure in subsection B.1 above is not successful, written notice shall be posted 
in a conspicuous, protected place on the exterior of the resource. 
C.	If the owner fails to commence work within the time allotted as evidenced by a building permit, the 
Historic Planning Commission shall notify the owner in the manner provided above to appear at a 
public hearing before the Historic Preservation Commission at a date, time and place to be specified 
in said notice, which shall be mailed or posted at least thirty (30) days before said hearing. For the 
purpose of insuring lawful notice, a previously scheduled hearing may be continued to a new date 
and time. 
D.	The Historic Preservation Commission shall receive evidence on the issue of whether the subject 
resource should be repaired, and the owner may present evidence in rebuttal thereto. If, after such 
hearing, the Historic Preservation Commission shall determine that the resource is being demolished 
by neglect, it may direct that the City Building Official bring misdemeanor charges against the owner 
if the necessary repairs are not completed within ninety (90) days of the determination by the Historic 
Preservation Commission that the subject building or structure is being demolished by neglect. 
E.	In addition to the powers specified in Miss. Code Ann. § 21-19-11(1) (Rev. 2000), the Board of 
Mayor and Commissioners of the City, if the Historic Preservation Division of the MDAH concurs, 
may, at its sole discretion, make those repairs necessary to correct demolition by neglect, and the 
cost of such repairs shall become a lien against the property in accordance with Section 21-19-11(3). 
F.	In the event a structure(s) is demolished without review and approval by the Historic Preservation 
Commission, the Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City may require that no permit be 
issued for any structure or structures proposed for the same parcel which would require a footprint 
larger than the footprint of the demolished structure or structures. 
G.	If a historic landmark or landmark site of statewide or national significance is demolished without 
review and approval by the Historic Preservation Commission, the Board of Mayor and 
Commissioners of the City may require that no permit for construction on the parcel from which the 
landmark or landmark site has been removed may be issued for a period of up to twenty-four (24) 
months. 
H.	The penalties set forth in Subsections F and G above shall be in addition to any other penalties for 
violations hereof. 
(Ord. No. 988, § 14, 10-28-2002) 


Sec. 11A-15. - Public safety exclusion. 
A.	None of the provisions of this ordinance shall be construed to prevent any action of construction, 
alteration or demolition necessary to correct or abate the unsafe or dangerous condition of any 
resource or part thereof, where such condition has been declared unsafe or dangerous by the City 
Building Official or the Clarksdale Fire Department and where the proposed actions have been 
declared necessary by such authorities to correct the said condition; provided, however, that only 
such work as is necessary to correct the unsafe or dangerous condition may be performed pursuant 
to this Section. 
B.	In the event any resource designated as a landmark or located within a historic district is damaged 
by fire or other calamity to such and extent that it cannot be repaired and restored, it may be 
removed in conformity with normal permit procedures and applicable laws, provided that: 
1.	The City Building Official concurs with the property owner that the resource cannot be repaired 
and restored and so notifies the Historic Preservation Commission in writing. 
2.	The Historic Preservation Commission, if in doubt after receiving such notification from the City 
Building Official, shall be allowed time to seek outside professional expertise from the State 
Historic Preservation Office and/or an independent structural engineer before issuing a 
certificate of appropriateness for the demolition. 
3.	The Historic Preservation Commission may indicate in writing appropriateness for the 
demolition. 
4.	The Historic Preservation Commission may indicate in writing by letter to the City Building 
Official, with a copy to the property owner, that it will require a time period of up to thirty (30) 
additional days for this purpose, and, upon such notification to the City Building Official and the 
property owner, this section shall be suspended until the expiration of such delay period. 
(Ord. No. 988, § 15, 10-28-2002) 


Sec. 11A-16. - Enforcement and penalties. 
    The following civil and criminal penalties may be imposed upon those persons, firms, or corporations 
found to have violated requirements or prohibitions contained within this ordinance: 
A.	Civil penalty. 
1.	Any person who constructs, alters, relocates or demolishes any resource in violation of this 
ordinance shall be required to restore the resource to its appearance or setting prior to the 
violation. An action to enforce this provision shall be brought by the City of Clarksdale. This 
civil remedy shall be in addition to, and not in lieu of, any criminal prosecution and penalty. 
2.	If construction, alteration or relocation of any resource occurs without having first obtained 
a certificate of appropriateness, then the license of the company, individual or principal 
owner or its or his successor in interest, who performs such construction, alteration or 
relocation shall be revoked for a period of three (3) years. 
3.	If demolition of a resource occurs without having first obtained a certificate of 
appropriateness, then the license of the company, individual, principal owner, or its or his 
successor in interest performing such demolition shall be revoked for a period of five (5) 
years. 
4.	If demolition of a resource occurs without having first obtained a certificate of 
appropriateness, then any permits on the subject property will thereafter be denied for a 
period of three (3) years. No permit will be issued for any structure or structures proposed 
for the same parcel which would require a footprint larger than the footprint of the 
demolished structure or structures. In addition, the owner must rebuild on the site using as 
much of the original building material as possible, and in general, following the same form. 
In addition, unauthorized demolition of a portion of a structure shall not serve as 
justification for a demolition permit whenever it can be shown that restoration or 
rehabilitation would still be feasible. In addition, the applicant shall not be entitled to have 
issued to him by any city office a permit allowing any curb cuts on the subject property for a 
period of three (3) years from and after the date of such demolition. 
5.	If a historic landmark or landmark site of statewide or national significance is demolished 
without review and approval by the Historic Preservation Commission, no permit for any 
construction on the parcel from which the landmark or landmark site has been removed 
may be issued for a period of up to twenty-four (24) months. 
B.	Criminal penalty. 
1.	Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this ordinance shall be guilty of a 
misdemeanor, and each shall be deemed guilty of a separate violation for each day during 
which any violation hereof is committed. 
2.	Each person upon conviction, shall be fined not less than Ten Dollars ($10.00) nor more 
than Five Hundred Dollars ($500.00) for each violation. 
3.	Each day that a violation continues to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 988, § 16, 10-28-2002) 


Sec. 11A-17. - Appropriations. 
    The City of Clarksdale is authorized to make such appropriations to the Historic Preservation 
Commission, as it in its sole discretion, deems necessary for the expenses of the operation of the Historic 
Preservation Commission, and may make additional amounts available as necessary for the acquisition, 
restoration, preservation, operation and management of historic properties. 
(Ord. No. 988, § 17, 10-28-2002) 


Sec. 11A-18. - Title to property acquired. 
A.	All property acquired using any funds whatsoever appropriated by the City of Clarksdale shall be 
acquired in the name of the City unless otherwise provided by the Board of Mayor and
