Commissioners of the City. So long as owned by the City, properties may be maintained by or under 
the supervision and control of the City, with the advise of the Historic Preservation Commission. All 
property acquired by the Historic Preservation Commission from funds other than those appropriated 
by the City will be acquired and held in the name of the City. All such properties shall be 
administered in accordance with this and other city ordinances. 
B.	Any property acquired in the name of the City of Clarksdale may be disposed of only in accordance 
with the provisions of Miss. Code Ann. § 21-17-1 (Rev. 2001) relating to the disposition of 
municipally-owned property, except as may otherwise be permitted by specific legislation applicable 
to properties within historic preservation districts. 
(Ord. No. 988, § 18, 10-28-2002) 


Sec. 11A-19. - Non restrictive clause. 
A.	Nothing in this ordinance shall be construed to prevent the regulation or acquisition of property, 
improved or unimproved, by the State of Mississippi or any of its political subdivisions, agencies, or 
instrumentalities or by the United States of America or any of its political subdivisions, agencies, or 
instrumentalities. 
B.	The City of Clarksdale hereby acknowledges that the Mississippi Antiquities Act, Miss. Code Ann. § 
39-7-1 et seq. (Rev. 2001), provides for the sensitive treatment of publicly owned property, improved 
or unimproved, shown to possess certain architectural, historical, or archaeological significance, 
which are designed by the Board of Trustees of the MDAH as Mississippi Landmarks. Whenever the 
City proposes to rehabilitate, alter, or enlarge a Mississippi Landmark (or proposes similar actions 
which would affect a Mississippi Landmark), the City shall submit its plans to the MDAH for review 
and compliance. 
(Ord. No. 988, § 19, 10-28-2002) 


Chapter 12 - HOUSING

Mississippi are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this section, 
with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in subsection (b) of this 
section.

Chapter 13 - LICENSES AND PRIVILEGE TAXES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Permit for persons dealing in secondhand jewelry and precious metals; electrician's 
license, § 7-23 et seq.; permit for food handling establishments, § 9-2; carnivals, § 14-7.1; plumber's 
license, § 16-13; taxation, Ch. 18; license for persons removing or transporting wastewater, § 20-29; 
taxicab license, § 21-1. 
State Law reference- For provision requiring city to levy and collect privilege taxes as prescribed by 
state law, see 1942 Miss. Code, § 9696-234. 


Sec. 13-1. - Privilege taxes-Adopted. 
    All of the provisions of 1942 Mississippi Code, sections 9696-01 through 9696-235, are hereby 
adopted as the privilege tax code of the city. All privileges set forth therein are hereby taxed in 
accordance therewith. 
(Ord. No. 403, § 5, 1-11-1949) 


Sec. 13-2. - Same-City adjudged second class. 
    The city is hereby found and adjudged to be a municipality of the second class within the purview of 
1942 Mississippi Code, section 10240. 
(Ord. No. 494, § 1, 9-9-1958) 
State Law reference- For provision of state law classifying municipalities, see 1942 Miss. 
Code, § 9427. 


Sec. 13-3. - Same-Collection by city tax collector; penalty for not obtaining or renewing. 
(a)	The city tax collector shall collect, and all persons liable therefor shall pay to the city tax collector a 
privilege tax levied and imposed by this chapter before the beginning of the business for which a 
privilege tax is required to be paid, and annually thereafter. The city tax collector shall, upon payment 
of such privilege taxes, issue a privilege license evidencing such payment. 
(b)	All persons liable for the privilege taxes herein levied and imposed who shall fail to procure the 
license therefor before beginning the business for which a privilege tax is required, or who shall fail 
to renew during the month in which it is due, the license on a business for which he has heretofore 
procured a privilege license, shall, in each or either instance, be liable for the amount of the tax 
required for such business and fifty per centum thereof; and it shall be the duty of the city tax 
collector to collect the said tax and penalty, issue the license, and to endorse across the face of the 
license issued the words, "penalty collected." 
(Ord. No. 403, § 6, 1-11-1949) 
State Law reference- For provisions requiring license to be purchased from tax collector, 
imposing penalty for failure to obtain license or to renew same, see 1942 Miss. Code, § 9696-
206. 


Sec. 13-4. - Same-License to be posted in conspicuous place. 
    All privilege licenses issued shall be pasted or posted in a conspicuous place in the place of 
business of the person to whom such license has been issued, where the business carried on has a 
permanent location, and any location shall be considered permanent that is not changed or moved 
oftener than sixty days. 
(Code, 1922, § 179) 
Cross reference- For provisions requiring license of vehicle for hire to be posted, § 21-3; 
requirement that signs be posted on vehicles for hire, § 21-12. 
State Law reference- For requirement that license be posted in a conspicuous place, see 1942 
Miss. Code, § 9696-213. 


Sec. 13-5. - Same-More than one place of business. 
    If any person shall exercise or follow more than one trade or calling, or conduct more than one 
establishment, he shall pay the privilege tax for each. 
(Code, 1922, § 182) 
State Law reference- For provision imposing separate license taxes on each place of business, 
see 1942 Miss. Code, § 9696-209. 


Sec. 13-5.1. - Expiration of privilege licenses. 
    The city does hereby, by its adoption of this section, determine to issue privilege licenses pursuant to 
the provisions of Title 27, Chapter 17 of the Mississippi Code of 1972 which shall expire one (1) year from 
the date of issuance. 
(Ord. No. 837, § 1, 7-11-1988) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 837, adopted July 11, 1988, did not specifically amend the Code. 
Inclusion of § 1 of the ordinance as § 13-5.1 was at the discretion of the editor. 


Sec. 13-6. - Coin machines-License schedules for slot amusement machines; license; definitions, etc. 
(a)	Title. This ordinance shall be cited as "Slot Amusement Machine Tax Ordinance." [Ord. No. 615, 7-7-
1970] 
(b)	Definitions. The words, terms, and phrases, when used in this ordinance, shall have the meaning 
ascribed to them herein. 
(1)	"Slot amusement machine" or "machine" means any mechanical device or contrivance which is 
operated, played, worked, manipulated, or used by inserting or depositing any coin, slug, token, 
or thing of value in which may be seen any picture or heard any music, or wherein any game 
may be played, or any form of diversion had. 
(2)	"Person" means and includes any individual, firm, partnership, joint venture, association, 
corporation, estate, trust, or other group or combination acting as a unit and includes the plural 
as well as the singular in number. 
(c)	Tax levied. There is hereby levied and imposed one-half (1/2) of the hereinafter described tax as 
authorized by House Bill 943, Regular Session, 1970 Mississippi Legislature, upon each person 
engaging in the business of owning or placing on location for the purpose of operation any slot 
amusement machine, annual license taxes according to the following schedule: 
(1)	For each machine wherein may be seen any picture or heard any music, a license tax for each 
such machine the sum of eighteen dollars ($18.00). 
(2)	For each machine (not elsewhere specifically taxed in this section) wherein or whereby any 
game may be played or any form of diversion had, a license tax for each such machine the sum 
of thirty dollars ($30.00). 
(3)	For each machine (not elsewhere specifically taxed in this section) wherein or by means of 
which children may obtain a ride upon a "hobby horse" or the figure of any animal, or upon the 
figure of a boat, airplane, rocket, or other such machine, a license tax of twelve dollars ($12.00) 
for each machine. 
(d)	License. Every person engaged in the business of owning or placing on location for the purpose of 
operation any slot amusement machine shall first, before commencing the same, apply for, pay for 
and procure from the city tax collector a privilege license authorizing him to engage in the business 
or exercise the privilege specified therein. Such license, or sticker evidencing same, issued by the 
city tax collector shall be securely affixed or attached to the machine to which it applies in such 
manner as to be readily visible. The absence of the proper license or sticker affixed to a machine 
shall be prima facie evidence of failure to pay the tax levied for operation of the machine. 
It shall also be unlawful for any owner, or lessee, of any premises, building or appurtenances thereto, 
boat, ship, airplane, vehicle, structure, automobile or any other property or part thereof, to permit the 
exhibition, operation, possession or use of any such machine, device, or equipment, without such license 
procured for the place in or upon which such machine is operated. 
(Ord. No. 403, § 1, 1-11-1949; Ord. No. 615, § 1, 7-7-1970) 
Amendment note- Ord. No. 615, § 1, amended § 13-6 to read as set out. Due to the nature of 
the subject matter a detailed analysis of the amendment is not included. 
Cross reference- For duty of officers with respect to gambling devices, § 14-16. 
State Law reference- For municipal authority to impose a privilege tax upon amusement 
devices, see 1942 Miss. Code, § 9418. 


Sec. 13-7. - Same-Term of license required by section 13-6; penalties; exemptions, etc. 
(a)	Term of license. The tax levied in section 13-6 upon each person engaged in the business of owning 
or placing on location for the purpose of operation any slot amusement machine shall be due and 
payable annually on January 1, and all licenses issued under the provisions of this ordinance shall 
expire annually on December 31. A license may be renewed without penalty during the month of 
January. The amount of the license tax to be paid for a period of less than twelve (12) months shall 
be that proportionate amount of the annual license tax that the number of months, or fractional part 
thereof, remaining until January 1 next bears to twelve (12) months. 
The license shall entitle the owner or the person placing the machine on location for the purpose of 
operation to operate a machine of the type specified until December 31 next. If a machine for which a 
license has been issued should be destroyed or traded, the privilege of operation for the remaining time 
covered by the license may be transferred to another machine of the same type by procedure to be 
specified by the tax collector. 
When ownership of a machine upon which a valid license is attached is transferred to another person, no 
additional tax shall be required. 
No refund shall be allowed for failure or inability to exercise the privilege granted after the license has 
been issued. 
(b)	Penalties. Any person engaged in the business of owning or placing on location for the purpose of 
operation any slot amusement machine without the payment of the tax imposed herein shall be liable 
for the amount of the tax and fifty per cent (50%) of the amount of the tax as penalty. 
Any person who has paid the tax for the operation of a machine, but who has failed to affix the license to 
the machine shall also be liable for fifty per cent (50%) of the amount of the tax as penalty. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to place on location any machine without paying the tax herein levied. 
(c)	Exemptions. This ordinance shall not apply to any machine operated for gambling purposes, to any 
machine kept at a regular place of business of distributors or manufacturers for sale or lease without 
being operated, or to any pool table operated in a place of business commonly known as a pool hall 
or billiard parlor when the gross income from the operation of such pool table is taxable under the 
Mississippi Sales Tax Law. 
(d)	License tax in addition to other taxes. The license tax levied by this ordinance shall be in addition to 
all other taxes levied by law. 
(e)	Administration and enforcement. All of the general provisions of Chapter 137, Laws of 1944 (Section 
9696-01 et seq.), insofar as they apply to municipalities, shall apply to and are hereby adopted as 
the means by which the provisions of this ordinance may be enforced and the taxes and penalties 
imposed may be collected. 
(f)	Records to be kept. It shall be the duty of every person taxable under this ordinance to keep and 
preserve for a period of three (3) years adequate records showing the location on which each 
machine is placed for the purpose of operation, type of machine and the size coin required to 
operate the machine one (1) time. 
(Ord. No. 403, § 1, 1-11-1949; Ord. No. 615, § 2, 7-7-1970) 
Amendment note- Ord. No. 615, § 2, amended § 13-7 to read as set out. Formerly said section 
set out the term of license required by former § 13-6 and provided for certain supplemental 
licenses. 
State Law reference- For provision of state law limiting license term to one year, see 1942 
Miss. Code, § 9422. 


Sec. 13-8. - Same-License schedules for weighing, vending machines. 
(a)	Tax imposed. There shall be levied and imposed an annual privilege tax upon each person owning 
or operating any automatic weighing machine, any automatic vending machine or device for 
dispensing or selling postage stamps, any automatic vending machine or device for dispensing or 
selling cigarettes, and automatic machines selling and vending merchandise for the sale of which 
any tax has been paid by the owner, which service, stamps, or merchandise is obtained by 
depositing therein any token, coin or coins, according to the following schedules: 
(1)

(b)	Operation without license prohibited; exception. It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, possess, 
use or exhibit for gain, or to operate, or to permit to be operated, or allow to be kept, used, 
possessed or operated for gain, such coin, slot, or token operated machine or device, contrivance or 
equipment, unless a license has been first procured and attached as set forth under the provisions of 
this section. Nothing herein shall apply to any such machine when such machine is kept in a regular 
place of business of distributors or manufacturers without being operated, for sale or lease only. 
Nothing herein shall be construed as authorizing or legalizing such manufacturers or any other 
person to operate for gain such machines without a license, nor to have in their possession or offer 
for sale gambling devices. 
(c)	License required for premises. It shall also be unlawful for any owner, or lessee, of any premises, 
building or appurtenances thereto, boat, ship, airplane, vehicle, structure, automobile or any other 
property or part thereof, to permit the exhibition, operation, possession or use of any such machine, 
device or equipment, without such license attached thereto. 
(Ord. No. 351, § 3, 4-1-1941) 
State Law reference- For municipal authority to tax vending devices, see 1942 Miss. Code, § 
9426-02; for schedule of such taxes, § 9426-01. 


Sec. 13-9. - Same-Term of license for weighing, vending machines; changing mechanism prohibited. 
    A license on the ownership or operation of weighing or vending machines shall be for a period of one 
year, and shall be renewed for another annual period upon the payment of the tax hereinabove levied and 
imposed and upon compliance with the terms and conditions prescribed for such license. No owner, 
lessee or other person shall alter or otherwise change the mechanism or method of operation of any coin 
or token operated vending or weighing device in any manner after a license shall have been issued 
therefor. 
(Ord. No. 351, § 3, 4-1-1941) 


Sec. 13-10. - Same-Exemptions from tax imposed under section 13-8. 
    No tax shall be imposed under the terms of section 13-8 upon any machine or machines when said 
machine or machines are owned and operated by the owner of a store when such machines are stationed 
in said store, and when the owner of said store has paid the proper privilege tax required of him under the 
section of the regular privilege tax law imposing privilege taxes on stores; nor shall the tax imposed by 
section 13-8 apply to persons operating said machines for the sale of articles to their own employees, 
exclusively, without profit where no privilege tax has been paid for operating a store; provided further, that 
nothing contained herein shall be construed to permit the licensing of any gambling machine or device. 
(Ord. No. 373, § 2, 5-4-1946; Ord. No. 403, § 1, 1-11-1949; Ord. No. 615, § 3, 7-7-1970) 
Amendment note- Ord. No. 615, § 3, amended § 13-10 to read as set out. Formerly said 
section provided for exemptions from §§ 13-6 and 13-8. 
State Law reference- For municipal authority to exempt certain activities from tax, see 1942 
Miss. Code, §§ 9421, 9426-03. 


Sec. 13-11. - Same-Seizure of machine. 
    The chief of police of the city or any lawful officer directed by him so to do, shall have full and 
complete authority, without order of any court, to seize any coin or token operated device possessed, 
leased, used or operated for which no license has been obtained, or for which the license has been 
revoked as provided in this chapter, or bearing a fictitious or counterfeit license, and the same shall be 
held until, on appropriate proceedings, there shall be an order of court for the disposal of said device or 
machine. The attaching of any fictitious or counterfeit license to any machine shall be a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 351, §§ 1-4, 4-1-1941; Ord. No. 373, § 2, 5-21-1946) 


Sec. 13-12. - Light wine and beer-Definitions. 
    When used herein the words and terms "person," "consumer," "retailer," "wholesaler," "sale," "light 
wines or beer," and "distributor," shall have the definitions as defined and described in 1942 Mississippi 
Code, Section 10237, which said definitions, as contained in said section of said act, are hereby adopted 
for the purposes of sections 13-13 through 13-16 hereof. 
(Ord. No. 290, § 1, 3-6-1934) 
Editor's note- It should be noted that the state law provisions referenced in § 13-12 are now 
reflected in Titles 27 and 67 of the 1972 Code. 
Cross reference- Prohibition against sale of spirituous or vinous liquors, § 14-4; dealing with 
minors regulated, § 14-41. 


Sec. 13-13. - Same-Schedule of privilege taxes. 
    There is hereby imposed, levied and assessed, to be collected and paid to the tax collector of the 
city, privilege taxes on persons engaged in the sale or distribution of light wines or beer for the privilege of 
engaging in or continuing in such business in accordance with the following schedule, to-wit:

Sec. 13-14. - Same-Payment conditional to doing business; term of license. 
    The payment of privilege taxes are required before a person may engage in any of the businesses 
taxed in section 13-13 and the said license issued upon the payment thereof shall authorize the person 
paying the same to engage in said business for a period of twelve (12) months from the date thereof, and 
shall not be transferable. 
(Ord. No. 290, § 6, 3-6-1964) 


Sec. 13-15. - Same-State acts incorporated by reference. 
    All of the provisions of 1942 Mississippi Code, Sections 10237 through 10265, inclusive, which are 
applicable and adapted to the city are incorporated herein and adopted as a part hereof, as fully as if the 
same were set forth at length. 
(Ord. No. 290, § 5, 3-6-1934) 
Editor's note- It should be noted that the state law provisions referenced in § 13-15 are not 
reflected in Titles 27 and 67 of the 1972 Code. 


Sec. 13-16. - Same-Compliance with state law required. 
    No privilege or license required by section 13-13 shall issue to any person unless satisfactory 
evidence is furnished to the tax collector of the city that such person has complied with the requirements 
of state law, and if the permit required by state law is at any time revoked, the said revocation shall 
operate as a cancellation and forfeiture of the rights of the person holding a privilege tax under the terms 
hereof. 
(Ord. No. 290, § 6, 3-6-1934) 


Sec. 13-17. - Tobacco, cigarettes-Sale at wholesale. 
    There is hereby levied and imposed an annual privilege tax of fifty dollars ($50.00) upon each person 
in the business of distributing or selling at wholesale cigarettes or smoking tobacco; provided, however, 
that the warehouse or wholesale business be located in the city. 
(Ord. No. 365, § 3, 9-14-1944) 


Sec. 13-18. - Same-Sale at retail. 
    There is hereby levied and imposed an annual privilege tax of five dollars ($5.00) upon each person 
selling cigarettes or smoking tobacco at retail where the business is located in the city; provided that this 
tax shall be paid for each place of business operated by such retailers. 
(Ord. No. 365, § 4, 9-14-1944) 


Chapter 13A - MECHANICAL CODE[1]

the editors have herein redesignated § 13A-1 of new Ch. 13A to preserve the alphabetical sequence of 
this Code. 


Sec. 13A-1. - International Mechanical Code, 2012 edition.

Mechanical Code Section 101.2.1, 2012 Edition), as published by the International Code Council, be

the design, construction, quality of materials, erection, installation, alteration, repair, location, 
relocation, replacement, addition to, use or maintenance of mechanical systems as herein provided; 
providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefor; and each and all of the 
regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said Mechanical Code on file in the office 
of the City Clerk of the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a 
part hereof, as if fully set out in this section, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if 
any, prescribed in subsection (b) of this section.

Chapter 14 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Terms of general penalty imposed for violation of Code, § 1-8. 


ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 


Sec. 14-1. - Advertising-Posting on poles, trees, public structures; distributing in public way. 
(a)	Prohibited. No person shall post or cause to be posted any poster, handbill, paper or device 
calculated to attract the attention of the public, to any light post, public utility poles or shade trees, or 
upon any public structure or building, except as may be provided by law; nor shall any person 
deposit or cause to be deposited on any of the streets, sidewalks or alleys, or upon any public 
premises any poster, handbill, paper or device calculated to attract the attention of the public. The 
prohibitions of this section shall not apply to any legal notice required by law to be posted. 
(b)	Penalties. A violation of the provisions hereof shall be a misdemeanor, and shall be punished as 
follows: For the first offense, a fine of not more than twenty-five dollars ($25.00); for the second 
offense, a fine of not more than fifty dollars ($50.00); and for the third and subsequent offenses, a 
fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or imprisonment in the city jail not more than ten 
(10) days, or both. 
(Ord. No. 466, § 1, 3-8-1955; Ord. No. 529, §§ 7, 11, 5-28-1962) 
Cross reference- Prohibition against posting advertising on utility poles, guy wires, § 7-52. 


Sec. 14-2. - Same-Billboards prohibited on public property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or cause to be erected, locate or cause to be located, any 
billboards or sign boards for the posting of bills or the painting of signs along any of the streets or 
sidewalks in the city, unless such billboards or sign boards are erected or located upon private property. 
The erection or location of such billboard or sign board, otherwise than above provided, or the 
maintaining of any billboard or sign board erected or located otherwise than as above provided, shall be a 
misdemeanor, and the person erecting or causing to be erected, locating or causing to be located, or 
maintaining a sign board or billboard otherwise than as above provided shall be deemed guilty of a 
misdemeanor, and shall be punished by a fine of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) and costs. 
(Code 1922, §§ 30, 31) 


Sec. 14-3. - Air rifles, firing or permitting firing prohibited. 
(a)	Firing prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to fire or discharge within the city any air rifle, BB 
gun, or any like or similar contrivance which propels or discharges by means of compressed air any 
pellet, dart, bullet or similar object. 
(b)	Unlawful to permit firing by minor. It shall be unlawful for any parent of a minor, or any other person 
standing in loco parentis to any minor, knowingly to permit such minor to discharge or fire within the 
city any air rifle, BB gun, or any like or similar contrivance which propels or discharges by means of 
compressed air any pellet, dart, bullet or similar object. 
(c)	Penalty for violation. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a 
misdemeanor and upon conviction, shall be fined not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) and 
costs. 
(Ord. No. 458, §§ 1-3, 3-23-1954) 


Sec. 14-4. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Former § 14-4, which prohibited the sale, possession, etc., of intoxicating 
liquors and derived from Ord. No. 300, § 1, enacted Oct. 30, 1934, has been deleted in light of 
the enactment of provisions regulating the sale and possession thereof. See § 14-41 et seq. 


Sec. 14-5. - Reserved. 


Sec. 14-6. - Assault, battery. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commit an assault or an assault and battery upon another within 
the city. 
(Code 1922, §§ 131, 141; Ord. No. 647, § 1, 9-11-1972) 


Sec. 14-7. - Begging, soliciting; exception; penalty. 
(a)	Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit alms for himself within the city. This section 
shall also apply to the vending and sale of shoe strings, pencils and other merchandise commonly 
sold by beggars. 
(b)	Soliciting for out-of-state benevolent organizations. It shall be unlawful to solicit on the streets, 
sidewalks, alleys and ways, or from house to house in the city, for philanthropic or benevolent 
purposes for institutions located outside of the State of Mississippi. 
(c)	Local organizations. It shall be lawful only for local organizations and charities to solicit funds for their 
several organizations. However, if any person shall make application to any local organization for 
permission to seek alms and the said charitable organization, after a thorough investigation reports 
and recommends to the board of mayor and commissioners the issuance of a permit, then the mayor 
may in his discretion grant a permit to such person to solicit alms or have someone solicit alms for 
him, or may permit him to sell articles on the street. 
(Ord. No. 258, §§ 1-4, 11-19-1929; Ord. No. 553, §§ 1, 2, 7-24-1963; Ord. No. 648, § 1, 9-11-
1972) 
Cross reference- For section defining, punishing vagrancy, § 14-39. 
State Law reference- Provisions regarding vagrancy, 1942 Miss. Code § 2666 et seq. 


Sec. 14-7.1. - Carnivals. 
(a)	Permit required; application. No firm, person or corporation shall operate within the corporate limits 
of the City of Clarksdale, any circuses, carnivals, midways, carnival and concessions, or carnival 
amusement-type rides (hereinafter "amusement") without first having made application to and 
received permission to do so in accordance with the conditions and limitations as set out in this 
section. Said application shall be filed at least thirty (30) days prior to the proposed first date of 
operation. 
(b)	Application; required information. The applicant for such permission shall file an application in writing 
with the city clerk in duplicate, which application shall indicate clearly: 
(1)	The name of the person, firm or corporation which will operate such amusement. 
(2)	The location of the principal place of business of such person, firm or corporation. 
(3)	The names and addresses of the officers of such firm or corporation. 
(4)	The names and addresses of the person, firm or corporation sponsoring the applicant. 
(5)	The length of time the amusement is to remain in operation, which shall not exceed six (6) days. 
(6)	The hours of the day or night during which the amusement will be open and operating, which 
hours shall be confined to the hours of 10:00 a.m. to 12:00 midnight daily. 
(7)	That provisions have been made for sanitary facilities for persons using the premises on which 
the amusement is to be erected or maintained, and description of such facilities. 
(8)	A description of the premises where such amusement is to be located, the name and address of 
the owner of record of such premises, and the consent of said owner in writing consenting to the 
location of the amusement on such premises. Said amusement shall in no event be located on 
property owned, leased or controlled by the City of Clarksdale. The board of mayor and 
commissioners shall have the right of approval of the premises where such amusement is to be 
located, and no permit shall issue hereunder until such approval is granted. Should the board 
not approve such premises, no permit shall be granted. 
(9)	Such other relevant information as the chief of police and fire inspector of the city may require. 
(c)	Provision of special police and/or fire officers; cost to be borne by applicant. The applicant shall 
provide such special police and/or fire officers as the chief of police and the fire inspector may deem 
necessary for the control of crowds and traffic as may be required for the public safety; and the cost 
of such special officers is to be borne by the applicant. 
(d)	Insurance. The applicant shall furnish evidence that a public liability insurance policy in amounts of 
not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for one person, and one million dollars 
($1,000,000.00) for any one accident, shall be in force and effect at the time such amusement is to 
be operated and patronized by the public. 
(e)	Bond. The applicant shall deposit with the city clerk a cash bond in the sum of one thousand five 
hundred dollars ($1,500.00), conditioned upon saving harmless the City of Clarksdale for any and all 
liabilities or causes of action which might arise by virtue of the granting of a permit to the applicant, 
and conditioned further that no damage will be done to the streets, sewers, trees or adjoining 
property and that no dirt, paper, litter or other debris will be permitted to remain upon the streets or 
upon any private property by such applicant. Such cash bond shall be returned to the applicant upon 
certification by the chief of police of the city, that all conditions of this section have been complied 
with. 
(f)	Fees. The applicant shall pay to the city clerk such fee or fees as may be required by law for the 
privilege of operating said amusement. 
(g)	Prohibited activities. No lewd, lascivious, immoral or unlawful activities shall be conducted upon the 
applicant's premises, and no nudity in any form shall be allowed in connection with the applicant's 
operation of such amusement. 
(h)	Issuance of permit. If the city clerk finds that the provisions of paragraphs (a) through (g) have been 
or will be fully complied with by the applicant, he shall issue a permit thereto upon such reasonable 
terms and conditions as he, the chief of police, the fire inspector, and the board of mayor and 
commissioners may deem necessary for the safety of persons and property. 
(i)	Exceptions. The provisions of this section shall not apply to small indoor circuses, or to local fairs, 
bazaars, and similar activities which are sponsored, constructed, operated, and controlled by 
religious, civic, or fraternal organizations solely for charitable purposes. 
(j)	Penalty for violation; revocation of permit. Any violation of this section shall subject the violators to a 
fine not exceeding three hundred dollars ($300.00) for each day of violation, or imprisonment for not 
more than ninety (90) days, or both, for each day of violation of the same; and to immediate 
revocation of any permit issued hereunder. 
(k)	Findings of fact. All findings of fact as made by the board of mayor and commissioners shall be final 
and binding on the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 584, §§ 1-3, 9-20-1965; Ord. No. 736, § 1, 4-30-1979; Ord. No. 738, §§ 1, 2, 8-6-
1979; Ord. No. 739, §§ 1-3, 9-17-1979; Ord. No. 780, § 1, 10-25-1982) 


Sec. 14-8. - Circus parades; permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner, manager, agent or employee of any circus or minstrel show to 
parade over the streets of the city, or any part thereof, with wagons, horses or animals, or for the 
performers of said circus or show to take part in such parade without first obtaining from the mayor and 
board of commissioners of the city a permit to conduct such parade. 
(Ord. No. 207, 9-25-1923) 


Sec. 14-8.1. - Communication media; permit required to report from city-owned property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, or persons, to make voice or other sound recordings or 
transmissions of voice or other sounds by radio, or other sound media, or to take photographs, still 
pictures, motion pictures or television pictures within any buildings belonging to the City of Clarksdale, 
Mississippi, or on any other properties belonging to said city, without the prior permission of the board of 
mayor and commissioners of the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi. 
(Ord. No. 550, §§ 1, 2, 6-18-1963; Ord. No. 649, § 1, 9-11-1972) 


Sec. 14-9. - Deadly weapons-Carrying concealed. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person found within the city, not being a peace officer or deputy in the 
discharge of his duties, to carry concealed in whole or in part a bowie knife, pistol, brass or metallic 
knucks, slingshot or other deadly weapons of like kind or description. 
(Code 1922, § 142) 
State Law reference- For similar state law prohibition, see 1942 Miss. Code, § 2079. 


Sec. 14-9.1. - Same-Bows and arrows. 
(a)	Prohibited; exception. It shall be unlawful for any person to shoot a target or hunting types of bows 
and arrows within the city, except in areas designated by the chief of police of said city and 
supervised by the park commission or other civic agency. 
(b)	Applicability. This section shall not apply to bows and arrows where the arrow has a rubber suction 
tip. 
(c)	Penalty. Any violation of this section shall subject the violator to a fine of not more than twenty-five 
dollars ($25.00). 
(Ord. No. 540, §§ 1-3, 9-5-1962) 
Editor's note- Sec. 14-9.1 is derived from Ord. No. 540, §§ 1-3. Said ordinance not being 
specifically amendatory of this Code, the manner of codification has been at the discretion of the 
editors. 


Sec. 14-10. - Same-Exhibit of. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person having or carrying any device, knife, swords, sword cane, or other 
deadly weapons, within the corporate limits and in the presence of three (3) or more persons to exhibit 
the same in a rude, angry or threatening manner, and not in necessary self-defense, or to use the same 
in any fight or quarrel. 
(Code 1922, § 132) 


Sec. 14-11. - Same-Duty of physician, hospital to report wounds. 
(a)	All physicians and surgeons shall report to the police department of the city, all cases of gunshot 
wounds and severe knife wounds treated by such physicians and surgeons within the city. All 
hospitals, whether public or private, located within the city shall likewise report to the police 
department of the city the entrance of patients suffering from gunshot wounds or severe knife 
wounds. 
(b)	The reports provided for in subsection (a) hereof shall be made immediately by telephone or in 
writing and shall set forth the name, age, sex and color of the person so injured and his or her 
present location, and shall be delivered to the police department either in person or by letter 
immediately after the case comes to the knowledge of such physician, surgeon or hospital. 
(Ord. No. 436, §§ 1, 2, 3-25-1952) 


Sec. 14-12. - Discharging firearms. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person within the city, to discharge any pistol, gun or other firearm. 
(Code 1922, § 139) 
Cross reference- For provisions requiring reports regarding vehicles struck by bullets, § 19-12. 
State Law reference- For provisions prohibiting use or exhibition of deadly weapons 
generally, see 1942 Miss. Code, § 2086. 


Sec. 14-13. - Disturbing the peace. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or persons within the city wilfully to disturb the peace and quiet of 
said city by loud or unusual noises, by yelling, swearing, using obscene language or conversation or by 
quarreling, challenging or fighting. 
(Code 1922, § 138; Ord. No. 650, § 1, 9-11-1972) 
State Law reference- For provisions penalizing offensive conduct, see 1942 Miss. Code, § 
2088; for abusive language, § 2089; for breach or threatened breach of the peace in a public 
place, § 2090.5; for profanity in a public place, § 2291. 


Sec. 14-14. - Drunkenness, disorderly conduct. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to be drunk or disorderly upon any of the lots or streets, alleys or 
ways within the city. 
(Code 1922, § 137; Ord. No. 651, § 1, 9-11-1972) 


Sec. 14-15. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 750, enacted March 3, 1980, repealed former § 14-15, 
which pertained to fireworks and derived from Ord. No. 477, §§ 1-3, enacted Nov. 13, 1956. 


Sec. 14-16. - Gambling; duty of officers. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police and the policemen of the city to keep themselves as much as 
possible advised of any gambling house being established or operated within the city and to take 
immediate steps for the suppression of same and the arrest of all parties concerned therein, and a failure 
to comply with this section shall be punished by removal from office upon conviction by the board of 
mayor and commissioners. 
(Code, 1922, § 129) 
Cross reference- For prohibition against operation of gambling machines, § 18-6, § 13-8. 
State Law reference- For provision of state law punishing certain officers for permitting 
gambling, see 1942 Miss. Code, § 2191. 


Sec. 14-16.1. - Junkyards, automobile graveyards, etc.; fencing requirements. 
(a)	Owners responsibility. All the owners of property on which junk, automobile bodies, rubbish or other 
like unsightly materials and objects are located are required within sixty (60) days from and after 
October 18, 1965, to construct a fence of sturdy construction of either chain link or wood sufficient to 
contain said junk, automobile bodies, rubbish or other like unsightly materials and objects within said 
owner's premises, and properly maintain the same. 
(b)	Specifications and approval. The minimum fence height shall be six (6) feet, with three strands of 
barb wire projecting toward the outside at the top. All fence posts will be set in a minimum of twenty-
four (24) inches of concrete at least twelve (12) inches in diameter. Gates will be kept locked at all 
times except when necessary to be opened. Fences shall be constructed at least six (6) inches from 
the property line so that the overhanging barb wire will not project across the adjacent property. All 
fences shall be subject to the approval or disapproval of the engineer of the City of Clarksdale, 
Mississippi, and if disapproved by him appeal may be made to the board of mayor and 
commissioners of the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi. 
(c)	Exception. The foregoing provisions of this section shall not be applicable to the owner of any 
existing fence which meets with the approval of the board of mayor and commissioners of the City of 
Clarksdale, Mississippi, except insofar as it applies to maintenance. 
(d)	Violation; penalty. Any violation of this section shall subject the violators to a fine not exceeding one 
hundred ($100) dollars for each day of violation. 
(Ord. No. 585, §§ 1, 2, 10-18-1965) 
Editor's note- Section 14-16.1 is derived from Ord. No. 585 which being nonamendatory of 
this Code has been codified as said section at the editor's discretion. 
Cross reference- For provision defining the keeping and maintaining of junk and unsightly 
material on vacant lots as a nuisance, § 14-25(9). 


Sec. 14-17. - Loitering-Public places of business. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to frequent any public place of business and loaf around the same, 
having no business therein, or to congregate into crowds of three or more at such places, having no 
business therein, unless invited by the proprietor to be there and remain in such place. 
(Code, 1922, § 145) 
Cross reference- For provision defining, punishing vagrants, § 14-39. 
State Law reference- For provision of state law defining tramps, see 1942 Miss. Code, § 2393; 
punishing tramps, § 2394; defining vagrants, § 2666; requiring arrest of vagrants, § 2667. 


Sec. 14-18. - Same-Streets, alleys after midnight. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to be found upon the streets, alleys or about the premises of any 
person in the city after the hour of midnight, who cannot give a satisfactory account of his business and 
reason for his presence at such place. 
(Code, 1922, § 145) 


Sec. 14-19. - Same-Property of Illinois Central Railroad Company. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to frequent the public depot grounds of the Illinois Central Railroad 
Company in the city, and to loaf around said premises at and during the arrival and departure of 
passenger trains at said depot, unless such person has business there, is there to meet passengers or to 
transact business with the express company or the railroad company, or to take passage upon a train 
then due. Any person so offending shall be deemed guilty of loitering. 
(Code, 1922, § 145) 


Sec. 14-20. - Misdemeanors under state law. 
    All offenses under the penal laws of the State of Mississippi and all violations of the laws of the State 
of Mississippi which are and amount to misdemeanors when committed within the city shall be offenses 
against the city, and all persons committing any of said offenses within the city shall be deemed guilty of 
violating the ordinances of the city and upon conviction thereof and therefor by the police justice shall be 
punished as prescribed by the general penalty punishing for violations of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 230, § 1, 5-22-1928) 
Note- See state law reference at beginning of chapter. 


Sec. 14-21. - Moving household goods; information required; records; violation. 
(a)	Correct name to be given. It shall be unlawful for any person causing household goods or personal 
effects to be moved as herein set forth to give to the owner, driver or operator of any vehicle used in 
hauling said property a fictitious name, or to refuse to give the correct name of the owner or person 
in possession of such property. 
(b)	Movers for hire to make report. It shall be the duty of all persons owning or operating any moving 
van, furniture van, furniture car, transfer wagon, express wagon or other vehicle for hire, who shall 
haul or cause to be hauled or moved, household goods or personal effects of any person in the city 
who is changing the place of his or her abode, to make a report thereof to the chief of police, which 
report shall be made within one day thereafter on a blank form, hereinafter described. 
(c)	Owners, operators of vehicles to make report. It shall be the duty of all persons owning or operating 
any kind of vehicle, whether for hire or not, who shall haul or cause to be hauled therein any 
household goods or personal effects of any person in the city who is changing his or her place of 
abode, whether to another residence in the city or to a point without the city, to make a report thereof 
to the chief of police as provided in subsection (b). 
(d)	Form of report. The form or blank to be given or filled in by the persons embraced in subsections (b) 
and (c) above shall be as follows: 
Name of owner or party in possession ____________________________ 
Moved from ______________________________________________________ 
Moved to ________________________________________________________ 
Date moved ______________________________________________________ 
_________________________ 
Owner of Vehicle 
_________________________ 
Driver of Vehicle. 
Date filed with chief of police ________________________________. 
(e)	Record of reports. It shall be the duty of the chief of police to keep an alphabetically arranged record 
of such reports and certificates, which shall be open to inspection at all reasonable hours, said 
record to be kept at police headquarters. 
(f)	Violation. It shall be a misdemeanor for the owner or possessor of any such property as herein 
described or for the driver or owner of any vehicle used in transporting such goods to violate any 
provision of this section. 
(Ord. No. 328, §§ 1-6, 2-1-1938) 
Cross reference- For provision that operator of vehicle for hire forfeits license for violation of 
criminal ordinances, § 21-5. 


Sec. 14-22. - Noises and disturbances-In general; exceptions, permit; penalty. 
(a)	Unreasonable noises. The creating of any unreasonably loud, disturbing and unnecessary noise 
within the city is a public nuisance and shall be prohibited. 
(b)	Detrimental to life, health. Noise of such character, intensity or duration as to be detrimental to the 
life or health of any individual, or in disturbance of the public peace and welfare shall be prohibited. 
(c)	Prohibited disturbances enumerated. The following acts, among others, are declared to be loud, 
disturbing and unnecessary noises and noises in violation of this section, but this enumeration shall 
not be deemed to be exclusive: 
(1)	The sounding of any horn or signal device on any automobile, motorcycle, bus, streetcar or 
other vehicle while not in motion, except as a danger signal if another vehicle is approaching 
apparently out of control, or if in motion only as a danger signal after or as brakes are being 
applied and deceleration of the vehicle is intended; the creation by means of any such signal 
device of any unreasonably loud or harsh sound; and the sounding of such device for an 
unnecessary and unreasonable period of time. 
(2)	The playing of any radio, phonograph or musical instrument in such manner or with such 
volume, particularly during the hours between 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., as to annoy or disturb 
the quiet, comfort or repose of persons in any office, hospital, dwelling, hotel or any other type 
of residence, or of any persons in the vicinity. 
(3)	Yelling, shouting, hooting, whistling or singing on the public street, particularly between the 
hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. or at any time or place so as to annoy or disturb the quiet, 
comfort or repose of any persons in any hospital, dwelling, hotel or any other type of residence, 
or of any person in the vicinity. 
(4)	The keeping of any animal, bird or fowl which by causing frequent or long continued noise shall 
disturb the comfort or repose of any person in the vicinity. 
(5)	The use of any automobile, motorcycle, streetcar or vehicle so out of repair, so loaded or in 
such manner as to cause loud and unnecessary grating, grinding, rattling or other noise. 
(6)	The blowing of any steam whistle attached to any stationary boiler, except to give notice of the 
time to begin or stop work or as a warning of fire or danger, or upon request of proper city 
authorities. 
(7)	The discharge into the open air of the exhaust of any steam engine, stationary internal 
combustion engine, motor vehicle or motorboat engine except through a muffler or other device 
which will effectively prevent loud or explosive noises therefrom. 
(8)	The erection (including excavation), demolition, alteration or repair of any building in any 
residential district or section or the excavation of streets and highways in any residential district 
or section, other than between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. on weekdays, except in 
case of urgent necessity in the interest of public health and safety, and then only with a permit 
from the building inspector, which permit may be granted for a period not to exceed thirty days 
while the emergency continues. If the building inspector should determine that the public health 
and safety will not be impaired by the erection, demolition, alteration or repair of any building or 
the excavation of streets and highways between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. and if he 
shall further determine that loss or inconvenience would result to any party in interest, he may 
grant permission for such work to be done within the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. upon 
application being made at the time the permit for the work is awarded or during the progress of 
the work. 
(9)	The creation of any excessive noise on any street adjacent to any hospital, school, institution of 
learning, church or court while the same are in session, which unreasonably interferes with the 
workings or sessions thereof. 
(10)	The creation of a loud and excessive noise in connection with loading or unloading any vehicle 
or the opening or destruction of bales, boxes, crates and containers. 
(11)	The use of any drum, loud-speaker or other instrument or device for the purpose of attracting 
attention by creation of noise to any performance, show or sale or display of merchandise. 
(12)	The use of mechanical loud-speakers or amplifiers on trucks or other moving or standing 
vehicles for advertising or other purposes. 
(d)	Exceptions to enumerated disturbances. The terms or prohibitions set forth in subsection (c) hereof 
shall not apply to or be enforced in the following instances: 
(1)	Operation of any vehicle of the city while engaged upon necessary public business. 
(2)	Excavations or repairs of bridges, streets or highways by or on behalf of the city, the county or 
the state, during the night season when the public welfare and convenience render it impossible 
to perform such work during the day. 
(3)	The reasonable use of amplifiers or loud-speakers in the course of public addresses which are 
noncommercial in character. 
(Ord. No. 413, §§ 1-5, 8-30-1949; Ord. No. 652, § 1, 9-11-1972) 
Cross reference- For provision regulating speed, operation of vehicles carrying loudspeakers, 
§ 19-47. 
State Law reference- For provision of state law applicable to disturbances caused by use of 
explosives, loud noise or tumultuous or offensive conduct, see 1942 Miss. Code, § 2088; to 
regulate regarding nuisances, § 3374-116. 


Sec. 14-23. - Same-Musical instruments, devices; exceptions; permit required; penalties. 
(a)	Loudspeakers prohibited. It shall be a public nuisance and unlawful for any person between the 
hours of 12:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. to play or cause to be played in any commercial establishment or 
any place or building wherein business of any kind is conducted any music instrument equipped with 
a loudspeaker or any other device whereby the sounds of such instrument or instruments are 
projected and broadcast beyond the walls of the building or structure wherein such business is 
conducted. 
(b)	Playing musical instruments prohibited. It shall be a public nuisance and unlawful for any person 
between the hours of 12:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. to play or cause to be played any music instrument 
or instruments with such loudness or tone as to disturb other persons in the neighborhood or vicinity 
and within hearing who might be desirous of obtaining sleep or rest. 
(c)	Exceptions; permission required. The provisions of this section shall not apply to temporary 
operation of places of amusement such as circuses, fairs, musical concerts, etc., provided that 
permission to operate a musical instrument or instruments or play therein shall be obtained from the 
chief of police. The chief of police shall be charged with the duty of investigating the situation and of 
withholding license or permission in the event that in his judgment the playing of musical instruments 
in the manner in which they are proposed to be played will unreasonably disturb those in the vicinity 
and neighborhood desiring to obtain rest, sleep or quiet. 
(Ord. No. 334, §§ 1-4, 7-5-1938; Ord. No. 653, § 1, 9-11-1972) 
Note- See state law reference to preceding section. 


Sec. 14-24. - Same-Offensive language or conduct. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, within the city, to suffer screaming, the using of obscene 
language, fighting, quarreling, singing, dancing or any other unusual noise in his or her house or 
enclosures in such manner as to disturb the neighborhood or persons passing along the streets. 
(Code 1922, § 130; Ord. No. 654, § 1, 9-11-1972) 
State Law reference- For provisions regarding abusive language, see 1942 Miss. Code, §§ 
2089, 2090.5, 2291. 


Sec. 14-25. - Nuisances-Defined. 
    The following matters, things, places and occupations are hereby declared to be public nuisances 
when maintained, carried on or suffered or permitted to be maintained or carried on within the city: 
(a)	All occupations, business buildings or vacant lots which are kept in an unsanitary condition by 
either renter or owner or other person in charge so that the existence of the same shall be a 
menace to the public health. 
(b)	The following acts, businesses, buildings, lots or occupations are hereby declared to be 
nuisances: 
(1)	The leaving of carcasses of dead animals of any kind unburied on any premises. 
(2)	The maintenance of stockyards, cattle yards, cattle pens, hogpens, or pig sties in proximity 
to dwelling houses, except those kept and maintained in connection with operation of 
licensed establishments for the processing, preparation and handling of meat and meat 
products. 
(3)	The allowance of sewerage, garbage, filth, refuse, manure, fertilizer or other noxious 
matter to stand or remain on premises situated in the city limits so as to become a 
detriment to the health of any citizen or the community or liable to become so, within the 
discretion of the board of health. 
(4)	The maintenance or allowance of any wooden buildings in unsanitary condition or in a 
condition dangerous to the safety of the community with reference to fire or health. 
(5)	The maintenance or operation or the allowance by the owners or lessees of any wooden 
buildings in unsanitary condition within four hundred feet of any hotel or restaurant or 
places where food for human consumption is stored or kept. 
(6)	The maintenance of any building of any kind, character or description, of any vacant lot or 
place of any kind from which noxious smells emanate or escape or about which flies 
gather. 
(7)	The allowance by any person of dense gray or black smoke, to issue or emanate from any 
smoke stack, from any manufacturing plant or locomotive, or chimney of any building or 
any other plant within the city. 
(8)	The keeping or maintaining of any buildings or structures of any kind whatsoever 
dangerous to the community in any respect, either from fire or otherwise. 
(9)	The keeping or maintaining by any person, tenant or owner, of unsightly material, junk, 
automobile bodies, rubbish, refuse, weeds, grass, garbage or other unsightly objects on 
any vacant lots within the city in the residence districts, which will cause unsanitary 
conditions or hide or obscure from view unsanitary conditions or permit the collection of 
water. 
(Code 1922, § 153) 
Cross reference- Junkyards, automobile graveyards, etc., see § 14-16.1. 
State Law reference- For municipal authority to regulate for prevention and abatement of 
nuisances, see 1942 Miss. Code, § 3374-116. 


Sec. 14-26. - Same-Abatement; appeal. 
(a)	Abatement. The nuisances described in the preceding section may be abated in the following 
manner: Any person interested may make affidavit before the city judge of the police court of the city 
against the person or property, or both, alleged to be guilty of violating section 14-25, and thereupon 
process as in other cases shall issue, commanding the person alleged to be violating said section to 
appear at a date to be named in said process, not less than five days from the date thereof, to plead, 
answer or demur to the affidavit. Thereupon the said judge, after a full investigation, may make such 
order in the premises as he may deem advisable, and by such order declare the person, building or 
lot, guilty of nuisance as defined, shall order same abated, and may give such orders to the police or 
health authorities as will cause immediate abatement of such nuisance by tearing down the buildings 
or cleaning up the lots or abating the nuisance in such way as may be deemed advisable, at the cost 
of the owner of such lot, building or structure. Thereupon the police or health authorities shall carry 
out said orders of said judge. 
(b)	Appeals. Appeals may be granted from the decision of the said judge in regard to the above matters 
by either the city or the person aggrieved thereby under the usual penalties, but no supersedeas 
shall be granted by the judge on appeals if, in his opinion, the nuisance is dangerous to the public 
health or welfare of the community and such supersedeas would operate to the detriment of the 
health and general welfare of the community. This section shall not repeal but shall be concurrent 
with other sanitary and nuisance ordinances. 
(Code, 1922, §§ 155, 156) 
Cross reference- For effect of failure to abate health nuisance, § 11-4. 


Sec. 14-27. - Same-When offensive to public decency. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to commit a nuisance upon the streets, sidewalks or in 
any enclosure within the city, when the same will be an offense to public decency. 
(Code 1922, § 146; Ord. No. 655, § 1, 9-11-1972) 


Sec. 14-28. - Peddling prohibited; exception; penalty. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale or display for sale, or to solicit the purchase of 
any merchandise, commodity or article, except newspapers, on any street, alley or sidewalk within 
the city; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to any person selling, offering for sale, 
displaying for sale or soliciting the purchase of any dairy, poultry, orchard or farm products raised by 
said person on property controlled by him. 
(b)	It shall further be unlawful for any person to aid, abet, or assist another in committing any of the 
foregoing prohibited acts. 
(Ord. No. 401, §§ 1, 2, 9-21-1948; Ord. No. 656, § 1, 9-11-1972) 
Cross reference- For regulations as to food peddling, § 9-8. 


Sec. 14-29. - Petty larceny. 
    If any person shall feloniously take, steal or carry away any personal property of another under the 
value of one hundred dollars ($100.00) he shall be guilty of petty larceny and shall be guilty of a violation 
of this Code. 
(Code, 1922, § 143; Ord. No. 657, § 1, 9-11-1972) 
State Law reference- For similar provision of state law, see 1942 Miss. Code, § 2242. 


Sec. 14-29.1. - Police, other officials of city: Interference with, false information to. 
(a)	Interference with police in performance of duty. It shall be unlawful to interfere with any police officer 
of the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi, by threats, veiled or otherwise, pushing or crowding, or any 
other means, to delay or interfere in any manner with the performance of any of the duties of said 
police officer. 
(b)	False information to police, other city officials. It shall be unlawful knowingly to give false information 
to any of the members of the police department of the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi, or any other 
official of the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi, with reference to the enforcement of any of the 
ordinances of said city. 
(Ord. No. 552, §§ 1-3, 7-9-1963; Ord. No. 658, § 1, 9-11-1972) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 552 has been codified as § 14-29.1 in Supp. No. 3 at the discretion of 
the editors as the ordinance was not an amendment to this Code. 


Sec. 14-30. - Poolrooms. 
    It shall be unlawful for any poolroom or billiard parlor within the city to remain open on any night past 
midnight, or for any owner or operator of any poolroom or billiard parlor to allow patrons or customers to 
remain in such buildings after midnight. 
(Ord. No. 408, §§ 1, 2, 5-24-1949; Ord. No. 659, § 1, 9-11-1972) 


Sec. 14-31. - Reserved. 


Sec. 14-32. - Railroads-Jumping on or off cars in motion. 
    If any person other than employees engaged in operating a railroad, shall climb, jump on, step upon 
or in any way attach himself to, or jump off a locomotive, tender or car, while in motion on any railroad 
track or siding within the city, he shall upon conviction thereof be fined not less than ten dollars ($10.00) 
nor more than fifty dollars ($50.00) and shall remain in custody of the police until such fine and costs are 
paid. 
(Code, 1922, § 184) 
State Law reference- For similar prohibition of state law, see 1942 Miss. Code, § 2347. 


Sec. 14-33. - Same-Walking on elevated tracks. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful for any person or persons save employees of the Illinois Central Railroad in 
discharge of their duties, to enter or be upon or to walk across or along the elevated tracks and 
structures at any place within the limits of the said elevated tracks and structures except at the 
regular grade crossing. 
(b)	Any person violating or causing to be violated, any terms of this section shall be fined a sum not 
exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. No. 235-B, §§ 1, 2, 12-4-1928) 
State Law reference- For prohibition against using railroad tracks as a public road, see 1942 
Miss. Code, § 2342. 


Sec. 14-34. - Minors prohibited on school grounds, property of city at night. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of twenty-one years to go upon any of the school 
grounds or property in the city, between the hours of 7:30 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. unless said person 
shall be in the company of his parent or parents, or shall be going to or from the swimming pool on 
the said property, or shall be going to or from one of the school buildings to attend some public 
meeting therein. In case said person should be going to or from said swimming pool and not in the 
company of his parent or parents, he or she shall not remain upon said school grounds or at said 
swimming pool after 10:00 p.m. 
(b)	Anyone violating this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be fined not 
more than twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(Ord. No. 211, §§ 1, 2, 5-19-1925) 
State Law reference- For prohibition against a person trespassing upon the enclosed land of 
another, when proper notice of such prohibition has been given see 1942 Miss. Code, § 2411. 


Sec. 14-35. - Secondhand apparel, sale of. 
(a)	Prohibited; exceptions. The sale of secondhand or used articles or clothing, wearing apparel or 
shoes on the streets of the city shall be prohibited; provided, however, that upon the terms and 
conditions hereinafter specified, any duly constituted and recognized charitable organization 
appropriating the entire proceeds of the sales of such articles to charity may make such sales. 
(b)	Sale in store, excepted. Nothing in this section shall prohibit the sale of such articles in a store 
paying a privilege tax to the city. 
(c)	Charities excepted. Any duly constituted and recognized charitable organization or corporation may 
make sale of the articles mentioned in subsection (a) of this section by complying with the following 
conditions and regulations: 
(1)	The chief local officer of such organization shall apply to the city clerk for a permit to engage in 
the sale of the said articles, and furnish satisfactory evidence of the existence of the 
organization, if not known by the clerk, and that the entire proceeds from the sale of such 
articles will be devoted to charitable purposes; 
(2)	When such charitable organization engages in the sale of the said articles it shall select a 
location on the streets or sidewalks that will not impede or interfere with public travel on said 
streets or sidewalks. 
(d)	Penalty. Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be fined in a sum not 
exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. No. 294, §§ 1-4, 4-10-1934) 
Cross reference- Regulation of food peddling, § 9-8; peddling generally, § 14-28; transient 
merchants or vendors, Ch. 19A. 


Sec. 14-36. - Spitting. 
    All persons are prohibited from spitting upon the sidewalks and upon the floor or walls of any place 
where food is handled or stored, and upon the floor or wall of any courthouse, city hall, schoolhouse, 
depots, depot platform and places where the public are likely to walk or to congregate. 
(Code 1922, § 114) 


Sec. 14-37. - Trespass-On property of another. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to trespass upon the real or personal property of another within 
the city. 
(Code 1922, § 131; Ord. No. 660, § 1, 9-11-1972) 


Sec. 14-38. - Same-Damaging property; driving across sidewalks. 
(a)	Damaging property. It shall be unlawful for anyone to damage or mutilate private or public property 
within the corporate limits. 
(b)	Driving across sidewalks. It shall be unlawful for anyone to drive any wheeled vehicles across the 
sidewalks in the city, except at a regular street or alley crossing. 
(Code 1922, § 136; Ord. No. 661, § 1, 9-11-1972) 
Cross reference- Prohibition against defacing streets, sidewalks, see § 17-5. 


Sec. 14-39. - Vagrancy. 
    The following persons are hereby deemed, adjudged and shall be punished as vagrants: 
(a)	Persons known as tramps, wandering or strolling about in idleness, who are able to work and 
have no property to support them. 
(b)	Persons leading an idle, immoral or profligate life, who have no property to support them, and 
who are able to work and do not work. 
(c)	All persons able to work, having no property to support them, and who have no visible or known 
means of a fair, honest and reputable livelihood. The term "visible or known means of a fair, 
honest and reputable livelihood," as used in this subsection, shall be construed to mean 
reasonably continuous employment at some lawful occupation for reasonable compensation, or 
a fixed and regular income from property or other investment, which income is sufficient for the 
support and maintenance of such person. 
(d)	All able-bodied persons who habitually loaf, loiter and idle in the streets or alleyways of the city, 
or about public places of business or amusement, or railroad stations or any other public place 
in the city, for the larger portion of their time, without any regular employment and without any 
visible means of support. An offense under subparagraph (d) of this section shall be made out 
whenever it is shown that any person has no visible means of support and only occasionally has 
employment at odd jobs, being for the most part unemployed. 
(e)	Persons trading or bartering stolen property, or who unlawfully sell or barter any vinous, 
alcoholic, malt, intoxicating or spirituous liquors. 
(f)	Every common gambler or person who for the most part maintains himself by gambling. 
(g)	Every able-bodied person who shall beg for a livelihood. 
(h)	Every common prostitute. 
(i)	Every keeper of a house of prostitution. 
(j)	Every keeper of a house of gambling or gaming. 
(k)	Every able-bodied person who lives without employment or labor, and who has no visible 
means of support. 
(l)	All persons who are able to work and do not work, but hire out their minor children or allow them 
to be hired out, and live upon their own wages. 
(m)	All persons over sixteen (16) years of age and under twenty-one (21), able to work and who do 
not work, and who have no property to support them, who have not some known visible means 
of a fair, honest and reputable livelihood, whose parents or those in loco parentis are unable to 
support them and who are not in attendance upon some educational institution. 
(Ord. No. 217, § 1, 5-10-1927) 
Cross reference- Provision requiring report to county health officer of arrest for vagrancy, § 
11-37; prohibiting loitering at public places, § 14-17; on streets, alleys, § 14-18; on property of 
Illinois Central Railroad, § 14-19. 


Sec. 14-40. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 702, § 1, adopted Sept. 22, 1975, repealed § 14-40 which had 
pertained to walkathons, marathons, etc. Said section had been derived from Ord. No. 295, §§ 
1-4, adopted April 17, 1934. 


Sec. 14-41. - Wine, beer or intoxicating beverages-Possession, consumption in public places, places of 
sale, etc. 
(a)	Lawful hours. No person shall have in his or her possession or consume any wine, beer or other 
intoxicating beverage in any restaurant, cafe, lounge, grocery and/or market as defined in subsection 
14-42(a)(2) of this Code, or in any public place as defined in subsection 14-42(a)(5) of this Code 
within the city, except on the premises of the city auditorium or on the premises of the Clarksdale-
Coahoma County Expo Center, between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(b)	Display of sign by licensee. All licensed wine, beer and intoxicating beverage dealers in the city shall 
display a sign in a prominent place on their premises indicating what is a violation of this section. 
(c)	Penalty for violation of section. Any violation of this section shall subject the violator to punishment 
as prescribed by the general penalty punishing for violations of this Code. 
(d)	Responsibility of licensees. It shall be unlawful for any person who owns, operates, manages or 
oversees a restaurant, cafe, lounge or other establishment where beer, wine or alcoholic beverages 
are sold to the consumer or for consumption by any person to allow any person to possess or 
consume wine, beer or any other intoxicating beverages in violation of the provisions of subsection 
(a) hereinabove. 
(Ord. No. 532, §§ 1-3, 7-3-1962; Ord. No. 533, § 1, 7-9-1961; Ord. No. 598, § 1, 1-22-1968; 
Ord. No. 662, § 1, 9-11-1972; Ord. No. 721, § 1, 12-12-1977; Ord. No. 850, §§ 1, 2, 2-6-1989; 
Ord. No. 951, § 1, 1-20-1998; Ord. No. 968, § 1, 6-7-1999) 
Editor's note- Former subsections 14-41(a)-(c), which pertained to alcoholic beverages, wine 
and beer and the possession, consumption or sale thereof by or to persons under eighteen years 
of age, have been deleted as being superseded by the provisions of Ord. No. 751, codified herein 
as § 14-42. Consequently, former subsections 14-41(d)-(f) have been redesignated as § 14-
41(a)-(c). 


Sec. 14-42. - Same-Sale, possession, consumption, etc., by under-age persons. 
(a)	Definitions. For the purpose of this section, the following terms, phrases, words and derivations shall 
have the meanings given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present 
tense include the future, words of the plural include the singular number, words in the singular 
number include the plural, and words in the masculine gender include the feminine gender. The word 
"shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
(1)	City is the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi. 
(2)	Restaurants, cafes, lounges, groceries and markets are any establishments where food, other 
edibles, frozen desserts and/or beverages, including but not limited to carbonated drinks, soft 
drinks, beer, light wines, alcoholic beverages and non-alcoholic beverages, are sold to the 
consumer or for the consumption of any person. 
(3)	Person is any firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind, 
regardless of age, and any natural person. 
(4)	Beer, light wine and alcoholic beverages shall be defined by and according to the laws of the 
State of Mississippi. 
(5)	Public place is any and all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys or other public ways, within the 
city limits, and any and all public parks, squares, spaces, grounds and buildings, and any public 
parking lot. 
(b)	Possession, consumption by persons under twenty-one. No person under the age of twenty-one (21) 
years shall purchase, receive or have in his or her possession in any restaurant, cafe, lounge, 
grocery or market as defined in subsection (a)(2) above, or in any public place as defined in 
subsection (a)(5) above, any alcoholic beverage, including beer or wine, nor shall any person under 
the age of twenty-one (21) years, on the premises of any restaurant, cafe, lounge, grocery, market or 
public place, including any parking lot serving such facility, consume, possess, or have under his or 
her control, or offer to give to any other person to consume or possess, any alcoholic beverage, 
including beer and/or wine. 
(c)	Reserved. 
(d)	False identification. It shall be unlawful for any person under the applicable age stated in subsection 
(b) hereof to furnish false information, or to furnish, present, or exhibit any fictitious or false 
registration card, identification card or note or other document, or to furnish, present or exhibit such 
document or documents issued to a person, other than the one presenting the same, for the purpose 
of procuring the sale, gift or delivery of beer, light wine or alcoholic beverage. 
(e)	Utilizing other persons. It shall be unlawful for any person under the applicable age stated in 
subsection (b) hereof to engage or utilize the services of any other person, whether for remuneration 
or not, to procure for such under-age person, any article which the under-age person is forbidden by 
law to purchase, possess or consume. 
(f)	Violation; penalty. Violation of this section, or any subsection hereof, shall constitute a misdemeanor 
and be punishable by a fine of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00), nor more than three 
hundred dollars ($300.00), or imprisonment in the city jail for not more than ninety (90) days, or by 
sentencing to both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 751, §§ 1-6, 4-7-1980; Ord. No. 850, § 4, 2-6-1989) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 751, enacted April 7, 1980, did not specifically amend this Code; 
hence, codification of §§ 1-6 of said ordinance as § 14-42 is at the discretion of the editor. 
Former subsection 14-42(c) has been deleted, at the discretion of the editor, as superseded by the 
provisions of Ord. No. 850, § 4, adopted Feb. 6, 1989, included herein as subsection 14-42(b). 
Subsection (C) formerly pertained to possession or consumption of alcoholic beverages by 
persons under twenty-one. 


Sec. 14-43. - Possession of open containers of beer or light wine. 
(a)	Prohibited in public places. It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his or her possession any 
open container, original or otherwise, of light wine or beer or consume such light wine or beer in any 
public place within the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi. As used herein, "public place" shall have the 
definition as set forth in section 14-42(a)(5), and in addition thereto, shall include the front or 
immediately adjacent area, including parking lots, of any store, shop, restaurant, cafe, lounge, tavern 
or other place of business within the city even though the same need not be devoted solely to the 
public use. 
(b)	Exceptions. 
(1)	The provisions of this article shall not apply to the interior of the city auditorium nor to the area 
within the permanent fencing of the Clarksdale-Coahoma County Expo Center, including the 
interior of the Expo Center, subject to the provisions of section 14-41 of this Code, but shall 
apply to the auditorium grounds, including the parking lot, and shall also apply to the Expo 
Center grounds outside of the permanently fenced area, including the Expo Center parking lot. 
(2)	Nonprofit permits. Any bona fide nonprofit corporation chartered under the laws of the State of 
Mississippi and having previously received tax exempt status from the Internal Revenue Service 
under Section 501 of the Internal Revenue Code, may, but only jointly with the chamber of 
commerce, apply for and receive permission to sponsor a special event with community-wide 
appeal within the corporate limits of the city (the "event") and to allow open containers of light 
wine or beer on the premises of such event, upon the following conditions: 
a.	An application for such exemption shall be filed at least thirty (30) days prior to the 
proposed date of operation of the event; 
b.	The applicants for such event shall file an application in writing with the city clerk, in 
duplicate, which application shall clearly indicate: 
1.	The name of the nonprofit corporation which will operate the event; 
2.	The location of the principal place of business of such nonprofit corporation; 
3.	The names and addresses of the officers of such nonprofit corporation; 
4.	That the Clarksdale-Coahoma County Chamber of Commerce is cosponsoring the 
event; 
5.	The length of time that the event shall remain in operation, which shall not exceed six 
(6) days; 
6.	The hours of the day or night during which the event shall be open and operating, 
which hours shall be confined between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 1:00 a.m. daily; 
7.	That provisions have been made for sanitary facilities for persons using the premises 
upon which the event is to be located, and a description of such facilities; 
8.	A description of the premises upon which the event is to be held, including the name 
and address of the owner of record of the premises and the consent of said owner, in 
writing, consenting to the location of the event on such premises; 
9.	An event shall be located upon any public property or property owned, leased or 
controlled by the city only upon specific authority by the board; 
10.	The board shall have the final right of approval of any premises where an event is to 
be located, and no permit shall issue hereunder until such approval is granted. Should 
the board not approve such premises, no permit shall be granted; and 
11.	Such other relevant information as the chief of police and/or the fire inspector of the 
city may require. 
c.	Provision of special police and/or fire officers; costs to be borne by applicant. The applicant 
shall provide such special police and/or fire officers as the chief of police and/or the fire 
inspector may deem necessary for the control of crowds and traffic as may be required for 
the public safety. The cost of such special officers shall be borne by the applicants.
