d.	Insurance. The applicants shall furnish evidence that a public liability insurance policy in 
amounts of not less than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for one (1) person 
and one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for any one (1) accident shall be in full force and 
effect at the time the event is to be operated and patronized by the public. Each applicant 
shall further agree, in writing, to assume the defense of and indemnify and hold harmless 
the city, its elected officials, officers, employees and agents, from and against all suits, 
actions, damages or claims to which the city shall be subjected to, resulting from, caused 
by, or arising out of or as a consequence of the proposed event. 
e.	Damages. The applicants shall execute an indemnification agreement, saving harmless the 
city for any and all liabilities or causes of action which might arise by virtue of the granting 
of a permit to the applicant and/or allowing the use of premises for the event. Any damages 
to the streets, sewers, trees, adjoining property or other real or personal property shall be 
the financial responsibility of the applicants including the chamber. 
f.	Cleaning. No dirt, paper, litter or other debris will be permitted to remain upon the streets or 
any public or private property following the event. The applicants shall be solely 
responsible for cleaning the site to the satisfaction of the director of public works of the city. 
g.	Fees. The applicant shall pay to the city clerk such fee or fees required by law for the 
privilege of sponsoring such event. 
h.	Prohibited activities. No lewd, lascivious, immoral or unlawful activities shall be conducted 
upon the applicant's premises, and no nudity of any form shall be allowed in conjunction 
with the applicant's operation of the event. 
i.	Issuance of permit. If the city clerk finds that the provisions hereof have been or will be fully 
complied with by the applicant, the clerk shall issue a permit thereto upon such reasonable 
terms and conditions as the city clerk, chief of police, the fire inspector and the board of 
mayor and commissioners may deem necessary for the safety of persons and property 
within the city. 
j.	Findings of fact. All findings of fact made by the board of mayor and commissioners shall 
be final and binding upon the applicants. 
k.	Compliance with state laws. The applicant shall be required to comply, in all respects, with 
the provisions of the laws of the State of Mississippi regarding the sale and/or consumption 
of alcoholic beverages, including obtaining all necessary permits therefore. 
(c)	Prohibited in automobiles. No light wine or beer shall be found open, in the original container or 
otherwise, in the possession of any person in any automobile or other vehicle at any public place as 
the same is defined herein. 
(d)	Violation and penalty. Any violation of this section or any provisions hereof shall constitute a 
misdemeanor and be punishable in accordance with the provisions of section 1-8 of the Code of 
Ordinances of the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi. 
(e)	Provisions supplemental to state law. The provisions of this article shall be deemed to be 
supplemental to any and all acts and laws of the State of Mississippi or the City of Clarksdale 
pertaining to or governing the sale or distribution of light wines or beer, and is in the interest of 
promoting the public health, morals and safety of the citizens of the city. 
(Ord. No. 769, §§ 1-4, 10-19-1981; Ord. No. 878, § 1, 7-8-1991; Ord. No. 968, § 3, 6-7-1999) 


Sec. 14-44. - Protection of cable television facilities and services. 
(a)	Definition. For the purpose of this section, "cable television service" means any and all services 
provided by or through the facilities of any cable television system or closed circuit coaxial cable 
communications system, or any microwave or similar transmission service used in connection with 
any cable television system or other similar closed circuit coaxial communications system. 
(b)	Unauthorized tampering, use, etc., prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person, without authority of 
the person, firm, or corporation providing cable television service or operating the system by means 
of which cable television service is provided, intentionally in any way to obstruct, injure, break, 
tamper with or destroy or in any manner interfere with or interrupt any cable television service, line or 
cable or the transmission of television signals in connection with such line or cable, or in any manner 
use and receive any television, radio, audio or video signal from any unauthorized connection with 
such line or cable, or to take, carry away, injure or destroy any of these posts, cables, wires, 
insulators, fixtures, equipment, installations or other things belonging to any cable television service 
or used in connection with the furnishing of cable television service. 
(c)	Devices, wires resulting in diversion of signal unlawful. The presence at any time on or about such 
wires, cables or cable television equipment of any device or wire resulting in the diversion of 
television, radio, audio or video signals with the knowledge and intent to divert on the part of the 
person, firm or corporation having custody or control of the room or place where such signals are 
diverted and received, shall be unlawful, where the presence of such device or wire is without the 
authority of the person, firm or corporation providing the cable television service or operating the 
system by means of which such cable television service is provided. 
(d)	Penalty. Any person, firm or corporation committing any act declared unlawful hereunder shall be 
guilty of a misdemeanor and, on such conviction, shall be punishable by a fine not exceeding one 
thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or by imprisonment not exceeding ninety (90) days, or both. Every day 
any violation of this section shall continue shall constitute a new and separate offense and shall be 
punishable as such hereunder. Any violator shall also be ordered to pay restitution to the person, 
firm or corporation providing such cable television services in the amount of the reasonable value of 
such cable television services obtained in violation of this section; however, the combined total of 
such fine and restitution shall not exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(Ord. No. 797, §§ 1-4, 6-25-1984) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 797, enacted June 25, 1984, did not specifically amend this 
Code; hence, codification of the substantive provisions of §§ 1-4 of said ordinance as § 14-44 
is at the discretion of the editor. 


Sec. 14-45. - Hours of operation of businesses in residential districts. 
(a)	Hours specified. It shall be unlawful for any store, shop, dance hall, pool hall, cafe, restaurant, or 
other place of business open to public patronage which is located in an area which is zoned R-1, R-
2, R-3, or R-4 according to the official zoning map of the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi, on file in the 
office of the city engineer, City Auditorium, Clarksdale, Mississippi, to remain open between the 
hours of 12:00 midnight and 7:00 a.m.; the provisions of any statute, ordinance, order or rule 
covering the hours of operation of establishments selling beer and alcoholic beverages 
notwithstanding. 
(b)	Penalty. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and 
upon conviction thereof shall be fined not less than three hundred dollars ($300.00) nor more than 
one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or imprisoned for not more than ninety (90) days, or punished by 
both such fine and imprisonment, and shall be assessed with all costs of such proceedings. "Person" 
as used herein shall be defined as the licensed owner of said business and his or her managers, 
agents and employees. Each day any violation of this section shall continue shall be regarded as a 
new and separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 801, §§ 1, 2, 8-6-1984) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 801, enacted Aug. 16, 1984, did not specifically amend this 
Code; hence, codification of the substantive provisions of §§ 1 and 2 of said ordinance as § 14-
45 is at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Zoning, App. A. 


ARTICLE II. - ARRESTS 


Sec. 14-46. - Who may make arrests. 
    Arrests for crimes and offenses against the laws of the state or the city ordinances may be made by 
any officer acting as sheriff, or his deputy, or by any constable or policeman, or by private persons. 
(Code, 1922, § 21) 


Sec. 14-47. - Power to arrest without warrant-By police or private persons. 
    An officer or private person may arrest any person without warrant for an indictable offense 
committed or a breach of the peace threatened or attempted in his presence; or when such person has 
committed a felony, though not in his presence, or when a felony has been committed, and he has 
reasonable ground to suspect and believe the person proposed to be arrested has committed it; or on a 
charge, made upon reasonable cause, of the commission of a felony by the party proposed to be 
arrested. 
(Code 1922, § 27) 


Sec. 14-48. - Same-Violation of ordinances. 
    The mayor, police justice, chief of police or any policeman may arrest any person without warrant for 
a violation of any of the city ordinances committed in his presence. In all other cases when it is proposed 
to arrest a person for violating any city ordinance, it shall be the duty of the officer, before making the 
arrest, to procure a warrant therefor; provided, however, that where the appearance of offenders can be 
had without arrest, no warrant need be issued. 
(Code 1922, § 20) 


Sec. 14-49. - Same-Right of accused. 
    In all cases of arrest without warrant, the person making such arrest must inform the accused of the 
object and cause of such arrest, except when he is in the actual commission of the offense, or is arrested 
on pursuit. 
(Code 1922, § 19) 


Sec. 14-50. - Duty of person making arrest. 
    Every person making an arrest within the city shall deliver the person arrested to the keeper of the 
jail and enter such arrest on the docket without unnecessary delay. 
(Code 1922, § 22) 


Sec. 14-51. - Forcible entry to effect arrest. 
    To make an arrest as provided for in this article, an officer or private person if admittance be refused 
after notice of his office and object, may break open a window or outer or inner door of any dwelling or 
other house in which he believes the offender may be found. 
(Code 1922, § 23) 


Sec. 14-52. - Time and place of making. 
    Arrests for offenses committed, or to prevent a breach of the peace, or the commission of a crime, 
may be made at any time or place. 
(Code 1922, § 26) 


Sec. 14-53. - Resisting arrest, obstructing police. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to resist, or obstruct the police, or any other officer of the city in 
the discharge of any of their duties. 
(Ord. No. 206, § 1, 2-7-1922; Ord. No. 663, § 1, 9-11-1972) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code Ann., 1972, §§ 97-9-73, 97-9-75. 


Sec. 14-54. - Failure to assist arresting officer. 
    All officers of the city shall have the power to summon any bystander to assist them in the execution 
of their duties, and it shall be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse to render the required assistance. 
(Ord. No. 206, § 2, 2-7-1922; Ord. No. 664, § 1, 9-11-1972) 
State Law reference- Requirement that persons must aid in making an arrest when directed to 
do so, Miss. Code Ann., 1972, § 99-3-5. 


Sec. 14-55. - Escape from detention. 
(a)	Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person, after arrest by any person authorized by the laws of 
the state or ordinance of the city to make arrest, to escape or attempt to escape by any means 
whatever from the custody of such person, or from the city jail, jail yard, city hall or any other place of 
lawful confinement or detention, either before or after conviction. 
(b)	Violations. A violation of this section shall constitute an offense separate and distinct from the 
offense for which such person is in custody. 
(Code, 1922, § 135; Ord. No. 206, § 3, 2-7-1922; Ord. No. 665, § 1, 9-11-1972) 
State Law reference- Escape by a prisoner from detention and attempt by force to escape, 
Miss. Code Ann., 1972, § 97-9-51; authority of one from whose custody an accused has escaped 
to retake such accused, Miss. Code Ann., 1972, § 99-3-15. 


Sec. 14-56. - Process against corporations. 
    When an affidavit shall be lodged with the mayor or police justice against any corporation for an 
alleged violation of any of the ordinances of the city, a summons shall be issued against it, by its 
corporate name, to appear and answer the affidavit, which summons may be executed as a summons 
against a corporation in a civil suit, as now or hereafter provided by statutes; and upon the summons 
being returned executed, the corporation shall be considered in court and appearing to the affidavit, and 
the court shall, unless the defendant do so of its own accord, cause an appearance to be made by record. 
Such proceedings may then be had thereon as if the defendant had appeared and answered thereto; and 
if the corporation shall be convicted on the affidavit the court may pass judgment thereon, and cause 
process of execution to be issued against the goods and chattels, lands and tenements of the corporation 
for the amount of the fine and costs which may be awarded against it, as on a judgment in a civil suit; and 
the chief of police or any subordinate officer shall proceed to sell the goods and chattels, and tenements 
of the corporation in the execution as on an execution issuing against a corporation in a civil suit. 
(Code, 1922, § 56) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Miss. Code Ann., 1972, § 99-9-3. 


Secs. 14-57-14-62. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE III. - POLICE COURT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- For authority of police court to abate nuisances, § 14-26. 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to exercise judicial powers, Miss. Code Ann., 1972, § 21-5-9; 
authority to provide for police court, police justice and cognate matters, Miss. Code Ann., 1972, § 21-23-3 
et seq. 


Sec. 14-63. - Office of police justice created. 
    There is hereby created the office of police justice in the city, who shall be appointed and whose 
compensation or salary shall be fixed from time to time by the board of mayor and commissioners of the 
city. The qualifications, powers and duties of the said office are those conferred by law upon the office of 
police justice in 1942 Mississippi Code, section 3374-103. 
(Code, 1922, § 169) 
Cross reference- As to the office of police justice being within the first department, § 2-4. 


Sec. 14-64. - Police justice, pro tem; duties, power; compensation. 
    The office of police justice, pro tem, is hereby created. Whenever the police justice shall be absent, 
the police justice, pro tem, shall act in his stead and any act performed by him shall be as binding as if 
done by the officer elected for that purpose. The compensation or salary of the police justice, pro tem, 
shall be fixed from time to time by the board of mayor and commissioners of the City of Clarksdale, 
Mississippi. 
(Code, 1922, §§ 172-174; Ord. No. 640, § 1, 12-13-1971) 


Sec. 14-65. - Terms of court; sessions; where held; officers of court. 
    There shall be twelve (12) terms of police court, which said terms shall begin on the first day of the 
month and end on the last day of the month, all Sundays excluded. Daily sessions of the said court shall 
be held when business requires it, except on Sundays and legal holidays. The said court shall be held at 
the city hall or other municipal building as from time to time may be named and designated by the board 
of mayor and commissioners, and the officers of said court shall be those named and designated from 
time to time by orders of the board of mayor and commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 286, §§ 1-3, 10-31-1933; Ord. No. 683, § 1, 10-22-1973) 


Sec. 14-66. - Police docket to be kept; content. 
    The police justice shall number each case upon the police docket, giving the date, true name of 
defendant when known, the offense charged, and by whom the affidavit was made. 
(Code, 1922, § 175) 
State Law reference- Authority to maintain a docket, 1942 Miss. Code, § 3374-105. 


Sec. 14-67. - Disposition of proceeding to be docketed; mittimus to issue, contents. 
    All judgments of the police court of the city shall be printed, stamped or written on the docket or 
minute book of the court and shall be dated and signed by the police justice or police justice, pro tem, as, 
if and when so entered on said docket or minute book. After trial and judgment, a mittimus shall be issued 
to the chief of police, setting forth the name of the defendant when known, the offense charged and the 
judgment of the court. 
(Code, 1922, § 176; Ord. No. 301, § 1, 2-19-1935) 
State Law reference- Requirement that disposition of proceeding be entered upon the docket, 
1942 Miss. Code, § 3374-105. 


Sec. 14-68. - Compensation of clerk. 
    It shall be the duty of the police justice to notify the city clerk of all warrants sworn out before him and 
of all cases instituted before him for violation of the ordinances of the city. In each such case there shall 
be prepared a detailed cost bill in which there shall be included for payment to the City of Clarksdale, 
Mississippi, as compensation for the performance by the city clerk of his duties as prescribed hereunder 
all fees that may now or hereafter be allowed by law to clerks of the circuit court for performing like 
services. All of said fees shall be charged in the bill of costs against all offenders convicted in said court 
and collected as the fines and other costs are now collected by law. 
(Code 1922, § 171; Ord. No. 686, § 1, 11-26-1973; Ord. No. 718, § 1, 11-22-1976) 
State Law reference- Duties of the police clerk generally, 1942 Miss. Code, § 3374-105. 


Sec. 14-69. - Contempt of court. 
    For any offense committed in the police court of the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi, amounting to 
contempt of court, the offender shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined by the police justice in 
any sum not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00) or imprisoned not longer than thirty (30) days, or 
both, within the discretion of the police justice. 
(Code 1922, § 170; Ord. No. 551, § 1, 7-9-1963) 
State Law reference- Provision that a court of record as incident to its power has the power to 
fine and imprison for contempt, 1942 Miss. Code, § 1810. 


Secs. 14-70-14-79. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE IV. - GARAGE SALES, YARD SALES, ETC.[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 809, §§ 1-8, passed, approved and adopted May 28, 1985, was not 
enacted as a specific amendment or addition to the Code, but is included herein as a new Art. IV, §§ 14-
80-14-87, to Ch. 14 at the discretion of the editor. 


Sec. 14-80. - Purpose. 
    This article is adopted for the express purpose of providing harmony and adequate open spaces for 
traffic and on- and off-street parking within residential areas and a distribution of population parking and 
traffic which will promote conditions favorable to health, safety, convenience, prosperity and general 
welfare. 
(Ord. No. 809, § 1, 5-28-1985) 


Sec. 14-81. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes hereof, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings prospectively 
ascribed to them by this section: 
    Goods. Any goods, wares, merchandise or other personal property capable of being the subject of a 
sale regulated by this article. 
    Person. Any person who is occupying any home or mobile home located within a residential district 
of the City of Clarksdale and who conducts a sale as defined in this section. 
    Sale of goods. The selling of goods, wares or merchandise as individual units or in bulk to another 
within a residential area of the city commonly known as home, mobile home, garage, patio and yard sales 
and other sales activities associated and incidental thereto and held out in such a manner as to 
reasonably cause the public to believe that the person conducting the sale will cease and discontinue the 
selling of goods at the place of sale upon disposal of the stock of goods on hand. 
(Ord. No. 809, § 2, 5-28-1985) 


Sec. 14-82. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions hereof shall not apply to or affect the following: 
(1)	Persons acting pursuant to an order or process of a court of competent jurisdiction; 
(2)	Persons acting in accordance with their powers and duties as public officials; 
(3)	Duly licensed auctioneers selling at auction; and 
(4)	Any duly licensed, bona fide merchant of the city conducting a seasonal or special sale 
ordinarily conducted by merchants in the regular course of their business or any bona fide 
merchant who is closing out his stock of goods and advertises, such sale to that effect or any 
bona fide merchant whose stock of goods has been damaged by fire, smoke, water or 
otherwise, and who advertises as such. 
(Ord. No. 809, § 3, 5-28-1985) 


Sec. 14-83. - Notice to city. 
    No person shall conduct a garage or other residential sale, as defined in "sale of goods" 
hereinabove, without first filing with the city clerk a written notice giving the following information: 
(1)	His name and post office address; 
(2)	The location where the sale is to be held; 
(3)	The dates of commencement and termination of the sale; 
(4)	That the seller has not conducted at the location any sale regulated by this article during the 
one hundred eighty (180) days immediately preceding; and 
(5)	That the seller acknowledges that he will be responsible for the payment of any and all taxes 
due upon the proceeds of any such sale. 
(Ord. No. 809, § 4, 5-28-1985) 


Sec. 14-84. - False advertising. 
    A person who conducts a garage or other residential sale shall: 
(1)	Refrain from the employment of untrue, deceptive or misleading advertising; and 
(2)	Conduct the sale in strict conformity with any advertising or holding out incidental thereto. 
(Ord. No. 809, § 5, 5-28-1985) 


Sec. 14-85. - Maximum length. 
    No person shall conduct a garage or other residential sale, as defined in "sale of goods" 
hereinabove, so that the selling period pertaining to the sale of goods exceeds two (2) consecutive days. 
(Ord. No. 809, § 6, 5-28-1985) 


Sec. 14-86. - Frequency. 
    No person shall conduct a garage or other residential sale, as defined in "sale of goods" 
hereinabove, at the same location within one hundred eighty (180) days of another such sale at such 
location. 
(Ord. No. 809, § 7, 5-28-1985) 


Sec. 14-87. - Penalty. 
(a)	Any violation of this article shall constitute and be a misdemeanor, and any person found guilty shall 
be fined the sum of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than one hundred dollars 
($100.00) or imprisoned for a term not exceeding thirty (30) days, with each day of said violation 
constituting a separate offense. 
(b)	In addition to the above penalty, any conditions caused or permitted to exist in violation of this article 
shall be deemed a public nuisance and may be enjoined by the city as provided by law for other 
nuisances. 
(Ord. No. 809, § 8, 5-28-1985) 


Secs. 14-88-14-100. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE V. - RESERVED[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Pursuant to § 1, of Ord. No. 882, adopted Jan. 6, 1992, this article has been deleted as 
having expired January 31, 1993. Formerly Article IV consisted of §§ 14-101-14-112, which pertained to 
curfew and derived from Ord. No. 880, §§ 1-2, adopted Oct. 28, 1991. 


Secs. 14-101-14-120. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE VI. - FIREWORKS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Inasmuch as Ord. No. 891, §§ 1-9, adopted Aug. 24, 1992, did not specify manner of 
codification, inclusion herein as Article VI, §§ 14-121-14-129, was at the discretion of the editor. 


Sec. 14-121. - Findings. 
    The findings contained in the preamble of Ordinance No. 891, adopted August 24, 1992, are hereby 
affirmed and readopted as the findings of the board of mayor and commissioners of the City of 
Clarksdale. 
(Ord. No. 891, § 1, 8-24-1992) 


Sec. 14-122. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to eliminate the harm to public health and safety and property within the 
city and is designed to safeguard the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the city and to protect 
property therein. 
(Ord. No. 891, § 2, 8-24-1992) 


Sec. 14-123. - Scope of authority. 
    Unless exempted by the provisions hereof, this article shall apply to all persons within the city. 
(Ord. No. 891, § 3, 8-24-1992) 


Sec. 14-124. - Definitions. 
    The following terms shall have the following meanings, unless the context clearly indicates that a 
different meaning is intended: 
    City. The City of Clarksdale, Coahoma County, Mississippi. 
    Police chief. The duly appointed, qualified and acting Chief of the Clarksdale Police Department. 
    Fire chief. The duly appointed, qualified and acting Chief of the Clarksdale Fire Department. 
    Fireworks. Any combustible, explosive composition or any substance or combination of substances, 
or article prepared for the purpose of producing a visible or an audible effect by combustion, explosion, 
deflagration or detonation, which shall include firecrackers, roman candles, lady fingers, torpedoes, sky 
rockets, day glow bombs, sparklers or any other device containing such explosive substance. The term 
"fireworks" shall not include (i) toy pistols, toy canes, toy guns, or other devices in which paper caps 
manufactured in accordance with the United States Interstate Commerce Commission regulations for 
packing and shipping of toy paper caps are used or toy pistol paper caps manufactured as provided 
therein, the sale and use of which is permitted under the provisions of Miss. Code Ann. § 21-19-15 (1972) 
at all times, or (ii) model rockets and model rocket engines which are designed, sold and used for the 
purpose of propelling recoverable aero models, when actually used for that purpose, and used under the 
supervision of a competent adult, and when the place and time of firing the sky rockets or missiles shall 
have been previously approved by the fire chief. Nothing contained in this section shall be construed as 
applying to the manufacture, storage, sale or use of signals necessary for the safe operation of railroads 
or other classes of public or private transportation, or applying to the military or naval forces of the United 
States or the State of Mississippi, or to law enforcement officers. Further, nothing contained in this section 
shall be construed as forbidding the sale or use of blank cartridges for ceremonial, theatrical or athletic 
events. 
    Person. Any individual, firm, organization, partnership, unincorporated association or corporation. 
    Pyrotechnic expert. An individual who, by experience and training, has demonstrated the required 
skill and ability for safely setting up and discharging displays of fireworks. 
    Use. Setting off or otherwise causing to explode, discharge or burn, any firecrackers, torpedoes, 
rocket or other fireworks or explosives of inflammable material, or to discharge them or throw them from 
land, air or highway into any area of the city. This prohibition includes any substance, compound, mixture 
or article that, in conjunction with any other substance or compound, would be dangerous from any of the 
foregoing standards. This provision shall also mean and include casting, throwing, lighting or firing any 
squib, rocket, cracker, torpedo, grenade, gun, revolver, pistol, cap or cartridge or other fireworks or 
combustible firecrackers of any kind. 
(Ord. No. 891, § 4, 8-24-1992) 


Sec. 14-125. - Prohibitions; unlawful acts. 
(a)	Except as otherwise provided herein, it shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, 
possess for the purpose of sale, barter or distribute fireworks within the corporate limits of the city, or 
to allow or permit fireworks to be sold or distributed on his premises or premises under his control. 
(b)	Except as provided herein, it shall be unlawful for any person to use fireworks within the city. It shall 
be unlawful for any person to allow or permit fireworks to be used or exploded on his premises or 
premises under his control. It shall be further unlawful for any person to throw any firework, whether 
said firework is burning or not, or to mishandle or misuse fireworks in any manner. 
(Ord. No. 891, § 5, 8-24-1992; Ord. No. 925, § 1, 9-5-1995) 


Sec. 14-126. - Exceptions. 
    Nothing in section 14-125 hereof shall be construed as forbidding the possession or use of any 
fireworks by those in charge of a public exhibition. Such an exhibition may be held on any day or days of 
the year, authorized under state law, provided that (i) it is held at a location which does not endanger 
persons or property, and (ii) that a pyrotechnic expert is used, and (iii) that those in charge of the 
exhibition obtain a permit and comply with sections 14-127 and 14-128 herein and all applicable state 
laws and/or regulations, including Miss. Code Ann. § 45-13-11 (1972). 
(Ord. No. 891, § 6, 8-24-1992) 


Sec. 14-127. - Public exhibitions and permit applications. 
    An applicant for a permit for a public exhibition or display of fireworks shall file with the city clerk a 
written application therefore on a form to be provided by the clerk for that purpose, duly subscribed and 
sworn by the applicant, which application shall set forth, at minimum, the following: 
(1)	The name of the association, organization or corporation sponsoring the display, together with 
the names of the persons to be in charge of the display; 
(2)	The date and time of day at which the display is to be held; 
(3)	The exact location planned for the display; 
(4)	A description setting forth the name, age, address and experience of the persons who are to do 
the actual firing and discharging of the fireworks; 
(5)	The number and kinds of fireworks to be discharged; 
(6)	The manner and place of the storage of such fireworks between the date of purchase and the 
date of display; and 
(7)	A sketch or diagram of the grounds on which the display is to be held, showing the point at 
which the fireworks are to be discharged, the location of all buildings, streets, trees, telephone, 
electrical or other overhead lines and any other overhead obstructions within a distance of fifty 
(50) yards from the point of discharge, and the lines behind which the public will be restrained. 
(Ord. No. 891, § 7, 8-24-1992) 


Sec. 14-128. - Public exhibitions-Permit filing requirements. 
    An application for a permit for a public exhibition or display of fireworks shall be filed with the city 
clerk at least twenty (20) days before the date set for the display. A copy of such application shall be sent 
at once to the police chief and to the fire chief, who shall make or cause to be made an investigation of 
the site of the proposed display and investigate the competence and skill of the persons in charge of the 
firing and discharge of the fireworks. If satisfied that the display will be conducted lawfully and in 
accordance with the provisions of this article, they shall so advise the city clerk within ten (10) days, who 
shall then issue the permit. The applicant for a permit, shall, at the time of filing the application therefore, 
pay to the city clerk a fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00), which sum shall be retained as a permit fee in 
the event that the permit is issued, and which sum shall be refunded in the event the application for such 
permit is denied. Each applicant shall also pay the city clerk a nonrefundable investigation fee of twenty-
five dollars ($25.00). 
(Ord. No. 891, § 8, 8-24-1992) 


Sec. 14-129. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provisions of this article shall be guilty of a 
misdemeanor, and upon conviction, shall be fined not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) and not more 
than five hundred dollars ($500.00), plus costs, or imprisoned for not more than ninety (90) days, or by 
sentencing to both such fine and imprisonment. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each 
day during or on which the violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 891, § 9, 8-24-1992) 


Secs. 14-130-14-139. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE VII. - MINORS 


DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 


Secs. 14-140-14-149. - Reserved. 


DIVISION 2. - CURFEW[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 907, adopted May 31, 1994, pertaining to curfew, did not specify manner of 
codification, but has been codified as Art. VII, Div. 2, §§ 14-150-14-160 at the editor's discretion and 
with the concurrence of the city. Subsequently, Ord. No. 957, adopted November 30, 1998; Ord. No. 983, 
adopted July 30, 2001; Ord. No. 993, adopted May 12, 2003; Ord. No. 1019, adopted September 25, 
2006; Ord. No. 1028, adopted July 14, 2008; Ord. No. 1034, adopted June 14, 2010; and Ord. No. 1040, 
adopted May 14, 2012; amended the curfew division, formerly §§ 14-150-14-160, in its entirety. While 
section titles have not been changed and history notes have been left intact accordingly, this division has 
been renumbered for clarity upon amendment, at the discretion of the editor, and now consists of §§ 14-
150-14-161, as set out herein. 


Sec. 14-150. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Clarksdale Curfew Ordinance" or the "curfew 
ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 907, § 1, 5-31-1994; Ord. No. 923, § 1, 8-7-1995; Ord. No. 933, § 1, 12-2-1996; Ord. 
No. 957, § 1, 11-30-1998; Ord. No. 983, § 1, 7-30-2001; Ord. No. 993, § 1, 5-12-2003; Ord. No. 
1019, § 1, 9-25-2006; Ord. No. 1028, § 1, 7-14-2008; Ord. No. 1034, § 1, 6-14-2010; Ord. No. 
1040, § 1, 5-14-2012 Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 6-30-2014; Ord. No. 2016-01, § 1, 6-13-2016) 


Sec. 14-151. - Purposes and findings. 
    The board of mayor and commissioners of the city hereby: 
(1)	Readopts and reaffirms the statements and findings made in the preamble to this article; 
(2)	Finds and determines that special and extenuating circumstances presently exist within the city 
which call for special regulation of minors in the city in order to protect them from each other 
and from other persons in the street during certain specified nocturnal hours; to aid in crime 
prevention; to promote parental supervision and authority over minors; and to decrease 
nocturnal juvenile crime rates; 
(3)	Further finds and determines that a significant number of automobile burglaries and thefts and 
home burglaries have been committed by juveniles in the nocturnal hours; 
(4)	Further finds and determines, in accordance with the prevailing community standards, that this 
article shall serve to regulate the conduct of juveniles on streets and public places during 
nocturnal hours; to be effectively and consistently enforced for the protection of juveniles in the 
city from each other and from other persons in the streets and in other public places during 
nocturnal hours; for the enforcement of parental control of, authority over and responsibility for 
their children; for the protection of the public from nocturnal mischief by juveniles; for the 
reduction of incidents of juvenile criminal activity; to suppress and discourage "gang" and similar 
activity; for the furtherance of family responsibility; and for the public good, safety and welfare; 
and 
(5)	Further finds and determines that the public convenience and necessity requires the adoption 
and enforcement of this article and that this article should take effect immediately to preserve 
the public peace, health and safety. 
(Ord. No. 907, § 2, 5-31-1994; Ord. No. 923, § 2, 8-7-1995; Ord. No. 933, § 2, 12-2-1996; Ord. 
No. 957, § 2, 11-30-1998; Ord. No. 983, § 2, 7-30-2001; Ord. No. 993, § 2, 5-12-2003; Ord. No. 
1019, § 2, 9-25-2006; Ord. No. 1028, § 2, 7-14-2008; Ord. No. 1034, § 2, 6-14-2010; Ord. No. 
1040, § 2, 5-14-2012; Ord. No. 2014-03, § 2, 6-30-2014; Ord. No. 2016-01, § 2, 6-13-2016) 


Sec. 14-152. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations shall have 
the meanings given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense 
include the future, words in the plural number include the singular number, and words in the singular 
number the plural number. The masculine gender shall include the feminine and the feminine shall 
include the masculine. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
    Chief of police shall mean the duly appointed, qualified and acting chief of the city police department, 
or his designee. 
    City is the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi, a municipal corporation domiciled in Coahoma County, 
Mississippi with its administrative offices located at City Hall, 121 Sunflower Avenue, Post Office Box 940, 
Clarksdale, Mississippi 38614. 
    Emergency means an unforeseen combination of circumstances or the resulting state that calls for 
immediate action. The term includes, but is not limited to, a fire, natural disaster or automobile accident, 
or any situation regarding immediate action to prevent serious bodily injury or loss of life. 
    Establishment means any privately owned place of business operated for profit to which the public is 
invited, including, but not limited to any place of amusement or entertainment. 
    Law enforcement officer shall include any regular or special police officer of the city, the county 
sheriff and his duly authorized deputies, and any other law enforcement designated by the state as 
having arrest powers. 
    Minor or juvenile is any unemancipated person under the age of eighteen (18) years, or, in 
equivalent phrasing employed from time to time in this article, any person seventeen (17) or less years of 
age. 
    Operator is any individual, firm, association, partnership, corporation or other business entity 
operating, managing or conducting any establishment. The term includes the members or partners of an 
association or partnership and the officers of a corporation. 
    Parent is any person having legal custody of a minor: 
(1)	As a natural or adopted parent of the minor; 
(2)	As a legal guardian of the minor; 
(3)	As a person who stands in loco parentis; or 
(4)	As a person to whom legal custody has been given by any court. 
    Police department or police station shall refer to the police department headquarters and central 
station located at City Hall, 121 Sunflower Avenue, Clarksdale, Mississippi, or at any officially designated 
precinct of said department. 
    Public place shall mean any street, highway, park, playground or place to which the general public 
has access and a right to resort for business, entertainment, recreation or other lawful purpose. A public 
place shall include, but not be limited to, any store, shop, restaurant, tavern, bowling alley, cafe, theater, 
drug store, pool room, shopping center or any other place devoted to amusement or entertainment of the 
general public. The term "public place" shall also include the front of and the area immediately adjacent to 
the above. 
    Remain means to stay behind, to tarry and/or to stay unnecessarily upon the streets or public places 
of the city, including the congregation of groups (or of interacting minors) totaling three (3) or more 
persons in which any minor involved would not be using the streets for ordinary or serious purposes such 
as mere passage or going home. To implement that thought with additional precision and precaution, 
numerous exemptions are expressly defined in section 14-156 hereof so that this shall not be construed 
as simply a prohibitory or presence-type article. 
    Street is a way or place, of whatsoever nature, open to the use of the public as a matter of right for 
purposes of vehicular travel, or in the case of a sidewalk thereof, for pedestrian travel, which term shall 
include the legal right-of-way, including, but not limited to, the traffic lanes, the curb, the sidewalk, 
whether paved or unpaved, and any grass, plots or other grounds found within the legal right-of-way 
within the street. The term "street" shall include, irrespective of name, any street, highway, alley, avenue, 
boulevard, court, or road, dedicated or otherwise. 
    Time of night as referred to herein is based upon the prevailing standard of time, whether Central 
Standard Time or Central Daylight Savings Time, generally observed at that hour by the public in the city, 
and shall be, prima facia, the time officially observed in the city's administrative offices or at the police 
station. 
    Year of age shall continue from one (1) birthday, to, but not including the day of, the next. It is 
intended to be clear that the phrase "seventeen or less years of age" is treated as equivalent to the 
phrase "under eighteen years of age". 
(Ord. No. 907, § 3, 5-31-1994; Ord. No. 923, § 3, 8-7-1995; Ord. No. 933, § 3, 12-2-1996; Ord. 
No. 957, § 3, 11-30-1998; Ord. No. 983, § 3, 7-30-2001; Ord. No. 993, § 3, 5-12-2003; Ord. No. 
1019, § 3, 9-25-2006; Ord. No. 1028, § 3, 7-14-2008; Ord. No. 1034, § 3, 6-14-2010; Ord. No. 
1040, § 3, 5-14-2012; Ord. No. 2014-03, § 3, 6-30-2014; Ord. No. 2016-01, § 3, 6-13-2016) 


Sec. 14-153. - Curfew for minors. 
    It shall be unlawful for any minor to remain, idle, wander, stroll or play in or upon any public street, 
highway, park, vacant lot or other public place, either on foot or to cruise about without a set destination in 
any vehicle, in, about, or upon any street or public place in the city beginning at 9:00 p.m. during 
weekdays, specifically on Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday evening and beginning 
at 10:59 p.m. on Friday and Saturday evenings, and ending the following day at 5:30 a.m. for any minors 
under eighteen (18) years of age. 
(Ord. No. 907, § 4, 5-31-1994; Ord. No. 923, § 4, 8-7-1995; Ord. No. 933, § 4, 12-2-1996; Ord. 
No. 957, § 4, 11-30-1998; Ord. No. 983, § 4, 7-30-2001; Ord. No. 993, § 4, 5-12-2003; Ord. No. 
1019, § 4, 9-25-2006; Ord. No. 1028, § 4, 7-14-2008; Ord. No. 1034, § 4, 6-14-2010; Ord. No. 
1040, § 4, 5-14-2012; Ord. No. 2014-03, § 4, 6-30-2014; Ord. No. 2016-01, § 4, 6-13-2016) 


Sec. 14-154. - Responsibility of parents. 
    It is unlawful for a parent to knowingly permit, or by ineffective or inefficient control, to allow a minor 
under his or her care, custody or control to be or remain upon any city street or public place under any 
circumstances not constituting an exception to, or otherwise beyond the scope of this article. The term 
"knowingly" includes knowledge which a parent should reasonably be expected to have concerning the 
whereabouts of a minor in that parent's legal custody. It is intended to keep neglectful or careless parents 
up to a reasonable community standard of parental responsibility through an objective test. It shall, a 
fortiori, be no defense that a parent was completely indifferent to the activities or conduct or whereabouts 
of his or her minor child. 
(Ord. No. 907, § 5, 5-31-1994; Ord. No. 923, § 5, 8-7-1995; Ord. No. 933, § 5, 12-2-1996; Ord. 
No. 957, § 5, 11-30-1998; Ord. No. 983, § 5, 7-30-2001; Ord. No. 993, § 5, 5-12-2003; Ord. No. 
1019, § 5, 9-25-2006; Ord. No. 1028, § 5, 7-14-2008; Ord. No. 1034, § 5, 6-14-2010; Ord. No. 
1040, § 5, 5-14-2012; Ord. No. 2014-03, § 5, 6-30-2014; Ord. No. 2016-01, § 5, 6-13-2016) 


Sec. 14-155. - Responsibility of owners or operators of public places. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, partnership, corporation or other business entity operating or 
having charge of any establishment or other public place, including any place of amusement, 
entertainment, refreshment or other place of business, other than as specifically authorized by this article, 
to suffer or permit any minor to remain, loiter, loaf or idle in such public place or upon the premises 
thereof during the hours prohibited in section 14-153 of this article. The owner, operator or person in 
charge of such place of business who shall find a minor or minors upon the premises during hours 
prohibited under this article shall order such minor to leave, and if such minor refuses to leave and 
remains upon the premises, the owner or operator of such establishment shall notify the city police 
department of such violation. 
(Ord. No. 907, § 6, 5-31-1994; Ord. No. 923, § 6, 8-7-1995; Ord. No. 933, § 6, 12-2-1996; Ord. 
No. 957, § 6, 11-30-1998; Ord. No. 983, § 6, 7-30-2001; Ord. No. 993, § 6, 5-12-2003; Ord. No. 
1019, § 6, 9-25-2006; Ord. No. 1028, § 6, 7-14-2008; Ord. No. 1034, § 6, 6-14-2010; Ord. No. 
1040, § 6, 5-14-2012; Ord. No. 2014-03, § 6, 6-30-2014; Ord. No. 2016-01, § 6, 6-13-2016) 


Sec. 14-156. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply in the following circumstances, which shall constitute 
valid exemptions to the operation of the curfew: 
(1)	At any time, if a minor is accompanied by his or her parent. 
(2)	When accompanied by an adult authorized by a parent of such minor to take the parent's place 
in accompanying said minor for a designated period of time and purpose within a specified area. 
(3)	Until the hour of 12:00 a.m., if the minor is on a specific errand as directed by his or her parent 
either verbally or in writing. 
(4)	If the minor is legally employed, for the period of thirty (30) minutes before to thirty (30) minutes 
after work, while going directly between his or her home and place of employment. This 
exemption shall also apply if the minor is in a public place during curfew hours in the course of 
his or her employment. In order to avail himself or herself of this exemption, such minor must be 
carrying, on his or her person, a written statement from the employer attesting to the place and 
hours of employment. 
(5)	An emergency affecting life or property which initially serves as a cause for the minor's public 
presence. 
(6)	Until the hour of 12:00 a.m., if the minor is on the property of or on the sidewalk directly 
adjacent to the place where such minor resides or the place immediately adjacent thereto, if the 
owner of the adjacent property does not communicate an objection to the minor and to the city 
police department or an officer or agent thereof. "Immediately adjacent" as used herein shall not 
exceed one hundred (100) feet from the place of the minor's residence. 
(7)	Returning home, by a direct route from, and within thirty (30) minutes of the termination of any 
special function of entertainment or a school activity or activity of a religious or other voluntary 
association or a place of public entertainment, such as a movie, play or sporting event. This 
exception will not apply beyond 11:30 p.m. on Sunday through Thursday, or 12:30 a.m. on 
Saturday and Sunday. If the event is not commercial in nature or does not have a fixed, publicly 
known time at which it will end or does end, the sponsoring organization shall register in 
advance with the chief of police of the city police department or his designee, at least twenty-
four (24) hours in advance, informing the chief, or his designee, of the time which such event is 
scheduled to begin, the place at which it shall be held, the time at which it shall end and the 
name of the sponsoring organization. Any minors who attend such function shall be required to 
be in their homes or usual places of abode within thirty (30) minutes after the special function 
concludes. 
(8)	In the case of reasonable necessity, but only after such minor's parent has communicated to the 
city police department the facts establishing such reasonable necessity relating to the specified 
street or public place at a designated time for a described purpose, including place of origin and 
destination. A copy of such communication or the police record thereof, duly certified by the 
chief to be correct, an appropriate notation of the time it was received and of the names and 
addresses of such parent and minor shall constitute evidence of qualification under this 
exemption. Simple verbal authorization from any law enforcement officer shall not be sufficient 
to claim this exception. 
(9)	When a minor is attending or traveling to or from an activity involving or exercising First 
Amendment rights protected by the United States Constitution, such as the free exercise of 
religion, freedom of speech and the right of assembly. Such minor shall evidence the bona fides 
of such exercise and provide notice to city officials by first delivering to the police department a 
written communication signed by such minor and countersigned, if practicable, by his or her 
parent, specifying his or her home address and telephone number, addressed to the mayor of 
the city and specifying further, when, where and in what manner said minor will be on the 
streets or public places of the city at night during hours when the article is still otherwise 
applicable to said minor, in the exercise of such First Amendment right as is specified in such 
communication. 
(10)	When a minor is, with parental consent, in a motor vehicle engaged in bona fide interstate or 
intrastate travel through the city, particularly on U.S. Highway 61, U.S. Highway 49 and any 
access roads to these major thoroughfares. This exemption shall also apply to interstate travel 
beginning or terminating in the city. 
(11)	When authorized, by special permit from the chief of police carried on the person of the minor 
thus authorized, as follows: when necessary nighttime activities of the juvenile may be 
inadequately provided for by other provisions of this article, then recourse may be had to the 
chief of police, either for a regulation as provided in subsection (l) hereof, or for a special permit, 
as the circumstances warrant. Upon the findings of reasonable necessity for the use of a public 
place to the extent warranted by a written application signed by a juvenile and by the parent of 
the juvenile, if feasible, stating 
a.	The name, age and address of the juvenile; 
b.	The name, address and telephone number of a parent of the juvenile; 
c.	The height, weight, sex, color of eyes and hair and other physical characteristics of the 
juvenile; 
d.	The necessity that requires the juvenile to remain upon a public place during curfew hours 
otherwise applicable; 
e.	The public place; and 
f.	The beginning and ending of a period of time involved by date and hour; 
The chief of police may grant a permit in writing for such juvenile's use of a public [place] at 
such hours as in the opinion of the chief of police may reasonably be necessary and consistent 
with the purposes of this article. In an emergency, this may be handled by telephone or other 
effective communication, with a corresponding record being made contemporaneously to the 
chief of police or the person designated by the chief of police to act upon his behalf in an 
emergency, at the police station. 
(12)	When authorized, by regulation issued by the chief of police and other similar cases of 
reasonable necessity, similarly handled but adopted to reasonably necessary nighttime 
activities of more juveniles than can readily be dealt with on an individual special permit basis. 
Normally, such regulation by the chief of police permitting use of public places should be issued 
sufficiently in advance to permit appropriate publicity through news media and through other 
agencies, such as the schools, and shall define the activity, the scope of the use of the public 
places permitted, the period of time involved not to extend more than one (1) hour beyond the 
time for termination of the activity, and the reason for finding that the regulation is reasonably 
necessary and is consistent with the purposes of this article. 
(13)	When the juvenile is married or has been married pursuant to state law. 
(14)	In the case of an operator of an establishment, when the operator has notified the police that a 
juvenile was present on the premises of the establishment during curfew hours and refused to 
leave. 
(15)	The foregoing exemptions and their several limitations, such as provisions for notification, are 
severable as hereinafter provided, but here reemphasized. Additional, also severable, 
exemptions, broadening with the progress towards maturity of minors enrolled respectively at 
elementary, junior high and high schools, will be considered by the board of mayor and 
commissioners as warranted by future experience illuminated by the use of student government 
associations, school personnel, citizens, associations, ward and/or neighborhood 
spokesperson, parents, juvenile and police officers, youth court officials and persons in authority 
concerned positively with minors, as well as with juvenile delinquency. 
(Ord. No. 907, § 7, 5-31-1994; Ord. No. 923, § 7, 8-7-1995; Ord. No. 933, § 7, 12-2-1996; Ord. 
No. 957, § 7, 11-30-1998; Ord. No. 983, § 7, 7-30-2001; Ord. No. 993, § 7, 5-12-2003; Ord. No. 
1019, § 7, 9-25-2006; Ord. No. 1028, § 7, 7-14-2008; Ord. No. 1034, § 7, 6-14-2010; Ord. No. 
1040, § 7, 5-14-2012; Ord. No. 2014-03, § 7, 6-30-2014; Ord. No. 2016-01, § 7, 6-13-2016) 


Sec. 14-157. - Operator responsibility. 
    It shall be unlawful for any operator of an establishment to knowingly permit a juvenile to remain at 
the establishment under circumstances not constituting an exception, or otherwise beyond the scope of 
this article. The term "knowingly" includes knowledge that an operator should reasonably be expected to 
have concerning the patrons of the establishment. The standard for "knowingly" shall be applied through 
an objective test: whether a reasonable person in the operator's position should have known that the 
patron was juvenile in violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 923, § 8, 8-7-1995; Ord. No. 933, § 8, 12-2-1996; Ord. No. 957, § 8, 11-30-1998; Ord. 
No. 983, § 8, 7-30-2001; Ord. No. 993, § 8, 5-12-2003; Ord. No. 1019, § 8, 9-25-2006; Ord. No. 
1028, § 8, 7-14-2008; Ord. No. 1034, § 8, 6-14-2010; Ord. No. 1040, § 8, 5-14-2012; Ord. No. 
2014-03, § 8, 6-30-2014; Ord. No. 2016-01, § 8, 6-13-2016) 


Sec. 14-158. - Violations. 
(a)	Any law enforcement officer, upon finding a minor in violation of this article, shall ascertain the name 
and address of such minor and warn the minor that he or she is in violation of curfew, and shall direct 
the minor to proceed at once to his or her home or usual place of abode. The law enforcement officer 
shall report such action to the police chief or his designee, who shall in turn, notify the parent, 
guardian or person having custody or control of such minor. 
(b)	If such minor: 
(1)	Refuses to heed such warning or direction by any law enforcement officer; 
(2)	Shall refuse to give such law enforcement officer his or her correct name and address; or 
(3)	If the minor has been warned on any previous occasion that he or she is in violation of curfew; 
    He or she shall be taken to the police department and the parent, guardian or other adult person 
having the care and custody of such minor shall be immediately contacted. If, after this contact, there is 
still probable cause to believe that the minor was violating this article, the minor shall be held until the 
parent comes to the police department to take charge of the minor. When the parent arrives, he or she 
shall be given a copy of this article. If the parent, guardian or other adult person above cannot be located, 
or fails to come and take charge of the minor within two (2) hours, the minor shall be turned over to the 
custody of the juvenile authorities until a parent can take custody of him or her. 
(c)	Any minor violating the provisions of this article may be dealt with in accordance with the Youth 
Court Law of the State of Mississippi, Miss. Code Ann. § 43-21-101 et seq. (1972) or as thereafter 
amended and in accordance with the directives of the Youth Court of Coahoma County, Mississippi 
or such other court, to include but not limited to, the Municipal Court of the City of Clarksdale, as 
shall have jurisdiction over said minor. 
(d)	(1)	In the case of a first violation by a minor, the police chief shall, by certified mail, return receipt 
requested, send to the minor's parent written notice of said violation with a warning that any 
subsequent violation will result in a full enforcement of this article, including enforcement of 
parental responsibility and the application of applicable penalties. Said notice shall be sent to 
the minor's parent at his or her last known address. Evidence of the mailing of the notice 
required hereunder as specified shall constitute sufficient notice of the minor's violation, whether 
actually received by the parent or not; or have the parent execute an acknowledgment of notice 
of first violation by a minor, with a warning that any subsequent violation will result in a full 
enforcement of this article, including enforcement of parental responsibility and the application 
of applicable penalties, and a copy of same shall be provided to the parent. 
(2)	If, after the mailing of the warning notice set forth in section 14-158, subsection (d) (1) above of 
any first violation by a minor, a parent violates this article in connection with a second or 
subsequent offense by a minor, the offending parent, guardian or other adult person having the 
care or custody of the minor subject to the provisions of this article found in violation thereof 
may be fined an amount, not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and costs, or 
imprisoned for not more than ninety (90) days, or subjected to sentencing to the municipal work 
program, for any one (1) or combination of such penalties. Each violation of this article shall 
constitute a separate offense. 
(e)	Any owner, operator or person in charge of a public place who shall violate the provisions of sections 
14-155 and/or 14-157 of this article, shall, upon conviction be fined not less than one hundred dollars 
($100.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and/or be imprisoned for not more than 
ninety (90) days, or both. Each violation hereof shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 907, § 8, 5-31-1994; Ord. No. 923, § 9, 8-7-1995; Ord. No. 933, § 9, 12-2-1996; Ord. 
No. 957, § 9, 11-30-1998; Ord. No. 983, § 9, 7-30-2001; Ord. No. 993, § 9, 5-12-2003; Ord. No. 
1019, § 9, 9-25-2006; Ord. No. 1028, § 9, 7-14-2008; Ord. No. 1034, § 9, 6-14-2010; Ord. No. 
1040, § 9, 5-14-2012; Ord. No. 2014-03, § 9, 6-30-2014; Ord. No. 2016-01, § 9, 6-13-2016) 


Sec. 14-159. - Mississippi Compulsory School Attendance Law enforcement. 
    The city police department shall assist in the enforcement of the Mississippi Compulsory School 
Attendance Law, Miss. Code Ann. § 37-13-91 et seq. (Rev. 2013), or as thereafter amended, with respect 
to identification to compulsory school age children found on the streets or public places within the city 
during regular school hours and shall report violations of the same to the school attendance officer(s). 
(Ord. No. 907, § 9, 5-31-1994; Ord. No. 923, § 10, 8-7-1995; Ord. No. 933, § 10, 12-2-1996; 
Ord. No. 957, § 10, 11-30-1998; Ord. No. 983, § 10, 7-30-2001; Ord. No. 993, § 10, 5-12-2003; 
Ord. No. 1019, § 10, 9-25-2006; Ord. No. 1028, § 10, 7-14-2008; Ord. No. 1034, § 10, 6-14-
2010; Ord. No. 1040, § 10, 5-14-2012; Ord. No. 2014-03, § 10, 6-30-2014; Ord. No. 2016-01, § 
10, 6-13-2016) 


Sec. 14-160. - Construction and severability. 
(a)	Severability is intended throughout and within the provisions of this article. If any provision, including 
inter alia any exception, part, phrase or term or the application thereof to any person or circumstance 
is held invalid, the application to other persons or circumstances shall not be affected thereby, and 
the validity of the article in any and all other respects shall not be affected thereby. The board of 
mayor and commissioners of the city does not intend a result that is absurd, impossible to execute or 
unreasonable. It is intended that the article be held inapplicable in such cases, if any, where its 
application would be unconstitutional. A constitutional construction is intended and shall be given. 
The board of mayor and commissioners of the city does not intend to violate any provisions of the 
Constitution of the United States of America or the Constitution of the State of Mississippi. 
(b)	The mayor, after consultation with the city attorney, is hereby authorized to give advisory opinions in 
writing, which shall be binding and shall be adhered to by the police, until the article is amended in 
such respect, interpreting terms, phrases, parts or any provisions thereof. Normally, such advisory 
opinions shall be in response to good faith, signed letters addressed to the mayor or to a city 
commissioner questioning the article as: 
(1)	Ambiguous; 
(2)	having a potentially chilling effect on constitutional rights specifically invoked; or 
(3)	otherwise invalid, or in all three (3) categories with respect to proposed conduct definitely 
described. 
    This administrative remedy must be exhausted prior to presenting to any court a question in any of 
the three (3) categories. The board of mayor and commissioners does not intend a result through the 
enforcement of the article that is absurd, impossible of execution or unreasonable. The board of mayor 
and commissioners intends that the article be held inapplicable in such cases, if any, where its application 
would be unconstitutional under the Constitution of the State of Mississippi or the Constitution of the 
United States of America. 
(Ord. No. 907, § 10, 5-31-1994; Ord. No. 923, § 11, 8-7-1995; Ord. No. 933, § 11, 12-2-1996; 
Ord. No. 957, § 11, 11-30-1998; Ord. No. 983, § 11, 7-30-2001; Ord. No. 993, § 11, 5-12-2003; 
Ord. No. 1019, § 11, 9-25-2006; Ord. No. 1028, § 11, 7-14-2008; Ord. No. 1034, § 11, 6-14-
2010; Ord. No. 1040, § 11, 5-14-2012;Ord. No. 2014-03, § 11, 6-30-2014; Ord. No. 2016-01, § 
11, 6-13-2016) 


Sec. 14-161. - Continuing evaluation. 
    The board of mayor and commissioners of the city will continue its evaluation and updating of this 
article through means including, but not limited to, receipt of crime statistical reports from the police chief 
concerning crimes committed by and against minors, and of the number of arrests of minors and parents 
hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 907, § 11, 5-31-1994; Ord. No. 923, § 12, 8-7-1995; Ord. No. 933, § 12, 12-2-1996; 
Ord. No. 957, § 12, 11-30-1998; Ord. No. 983, § 12, 7-30-2001; Ord. No. 993, § 12, 5-12-2003; 
Ord. No. 1019, § 12, 9-25-2006; Ord. No. 1028, § 12, 7-14-2008; Ord. No. 1034, § 12, 6-14-
2010; Ord. No. 1040, § 12, 5-14-2012; Ord. No. 2014-03, § 12, 6-30-2014; Ord. No. 2016-01, § 
12, 6-13-2016) 


Sec. 14-162. - Expiration. 
    This article shall expire and be null and void from and after June 30, 2018. This provision, known as 
a "sunset provision", is included herein to ensure that the article, its effectiveness and its necessity, will 
continue to be reviewed by the board of mayor and commissioners of the city from time to time and within 
a reasonable time after its adoption and extension. (Ord. No. 2014-03, § 13, 6-30-2014; Ord. No. 2016-
01, § 13, 6-13-2016) 


Sec. 14-163. - Ordinance cumulative. 
    This ordinance from which this article derives shall be cumulative and in addition to any other laws in 
force. 
(Ord. No. 2014-03, § 14, 6-30-2014; Ord. No. 2016-01, § 14, 6-13-2016) 


Secs. 14-164-14-170. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE VIII. - PUBLIC INDECENCY[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- This article is derived from Ord. No. 1041, adopted May 29, 2012. 


Sec. 14-171. - Prohibited acts. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully perform any of the following acts in a place where a 
person should reasonably expect to be in view of the public: 
(1)	An act or simulated act of sexual intercourse or masturbation; 
(2)	Exposure of the genitals; 
(3)	A lewd appearance in a state of partial or complete nudity; 
(4)	A lewd caress or indecent fondling of the body of another person; 
(5)	A lewd caress or indecent fondling of the sexual organs of any person, including oneself; 
(6)	Urination or defecation; or 
(7)	Appears wearing pants or skirts more than three inches below the top of the hips (crest of the 
ilium) exposing the skin or undergarments. 
(Ord. No. 1041, § 1, 5-29-2012) 


Sec. 14-172. - Fines and penalties. 
    A citation shall be issued to the offender and the person shall be subject to a penalty of not less than 
fifty dollars ($50.00) for the first offense and not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for a 
subsequent offense. In addition to the fine, the Clarksdale Municipal Court may order such person to 
participate in up to forty (40) hours of court approved community services activities. Violators shall not be 
subject to arrest or imprisonment for violation of this section, however, the Clarksdale Municipal Court 
shall have full authority to enforce its orders, judgments and sentences. 
(Ord. No. 1041, § 2, 5-29-2012) 


Sec. 14-173. - Defenses. 
    It is a defense under this section if it is determined, after a hearing or trial, that the person was 
exercising rights protected by the federal or state constitution. Any defense under this section must be 
asserted prior to any hearing or trial in the matter. 
(Ord. No. 1041, § 3, 5-29-2012) 


Chapter 15 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- For municipal authority to acquire property for park purposes, see 1942 Miss. 
Code, § 3374-112; to regulate parks, § 3374-118; to exercise the right of eminent domain to secure land 
for parks, § 3374-128; to exercise full jurisdiction in the matter of parks, § 3374-129; to provide for the 
lighting of parks, § 3374-146. 


Sec. 15-1. - Park commission-Created; membership; compensation; term. 
    Under and by virtue of the authority of 1942 Mississippi Code, sections 3374-158 to 3374-163, there 
is hereby created a park commission to manage all of the parks, playgrounds and swimming pools now or 
hereafter maintained and established in the city. Said commission shall consist of five members to be 
elected by the board of mayor and commissioners of the city. The members of said commission shall be 
qualified electors of the city and shall not hold any other municipal office of honor or profit and shall 
receive no monetary compensation for their services. The terms of office of said commissioners shall be 
for five years each; provided, however, that at the first election of said commissioners under this section, 
one shall be elected for a term of one year, one for a term of two years, one for a term of three years, one 
for a term of four years, and one for a term of five years. The term of office for the first commissioners 
elected shall commence on June 10, 1953, and each of said commissioners shall hold office until their 
successors are duly elected and qualified. The board of mayor and commissioners of the city shall have 
the power to remove any member of the park commission for inefficiency or incompetency or for any 
other cause. 
(Ord. No. 450, § 1, 6-9-1953) 
State Law reference- For municipal authority to create a park commission, prescribe 
qualifications and terms of its members, see 1942 Miss. Code, § 3374-158; for authority to 
remove a member, § 3374-161. 


Sec. 15-2. - Same-Officers, employees; bond of treasurer; depository. 
    The commission provided for by the preceding section shall elect one of its members as treasurer of 
the commission and he shall give bond in such amount as the governing authorities of the city shall 
require, with said bond payable to the city. All funds in the hands of the park commission shall be placed 
in the municipal depository and shall be considered municipal funds. In addition to the election of a 
treasurer the commissioners are authorized to elect such officers and appoint such employees as may be 
necessary to maintain the parks, playgrounds and swimming pools efficiently, and they shall have entire 
control and management of said parks, playgrounds and swimming pools, together with all property 
connected or in any wise appertaining to the same. 
(Ord. No. 450, § 2, 6-9-1953) 
State Law reference- For provisions regarding the organization of the park commission, see 
1942 Miss. Code, § 3374-159. 


Sec. 15-3. - Same-By-laws and regulations. 
    The park commission shall have the authority to make such by-laws for the holding and conducting 
of its meetings and such other regulations as it may deem necessary for the safe, economic and efficient 
management of such parks, playgrounds and swimming pools, and providing for wholesome and healthful 
recreation to all the citizens of the city. 
(Ord. No. 450, § 3, 6-9-1953) 
State Law reference- For authority to make by-laws and enact regulations, see 1942 Miss. 
Code, § 3374-160. 


Sec. 15-4. - Same-Power and duties. 
(a)	Powers. The park commission shall have the following powers: 
(1)	To fix the salaries or wages of all employees and to direct them in the discharge of their duties. 
(2)	To discharge employees, when found inefficient or for other good cause. 
(3)	To make and collect rates for use of the swimming pool and for the use of any other amusement 
device that may be installed in said playground, as well as the leasing of concessions or 
privileges for the sale of cold drinks, confections, popcorn, peanuts or other such articles. 
(4)	To operate such concessions or privileges as set out in subparagraph (3) itself. 
(5)	To insure all property against loss by fire and tornado and to carry public liability, property 
damage or other miscellaneous casualty insurance as in the discretion of said commission may 
be deemed proper, and to pay all premiums therefor out of the funds appropriated by the city or 
out of the revenues derived in the operation of such parks, playgrounds and swimming pools. 
(6)	To exercise full jurisdiction of all funds coming into its possession either by appropriation of the 
city or by gift or by revenue derived from the operation of said parks, playgrounds and 
swimming pools, and to make all contracts in relation to the same. 
(b)	Duties. The park commission shall have the following duties: 
(1)	To report quarterly to the city all its doings and transactions of any kind whatsoever. 
(2)	To make a complete statement of its financial condition at the end of each quarter. 
(3)	To make a statement annually covering the entire management and operation of said parks, 
playgrounds and swimming pools, together with recommendations for the further development 
of such parks, playgrounds and swimming pools. 
(4)	To purchase all supplies for said parks, playgrounds and swimming pools in the manner now 
provided by law for the purchase of such supplies by the city, and to issue vouchers in payment 
therefor. 
(Ord. No. 450, § 2, 6-9-1953) 
State Law reference- For powers and duties of park commission as set forth in state law, see 
1942 Miss. Code, § 3374-159. 


Sec. 15-5. - Park superintendent or manager; powers, duties. 
    The park commission shall have the authority to employ a park superintendent or manager, who 
shall have actual charge of the parks, playgrounds and swimming pools, and the enforcement and 
execution of all the rules, regulations, and the direction of all programs and festivities, and the operation 
of all devices for recreation installed therein. 
(Ord. No. 450, § 3, 6-9-1953) 
State Law reference- For authority to appoint a park superintendent or manager, and an 
outlining of his powers and duties, see 1942 Miss. Code, § 3374-160. 


Sec. 15-6. - Competitive bidding for supplies required; records required. 
    The park commission shall advertise for competitive bids in the purchase of its supplies in the 
manner and in the form required of the governing authorities of the city. Said commission shall make and 
keep full and proper books and records of all purchases and shall submit them in its quarterly and annual 
reports to the city. 
(Ord. No. 450, § 3, 6-9-1953) 
State Law reference- For state law requiring competitive bidding, keeping of records, etc., see 
1942 Miss. Code, § 3374-160. 


Sec. 15-7. - Disposition of revenues. 
    All moneys derived by the park commission from appropriation, gift, revenue or any other source 
shall be devoted by the park commission to the payment of all maintenance and operating expenses, the 
purchase of parks and playground equipment, the repair and replacement thereof and the extension of 
recreational facilities for the wholesome and healthful recreation of all citizens of the city. 
(Ord. No. 450, § 4, 6-9-1953) 
State Law reference- For statute dealing with the disposition of revenues by the park 
commission of a municipality, see 1942 Miss. Code, § 3374-162. 


Sec. 15-8. - Tax levy for parks and playgrounds. 
    The board of mayor and commissioners of the city shall levy and collect not more than two mills 
annually for the purpose of constructing, supporting and maintaining parks and playgrounds and for 
recreational purposes in said city; and the funds so collected shall be used for no other purpose. 
(Ord. No. 450, § 5, 6-9-1953) 
Cross reference- As to tax levies generally, see Ch. 18. 
State Law reference- For authority to levy tax, see 1942 Miss. Code, § 3374-164. 


Chapter 16 - PLUMBING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings, Ch. 6; electricity, Ch. 7; gas, Ch. 10; housing, Ch. 12. 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt plumbing code, 1942 Miss. Code, § 3374-80; to regulate as to

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 


Sec. 16-1. - Provisions of chapter to be certified, filed. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall be certified to by the board of mayor and commissioners of the 
city and shall be filed as a permanent record in the office of the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 390, § 2, 2-10-1948) 


Sec. 16-2. - The International Plumbing Code, 2012 Edition. 
(a)	That a certain document, which is on file in the office of the City Clerk, being marked and designated 
as the International Plumbing Code, 2012 Edition, including Appendix Chapters B-G, as published by 
the International Code Council, be and is hereby adopted as the Plumbing Code of the City of 
Clarksdale, in the State of Mississippi for regulating and governing the design, construction, quality 
of materials, erection, installation, alteration, repair, location, relocation, replacement, addition to, use 
or maintenance of plumbing systems as herein provided; providing for the issuance of permits and 
collection of fees therefor; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and 
terms of said Plumbing Code on file in the office of the City Clerk of the City of Clarksdale, 
Mississippi are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this section, 
with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in subsection (b) of this 
section. 
(b)	That the following sections are hereby revised: 
Section 101.1 City of Clarksdale 
Section 106.6.2. Add: See International Building Code Section 109.2, Schedule of Building Permit 
Fees 
Section 106.6.3. 100% and 100% 
Section 108.4. Misdemeanor, $1,000.00, 90 Days 
Section 108.5. $100.00 and $1,000.00 
Section 109 Delete 
(Ord. No. 516, §§ 1, 2, 5-9-1961; Ord. No. 572, § 1, 12-15-1964; Ord. No. 624, § 1, 12-21-1970; 
Ord. No. 637, § 1, 9-21-1971; Ord. No. 641, § 1, 4-10-1972; Ord. No. 676, § 1, 7-23-1973; Ord. 
No. 730, § 2, 1-22-1979; Ord. No. 743, § 2, 9-24-1979; Ord. No. 781, § 2, 12-27-1982; Ord. No. 
814, § 2, 8-12-1985; Ord. No. 838, § 2, 8-1-1988; Ord. No. 876, § 2, 6-24-1991; Ord. No. 915, § 
2, 11-14-1994; Ord. No. 946, § 2, 10-13-1997; Ord. No. 1006, § 3, 2-14-2005; Ord. No. 2014-09, 
§§ 1, 2, 11-24-2014) 
Cross reference- Building code adopted, § 6-1; swimming pool code adopted, § 6-13.1; 
electrical codes adopted, § 7-33; fire prevention code adopted, § 8-1; gas code adopted, § 10-1, 
housing code adopted, § 12-1, mechanical code adopted, § 13A-1. 


Sec. 16-2.1. - Violation; penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of section 16-2 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of 
Clarksdale, Mississippi, (Standard Plumbing Code), shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction 
thereof, shall be fined not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
State Law reference- Authority of a city to adopt a plumbing code, 1942 Miss. Code, § 3374-
80. 


Sec. 16-3. - Plumbing inspector-Position created; appointment, removal, salary; not to engage in 
plumbing occupation. 
    The position of plumbing inspector of the city is hereby created. Said plumbing inspector shall be 
appointed by the board of mayor and commissioners and shall be subject to removal from employment at 
any time in the discretion of said board, and he shall serve at a monthly salary to be fixed by said board, 
which salary shall be subject to change at the expiration of any monthly period. The plumbing inspector 
shall not engage in the occupation of plumbing, directly or indirectly, while holding such position. The 
plumbing official referred to in Part III, Plumbing, of the Southern Standard Building Code, 1957-58 
Edition [the plumbing code adopted by this chapter], shall be taken to mean the plumbing inspector 
referred to herein. 
(Ord. No. 390, § 1, 2-10-1948) 


Sec. 16-4. - Same-Duties; to issue certificate of compliance. 
    It shall be the duty of the plumbing inspector, under the direction and control of the city engineer, to 
examine all plumbing and drainage work hereafter done for which a permit is necessary, and if the same 
is found to comply with this chapter and with the rules and regulations herein contained, he shall issue a 
certificate in duplicate, stating that the terms of this chapter have been complied with. No such certificate 
shall be issued until such work complies herewith. All work ready for inspection shall be referred to the 
plumbing inspector by the person doing the work, and inspection shall be made if reasonably possible 
within twenty-four (24) hours after such reference. The plumbing inspector in making his inspection shall 
inspect all fixtures connected with the plumbing, such as sewer and water pipes, soil and waste pipes, 
gas pipes and gas heaters, etc. 
(Ord. No. 390, § 1, 2-10-1948)
