Sec. 16-5. - Same-Application for permit, time for approving. 
    An application for a plumbing permit shall be passed upon if possible within two (2) legal working 
days after the inspector receives the application, plans and specifications, and a permit either issued or 
denied. 
(Ord. No. 390, § 1, 2-10-1948) 
Cross reference- For provision requiring certificate from health department before installation 
of disposal system, § 11-55; permit required for connection to sewage system, § 20-26. 


Sec. 16-6. - Same-To be notified when sewer or drain excavated. 
    The plumbing inspector shall be notified when the sewer or drain is excavated and the pipe is laid, 
and in no case shall the sewer or drain be covered or concealed until it has been inspected by the 
plumbing inspector. 
(Ord. No. 390, § 1, 2-10-1948) 


Sec. 16-7. - Same-Right to enter premises, order repairs or removal; interfering with. 
    The plumbing inspector shall, as far as may be necessary for the performance of his duties and for 
the maintenance of the health of the citizens of the city, have the right to enter any building or premises 
within the city limits. The plumbing inspector shall have the right to order the repair or removal when 
necessary of any plumbing fixtures, soil drain or waste pipes that are in an unsanitary condition. Any 
person who shall interfere with him in the performance of such duties shall be deemed to have violated 
this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 390, § 1, 2-10-1948) 


Sec. 16-8. - Final inspection; time for making; suspension authorized. 
    All plumbing and installations shall be reported for final inspection when completed. Any plumber 
who fails to report for final inspection within thirty (30) days after completion shall be subject to 
suspension and no permits will be issued to him until such inspection is made. 
(Ord. No. 390, § 1, 2-10-1948) 


Sec. 16-9. - Inspection fees. 
    A fee of one dollar and fifty cents ($1.50) will be charged for the original inspection of the first fixture 
and twenty-five cents ($0.25) for each additional fixture. This fee is to be paid by the plumber to whom the 
permit is issued and must be paid before or at the time the certificate of acceptance is issued. A fee of 
one dollar ($1.00) will be charged for any reinspection. 
(Ord. No. 390, § 1, 2-10-1948) 


Sec. 16-10. - Enforcement. 
    The provisions of this chapter may be enforced by injunctions taken out in the name of the city, in all 
proper cases. 
(Ord. No. 890, § 1, 2-10-1948) 


Sec. 16-11. - Revocation of license for violations. 
    If any person is convicted three (3) times in any one year of violating any of the provisions of this 
chapter, his license may be revoked by the board of mayor and commissioners, said revocation to be 
effective for one year. 
(Ord. No. 390, § 1, 2-10-1948) 


Sec. 16-12. - Appeals. 
    Appeals may be taken from all decisions of the plumbing inspector to the board of mayor and 
commissioners within ten (10) days from the date of said decision. Said appeals shall be by written 
petitions filed with the board of mayor and commissioners. Appeals from the decision of the board of 
mayor and commissioners, including decision to revoke licenses may be had in the manner now provided 
by law for appeals from other orders by the said board of mayor and commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 390, § 1, 2-10-1948) 


Sec. 16-13. - License and bond required. 
(a)	A person shall not engage in or work at plumbing within the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi, until such 
person shall have secured a license as hereinafter provided, and shall, have executed and delivered 
a good and sufficient bond in the sum prescribed and as required by the administrative authority, 
with corporate surety, conditioned for the faithful performance of all such work, entered upon or 
contracted for, in strict accordance and compliance with the provisions of this Code. 
(b)	Upon approval of said bond, the person desiring to do such work shall secure from the proper 
municipal, county or state authority a license to do business which shall run concurrent with the fiscal 
policy of such authority, unless sooner revoked. 
(c)	Nothing herein contained shall be construed as prohibiting an individual from installing or repairing 
his own plumbing or installing, extending, replacing, altering, or repairing consumer's plumbing on 
his own premises, or as requiring a license or a bond from an individual doing such work on his own 
premises; provided, however, all such work must be done in conformity with all other provisions of 
this code, including those relating to permits, inspections, and fees. 
(Ord. No. 390, § 1, 2-10-1948; Ord. No. 734, § 1, 1-22-1979) 


Secs. 16-14-16-18. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE II. - BOARD OF EXAMINERS FOR PLUMBERS, GAS FITTERS 


Sec. 16-19. - Creation of board. 
    There is hereby created a board for the examination of plumbers and gas fitters, for the examination 
of all plumbers, gas fitters and steam fitters, including natural gas, artificial gas, propane gas and butane 
gas, working at or doing the business of such trades in the city, which said board shall be referred to as 
the board of examiners or simply as the board. 


Sec. 16-20. - Membership, organization, meetings. 
(a)	The board of examiners shall consist of the plumbing inspector for the city, the city engineer and one 
plumber with not less than five years' active and continuous experience. 
(b)	The plumber member shall be appointed by the board of mayor and commissioners and shall serve 
for a period of two years. Any or all members of the board may be removed, for cause, and after a 
hearing, and their places filled by the board of mayor and commissioners. 
(c)	The board shall meet at least once every three months, at a place designated by the board of mayor 
and commissioners, and special meetings may be called by the board of mayor and commissioners 
at any time deemed expedient. The plumbing inspector shall serve as chairman of the board. 
Records shall be kept of all proceedings and of the disposition of all matters coming before it, and 
such records shall be available for public inspection at all times during regular business hours. 
(d)	The members of the board shall receive no compensation for their services as such. 


Sec. 16-21. - Board to examine applicant, issue certificate of registration. 
(a)	It shall be the duty of the board of examiners to examine and pass upon the qualifications of all 
applicants who intend to engage in the business of plumbing, gas fitting or steam fitting within the 
city. Such examination shall satisfy the board as to the applicant's ability and qualifications. 
(b)	The examination shall determine the theoretical and practical knowledge of the applicant, including 
plumbing, house drainage, ventilating and the hazards of gas and steam installations; it shall further 
determine the ability of the applicant to lay out systems for such work in conformity with approved 
practice and with all city and state requirements, including particularly his ability to interpret and 
observe the regulations and provisions of this chapter. 
(c)	If upon the examination of an applicant the board is satisfied as to his fitness and qualifications, it 
shall issue or cause to be issued a certificate to that effect. 
(d)	Every applicant for examination shall pay to the city an examination fee of five dollars before he can 
be qualified to take the examination, and no part of this fee is refundable for any cause. The fee of 
five dollars shall cover the cost of registration and of the certificate for the then fiscal year. 
(e)	Certificates shall be valid for the fiscal year or part thereof during which they are issued and expiring 
on the same date as the privilege license issued to the applicant, and shall be renewed each year, 
the fee for such renewal to be one dollar; provided, however, that if a certificate is not renewed within 
ten days after termination of the term of the previous certificate, then the fee for renewal shall be five 
dollars; and provided further, that if such renewal is not effected within thirty days of such termination 
date, renewal shall not be made without examination and payment of the examination fee. 


Sec. 16-22. - Certificate prerequisite to issuance of license. 
(a)	No person shall be issued a city license for the business of plumbing, steam fitting or gas fitting in 
the city, who does not hold, at the time of his application for city license, a current and valid 
certificate as required by this article; provided, however, that this section shall not be interpreted to 
prevent partnerships, firms or corporations from having members who do not hold certificates; and 
provided further, that the application and the city license shall be in the name of the holder of the 
certificate. 
(b)	A city license shall not be issued to any person upon a certificate not his own; and it shall be unlawful 
for any person to permit the use of his certificate by any person other than himself, for any purpose. 
Cross reference- For amount of license, see local privilege tax schedule, adopted in § 13-1. 


Sec. 16-23. - Board empowered to revoke certificate. 
(a)	It shall be the duty of the board of examiners to revoke or cause to be revoked the certificate of any 
person for any one or more of the following reasons: 
(1)	Willful misstatements in the application for examination; 
(2)	False statements in the application for city license; 
(3)	Permitting use of a certificate by any person other than himself; 
(4)	Persistent refusal or neglect to comply with this chapter; 
(5)	Any other act intended to vitiate the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)	The revocation of a certificate shall not operate to bar any further remedy or action at law that might 
be invoked by the city. 
Cross reference- As to revocation of plumbing license, § 16-11. 


Chapter 17 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Provision prohibiting bicycles being operated on sidewalks, § 5-9; prohibition against 
billboards on public property, § 14-2; against driving across sidewalks, § 14-38; traffic requirements 
generally, Ch. 19. 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to cause construction and tax for cost, 1942 Miss. Code, § 
3374-126; to close, vacate, § 3374-127; to exercise power of eminent domain regarding, § 3374-128; to 
regulate, § 3374-129. 


ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 


Sec. 17-1. - Duty of abutting owners, lessees to maintain, repair sidewalks. 
    All lot owners or lessees shall be required to keep the walks along and in front of their premises in 
good condition and repair. Any person violating this section shall be punished by a fine in any sum not 
exceeding ten dollars ($10.00) or by imprisonment in the city jail not exceeding thirty days, or by both 
such fine and imprisonment. 
(Code, 1922, § 211) 


Sec. 17-2. - Obstructing with merchandise, refuse, etc., or in any other manner; penalty. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct any public street, sidewalk or alley within the city by 
placing or leaving thereon any merchandise, box, barrel, refuse matter or any other article, or to obstruct 
any of said streets, sidewalks or alleys in any other manner whatsoever. Any person violating any of the 
provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not less than ten dollars 
($10.00) nor more than fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(Code, 1922, §§ 212, 213) 
Cross reference- For prohibition against train obstructing crossings, see § 19-102. 


Sec. 17-2.1. - Parades, processions or other public demonstrations. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful to organize or hold, or to assist in organizing or holding, or to take part or 
participate in, any parade or procession or other public demonstration on the streets or other public 
ways of the city, unless a permit therefor has been secured from the chief of police of the city. 
(b)	To secure such permit, written application shall be made to the chief of police of the city, setting forth 
the probable number of persons, vehicles and animals which will be engaged in such parade, 
procession or other public demonstration, the purpose for which it is to be held or had, and the 
streets or other public ways over, along or in which it is desired to have or hold such parade, 
procession or other public demonstration. 
(c)	The chief of police of the city shall grant a written permit for such parade, procession or other public 
demonstration, prescribing the streets or other public ways which may be used therefor, if he finds 
that the convenience of the public in the use of the streets would not thereby be unduly disturbed. 
(d)	No permit shall be granted under this section for a parade, procession or other public demonstration 
to begin before 9:00 a.m. or to be held between 11:30 a.m. to 1:30 p.m., or 5:00 p.m. to 6:00 p.m., or 
to terminate after 8:00 p.m. 
(e)	No permit shall be granted under this section for a parade, procession or other public demonstration 
over, along or in Second Street, or over, along or in Yazoo Street between First Street and Third 
Street, except by no more than six (6) persons at one time, all of whom shall remain on the 
sidewalks. However, such parades, processions and other public demonstrations may cross Second 
Street and Yazoo Street at regular intersections. 
(f)	Every applicant for a permit shall deposit in advance for such permit, for the use of the city in 
defraying the special expenses actually incurred incident to the administration of this ordinance and 
to the maintenance of public order in the matter permitted, the sum of two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
Any part of said two hundred dollars ($200.00) not needed for defraying the special expenses 
actually incurred incident to the administration of this ordinance and to the maintenance of public 
order in the matter permitted, shall be refunded to the applicant within a reasonable time after the 
termination of the matter permitted. 
(g)	Participants in such parades, processions or other public demonstrations shall conduct themselves 
in the following manner: 
(1)	All persons walking will line up no more than 4 abreast in right hand lane of traffic in units of 100 
or less, with an interval of 15 feet being maintained between units. 
(2)	All traffic directions at intersections along the route of march and directions of police officers will 
be obeyed. 
(3)	All persons covered by the permit will adhere strictly to the designated route. 
(4)	All persons involved shall conduct themselves in an orderly manner, and no profanity will be 
used. 
(5)	All persons covered by the permit must assemble at the prescribed area and accompany the 
march only on the sidewalks and/or streets designated and in formation. 
(6)	Any person not in formation will not be covered by the permit. 
(h)	This section shall not apply to funeral processions which are supervised, managed and directed by a 
licensed funeral home doing business in the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi. 
(i)	If an application for a permit is denied, after the filing of a proper application therefor, the applicant 
shall have the right to have the board of mayor and commissioners of the City of Clarksdale consider 
the application immediately, and to pass on whether the requested permit should be issued or not, 
by filing with the clerk of such board a written request for a review of the action of the chief of police 
with respect to the application. Such review shall be held within twenty-four (24) hours after the filing 
of such request with the clerk of said board, and the applicant shall have the right to appear thereat 
and to present proof in support of the application for the permit. The said board shall, without delay, 
pass on the question of whether the permit should be issued or not, and should it be of the opinion 
that such permit should be issued, the same shall be issued forthwith, upon the deposit of the fee 
herein required. 
(Ord. No. 549, §§ 1, 2, 6-4-1963; Ord. No. 618, § 1, 11-23-1970; Ord. No. 633, §§ 1-6, 8, 8-16-
1971) 
Amendment note- Ord. No. 633, §§ 1-6, 8, amended § 17-2.1 to read as set out. 


Sec. 17-3. - Width, grades, curbing of sidewalks. 
(a)	The width of all sidewalks on all streets and avenues which are seventy feet or more in width, is 
hereby fixed as and is to be fourteen feet from the property line to the outside of the curbline, and to 
this point gutters or drains may be cut, dug and maintained. 
(b)	The width of all sidewalks on streets and avenues which are less than seventy feet in width shall be 
twelve feet from the property line to the outside of the curbline and up to this point, gutters or drains 
may be cut, dug and maintained. 
(c)	Whenever concrete or other walks of like character shall be laid between the property line and the 
curbline on any street or avenue, the sidewalks shall be of a uniform width of six feet, and they shall 
not extend to a point nearer than two feet from the property line. 
(d)	All sidewalks shall be laid on such grades and all curbing shall be fixed at and of such an elevation, 
depth and grade as may from time to time be fixed by order of the mayor and board of 
commissioners, and under the direction of such engineer or representative of the city as may from 
time to time be designated. 
(e)	Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be fined not less than ten dollars 
($10.00) nor more than fifty dollars ($50.00) for each violation thereof, and each day's violation of 
this section shall be a separate and distinct offense punishable as such. All walks and curbings 
hereafter constructed in violation of this section shall be deemed and declared a public nuisance, 
and shall be removed and abated as such by the chief of police of the city. 
(Code 1922, §§ 214, 215) 


Sec. 17-4. - Gates opening onto streets, sidewalks prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person who shall maintain a gate along any street upon which a sidewalk 
is laid, to keep or maintain any gate which shall open out upon any such sidewalk, and to open out upon 
any sidewalks any such gate kept or maintained by any such person. The occupant of all houses and 
premises shall be responsible for any violation of this section. 
    Each day's violation of this section shall constitute a separate offense. Every person who shall 
violate the provisions of this section shall be fined not less than one dollar ($1.00) nor more than ten 
dollars ($10.00) for each offense. 
(Code 1922, § 216) 


Sec. 17-5. - Defacing streets, sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to paint or mark upon the sidewalks or pavements of the city or to 
make any signs, writings or other device thereon. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall 
be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be fined not less than ten dollars ($10.00) 
nor more than fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(Code 1922, § 219) 


Sec. 17-6. - Tractors and similar vehicles prohibited on paved streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or cause to be driven or operated any tractor or other 
vehicle equipped with wheels with metal flanges or cleats thereor, upon any of the paved streets or alleys 
of the city. 
(Ord. No. 256, § 2, 9-10-1929) 


Sec. 17-7. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 906, adopted March 21, 1994, has been codified as superseding § 17-
7, and designated as §§ 21A-21-21A-38. Formerly, § 17-7 pertained to cutting trees on streets 
and derived from Ord. No. 602, adopted Sept. 9, 1968, and Ord. No. 691, adopted July 29, 1974. 


Sec. 17-8. - Obstructing sidewalks or streets; penalty. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful for any persons to gather or congregate on the streets or sidewalks of the City of 
Clarksdale, Mississippi, or any highway within said city, in such numbers as to interfere with free and 
unrestricted ingress into and egress from any place of business in said city, or so as to impede the 
movement of traffic in the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi. Any person who joins, or persons who join, 
in such gathering, or who are a part of said gathering or congregating, shall be guilty of a 
misdemeanor. 
(b)	Any person violating this section shall be punishable by a fine not exceeding one hundred dollars 
($100.00) for each offense. 
(Ord. No. 608, §§ 1, 2, 6-16-1969) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 608 was not amendatory of this Code and was codified as § 17-8 at the 
discretion of the editors. 


Secs. 17-9-17-18. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE II. - EXCAVATIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 727, §§ 1-42, enacted Aug. 28, 1978 was nonamendatory to the Code and 
therefore included as Art. II, §§ 17-19-17-60 at the editor's discretion. 


Sec. 17-19. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Street Excavation Ordinance of the City of 
Clarksdale, Mississippi." 
(Ord. No. 727, § 1, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-20. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations shall have 
the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense 
include the future, words in the plural number include the singular number, and words in the singular 
number include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
(1)	Applicant is any person making written application to the city engineer for an excavation permit 
hereunder. 
(2)	City is the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi. 
(3)	City board or board is the board of mayor and commissioners of the City of Clarksdale, 
Mississippi. 
(4)	City engineer is the city engineer of the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi. 
(5)	Excavation work is the excavation and other work permitted under an excavation permit and 
required to be performed under this article. 
(6)	Permittee is any person who has been granted and has in full force and effect an excavation 
permit issued hereunder. 
(7)	Person is any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of 
any kind. 
(8)	Street is any street, highway, sidewalk, alley, avenue, or other public way or public grounds in 
the city. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 2, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-21. - Excavation permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to dig up, break, excavate, tunnel, undermine or in any manner 
break up any street or to make or cause to be made any excavation in or under the surface of any street 
for any purpose or to place, deposit or leave upon any street any earth or other excavated material 
obstructing or tending to interfere with the free use of the street, unless such person shall first have 
obtained an excavation permit therefor from the city engineer as herein provided. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 3, 7-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-22. - Application for permit. 
    No excavation permit shall be issued unless a written application for the issuance of an excavation 
permit is submitted to the city engineer. The written application shall state the name and address of the 
applicant, the nature, location and purpose of the excavation, the date of commencement and date of 
completion of the excavation, and other data as may reasonably be required by the city engineer. The 
application shall be accompanied by plans showing the extent of the proposed excavation work, the 
dimensions and elevations of both the existing ground prior to said excavation and of the proposed 
excavated surfaces, the location of the excavation work, and such other information as may be prescribed 
by the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 4, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-23. - Excavation permit fees. 
    A permit fee shall be charged by the city engineer for the issuance of an excavation permit which 
shall be in addition to all other fees for permits or charges relative to any proposed construction work. The 
excavation permit fee shall be in the amount varying with the type of surface to be opened, dug or 
excavated under the permit issued as follows: 
(a)	On unpaved streets, including dirt and gravel, one dollar ($1.00). 
(b)	On streets paved with cement concrete base or cement concrete two dollars ($2.00). 
(c)	On streets paved with asphalt concrete and bitulithic on broken rock, two dollars ($2.00). 
(Ord. No. 727, § 5, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-24. - Excavation placard. 
    The city engineer shall provide each permittee at the time a permit is issued hereunder a suitable 
placard plainly written or printed in English letters at least one inch high with the following notice: "City of 
Clarksdale Permit No. ____________ , Expires ____________ ." and in the first blank space there shall 
be inserted the number of said permit and after word "expires" shall be stated the date when said permit 
expires. It shall be the duty of any permittee hereunder to keep the placard posted in a conspicuous place 
at the site of the excavation work. It shall be unlawful for any person to exhibit such placard at or about 
any excavation not covered by such permit, or to misrepresent the number of the permit or the date of 
expiration of the permit. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 6, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-25. - Surety bond. 
    Before an excavation permit as herein provided is issued, the applicant shall deposit with the city 
clerk a surety bond payable to the city in such amount as the city engineer shall find reasonably 
necessary to protect the best interests of the city, subject to appeal to the board of mayor and 
commissioners. The required surety bond must be: 
(a)	With good and sufficient surety; 
(b)	By a surety company authorized to transact business in the state; 
(c)	Satisfactory to the city attorney in form and substance; 
(d)	Conditioned upon the permittee's compliance with this section and to secure and to hold the city 
and its officers harmless against any and all claims, judgments, or other costs arising from the 
excavation and other work covered by the excavation permit or for which the city, the city 
council or any city officer may be made liable by reason of any accident or injury to persons or 
property through the fault of the permittee either in not properly guarding the excavation or for 
any other injury resulting from the negligence of the permittee, and further conditioned to fill up, 
restore and place in good and safe condition as near as may be to its original condition, and to 
the satisfaction of the city engineer, all openings and excavations made in streets, and to 
maintain any street where excavation is made in as good condition for the period of twelve (12) 
months after said work shall have been done, usual wear and tear excepted, as it was in before 
said work shall have been done. Any settlement of the surface within said one-year period shall 
be deemed conclusive evidence of defective backfilling by the permittee. Nothing herein 
contained shall be construed to require the permittee to maintain any repairs to pavement made 
by the city if such repairs should prove defective. Any owner of real estate repairing or engaging 
another to repair his own sidewalk shall not be required to give such bond. Recovery on such 
bond for any injury or accident shall not exhaust the bond but it shall in its entirety cover any or 
all future accidents or injuries during the excavation work for which it is given. In the event of 
any suit or claim against the city by reason of the negligence or default of the permittee, upon 
the city's giving written notice to the permittee of such suit or claim, any final judgment against 
the city requiring it to pay for such damage shall be conclusive upon the permittee and his 
surety. An annual bond may be given under this provision which shall remain in force for one 
year conditioned as above, in the amount specified above and in other respects as specified 
above but applicable as to all excavation work in streets by the principal in such bond during the 
term of one year from said date. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 7, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-26. - Cash deposits. 
    The application for an excavation permit to perform excavation work under this article shall be 
accompanied with a cash deposit, made to the city engineer for deposit with the city treasurer, as follows: 
a sum equal to one dollar ($1.00) per square foot of surface of each excavation to be made in streets 
which have been paved; a sum equal to fifty cents ($0.50) for each square foot of surface of each such 
excavation to be made in streets which are not paved. No deposit shall be less than fifty dollars ($50.00). 
Any person intending to make openings, cuts or excavation in streets may make and maintain with the 
city treasurer a general deposit in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), and the person so 
depositing shall not be required to make the special deposits provided in this section but shall, however, 
be required to comply with all other applicable provisions of this article. Any special or general deposit 
made hereunder shall serve as security for the repair and performance of work necessary to put the 
street in as good a condition as it was prior to the excavation if the permittee fails to make the necessary 
repairs or to complete the proper refilling of the opening and the excavation work under the excavation 
permit. Upon the permittee's completion of the work covered by such permit in conformity with this article 
as determined by the city engineer, two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of such cash deposit, except in the case of an 
annual deposit, shall be promptly refunded by the city to the permittee and the balance shall be refunded 
by the city to the permittee upon the expiration of such twelve-month period; provided, however, that as to 
any annual deposit two-thirds ( 2/3 ) thereof shall be refunded by the city at the end of the one-year 
period for which the deposit is made of the satisfactory period, whichever is later, and the balance of the 
annual deposit shall be refunded at the expiration of a twelve-month period following the completion of 
such excavation work; and provided further that the city may use any or all of any such deposit to pay the 
cost of any work the city performs to restore or maintain the street as herein provided in the event the 
permittee fails to perform such work, in which event the amount refunded to the permittee shall be 
reduced by the amount thus expended by the city. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 8, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-27. - Routing of traffic. 
    The permittee shall take appropriate measures to assure that during the performance of the 
excavation work traffic conditions as nearly normal as practicable shall be maintained at all times so as to 
cause as little inconvenience as possible to the occupants of the abutting property and to the general 
public, provided that the city engineer may permit the closing of streets to all traffic for a period of time 
prescribed by him if in his opinion it is necessary. The permittee shall route and control traffic including its 
own vehicles as directed by the city police department. The following steps shall be taken before any 
street may be closed or restricted to traffic: 
(a)	The permittee must receive the approval of the city engineer and the police department therefor; 
(b)	The permittee must notify the chief of the fire department and any ambulance service, public or 
private, which operates within the city limits of any street so closed; 
(c)	Upon completion of construction work the permittee shall notify the city engineer and city police 
department before traffic is moved back to its normal flow so that any necessary adjustments 
may be made; 
(d)	Where flagmen are deemed necessary by the city engineer they shall be furnished by the 
permittee at its own expense. Through traffic shall be maintained without the aid of detours, if 
possible. In instances in which this would not be feasible the city engineer will designate 
detours. The city shall maintain roadway surfaces of existing streets designated as detours 
without expense to the permittee but in case there are no existing streets the permittee shall 
construct all detours at its expense and in conformity with the specifications of the city engineer. 
The permittee will be responsible for any unnecessary damage caused to any streets by the 
operation of its equipment. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 9, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-28. - Clearance for fire equipment. 
    The excavation work shall be performed and conducted so as not to interfere with access to fire 
stations and fire hydrants. Materials or obstructions shall not be placed within fifteen (15) feet of fire 
plugs. Passageways leading to fire escapes or firefighting equipment shall be kept free of piles of 
materials or other obstructions. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 10, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-29. - Protection of traffic. 
    The permittee shall erect and maintain suitable timber barriers to confine earth from trenches or 
other excavations in order to encroach upon streets as little as possible. The permittee shall construct 
and maintain adequate and safe crossings over excavations and across streets under improvement to 
accommodate vehicular and pedestrian traffic at all street intersections. Vehicular crossings shall be 
constructed and maintained of plank, timbers and blocking of adequate size to accommodate vehicular 
traffic safely. Decking shall be not less than four (4) inches thick and shall be securely fastened together 
with heavy wire and staples. Pedestrian crossings shall consist of planking three (3) inches thick, twelve 
(12) inches wide and of adequate length, together with necessary blocking. The walk shall be not less 
than three (3) feet in width and shall be provided with a railing as required by the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 11, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-30. - Removal and protection of utilities. 
    The permittee shall not interfere with any existing utility without the written consent of the city 
engineer and the utility company or person owning the utility. If it becomes necessary to remove an 
existing utility this shall be done by its owner. No utility owned by the city shall be moved to accommodate 
the permittee unless the cost of such work be borne by the permittee. The cost of moving privately owned 
utilities shall be similarly borne by the permittee unless it makes other arrangements with the person 
owning the utility. The permittee shall support and protect by timbers or otherwise all pipes, conduits, 
poles, wires or other apparatus which may be in any way affected by the excavation work, and do 
everything necessary to support, sustain and protect them under, over, along or across said work. In case 
any of said pipes, conduits, poles, wires or apparatus should be damaged, they shall be repaired by the 
agency or person owning them and the expense of such repairs shall be charged to the permittee and his 
or its bond shall be liable therefor. The permittee shall be responsible for any damage done to any public 
or private property by reason of breaking of any water pipes, sewer, gas pipe, electric conduit or other 
utility and its bond shall be liable therefor. 
    Prior to applying for an excavation permit as provided in this article, the permittee shall inform itself 
as to the existence and location of all underground utilities, and shall indicate the same on the plan of 
excavation submitted with the application for the excavation permit. Prior to the commencement of any 
excavation work, the permittee shall notify the utility company or person owning the utility of any existing 
utility which lies within the location or area of the proposed excavation work for the purpose of protecting 
the utility from damage. Thereafter, the utility company or person owning the utility, upon receiving such 
advance notification, shall, within a reasonable time, but not more than forty-eight (48) hours after said 
notification make investigation to determine the location of its utility in the location or area of the proposed 
excavation work, and mark by some reasonable and customary means the location of such utility in or 
near the location or area of the proposed excavation work so as to enable the permittee or other persons 
engaged in such excavation work to locate said utility in advance of and during such excavation work, or 
shall advise the permittee that marking is not necessary. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 12, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-31. - Protection of adjoining property. 
    The permittee shall at all times and at his or its own expense preserve and protect from injury any 
adjoining property by providing proper foundations and taking other measures suitable for the purpose. 
Where in the protection of such property it is necessary to enter upon private property for the purpose of 
taking appropriate protective measures, the permittee shall obtain a license from the owner of such 
private property for such purpose and if he cannot obtain a license from such owner the city engineer may 
authorize him to enter the private premises solely for the purpose of making the property safe. The 
permittee shall, at its own expense shore up and protect all buildings, walls, fences or other property likely 
to be damaged during the progress of the excavation work and shall be responsible for all damage to 
public or private property or streets resulting from its failure properly to protect and carry out said work. 
Whenever it may be necessary for the permittee to trench through any lawn area, the sod shall be 
carefully cut and rolled and replaced after ditches have been back filled as required in this article. All 
construction and maintenance work shall be done in a manner calculated to leave the lawn area clean of 
earth and debris and in a condition as nearly as possible to that which existed before such work began. 
The permittee shall not remove even temporarily any trees or shrubs which exist in parking strip areas or 
easements across private property without first having notified and obtained the consent of the property 
owner, or in the case of public property the appropriate city department or city official having control of 
such property. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 13, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-32. - Sidewalk excavations. 
    Any excavation made in any sidewalk or under a sidewalk shall be provided with a substantial and 
adequate footbridge over said excavation on the line of the sidewalk, which bridge shall be at least three 
(3) feet wide and securely railed on each side so that foot passengers can pass over safely at all times. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 14, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-33. - Protective measures. 
    The permittee shall erect such fence, railing or barriers about the site of the excavation work as shall 
prevent danger to persons using the city street or sidewalks, and such protective barriers shall be 
maintained until the work shall be completed or the danger removed. At twilight there shall be placed 
upon such place of excavation and upon any excavated materials or structures or other obstructions to 
streets suitable and sufficient lights which shall be kept burning throughout the night during the 
maintenance of such obstructions. It shall be unlawful for any one to remove or tear down the fence or 
railing or other protective barriers or any lights provided there for the protection of the public. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 15, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-34. - Attractive nuisance. 
    It shall be unlawful for the permittee to suffer or permit to remain unguarded at the place of 
excavation or opening any machinery, equipment or other device having the characteristics of an 
attractive nuisance likely to attract children and hazardous to their safety or health. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 16, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-35. - Care of excavated materials. 
    All material excavated from trenches and piled adjacent to the trench or in any street shall be piled 
and maintained in such manner as not to endanger those working in the trench, pedestrians or users of 
the streets, and so that as little inconvenience as possible is caused to those using streets and adjoining 
property. Where the confines of the area being excavated are too narrow to permit the piling of excavated 
material beside the trench, such as might be the case in a narrow alley, the city engineer shall have the 
authority to require that the permittee haul the excavated material to a storage site and then rehaul it to 
the trench site at the time of backfilling. It shall be the permittee's responsibility to secure the necessary 
permission and make all necessary arrangements for all required storage and disposal sites. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 17, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-36. - Damage to existing improvements. 
    All damage done to existing improvements during the progress of the excavation work shall be 
repaired by the permittee. Materials for such repair shall conform with the requirements of any applicable 
code or ordinance. If upon being ordered the permittee fails to furnish the necessary labor and materials 
for such repairs, the city engineer shall have the authority to cause said necessary labor and materials to 
be furnished by the city and the cost shall be charged against the permittee, and the permittee shall also 
be liable on his or its bond therefor. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 18, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-37. - Property lines and easements. 
    Property lines and limits of easements shall be indicated on the plan of excavation submitted with the 
application for the excavation permit and it shall be the permittee's responsibility to confine excavation 
work within these limits. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 19, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-38. - Cleanup. 
    As the excavation work progresses all streets and private properties shall be thoroughly cleaned of 
all rubbish, excess earth, rock and other debris resulting from such work. All clean-up operations at the 
location of such excavation shall be accomplished at the expense of the permittee and shall be completed 
to the satisfaction of the city engineer. From time to time as may be ordered by the city engineer and in 
any event immediately after completion of said work, the permittee shall at his or its own expense clean 
up and remove all refuse and unused materials of any kind resulting from said work and upon failure to do 
so within twenty-four (24) hours after having been notified to do so by the city engineer, said work may be 
done by the city engineer and the cost thereof charged to the permittee, and the permittee shall also be 
liable for the cost thereof under the surety bond provided hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 20, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-39. - Protection of water courses. 
    The permittee shall provide for the flow of all water courses, sewers or drains intercepted during the 
excavation work and shall replace the same in as good condition as it found them or shall make such 
provisions for them as the city engineer may direct. The permittee shall not obstruct the gutter of any 
street but shall use all proper measures to provide for the free passage of surface water. The permittee 
shall make provisions to take care of all surplus water, muck, silt, slickings or other runoff pumped from 
excavations or resulting from sluicing or other operations and shall be responsible for any damage 
resulting from its failure to so provide. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 21, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-40. - Breaking through pavement. 
    Whenever it is necessary to break through existing pavement for excavation purposes and where 
trenches are to be four (4) feet or over in depth, the pavement in the base shall be removed to at least six 
(6) inches beyond the outer limits of the subgrade that is to be disturbed in order to prevent settlement, 
and a six-inch shoulder of undisturbed material shall be provided in each side of the excavated trench. 
The face of the remaining pavement shall be approximately vertical. A power driven concrete saw shall 
be used so as to permit complete breakage of concrete pavement or base without ragged edges. Asphalt 
paving shall be scored or otherwise cut in a straight line. No pile driver may be used in breaking up the 
pavement. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 22, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-41. - Tunnels. 
    Tunnels under pavement shall not be permitted except by permission of the city engineer and if 
permitted shall be adequately supported by timbering and backfilling under the direction of the city 
engineer. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 23, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-42. - Backfilling. 
    Backfilling in any street opened or excavated pursuant to an excavation permit issued hereunder 
shall be compacted to a degree equivalent to that of the undisturbed ground in which the trench was dug. 
Compacting shall be done by mechanical tappers or vibrators, by rolling in layers or by water settling, as 
required by the soil in question and sound engineering practices generally recognized in the construction 
industry. The decision as to whether a trench shall be backfilled by water settling shall be based upon 
such engineering practices and shall be made by the city engineer. When water is taken from a fire 
hydrant the permittee shall assign one man to operate the hydrant and shall make certain that said man 
had been instructed by the city water department in the operation of the hydrant. The city water 
department shall likewise be notified at both the beginning and end of the job so that the condition of the 
fire hydrants can be checked on both occasions. Any damage done to the hydrant during the excavation 
shall be the responsibility of the permittee. Water shall be paid for by the permittee on the terms agreed 
upon with the city water department. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 24, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-43. - Backfilling by water settling. 
    When backfilling is done by water settling, excavated materials above utility installations shall be 
deposited uniformly in layers of not more than five (5) feet in thickness and shall be thoroughly flooded. 
During the flooding the water shall be allowed to flow slowly to the trench from high points and shall be 
worked down to the full depth of the layer of backfill with bars. All bars used shall be long enough to 
extend entirely through the layer being filled and shall be forced down through the layer being filled and 
shall be forced down through the loose backfill material. As the bars are withdrawn the water shall be 
allowed to flow downward around the bar. The channel or hole formed by the bar shall be kept open and 
the water kept running into it until the fill has settled. All work shall be done in such manner as to obtain a 
relative compaction through the entire depth of the backfill of not less than that existing adjacent to the 
excavation. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 25, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-44. - Dry backfilling. 
    Backfilling up to the first eighteen (18) inches above the top of the utility pipes or similar installations 
shall be done with thin layers. Each layer is to be tamped by manual or mechanical means. Layers that 
are hand tamped shall not exceed four (4) inches in thickness. Layers that are power tamped shall not 
exceed six (6) inches in thickness. The same requirements shall apply to the remainder of the backfilling 
if tamping is the method used for backfilling. Backfilling of all pipes of over twenty-four (25) inches in 
diameter shall be carried up to the spring line of the pipe in three-inch layers, with each layer moistened 
and thoroughly tamped with suitable mechanical equipment. The backfill around all pipes twenty-four (24) 
inches or less in diameter shall be flooded or tamped as specified above to a depth of eighteen (18) 
inches above the top of the pipe before any additional backfilling is placed thereon. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 26, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-45. - Backfill material. 
    Whenever any excavation for the laying of pipe is made through rock, the pipe shall be laid six (6) 
inches above the rock bottom of the trench and the space under, around and six (6) inches above the 
pipe shall be backfilled with clean river sand, noncorrosive soil or one-quarter (1/4) inch minus gravel. 
Broken pavement, large stones and debris shall not be used in the backfill. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 27, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-46. - Backfilling at the surface. 
    Backfilling shall be completed by placing the backfill material well up over the top of the trench. For 
dry backfilling, the material shall be compacted with a roller of an approved type or with the rear of a truck 
carrying at least five (5) tons until the surface is unyielding. The surface shall then be graded as required. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 28, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-47. - Restoration of surface. 
    The permittee shall restore the surface of all streets, broken into or damaged as a result of the 
excavation work, to its original condition in accordance with the specifications of the city engineer. The 
permittee may be required to place a temporary surface over openings made in paved traffic lanes. 
Except when the pavement is to be replaced before the opening of the cut to traffic, the fill above the 
bottom of the paving slab shall be made with suitable material well tamped into place and this fill shall be 
topped with a minimum of at least one inch of bituminous mixture which is suitable to maintain the 
opening in good condition until permanent restoration can be made. The crown of the temporary 
restoration shall not exceed one inch above the adjoining pavement. The permittee shall exercise special 
care in making such temporary restorations and must maintain such restorations in safe traveling 
condition until such time as permanent restorations are made. The asphalt which is used shall be in 
accordance with the specifications of the city engineer. If in the judgment of the city engineer it is not 
expedient to replace the pavement over any cut or excavation made in the street upon completion of the 
work allowed under such permit by reason of the looseness of the earth or weather conditions he may 
direct the permittee to lay a temporary pavement of wood or other suitable material designated by him 
over such cut or excavation to remain until such time as the repair of the original pavement may be 
properly made. 
    Permanent restoration of the street shall be made by the permittee in strict accordance with the 
specifications prescribed by the city engineers to restore the street to its original and proper condition, or 
as near as may be. 
    Acceptance or approval of any excavation work by the city engineer shall not prevent the city from 
asserting a claim against the permittee and his or its surety under the surety bond required hereunder for 
incomplete or defective work if discovered within twelve (12) months from the completion of the 
excavation work. The city engineer's presence during the performance of any excavation work shall not 
relieve the permittee of its responsibilities hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 29, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-48. - City's right to restore surface. 
    If the permittee shall have failed to restore the surface of the street to its original and proper 
condition upon the expiration of the time fixed by such permit or shall otherwise have failed to complete 
the excavation work covered by such permit, the city engineer, if he deems it advisable, shall have the 
right to do all work and things necessary to restore the street and to complete the excavation work. The 
permittee shall be liable for the actual cost thereof and twenty-five (25) per cent of such cost in addition 
for general overhead and administrative expenses. The city shall have a cause of action for all fees, 
expenses and amounts paid out and due it for such work and shall apply in payment of the amount due it 
any funds of the permittee deposited as herein provided and the city shall also enforce its rights under the 
permittee's surety bond provided pursuant to this article. 
    It shall be the duty of the permittee to guarantee and maintain the site of the excavation work in the 
same condition it was prior to the excavation for two (2) years after restoring it to its original condition. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 30, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-49. - Trenches in pipe laying. 
    Except by special permission from the city engineer, no trench shall be excavated more than two 
hundred fifty (250) feet in advance of pipe laying nor left unfilled more than five hundred (500) feet where 
pipe has been laid. The length of the trench that may be opened at any one time shall not be greater than 
the length of pipe and the necessary accessories which are available at the site ready to be put in place. 
Trenches shall be braced and sheathed according to generally accepted safety standards for construction 
work as prescribed by the city engineer. No timber bracing, lagging, sheathing or other lumber shall be 
left in any trench. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 31, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-50. - Prompt completion of work. 
    The permittee shall prosecute with diligence and expedition all excavation work covered by the 
excavation permit and shall promptly complete such work and restore the street to its original condition, or 
as near as may be, as soon as practicable and in any event not later than the date specified in the 
excavation permit therefor. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 32, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-51. - Urgent work. 
    If in his judgment traffic conditions, the safety or convenience of the traveling public or the public 
interest require that the excavation work be performed as emergency work, the city engineer shall have 
full power to order, at the time the permit is granted, that a crew of men and adequate facilities be 
employed by the permittee twenty-four (24) hours a day to the end that such excavation work may be 
completed as soon as possible. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 33, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-52. - Emergency action. 
    In the event of any emergency in which a sewer, main, conduit or utility in or under any street breaks, 
bursts or otherwise is in such condition as to immediately endanger the property, life, health or safety of 
any individual, the person owning or controlling such sewer, main, conduit, or utility, without first applying 
for and obtaining an excavation permit hereunder, shall immediately take proper emergency measures to 
cure or remedy the dangerous conditions for the protection of property, life, health and safety of 
individuals. However, such person owning or controlling such facility shall apply for an excavation permit 
not later than the end of the next succeeding day during which the city engineer's office is open for 
business, and shall not proceed with permanent repairs without first obtaining an excavation permit 
hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 34, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-53. - Noise, dust and debris. 
    Each permittee shall conduct and carry out the excavation work in such a manner as to avoid 
unnecessary inconvenience and annoyance to the general public and occupants of neighboring property. 
The permittee shall take appropriate measures to reduce to the fullest extent practicable in the 
performance of the excavation work noise, dust and unsightly debris and during the hours of 10:00 p.m. 
and 7:00 a.m. shall not use, except with the express written permission of the city engineer or in case of 
an emergency as herein otherwise provided, any tool, appliance of equipment producing noise of 
sufficient volume to disturb the sleep or repose of occupants of the neighboring property. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 35, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-54. - Preservation of monuments. 
    The permittee shall not disturb any surface monuments or hubs found on the line of excavation work 
until ordered to do so by the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 36, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-55. - Inspections. 
    The city engineer shall make such inspections as are reasonably necessary in the enforcement of 
this article. The city engineer shall have the authority to promulgate and cause to be enforced such rules 
and regulations as may be reasonably necessary to enforce and carry out the intent of this article. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 37, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-56. - Maintenance of drawings. 
    Users of subsurface street space shall maintain accurate drawings, plans, and profiles showing the 
location and character of all underground structures including abandoned installations. Corrected maps 
shall be filed with the city engineer within sixty (60) days after new installations, changes or replacements 
are made. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 38, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-57. - Article applicable to city work. 
    The provisions of this article shall be applicable to any excavation work under the direction of city 
employees of the city or by any contractor of the city performing work for and in behalf of the city 
necessitating openings or excavations in streets. However, the city engineer in his discretion may waive 
the excavation permit fees, surety bonds, and cash deposits as required by this article. It is further 
provided that the city engineer may charge the appropriate person, agency or department of the city a 
reasonable sum to pay for the cost of any work the department of public works performs to restore or 
maintain the street as herein provided in the event such permittee fails to perform such work, or in the 
event such permittee requests the department of public works to perform such work, or to supply 
necessary materials for such work. 
Ord. No. 727, § 39, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-58. - Insurance. 
    A permittee, prior to the commencement of excavation work hereunder, shall furnish the city 
engineer satisfactory evidence in writing that the permittee has in force and will maintain in force during 
the performance of the excavation work and the period of the excavation permit public liability insurance 
of not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for any one person and three hundred 
thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for any one accident and property damage insurance of not less than fifty 
thousand dollars ($50,000.00) duly issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in this 
state. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 4, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-59. - Liability of city. 
    This article shall not be construed as imposing upon the city or any official or employee any liability 
or responsibility for damages to any person injured by the performance of any excavation work for which 
an excavation permit is issued hereunder; nor shall the city or any official or employee thereof be deemed 
to have assumed any such liability or responsibility by reason of inspections authorized hereunder, the 
issuance of any permit or the approval of any excavation work. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 41, 8-28-1978) 


Sec. 17-60. - Penalties. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of 
a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined in an amount not exceeding three hundred 
dollars ($300.00) or be imprisoned in the city jail for a period not exceeding ninety (90) days or be both so 
fined and imprisoned. Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue, shall constitute a 
separate offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 727, § 42, 7-28-1978) 


Chapter 18 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- For provision placing finance department in first department, see § 2-3; license and 
privilege taxes imposed, Ch. 13. 
State Law reference- For provision of state law requiring levy and assessment of ad valorem taxes on 
lands and other taxable property within the municipality, see 1942 Miss. Code, § 3742.01. For provision 
limiting the amount of such levy by municipal school districts, § 9882; by municipalities, § 9883. 


ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 


Sec. 18-1. - Assessments of personal, real property required. 
    The tax assessor of the city each year shall make a separate assessment of all taxable personal 
property within the city, and each year shall make a separate assessment of all taxable real estate within 
the city, including buildings, improvements, structures and other interests therein, except that railroad 
property and other property required by law to be assessed by the State Railroad Assessors shall be 
assessed under and as provided by 1942 Mississippi Code, Section 3742-04, and amendments thereto. 
(Code 1922, § 192; Ord. No. 453, § 1, 8-11-1953) 
State Law reference- For authority to require either assessments or use of county rolls, see 
1942 Miss. Code, § 3742-03. 


Sec. 18-2. - Place, notice for sales of personalty. 
    All sales of personal property for unpaid taxes shall be held at the north door of the city hall, unless 
the property is too cumbersome to be moved, in which case it shall be made where the property is 
located. Five days' notice of the time and place of the sale shall be given by advertisements or written 
notice, put up in three public places in said city, one of which shall be at said city hall. 
(Code 1922, § 198) 
State Law reference- For municipal authority to designate place of sale, see 1942 Miss. Code, 
§§ 3742-32 and 9898; for authority to prescribe manner of notice, see § 9898, as amended. 


Sec. 18-3. - Sales of real property. 
    All sales of real property for unpaid taxes shall be held at the north door of the city hall. Notice 
thereof and the time and manner of conducting such sales shall be as prescribed by state laws. 
(Code 1922, § 199) 
State Law reference- For authority to prescribe place for tax sales of realty, see 1942 Miss. 
Code, § 3742-32. Said section provides that notice, time and manner of conducting such sales 
shall be as provided for sales for state and county taxes. These provisions are set out in 1942 
Miss. Code, §§ 9921-9923. 


Sec. 18-4. - Sale of land acquired by city for taxes. 
(a)	Authorized; terms. Any and all lands in and to which the city has acquired title at a municipal tax sale 
and upon which the time for redemption has expired may be sold to any person offering to pay the 
amount or price of the said lands fixed and determined by the board of mayor and commissioners in 
its discretion and judgment as being a fair and reasonable sum for said lands. 
(b)	Form, execution of conveyance. All such sales shall be evidenced by a quit-claim conveyance 
signed by the mayor commissioner or acting mayor commissioner, and attested by the clerk, with the 
corporate seal thereunto affixed; and to effectuate such purpose the mayor commissioner or acting 
mayor commissioner shall be authorized and empowered to execute said conveyance, and the clerk 
shall be authorized to attest the same and to affix thereunto the corporate seal of the city for and on 
behalf of the city. 
(c)	Previous conveyances confirmed. All quit-claim conveyances heretofore made before the enactment 
of this section shall be and are hereby ratified, confirmed and approved. 
(d)	Intent of section. This section is intended to prescribe the manner of sales of such property now or 
heretofore owned by the city in and to which the city has acquired title at tax sales and upon which 
the time of redemption has expired, and is, likewise, intended to prescribe the manner of such sales 
on all property hereafter acquired by the city in such manner. 
(Ord. No. 293, §§ 1-4, 4-3-1934; Ord. No. 318, § 1, 4-3-1934) 
State Law reference- For authority to dispose of land purchased at tax sale, see 1942 Miss. 
Code, § 3742-39; for provision fixing time for redemption, § 3742-29. 


Sec. 18-5. - Tax exemption for industries. 
    It is the intention of the board of mayor and commissioners to exempt from ad valorem taxation 
levied by said board all new factories and new enterprises of public utility set out in section 9703 of the 
1942 Code of Mississippi, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 397, § 1, 5-25-1948) 
Editor's note- Sections 2-6 of Ord. No. 397, from section 1 of which § 18-5 above is derived, 
provided for publication of said ordinance and provided that it would become effective 60 days 
after passage unless within 30 days after publication 10% of the qualified electors petitioned for 
an election to determine whether or not the adoption of such ordinance should become effective. 
No such petition was filed. 


Sec. 18-6. - Sales tax levied; rates; exclusion. 
    A city sales tax, as hereinafter set forth is hereby adopted and the same shall be in full force and 
effect on and after January 1, 1962, at the following rates: 
(a)	On retail sales or gross income of persons engaged in any of the businesses taxed by sections 
2(c), 2(d), 2(f), and 2(g), Chapter 119, Laws of 1934, as amended, at the rate of one per cent 
(1%); 
(b)	Sales of farm tractors and self-propelled or drawn farm implements sold to farmers, sales of 
automobiles, trucks and truck-tractors shall be taxed at the rate of one-half of one per cent (1/2 of 
1%); and 
(c)	Sale of electricity, current, power, steam, coal, natural gas, liquefied petroleum gas or other fuel 
when sold to a manufacturer or custom processor for industrial purposes, shall be taxed at the 
rate of one-fourth of one per cent (1/4 of 1%). 
There shall be specifically excluded from this tax the gross income from ginning cotton, storing grain 
in elevators or warehouses, railroad transportation and sales of self-propelled construction 
equipment. 
(Ord. No. 525, 12-18-1961) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 523, enacted October 31, 1961, being an ordinance declaring the 
intention of the city to enact a sales tax, as prescribed by 1942 Miss. Code, § 10111.5, has not 
been codified. 
State Law reference- For municipal authority to levy sales tax, prescribing rates, see 1942 
Miss. Code, § 10111.5; for determination of persons taxed by §§ 2(c), 2(d), 2(f) and 2(g), Ch. 
119, Laws of 1934, as amended, see 1942 Miss. Code, §§ 10108, 10109 and 10111. 


Secs. 18-7-18-20. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE II. - CENTRAL BUSINESS DISTRICT TAX INCENTIVE 


Sec. 18-21. - Short Title. 
    This article may be known and may cited as the "Clarksdale Central Business District Tax Incentive 
Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 962, § 1, 4-5-1999) 


Sec. 18-22. - Purposes and Findings. 
    The Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City of Clarksdale hereby: 
(a)	Readopts and reaffirms the statements and findings made in preamble to this article; 
(b)	Further finds and determines that this article shall serve to regulate the application for and 
granting of tax abatement and/or partial exemptions for new structures or improvements to or 
renovations of existing structures located within the designated Central Business District of the 
City of Clarksdale, and provides a uniform method of application for and the City Board's 
consideration of exemption requests; and 
(c)	Further finds and determines that the public convenience and necessity so requires the 
adoption of this article. 
(Ord. No. 962, § 2, 4-5-1999) 


Sec. 18-23. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have 
the meanings given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense 
include the future tense, words in the plural number include the singular number, and words in the 
singular number, the plural number. The masculine gender shall include the feminine, and the feminine 
shall include the masculine. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
(a)	City or Clarksdale is the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi, a municipal corporation domiciled in 
Coahoma County, Mississippi, with its administrative offices located at City Hall, 121 Sunflower 
Avenue, Clarksdale, Mississippi, Post Office Box 940, Clarksdale, Mississippi 38614. 
(b)	Central Business District shall constitute that geographic area as is defined in section 18-24. 
(c)	The City Board shall be the Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City of Clarksdale, 
Mississippi. 
(d)	The City Clerk shall mean the duly appointed, qualified and acting City Clerk of the City of 
Clarksdale. 
(e)	The City Engineer shall mean the duly appointed, qualified and acting City Engineer of the City 
of Clarksdale, or his designee. 
(f)	The Public Works Director shall mean the duly appointed, qualified and acting Director of the 
Public Works Department, or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 962, § 3, 4-5-1999) 


Sec. 18-24. - Designation of Central Business District. 
    The following shall be, and is hereby designated as, the "Central Business District" for the purposes 
of MISS. CODE ANN. § 27-31-31 (Cum. Supp. 2009) and is hereafter amended as follows: 
    C-1, Central Commercial District; 
    C-2, Highway Commercial District; 
    C-3, General Commercial District; 
    C-4, Neighborhood Convenience District; 
as set forth and defined in the City Zoning Ordinance and as shown on the City's official zoning map. 
(Ord. No. 962, § 4, 4-5-1999; Ord. No. 1032, § 2(a), 12-14-2009) 


Sec. 18-25. - Map of District. 
    The Board of Mayor and Commissioners has caused a map delineating the designated Central 
Business District, as described in section 18-24, to be prepared by the City Engineer. A copy of the map 
so designating is on file in the City Clerk's office and in the Public Works Department and is available for 
public inspection. In the event of any conflicts between the boundaries of the Central Business District as 
reflected on the map and as described in section 18-24, the map shall control. 
(Ord. No. 962, § 5, 4-5-1999) 


Sec. 18-26. - Ad Valorem Tax Abatement or Partial Exemption. 
    The Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City hereby expresses its intention to grant a partial 
exemption from City ad valorem taxation, except ad valorem taxation for school district purposes, for new 
structures or improvements to or renovations of existing structures located in the designated Central 
Business District of the City of Clarksdale, upon the terms and conditions and for the time specified 
herein. The Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City of Clarksdale shall retain the exclusive 
discretion as to whether to grant any exemption applied for hereunder, in accordance with MISS. CODE 
ANN. § 27-31-31 (Rev. 1991). 
(Ord. No. 962, § 6, 4-5-1999) 


Sec. 18-27. - Amount of Abatement or Exemption. 
    The Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City of Clarksdale may exempt from City ad valorem 
taxation, but excluding Clarksdale Municipal Separate School District ad valorem taxation, the amount of 
any increase in assessed valuation occasioned by new construction of buildings or structures, or 
improvements to or renovations of existing structures, the assessed valuation of a qualifying property, as 
determined by the Coahoma County Tax Assessor, shall remain the same as it was prior to such new 
construction or improvements to or renovation of existing structures, for an initial period of five (5) years. 
For the next five (5) years thereafter, so long as the structure shall continue to comply with all building 
use and occupancy codes of the City of Clarksdale, the amount of the assessed value of the property 
shall be increased by one-fifth (1/5th) of the difference between the assessed value before such new 
construction or renovations or improvements, and the assessed value after completion of such new 
construction or renovations or improvements, per annum for each of the sixth through tenth years of the 
exemption. After the tenth year following the initial grant of the exemption, the property shall no longer be 
entitled to any further exemption. 
(Ord. No. 962, § 7, 4-5-1999; Ord. No. 1030, § 2(a), 4-13-2009) 


Sec. 18-28. - Minimum Amount of Expenditures. 
    No improvement to or renovation of an existing structure located within the designated Central 
Business District of the City of Clarksdale shall be entitled to any exemption or abatement as provided for 
in this Ordinance, unless the actual cost of such improvement to or renovation of such existing structure 
shall exceed Five Thousand Dollars ($5,000.00). 
(Ord. No. 962, § 8, 4-5-1999) 


Sec. 18-29. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 1030, passed on April 13, 2009, deleted section 18-29 (section 9 
of Ordinance No. 962, the ordinance from which this article is derived). This section has been 
reserved at the discretion of the editor. 


Sec. 18-30. - Types of Approved Improvements or Renovations. 
    The Board of Mayor and Commissioners shall have the sole discretion as to whether to approve the 
cost of or the modifications to an existing structure. Activities not directly related to a building, office or 
similar edifice, including, but not limited to, landscaping, paving, parking improvements and the like, shall 
be excluded from any exemption granted hereunder. In the event of any controversy relative thereto, the 
decision of the Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City of Clarksdale as to whether such 
improvements should be included or excluded from the exemption should be final and conclusive. No 
more than the actual cost of the new structure or improvement may be exempted. 
(Ord. No. 962, § 10, 4-5-1999) 


Sec. 18-31. - Application, Contents. 
    Any person, firm or corporation desiring to obtain the benefits authorized by this Ordinance, shall first 
file a written application therefor, upon a form prescribed by the City. Such written application shall be 
filed with the City Clerk, and shall provide full information about the property for which the exemption is 
requested, including the true and assessed value of all of such property, the actual costs of construction, 
the use(s) of the property and the date from which the exemption is to begin. The application may require 
such other information, including present assessed value, plans and specifications regarding construction 
or renovation, pre-construction cost estimates thereof by contractors, certification of the actual costs 
expended, and such other information as the City may reasonably require. The application shall be 
accompanied by a non-refundable application fee of $100.00 to cover a portion of the City's administrative 
costs in processing the request. The Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City reserves the right to 
modify the application fee, from time to time, so as to cover the administrative costs of the City incurred in 
processing such application. The application shall be executed by the owner of the property, or if a 
business entity, by a duly authorized representative thereof, and shall be verified under oath as to the 
accuracy of the information provided thereby. 
(Ord. No. 962, § 11, 4-5-1999) 


Sec. 18-32. - Time of Filing of the Application. 
    Any application for an exemption under this Ordinance must be made within twelve (12) months from 
the date of the completion of the new structure or the completion of the improvements to or renovations of 
the existing structure for which the exemption is requested. In the event that an application is not timely 
filed, it shall not be considered. 
(Ord. No. 962, § 12, 4-5-1999) 


Sec. 18-33. - Review of Application and Inspection of Property. 
    Upon the filing of the application, the City Clerk shall deliver copies thereof to the Mayor and the 
Public Works Director. The Public Works Director shall cause an inspection of the property to be made, in 
order to verify the accuracy of the information in the application, and to insure the satisfactory completion 
of the new construction of or improvements to or renovations of existing structures within the designated 
Central Business District of the City, and to further insure full compliance with all building, zoning, 
occupancy and use ordinances and rules and regulations adopted by the City. Upon completion of such 
inspection and verification, the Public Works Director shall report to the Board of Mayor and 
Commissioners his findings. 
(Ord. No. 962, § 13, 4-5-1999) 


Sec. 18-34. - Action of the City Board. 
    Upon completion of the inspection and verification process by the Public Works Director, the Board 
of Mayor and Commissioners of the City shall review the application, all supporting data, the report of the 
Public Works Director and such other information as the City Board may reasonable require in order to be 
fully apprised. Upon its being satisfied as to the validity of the application, the accuracy of the information 
and the owner's full compliance with this Ordinance and with MISS. CODE ANN. § 27-31-31 (Rev. 1991), 
the City Board may, by order duly spread upon its minutes, approve such application for all or any part of 
the property for which the exemption is requested, for all or any part of the authorized period of exemption 
as specified herein. The order shall specify the property to be exempted, the amount of the exemption or 
abatement, and the dates upon which the exemption begins and expires. 
(Ord. No. 962, § 14, 4-5-1999) 


Sec. 18-35. - Duties of the Clerk. 
    Upon adoption by the City Board of the order specified in Section 14 above, the City Clerk shall 
record the application and supporting data and the order approving the same in a book kept in his or her 
office for that purpose. The City Clerk shall then file one (1) copy of the application and the order with 
each: 
(a)	The Chairman of the State Tax Commission; 
(b)	The State Auditor of Public Accounts; and 
(c)	The Tax Assessor of Coahoma County, Mississippi. 
(Ord. No. 962, § 15, 4-5-1999) 


Sec. 18-36. - No Waiver of Codes. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to modify, amend, waive or otherwise affect any 
zoning, building, occupancy, use or similar ordinance, rule or regulation previously adopted by the City of 
Clarksdale, including the methodology of application for, permitting or cost of permitting, of any new 
construction or the improvement to or renovation of existing structures. 
(Ord. No. 962, § 16, 4-5-1999) 


Sec. 18-37. - Other Taxing Entities. 
    No exemption granted hereunder shall be construed to exempt any property from ad valorem 
taxation for school district purposes, or from taxes assessed by Coahoma County, Mississippi, and/or the 
State of Mississippi. The City Board will request that Coahoma County honor exemptions or abatements 
granted by the City Board hereunder, but can make no assurances to applicants as to any actions taken 
by the Board of Supervisors or the Tax Assessor/Collector of Coahoma County, Mississippi, relative 
thereto. 
(Ord. No. 962, § 17, 4-5-1999) 


Sec. 18-38. - Exclusivity of Exemption.
