    Any exemption granted under this article shall be in lieu of any ad valorem tax exemptions 
authorized by any other provision of state or local law. 
(Ord. No. 962, § 18, 4-5-1999) 


Sec. 18-39. - No Retroactivity. 
    The provisions of this article shall not be retroactively applied to any new construction or any 
improvement to or renovation of structures completed prior to the adoption hereof. 
(Ord. No. 962, § 19, 4-5-1999) 


Sec. 18-40. - Distinction from Central Commercial District. 
    The Board of Mayor and Commissioners of the City of Clarksdale recognizes that it has, by 
Ordinance No. 690, adopted June 4, 1974, codified as "Appendix A - Zoning" of the Code of Ordinances 
of the City, has created, under Section 305 thereof, the "C-1," Central Commercial District, and has 
adopted certain rules and regulations relative thereto. The Board further recognizes that the area 
designated as the Central Business District, as delineated in section 18-24, contains somewhat different 
boundaries. Neither this article, nor the Central Business District designated in section 18-24, shall be 
deemed to modify or affect the Zoning Ordinance or the Central Commercial District as designated 
therein and upon the Official Zoning Map of the City. Likewise, neither shall the Zoning Ordinance, the 
Official Zoning Map nor the Central Commercial District as designated therein shall be deemed to modify 
or affect this article or the Central Business District as designated herein. 
(Ord. No. 962, § 20, 4-5-1999) 


Chapter 19 - TRAFFIC AND MOTOR VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- For provision making traffic laws applicable to bicycles, see § 5-8. 
State Law reference- For municipal authority to enact police regulations generally, see 1942 Miss. 
Code, § 3374-124; to regulate traffic, speed, etc., § 8151. 


ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 


Sec. 19-1. - Police officers to enforce traffic regulations. 
    It shall be the duty of any and all police officers of the city to enforce the traffic regulations enacted 
for the protection of life and property, and in addition said police officers shall regulate traffic on said 
streets, and shall direct the movements of any and all vehicles driven upon the streets of the city. 
(Code, 1922, § 229) 


Sec. 19-2. - Obedience to police officers. 
    It shall be the duty of every person driving or operating a vehicle on the streets of the city, and of 
every pedestrian crossing or using a public street, to obey all directions of police officers in directing traffic 
whether given by signal, word of mouth, or by posted, printed signs or other devices. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 1, 3-8-1938) 
State Law reference- For similar provision of state law, see 1942 Miss. Code, § 8147. 


Sec. 19-3. - Obedience to traffic devices, signs, lights. 
    The driver or operator of every vehicle, and every pedestrian crossing or using a public street, shall 
comply with all traffic devices, signs or lights provided for in this chapter or lawfully erected by the police 
department; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to fire apparatus, the official cars of the 
officers of the fire department, or cars of the police department. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 6, 3-8-1938) 


Sec. 19-4. - Traffic-control devices. 
(a)	Signal legend. Any traffic-control device exhibiting a red light shall indicate that all traffic shall come 
to a complete stop; exhibiting yellow, it shall indicate caution; and exhibiting green, it shall indicate 
that traffic may move in the direction of the light. 
(b)	Obedience by vehicles. All vehicular traffic shall come to a complete stop within the property lines of 
an intersecting street whenever the light shows red, and shall not move forward or make a right or 
left turn until the light flashes green; when the light flashes yellow, caution shall be exercised, and all 
vehicles shall be brought under such control that they may be stopped suddenly. Vehicular traffic 
shall be brought to a full stop in anticipation of a red signal whenever the light flashes yellow before a 
vehicle enters the intersection within the property lines of an intersecting street. 
(c)	Obedience by pedestrians. Pedestrians shall obey such signals, moving with traffic on a green light, 
stopping on the sidewalk before entering curb lines at an intersection when a light shows red in the 
direction of traffic, and exercising caution in the use of the intersection when the light is yellow. 
(d)	Traffic with green light to have right-of-way; violator deemed negligent. With the exception of fire and 
police vehicles, traffic over a street, avenue or alley while the green light on the said traffic light is 
burning shall have the right-of-way or preference at said intersections; the driver of any automobile 
or other vehicle proceeding while the red light is burning in his direction shall be deemed guilty of 
negligence. 
(Ord. No. 305, § 3, 1-21-1936; Ord. No. 329, § 7, 3-8-1938) 
State Law reference- For municipal authority to place and maintain traffic control devices, see 
1942 Miss. Code, § 8155. 


Sec. 19-5. - Fire chief can regulate traffic. 
    The chief of the fire department shall be authorized to prohibit and prevent all travel on the streets in 
the vicinity of a fire whenever, in his judgment, it is to the interest of the public to take such action. 
(Code, 1922, § 92) 


Sec. 19-6. - Stop signs authorized. 
    Whenever the public necessity and safety requires it, by reason of the nature of an intersection or 
the dangerous situation thereof, the chief of police shall place on any street which crosses into or 
intersects another street, railroad right-of-way, or any street railway right-of-way, a sign indicating that the 
drivers of all vehicles shall stop before entering the crossing or intersecting street or right-of-way. All such 
signs shall be plainly visible and shall be worded in such manner as to inform drivers of all vehicles that 
they shall stop before entering a cross or intersecting street or right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 8, 3-8-1938) 


Sec. 19-7. - Special traffic detail for special conditions. 
    When public gatherings are held in congested districts application shall be made to the chief of 
police for a special traffic detail, and it shall be the duty of the chief of police to provide such special detail 
as the circumstances demand. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 51, 3-8-1938) 


Sec. 19-8. - Use of special police to direct traffic, regulate parking. 
    On all occasions when a number of persons assemble to witness the playing of football, baseball or 
other games or any other entertainment or function when regular or special police officers are stationed to 
direct traffic and the parking of automobiles, the signs, signals and directions of such officers shall be 
strictly observed, obeyed and followed. This regulation shall apply and be in force not only on, at or near 
public playgrounds and places within the city, including Soldiers Field and the baseball park, but shall 
likewise be in effect on all streets, avenues or alleys within three city blocks thereof. 
(Ord. No. 304, § 1, 10-22-1935) 


Sec. 19-9. - Duties of pedestrians crossing streets. 
    No pedestrian shall cross any street except at a street intersection or at designated lanes, and no 
pedestrian crossing a street intersection shall cross diagonally, but shall use only such crossings for 
pedestrians as are designated by lines or other marks, or if not marked shall cross only in the space 
between the curb line extended and the property lines extended across any street over which said 
pedestrian intends to pass. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 41, 3-8-1938) 


Sec. 19-10. - Abandoned vehicles; impounding, sale, redemption. 
(a)	Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to leave standing and unattended any automobile, 
truck, vehicle or impediment of any kind on the streets, by-ways, alleys or commons of the city for 
more than twelve (12) hours. 
(b)	Impounding, sale. Any such motor, automobile, truck, vehicle or other impediment so found standing 
unattended on such streets, by-ways, alleys or commons shall be taken in charge by the city and 
disposed of substantially in the manner following: 
The chief of police or city clerk shall insert a notice in a newspaper published in the city for not less 
than five days to the effect that such impediment or other property has been seized by the city and 
will be sold in front of the city hall within legal hours at a time named not less than five days 
thereafter; said notice may be given by posting same in three public places in the city, one of which 
will be at the front door of the city hall. After either, or both said notices, at the time and place 
mentioned, the chief of police, or some person acting for him at his request, shall there offer for sale 
and for cash sell to the highest and best bidder for cash such automobile, truck, vehicle, or other 
impediment. From the proceeds of such sale the chief of police shall pay all the costs and expenses 
of the seizure, advertisement and sale, and all costs of every kind including a fee of not less than 
one per cent nor more than five per cent of the value of the said property to be assessed by the 
police justice as a penalty. The balance shall be held by the city clerk for six months and if not 
claimed the same shall be forfeited and paid into the city treasury. 
(c)	Redemption. Any person having the right of possession of said property may appear and claim the 
same at any time prior to sale and receive said property provided he shall first pay all said costs, 
including said fees. All said fees shall be paid by the officer into the city treasury as other fines and 
costs are paid. 
(Code, 1922, § 242) 
Cross reference- For prohibition against obstructing streets, sidewalks, see § 17-2. 


Sec. 19-11. - Towing, storage of certain vehicles authorized; release. 
(a)	Towing and storage permitted. Whenever any motor vehicle is disabled, illegally parked, or is being 
driven by a person while under the influence of intoxicating liquors within the city it may by order of 
any member of the police department of the city be driven or towed to a storage area, either inside or 
outside of a building, designated by said officer. 
(b)	Release of vehicle. The owner of any motor vehicle driven or towed by authority of section 19-11 or 
any person authorized by said owner, may have said motor vehicle released immediately from 
storage on applying to the police department for the same and paying any storage and towing 
charges, provided such owner or other person is not at the time of said request under the influence 
of intoxicating liquors. 
(Ord. No. 493, §§ 1, 2, 7-15-1958) 


Sec. 19-12. - Accidents; duties of operator, repair shop. 
(a)	Operator to give information and render assistance. In the event of accident to persons or property 
on the streets of the city due to the operation thereon of motor vehicles, the person operating such 
motor vehicle shall stop and upon request of a person injured, or any person present, give such 
person his name and address and, if not the owner of such motor vehicle, the name and address of 
the owner, and shall give to any police officer who makes inquiry similar information, and shall render 
to any person injured reasonable assistance, including the carrying of such person to a hospital or to 
a physician or surgeon for medical or surgical treatment if it be reasonably apparent that such 
assistance is necessary or is requested by the injured person. 
(b)	Operator to report. The driver of any vehicle involved in an accident resulting in injury or death to any 
person, or property damage to the amount of ten dollars ($10.00) or more shall report said accident 
to police headquarters, filling out as required such appropriate forms as may be prescribed by the 
chief of police. 
(c)	Garage, repair shop. The person in charge of any garage or repair shop to which is brought any 
motor vehicle having been involved in a serious accident or having been struck by any bullet shall 
report the facts to the police head-quarters of the city at once after such motor vehicle is received, 
giving the license number, the engine number, and the name and address of the owner or operator 
of such vehicle if known. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 39, 3-8-1938) 
State Law reference- For state law provision on the subject, see 1942 Miss. Code, §§ 8161-
8171, inclusive; for municipal authority to require an accident report, § 8172. 


Sec. 19-13. - Vehicle to be equipped as required by state law. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate any motor vehicle on the streets of the city unless equipped with 
respect to lights, brakes, signal devices, and warning apparatus as provided for by 1942 Mississippi 
Code, Title 30, Chapter 2, Article 15. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 38, 3-8-1938) 


Sec. 19-14. - Vehicle to be in reasonable repair. 
    No motor vehicle shall be operated upon the streets of the city in such condition that there is undue 
play in the steering wheel or in such mechanical condition with respect to brakes, steering, or other part of 
said car as to be dangerous or apt to cause a driver to lose control. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 36, 3-8-1938) 


Sec. 19-15. - Mufflers required; cut-outs prohibited. 
(a)	No person shall drive a motor vehicle on the streets of the city unless such motor vehicle is equipped 
with a muffler in good working order and in constant operation in order to prevent excessive or 
unusual noises, annoying smoke, and the escape of excessive gas, steam or oil. 
(b)	It shall be unlawful to use a muffler cut-out on any motor vehicle driven upon a street. 
(Ord. No. 329, §§ 33, 34, 3-8-1938) 


Sec. 19-16. - Rear vision mirror. 
    Every motor vehicle shall be equipped with a rear vision mirror or similar device, and it shall be 
unlawful to operate any vehicle upon the streets of the city without such device to reflect to the operator of 
said vehicle a view of the highway to the rear. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 37, 3-8-1938) 


Sec. 19-17. - Windshield wipers. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate any motor vehicle other than a motorcycle unless the same shall be 
equipped with a device for cleaning rain, snow or other moisture from the windshield of the vehicle, which 
device shall be so constructed as to be controlled and/or operated by the operator of the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 32, 3-8-1938) 


Sec. 19-18. - Signs, posters, etc., on vehicle windows prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any motor vehicle upon a street with any sign, poster or 
other nontransparent material upon the front windshield, side-wings, side or rear windows of such vehicle. 
The side-wings, windshield and windows of such vehicles shall be of transparent material so as to furnish 
the driver a clear and unobstructed view to the front, sides and rear. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 31, 3-8-1938) 


Sec. 19-19. - Leaking, sifting, spilling from vehicle-Prohibited. 
    No vehicle shall be driven or moved on any street unless such vehicle is so constructed as to 
prevent its contents from dropping, leaking, sifting or otherwise escaping therefrom. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 35, 3-8-1938) 


Sec. 19-20. - Same-Removal required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person hauling gravel, cinders, brick, coal, seed or other material along 
the public streets or alleys of said city to allow the same to spill, waste or fall from the conveyance 
transporting the same into the streets or alleys of said city without forthwith removing the same. 
(Ord. No. 529, § 5, 5-28-1962) 


Sec. 19-21. - Draining oil from motor vehicles in public way, prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to change or drain, or suffer or permit to be changed or drained, oil 
from the motors of motor vehicles on or into the streets, alleys, gutters, sidewalks or other public places of 
said city. 
(Ord. No. 529, § 6, 5-28-1962) 


Sec. 19-22. - Penalties for violations of sections 19-19 through 19-21. 
    A violation of any of the provisions of sections 19-19-19-21 shall be a misdemeanor, and the 
penalty for such violations is as follows: For the first offense, a fine of not more than twenty-five dollars 
($25.00); for the second offense, a fine of not more than fifty dollars ($50.00); and for the third or 
subsequent offense, a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), or imprisonment in the city jail 
not more than ten days, or both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 529, § 11, 5-28-1962) 


Sec. 19-23. - Authority for traffic regulations. 
    The traffic regulations set forth in this chapter have been determined to be necessary and proper, 
and have been enacted upon the basis of an engineering and traffic survey and investigation made on 
behalf of the city. 


Sec. 19-24. - Violation of chapter constitutes misdemeanor. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 55, 3-8-1938) 


Sec. 19-25. - Repair and sale of motor vehicles regulated. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to make any repairs to or replace any parts of 
any motor vehicle or expose for sale any motor vehicle within any zoning district of the City of 
Clarksdale, Mississippi, other than those zoning districts of the city which permit the carrying on of a 
garage or automotive repair business or automotive sales business. 
(b)	It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to make any repairs to or replacements on any 
motor vehicles while said motor vehicles shall be parked upon a public street or alley within the city 
limits. 
(c)	The board of mayor and commissioners may from time to time after due and proper investigation 
establish by resolutions certain zones on the public streets of the City of Clarksdale, in which motor 
vehicles may be parked for the purpose of exposing the same for sale during the months of January 
through November 15, inclusive, of each year. 
(1)	Upon payment of a parking fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) per parking space payable in 
advance before January 1 of each year, any person, firm or corporation shall be granted the 
nonexclusive use of a parking space on the streets of the city within the zones designated by 
resolution of the board of mayor and commissioners for the purpose of exposing for sale a 
motor vehicle to be parked thereon. The period of time of said nonexclusive use of said parking 
space shall extend from January 1 of each year to November 15 of each year, inclusive, the last 
fifteen (15) days of November and the month of December being specifically excluded. No 
refund of any part of the fee herein prescribed shall be requested or made on or after January 1 
of the year for which said fee is paid. 
(2)	No motor vehicle shall be parked upon the streets or alleys of the city for the purpose of 
exposing the same for sale except in accordance and in compliance with subsection (1) 
hereinabove. 
(3)	Inasmuch as this section shall not be in full force and effect until after January 1, 1976, it is 
hereby specifically provided that the parking fee prescribed in subsection (1) hereinabove shall 
be prorated in accordance with the remainder of the time period available for the granting of a 
nonexclusive use of a parking space during the calendar year 1976. 
(d)	It shall not be unlawful to change tires, repair tires or make minor adjustments on any motor vehicle 
which has unexpectedly become disabled while said motor vehicle is upon the streets or alleys of the 
city or while said vehicle is within a zoning district other than that permitting the carrying on of a 
garage or automotive repair business. Neither shall it be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation 
to make such repairs upon their own motor vehicles while located upon their own private property 
when such repairs are made by the owners of the vehicle and no compensation is paid or fee 
charged for such repair or replacements. 
(e)	Nothing contained in this section shall prohibit automotive repairs or replacements from being 
conducted by mobile or transient operators when the same shall be done upon private property 
within a zoning district of the city which permits the carrying on of a garage or automotive repair 
business; provided however, that such repairs or replacements by mobile or transient operators upon 
private property must be done only when such mobile or transient operator has the written consent of 
the owner or other person in control of said private property where the repairs or replacements are 
conducted. 
(f)	No person, firm or corporation shall make any repairs to or replacement of parts of any motor 
vehicles for compensation belonging to any other person, firm or corporation without first obtaining 
from the city the appropriate license or permit and paying therefor the appropriate privilege tax or fee 
as the same shall be in effect from time to time under the ordinances of the City of Clarksdale, or the 
laws of the State of Mississippi. 
(Ord. No. 700, §§ 1-6, 7-28-1975; Ord. No. 706 ,§ 1, 1-26-1976) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 700, §§ 1-6, adopted July 28, 1975, did not specifically amend the 
Code. Codification herein as § 19-25 was, therefore, at the discretion of the editor. 


ARTICLE II. - OPERATION 


Sec. 19-26. - Careful operation required. 
    All vehicles shall be driven at all times in a careful manner in order not to endanger the safety of 
persons or property. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 49, 3-8-1938) 


Sec. 19-27. - Reasonable speed required. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate a motor vehicle at any time or place in the city at a greater rate of 
speed than is reasonable or proper and demanded by a careful regard for persons and property; or at any 
time or place to operate a motor vehicle at such speed as to endanger the lives, persons and property of 
others. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 2, 3-8-1938) 


Sec. 19-28. - Vehicles to be operated to right of median line. 
    Every vehicle shall be driven to the right of the intersection or median line of the street, and as far to 
the right thereof as may reasonably be done in consideration of the conditions of traffic. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 9, 3-8-1938) 


Sec. 19-29. - Overtaking and passing. 
(a)	Manner. The operator of a vehicle overtaking another vehicle proceeding in the same direction shall 
signal with his horn and pass to the left of the overtaken vehicle at a safe distance, and shall not 
again travel to the right side of the highway until clear of such overtaken vehicle. The operator of an 
overtaken vehicle shall give way to the right in favor of the overtaking vehicle on suitable and audible 
signal and shall not increase the speed of his vehicle until completely passed by the overtaking 
vehicle. 
(b)	Prohibited at intersections. The operator of a vehicle shall not pass or undertake to pass another 
vehicle traveling in the same direction at any street intersection or railroad crossing unless permitted 
or directed so to do by a traffic or police officer. 
(Ord. No. 329, §§ 10, 16, 3-8-1938) 


Sec. 19-30. - Distance when following other vehicle. 
    The driver of a motor vehicle shall not follow another vehicle more closely than is reasonable and 
prudent, having due regard to the speed of such vehicles and the traffic upon and condition of the 
highway, nor so close that, considering speed and traffic conditions, the said driver could not bring his 
vehicle to a stop without collision in the event the vehicle in front should be stopped. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 11, 3-8-1938) 


Sec. 19-31. - Turning. 
    The operator of a vehicle turning to the right and into another street shall turn the corner as near to 
the right-hand curb as possible. The operator of a vehicle turning to the left into another street shall pass 
to the right of and beyond the center of the intersecting street before turning. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 12, 3-8-1938) 


Sec. 19-32. - Backing. 
    No vehicle shall be backed to make a turn in any street, or backed out of alleys or around street 
corners. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 13, 3-8-1938) 


Sec. 19-33. - U-turns. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to turn such vehicle in order to proceed in the 
opposite direction, upon any street or alley in the area described in section 19-53; and upon any other 
street such turn shall be accomplished only if it can be made in safety and without interfering with other 
traffic. 


Sec. 19-34. - Duties when meeting vehicles. 
    Every vehicle meeting another traveling in an opposite direction in any street shall on so meeting be 
operated on the right side of the street in such manner as to enable the vehicles to pass each other 
without accident. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 14, 3-8-1938) 


Sec. 19-35. Duty to keep to right when crossing intersections, railroads. 
    In crossing intersections of streets or the intersection of a street by a railroad right-of-way, the driver 
of a vehicle shall at once cause such vehicle to be driven on the right half of the roadway unless such 
right side is obstructed. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 15, 3-8-1938) 


Sec. 19-36. - Emergency vehicles-Designated; right-of-way. 
    All vehicles of the police and fire departments and all ambulances shall have the right-of-way in any 
street and through any procession when being operated in the regular course of duty, giving warning by 
siren, and marked with lights required by Section 8229-08 of the Mississippi Code 1942 Annotated as 
Amended. No driver of any vehicle shall interfere with the right-of-way of any of the vehicles named in this 
section. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 18, 3-8-1938; Ord. No. 634, § 1, 9-13-1971) 
Amendment note- Ord. No. 634, § 1, amended § 19-36 to read as set out. Formerly "cars of 
the city" also had the right-of-way. 
Cross reference- Provision exempting emergency vehicles from requirement of obedience to 
traffic devices, § 19-3. 


Sec. 19-37. - Same-Duty on approach; following. 
    The driver of every vehicle on the approach of a fire engine or other fire apparatus, or police 
department cars, or ambulances sounding sirens, shall immediately drive his vehicle as near as possible 
to the right hand curb, and if possible parallel therewith, bringing it to a stop, and shall keep it stationary 
until such cars shall have passed. 
    No motor vehicle shall follow any fire apparatus responding to an alarm of fire. Vehicles traveling in 
the same direction on the same street as fire apparatus or police department cars responding to an alarm 
shall be driven at least six hundred feet behind such cars. No vehicle shall approach closer than six 
hundred feet to a fire. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 19, 3-8-1938) 


Sec. 19-38. - Right-of-way at intersections. 
    All vehicles traveling upon any street of the city shall give the right-of-way to other vehicles 
approaching from an intersecting street from the right, and shall have the right-of-way over those 
approaching from the left; provided, however, that United States mail cars, vehicles of the police and fire 
departments and official cars shall have the right-of-way over other vehicles; and provided further, that 
this section shall not apply where traffic is being controlled by traffic or police officers or traffic control 
devices or signs. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 20, 3-8-1938) 


Sec. 19-39. - Driving over fire hose prohibited. 
    No person shall ride or drive over a hose of the fire department unless he be acting under the orders 
of the chief of the fire department or someone acting in his stead. 
(Code, 1922, § 93) 


Sec. 19-40. - Entering street from alley or private drive. 
    The driver of a vehicle entering into a street from an alley or from a private road or drive shall yield 
the right-of-way to all vehicles approaching on such street, and it shall be the duty of the driver of every 
vehicle entering such street to bring his vehicle to a stop until the same may be entered with safety and 
without danger to others using the street, and entry shall be effected with caution. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 21, 3-8-1938) 


Sec. 19-41. - Hand signals required when stopping, turning. 
    A driver of a vehicle shall not stop or turn such vehicle without giving an appropriate signal or 
warning of his purpose, either by hand signal or by means of an electrical or mechanical device, 
commonly called a turn-indicator, installed in said vehicle. Hand signals shall be as follows: For a left turn, 
or in pulling away from the curb, the left arm shall be extended out of the car with the index finger or 
hand, pointing, with the arm and finger horizontal; for a right turn, the arm and finger or hand shall be 
likewise extended with the arm pointing upward; for a stop, the arm and finger or hand shall be so 
extended with the arm pointing downward toward the ground. 
(Ord. No. 329, §§ 17, 22, 3-8-1938) 


Sec. 19-42. - Vigilance, signals required when starting. 
    The driver of any vehicle upon a highway before starting shall use due care to see that such 
movement can be made in safety, and if any other person might be affected by such movement he shall 
sound his horn or shall make other appropriate signal in order to attract attention and indicate his 
purpose. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 22, 3-8-1938) 


Sec. 19-43. - Duty when vision obstructed. 
    The driver of a motor vehicle approaching a crossing where the view is obstructed, or rounding a 
curb or corner on a public street where the view is obstructed, shall sound his horn or give other 
appropriate signal in such way as to give warning to other vehicles and to pedestrians of his approach. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 23, 3-8-1938) 


Sec. 19-43.1. - Riders, operators of two-wheeled vehicles to wear crash helmet. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or to ride upon any two-wheeled, self-propelled vehicle 
upon any public street, alley, or highway within the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi without wearing a crash 
helmet. No person shall operate or ride upon any vehicle covered under this section unless such person 
is equipped with and wearing on the head a crash helmet of the type designed and manufactured for use 
by operators of such vehicles. All such crash helmets shall be made of a hard plastic material and shall 
also consist of lining, padding, and chin straps, which chin straps shall be fastened at all times while the 
vehicle is moving, and such crash helmets shall be of the type as not to distort the view of the driver or 
rider of such vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 682, § 1, 9-20-1973) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 682, § 1, did not specifically amend this Code hence inclusion herein 
as § 19-43.1 was at the discretion of the editor. 


Sec. 19-44. - Speed regulations established. 
(a)	General. Except as otherwise specifically provided by the Code of Ordinances of the City of 
Clarksdale, Mississippi, motor vehicles shall not be operated at a greater rate of speed than thirty 
(30) miles per hour, nor at a lesser rate of speed than fifteen (15) miles per hour, upon any paved 
street of the city, and no motor vehicle shall be operated at a greater rate of speed than fifteen (15) 
miles per hour upon any unpaved street or upon any alley of the city, and the chief of police shall 
designate by appropriate signs, signals or otherwise the speed limits in effect upon said street and 
alleys in order to effectively regulate the conditions and demands of traffic. 
(b)	Business district Within the area described in section 19-61 of this chapter, motor vehicles shall not 
be operated at a greater rate of speed than twenty-five (25) miles per hour upon any street, nor at a 
lesser rate of speed than fifteen (15) miles per hour upon any street, nor a greater rate of speed than 
fifteen (15) miles per hour on any alley, of the city, and the chief of police shall designate by 
appropriate signs, signals or otherwise the speed limits in effect upon said streets and alleys in order 
to effectively regulate the conditions and demands of traffic. 
(c)	Highway district. No motor vehicle shall be operated at a greater rate of speed along the following 
sections of highways and streets intersecting said highways within the corporate limits of the city 
than that indicated for each respective section of highway or street: 
(1)

The chief of police will designate or cause to be designated by appropriate, signs, signals or otherwise 
speed limits in effect upon said streets in order to regulate effectively the conditions of traffic. 
(Ord. No. 607, § 1, 5-12-1969; Ord. No. 685, § 1, 11-12-1973; Ord. No. 704, § 1, 10-30-1975; 
Ord. No. 723, § 1, 1-16-1978; Ord. No. 787, § 1, 4-25-1983; Ord. No. 825, § 1, 4-21-1986; Ord. 
No. 858, § 1, 3-26-1990; Ord. No. 890, §§ 1, 2, 8-24-1992) 


Sec. 19-45. - Speed in special zones. 
(a)	Hospital zones. Motor vehicles shall not be operated at a greater rate of speed than fifteen miles per 
hour in any area designated as a hospital zone, and the chief of police, by appropriate signs or 
otherwise, shall designate the area to be included within such zone. 
(b)	Churches, schools. Motor vehicles shall not be operated at a greater rate of speed than fifteen miles 
per hour in any area designated as a school zone, or in any area designated as church zone or 
similar area, while such school, church or similar place of assembly is in session, and the chief of 
police, by appropriate signs or otherwise, shall designate the areas to be included within such zones 
while such places of assembly are in session. 
(c)	Park zone. Motor vehicles shall not be operated at a greater rate of speed than fifteen (15) miles per 
hour in any area designated as a park zone, and the chief of police, upon request of the city park 
commission, by appropriate signs or otherwise, shall designate the area to be included within such 
zone. 
(Ord. No. 836, § 1, 4-18-1988) 


Sec. 19-46. - Duty of operator with respect to pedestrians. 
    Drivers of vehicles shall exercise all possible care not to interfere with or injure pedestrians lawfully 
in the use of the streets, crossings and cross-walks. 
    When signaled by any traffic officer or traffic control device the driver of every vehicle shall stop back 
of the property line of any crossing, leaving it clear for the use of pedestrians. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 40, 3-8-1938) 


Sec. 19-47. - Speed, operation of vehicles used for advertising or display. 
    Vehicles used primarily for advertising purposes and displaying either posters or placards, or 
displaying for public inspection any article for sale, or being used to cry out advertisements by 
loudspeakers, or to advertise otherwise, shall not stop in the area set forth in section 19-53, but shall 
move continuously at a rate of speed of fifteen miles per hour, traffic permitting, except when ordered by 
traffic officers, or on approach of fire apparatus or when stopped by traffic control devices. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 42, 3-8-1938) 


Sec. 19-48. - Authority for speed regulations and speed limits. 
    The speed regulations and speed limits set forth in this article have been determined to be 
necessary and proper, and have been enacted upon the basis of an engineering and traffic survey and 
investigation made on behalf of the city. 
State Law reference- Engineering and traffic investigation required, 1942 Miss. Code, § 8177. 


Sec. 19-49. - One-way streets. 
(a)	Whenever the public convenience and necessity requires it, by reason of the nature of traffic 
congestion or of the improvement of traffic flow within the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi, the chief of 
police, upon direction by the board of mayor and commissioners of the City of Clarksdale, 
Mississippi, may designate any street, alley or other public way within the City of Clarksdale, 
Mississippi, as a one-way street, meaning that all vehicles standing on or traveling on said street, 
alley, or public way shall face or move in one direction designated by the chief of police. When any 
said street, alley, or public way has been so designated, a sign indicating that said street, alley, or 
public way is a one-way street, alley, or other public way and indicating the direction of travel shall be 
placed at all intersections or other points of entry into said one-way street, alley, or other public way. 
All such signs shall be plainly visible and shall be worded in such manner as to inform the operators 
of all vehicles of the permitted direction of travel on said street, alley, or other public way. 
(b)	Upon any street, alley, or public way designated and signposted for one-way traffic, a vehicle shall 
be driven only in the direction designated. 
(c)	Approach for a left turn from a two-way street into a one-way street, alley, or other public way shall 
be made in that portion of the right half of the roadway nearest the center line thereof and by passing 
to the right of such center line where it enters the intersection. A left turn from a one-way street, 
alley, or public way into a two-way street, alley, or other public way shall be made by passing to the 
right of the center line of the street, alley, or other public way being entered upon leaving the 
intersection. 
(Ord. No. 680, §§ 1-3, 8-27-1973) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 680, §§ 1-3, did not specifically amend this Code hence inclusion 
herein as § 19-49 was at the discretion of the editor. 


Secs. 19-50-19-52. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE III. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING 


Sec. 19-53. - Area where parking prohibited. 
    Except as otherwise provided in the Code of Ordinances of the City of Clarksdale and as designated 
by signs authorized by this Code of Ordinances, it shall be unlawful for the operator of any motor vehicle 
to park or to stop and permit the same to remain standing on any street or alley within the area and along 
the streets designated in section 19-57 during the time period specified therein, for any length of time 
whatsoever other than as specifically permitted therein, except that motor vehicles used for delivery 
purposes may park, stop, or stand in said alleys or streets for such time as may be reasonable and 
necessary in loading or unloading goods, wares, or merchandise in or from the trucks or other delivery 
vehicles from or to some person in the immediate vicinity thereof; provided, however, that one hour shall 
be deemed a reasonable time within which such loading or unloading of the delivery trucks must be 
accomplished. 
(Ord. No. 708, § 1, 5-13-1976) 


Sec. 19-54. - Chief of police may establish no parking areas. 
    The chief of police shall be authorized to establish anywhere within the city by appropriate signs or 
curb markings areas in the streets and alleys wherein absolutely no parking, stopping, or standing of 
motor vehicles shall be permitted, whether for the purpose of loading or unloading goods, wares, or 
merchandise, or otherwise, said areas to be established where necessary to prevent the obstruction of 
the view of operators of motor vehicles or the obstruction of traffic through the streets or alleys of the City 
of Clarksdale, Mississippi. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 52, 3-8-1938; Ord. No. 708, § 2, 5-13-1976) 


Sec. 19-55. - Limited parking zones. 
(a)	Creation of fifteen-minute limited parking zones. The public convenience and necessity so requiring, 
there is hereby created within the city a class of parking to be designated as fifteen-minute parking 
zones or spaces, in which vehicle parking shall be limited to a maximum period of fifteen (15) 
minutes. 
(b)	Creation of thirty-minute limited parking zones. The public convenience and necessity so requiring, 
there is hereby created within the city a class of parking to be designated as thirty (30) minute 
parking zones or spaces, in which the vehicle parked shall be limited to a maximum period of thirty 
(30) minutes. 
(c)	Designation by board. The board of mayor and commissioners of the city may, from time to time, 
designate one or more spaces at or near federal, state or local government offices, including 
agencies funded in whole or in part by the city or by the Board of Supervisors of Coahoma County, 
as either fifteen minute parking zones or spaces, or thirty minute parking zones or spaces, as, in the 
discretion of the board of mayor and commissioners, may be required, by resolution duly adopted 
and spread upon the minutes of the board of mayor and commissioners. 
(d)	Overparking in fifteen-minute zones. It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to park or allow 
his or her vehicle to remain for any period of time longer than fifteen (15) minutes in any zone or 
parking space so designated and marked as a fifteen (15) minute parking zone. 
(e)	Overparking in thirty-minute zones. It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to park or allow 
his or her vehicle to remain for any period of time longer than thirty (30) minutes in any zone or 
parking space so designated and marked as a thirty (30) minute parking zone. 
(f)	Signs. The public works director or other designee of the board of mayor and commissioners of the 
city shall cause appropriate signs to be posted in all areas where parking is limited, including such 
time limitations as may be designated by the board of mayor and commissioners for such zone or 
parking space so designated, and containing such other language as may be necessary and 
appropriate. 
(g)	Penalties. Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this section shall be guilty of a 
misdemeanor and shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not more than $250.00, plus all 
costs of court. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day or part thereof during or 
on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 860, §§ 1-5, 4-16-1990; Ord. No. 987, § 1, 7-10-2002) 
Editor's note- Inclusion of Ord. No. 860, §§ 1-5, adopted Apr. 16, 1990, as § 19-55 was at 
the discretion of the editor, the ordinance not being specifically amendatory of the Code. 


Sec. 19-56. - Chief of police may designate certain spaces as loading zones upon payment of annual 
rental. 
    The chief of police shall be authorized to designate spaces on the streets of the city as unloading 
and loading zones for the purpose of loading or unloading goods, wares, or merchandise in or from trucks 
or other delivery vehicles. The designation of said spaces by the chief of police shall be upon the request 
of some person, firm, or corporation in the immediate vicinity of the space requested and only upon a 
determination by the chief of police that such space is reasonably necessary for use by the person, firm, 
or corporation requesting the same in the loading or unloading of goods, wares, and merchandise from or 
to said person, firm, or corporation. The assignment of said loading zone to said person, firm, or 
corporation shall be for a period of one year from the date of the assignment thereof; and prior to the 
assignment of said loading or unloading zone, said person, firm, or corporation to whom the same shall 
be assigned shall pay to the clerk of the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi, the sum of one hundred eighty 
dollars ($180.00). Upon the payment of said fee and the assignment of said space by the chief of police, 
said person, firm, or corporation shall have the exclusive use and right of said space for the purpose of 
loading or unloading goods, wares, or merchandise in or from trucks or other delivery vehicles from or to 
said person, firm, or corporation. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 47, 3-8-1938; Ord. No. 708, § 4, 5-13-1976) 


Sec. 19-57. - Two-hour parking. 
    It shall be unlawful, between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. of any day, Sundays and legal 
holidays excepted, to park a vehicle in the areas hereinafter set forth for a period of time longer than two 
(2) hours: 
(a)	Sunflower Avenue from its intersection with the south line of First Street to its intersection with 
the north line of Third Street; 
(b)	Delta Avenue from its intersection with the south line of First Street to the north right-of-way line 
of the Illinois Central Gulf right-of-way; 
(c)	Yazoo Street from its intersection with the south line of First Street to the north right-of-way line 
of the Illinois Central Gulf Railroad right-of-way and along the east line of Yazoo Street from its 
intersection with the north line of First Street to its intersection with the south line of that certain 
alley in the J. A. Dolan Subdivision of Lot 1, Block 4, Ashton Land Company Addition Number 1; 
(d)	Issaquena Avenue from its intersection with the south line of Second Street to the north right-of-
way line of the Illinois Central Railroad right-of-way and along the west line of Issaquena 
Avenue from its intersection with the north line of Second Street to is intersection with the south 
line of First Street; 
(e)	Sharkey Avenue from its intersection with the south line of Second Street to its intersection with 
the north line of Third Street; 
(f)	Third Street from its intersection with the east line of Sunflower Avenue to its intersection with 
the west line of Issaquena Avenue and Third Street from its intersection with the east line of 
Sharkey Avenue to its intersection with the west line of Leflore; 
(g)	Second Street from its intersection with the east line of Sunflower Avenue to its intersection with 
the west line of Issaquena Avenue. 
(Ord. No. 708, § 5, 5-13-1976; Ord. No. 771, § 1, 12-28-1981; Ord. No. 777, § 1, 9-27-1982; 
Ord. No. 821, § 1, 1-6-1986) 


Sec. 19-58. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 708, § 6, adopted May 13, 1976, repealed former § 19-58, relative to 
restrictions on three hour parking, derived from Ord. No. 706, § 3, enacted Jan. 26, 1976. 


Sec. 19-59. - Overnight parking prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for the operator of any truck with carrying capacity of one ton or more, to park or 
permit the same to be parked upon any of the streets or alleys of the city between the hours of 7:00 p.m. 
and 6:00 a.m. 


Sec. 19-60. - Parking prohibited in front of places of assembly; exceptions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle in front of any theatre, main entrance of a hotel, 
moving picture house, or other place of assembly at any time during which there is assembled therein any 
persons for the purposes of witnessing the performance, seeing the picture, or taking part in the 
assembly; provided, however, that this shall not apply to churches or to any assembly hall which does not 
abut upon the street. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 48, 3-8-1938) 


Sec. 19-61. - Parking on left on two (2) way street, parking in front of alley or driveway. 
(a)	No vehicle shall stop or be parked with its left side to the curb on any two (2) way street in the area 
described as follows: Beginning at a point on the east bank of the Sunflower River where the same is 
crossed by the south line of Fourth Street, and extending thence in a northerly direction along the 
east waterline of the Sunflower River to the north line of First Street; thence in an easterly line along 
the north side of First Street to the east line of Desoto Avenue; thence in a southerly direction along 
the east line of Desoto Avenue to the south line of Fourth Street; thence in a southwesterly direction 
along the south side of Fourth Street to the point of beginning. 
(b)	No vehicle shall be stopped or parked in front of an alley or private or public driveway. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 24, 3-8-1938; Ord. No. 708, § 7, 5-18-1976) 


Sec. 19-62. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 700, § 7, adopted July 28, 1975, repealed § 19-62 which had pertained 
to parking vehicles on the street for the purpose of sale or repair. Said section had been derived 
from Ord. No. 329, § 29, adopted March 8, 1938. 


Sec. 19-63. - Standing on street prohibited; exception. 
    No vehicle shall be permitted to stand on any street so as to interrupt or interfere with the passage of 
other vehicles; provided, however, that if no space exists at the curb in which to park, vehicles may be 
stopped to receive or discharge passengers; provided further, that this be done as expeditiously as 
possible. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 27, 3-8-1938) 


Sec. 19-64. - Standing within ten feet of fire plug or fire hose. 
    No vehicle shall be permitted to stand on any street within ten feet of any fire plug or fire hose for a 
longer time than is necessary to receive or discharge passengers or freight. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 28, 3-8-1938) 


Sec. 19-65. - Stopping abreast of another vehicle. 
    No driver shall, except in case of emergency, stop a vehicle abreast of another vehicle on any street 
on which there is provided but one lane of travel for vehicles moving in the same direction. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 25, 3-8-1938; Ord. No. 708, § 8, 5-13-1976) 


Sec. 19-66. - Private signs to regulate parking prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place any sign or obstruction designating any portion of any 
street as a place in which vehicles shall not be parked except signs authorized as herein, and the chief of 
police shall see that all signs and obstructions of such character placed upon the curbs or sidewalks are 
removed. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 46, 3-8-1938) 


Sec. 19-67. - Manner of stopping, parking. 
    Except in an emergency or to allow another vehicle or pedestrian to cross the street, no vehicle shall 
be stopped in any street except as near to the curb thereof as possible, and if it be stopped for parking 
and the parking is designated as parallel, it shall be stopped with front and rear wheels within twelve (12) 
inches of the curb. No vehicle shall be stopped so as to obstruct a street crossing and shall not be 
stopped or allowed to stand within the intersection of any street. 
(Ord. No. 329, § 26, 3-8-1938; Ord. No. 708, § 9, 5-13-1976) 


Sec. 19-68. - Parking in areas reserved for handicapped persons. 
(a)	Designation of spaces. The chief of police shall be authorized to designate spaces on the streets of 
the city by appropriate signs or curbmarkings for the purpose of providing parking areas for 
handicapped persons, as defined in Section 27-19-56 of the Mississippi Code of 1972 Annotated, as 
amended and recompiled, and the decal and/or parking certificate as are defined therein shall grant 
privilege for the vehicle of such handicapped person in parking areas and other areas set aside for 
the handicapped when such handicapped person is the driver or occupant of the vehicle. 
(b)	Prohibited parking. Parking in such areas as are reserved for the handicapped, and as designated by 
appropriate signs or curbmarkings, by any motor vehicles which do not have the special decal on the 
vehicle license plate or the parking certificate on a vehicle dash board as defined in Section 27-19-
56, cited hereinabove, is hereby prohibited. 
(c)	Penalty for violation. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a 
misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars 
($100.00) for each such violation. 
(Ord. No. 818, §§ 1-3, 9-3-1985) 
Editor's note- Being not specifically amendatory of the Code, the provisions of §§ 1-3 of 
Ord. No. 818, adopted Sept. 3, 1985, have been included herein as § 19-68 at the discretion of 
the editor. 


Secs. 19-69-19-72. - Reserved.

Secs. 19-73-19-90. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE V. - TRUCKS, TRAILERS AND HOUSE CARS 


Sec. 19-91. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following terms shall be construed to have the meaning herein 
given: 
(a)	Trailer or house car. "Trailer or house car" shall be defined as being any structure mounted on 
wheels, self-propelled or drawn by a motor vehicle intended to be, or used for the 
accommodation of one or more persons as a temporary abode or dwelling, for recreation or 
business, and may or may not be equipped with any or all household conveniences as a 
dwelling. 
(b)	Single trailer or house car. A single trailer or house car, together with its motive power, shall 
hereafter be referred to in this article as a unit. 
(c)	Truck. A truck shall include any motor vehicle used as a truck with the designated capacity of 
one ton or more and shall include trailers which may be detached from their motor power and 
shall include cab, engine and the entire vehicle to which a detachable trailer truck may be 
attached. 
(Ord. No. 440, § 1, 5-27-1952) 


Sec. 19-92. - Parking trailers, house cars over thirty minutes prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park trailers or house cars on any street in the city for a period 
of time exceeding thirty (30) minutes when no emergency for repairs exists; such parking shall be further 
governed by all relevant traffic restrictions. 
(Ord. No. 440, § 2, 5-27-1952) 


Sec. 19-93. - Parking trucks at night over thirty minutes prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for the operator of any truck as defined in this article to park the same on any 
street in the city for a period of time longer than thirty (30) minutes, except between the hours of 12:00 
midnight and 6:00 a.m. of any day. 
(Ord. No. 440, § 3, 5-27-1952) 
Cross reference- For prohibition against overnight parking of trucks, § 19-59. 


Sec. 19-94. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 708, § 12, enacted May 13, 1976, repealed former § 19-94, pertaining 
to trucks and vehicles of certain sizes; parking restrictions; exceptions; penalty, and derived from 
Ord. No. 268, §§ 1, 2, enacted Nov. 3, 1931. 


Sec. 19-95. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Except as otherwise provided, any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be 
deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punishable by a fine of not less than ten 
dollars ($10.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. No. 440, § 4, 5-27-1952) 


Secs. 19-96-19-100. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE VI. - RAILROADS AND RAILROAD CROSSINGS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- For municipal authority to regulate railroad and railway crossing, see 1942 Miss. 
Code, § 3374-152. 
Editor's note- See editor's note following § 19-102. 


Sec. 19-101. - Definitions. 
(a)	Agent or employee. The word "agent" or "employee" shall apply to any and all engineers, 
conductors, flagmen, switchmen, brakemen or any other agents or employees contributing to a 
violation of this article. 
(b)	Street, avenue, alley, road or thoroughfare. The words "street, avenue, alley, road" or "thoroughfare" 
shall apply to every street, avenue, alley, road or thoroughfare having heretofore and now being 
used in the crossing of railroad tracks or right-of-way by any motor vehicle, any horse and wagon, 
any motor-propelled or animal-drawn vehicle or any other mode of traffic or travel, regardless of 
whether such public way or artery of traffic shall be dedicated or used for public use by public 
dedication by ordinance, plat, public usage or otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 552, §§ 3-5, 8-1-1961) 


Sec. 19-102. - Trains obstructing crossings prohibited. 
    Every railroad company and its agents and employees upon stopping any train or cars on any 
railroad which crosses or is crossed by any street, avenue or alley in the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi, 
shall uncouple its cars or remove the same so as not to obstruct travel upon such street, avenue or alley 
for a longer period than five (5) minutes. 
(Ord. No. 522, § 1, 8-1-1961; Ord. No. 586, § 1, 10-25-1965) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 586, nonamendatory of this Code, has been codified as §§ 19-102 and 
19-103 in lieu of former provisions set out therein on the same subject, derived from Ord. No. 
522. Section 3 of said Ord. No. 586 reads in part as follows, "That Ord. No. 483 ... is hereby 
repealed and all ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith as hereby repealed." As 
Ord. No. 522 was codified in the original codification in place of Ord. No. 483 the editors have 
treated the above quoted provisions as superseding §§ 1 and 2 of Ord. No. 522, §§ 19-102 and 
19-108 hereof. Sections 3-5 of Ord. No. 522 are set out in § 19-101. 
Cross reference- For general prohibition as to obstructing streets, sidewalks, § 17-2. 


Sec. 19-103. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Any railroad, or any employee of a railroad company, violating the provisions of section 19-102 shall 
be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon a conviction shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars 
($100.00) for each offense, and shall be subject to injunction by the chancery court of Coahoma County, 
Mississippi, to prohibit the violation of section 19-102. 
(Ord. No. 522, § 2, 8-1-1961; Ord. No. 586, § 2, 10-25-1965) 


Secs. 19-104-19-120. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE VII. - PARKING OF TRUCK TRAILERS, ROAD TRACTORS, TRAILERS AND SEMITRAILERS 


Sec. 19-121. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed 
to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Motor vehicle means every vehicle which is self-propelled and can be operated upon a street. 
    Road tractor means every motor vehicle designed and used for drawing other vehicles and not so 
constructed as to carry any load thereon either independently or any part of the weight of a vehicle or 
load so drawn. 
    Semitrailer means every vehicle without motive power designed for carrying persons or property and 
for being drawn by a motor vehicle and so constructed that some part of its weight and that of its load 
rests upon or is carried by another vehicle. 
    Trailer means every vehicle without motive power designed for carrying persons or property and for 
being drawn by a motor vehicle and so constructed that no part of its weight rests upon the towing 
vehicle. 
    Truck tractor means every motor vehicle designed and used primarily for drawing other vehicles and 
not so constructed as to carry a load other than a part of the weight of the vehicle and load so drawn. 
    Vehicle means every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or 
drawn upon a street. 
(Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2-26-2007) 


Sec. 19-122. - Parking regulations. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful for an operator or owner to park a truck tractor, road tractor, trailer or semitrailer, 
except for the purposes of loading and unloading, on public streets, public property, private property, 
driveways and parking areas. 
(b)	It is not unlawful to park a truck tractor, road tractor, trailer or semitrailer on private property, 
driveways and parking areas in areas of the city districts zoned A-1 Agricultural, C-2 Highway 
Commercial, C-3 General Commercial and I-1 Industrial. 
(Ord. No. 1022, §§ 2, 3, 2-26-2007) 


Sec. 19-123. - Penalty. 
    The penalty for violation of this article upon conviction shall be a fine of not more than five hundred 
dollars ($500.00) plus all costs of court for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed 
committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 1022, § 4, 2-26-2007) 


Sec. 19-124. - Parking in front yard and/or side yard of any real property prohibited. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful to park a motor vehicle in the front yard and/or side yard, (if the property is 
located on a corner lot) of any real property which is zoned residential under the city's zoning 
ordinance or used for residential purposes except where a concrete, paved stone or gravel driveway 
is provided. 
(b)	All properties zoned residential under the city's zoning ordinance or used for residential purposes 
must be brought in to compliance with the off street parking section of the city's zoning ordinance. 
(c)	The penalty for violation of this section upon conviction shall be a fine of not more than five hundred 
dollars ($500.00) plus all costs of court for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed 
committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 1043, §§ 1-3, 10-14-2013) 


Chapter 19A - TRANSIENT OR ITINERANT MERCHANTS AND VENDORS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 758, enacted Feb. 23, 1981, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, 
codification of the substantive provisions of said ordinance, as amended by Ord. Nos. 759 and 761, as a 
new Ch. 19A, is at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Dealers in secondhand jewelry and precious metals, Ch. 6B; license and privilege 
taxes, Ch. 13. 


Sec. 19A-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter a transient merchant, itinerant merchant or itinerant vendor is defined 
as any person, firm or corporation whether as owner, agent, consignee or employee, whether a resident 
of the city or not, who engages in the temporary business of selling and delivering goods, wares and 
merchandise within said city, and who in furtherance of such purposes hires, leases, uses or occupies 
any building, structure, motor vehicle, tent, railroad boxcar or boat, public room in hotels, motels, lodging 
houses, apartments, shops or any street, alley or other place within the city for the exhibition and sale of 
such goods, wares and merchandise, either privately or at public auction, provided that such definition 
shall not be construed to include any person, firm or corporation who while occupying such temporary 
location does not sell from stock but exhibits samples only for the purpose of securing orders for future 
delivery only. The person, firm or corporation so engaged shall not be relieved from complying with the 
provisions of this chapter merely by reason of associating temporarily with any local dealer, trader, 
merchant or auctioneer or by conducting such transient business in connection with, as part of, or in the 
name of any local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer. 
    The provisions of this section shall not apply to local fairs, bazaars and similar activities which are 
sponsored, operated and controlled by religious, civic or fraternal organizations solely for charitable 
purposes; nor to "garage" or "rummage" sales conducted by bona fide residents of the City of Clarksdale, 
Mississippi, or their residential premises where the items offered for sale are used personalty of the 
residents. 
(Ord. No. 768, § 2, 2-23-1981; Ord. No. 759, § 1, 3-9-1981) 


Sec. 19A-2. - Permit-Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for a transient merchant, itinerant merchant or itinerant vendor, as defined in 
section 19A-1, to engage in such business within the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi, without first obtaining 
a permit therefor in compliance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 1, 2-23-1981) 


Sec. 19A-3. - Same-Application. 
    Applicants for permits under this chapter, whether a person, firm or corporation, shall file a written, 
sworn application signed by the applicant if an individual, by all partners if a partnership, and by the 
president if a corporation, with the city clerk showing: 
(a)	The name or names of the person or persons having the management or supervision of 
applicant's business during the time that it is proposed that it will be carried on in the City of 
Clarksdale; the local address or addresses of such person or persons while engaged in such 
business; the permanent address or addresses of such person or persons; the capacity in which 
such person or persons will act (that is, whether as proprietor, agent or otherwise); the name 
and address of the person, firm or corporation for whose account the business will be carried 
on, if any; and if a corporation, under the laws of what state the same is incorporated; 
(b)	The fingerprints of the person or persons having the management or supervision of applicant's 
business or in lieu thereof, at least three (3) letters of recommendation from reliable property 
owners in the City of Clarksdale, State of Mississippi, certifying as to the applicant's good 
character and business responsibility or other evidence which establishes to the satisfaction of 
the city clerk the good character and business responsibility of such person or persons. 
Provided, however, that the provisions of this section shall not apply to applicants who are bona 
fide resident citizens of Coahoma County, Mississippi, and have been such for more than six (6) 
months prior to the date of application, if the city clerk is satisfied as to the good character and 
business responsibility of such applicant; 
(c)	The place or places in the city where it is proposed to carry on applicant's business and the 
length of time during which it is proposed that said business shall be conducted; 
(d)	The place or places other than the permanent place of business of the applicant where the 
applicant, within the six (6) months next preceding the date of said application, conducted a 
transient business, stating the nature thereof and giving the post office and street address of 
any building or office in which that business was conducted; 
(e)	A statement of the nature, character and quality of the goods, wares or merchandise to be sold 
or offered for sale by applicant in the city, the invoice value and quality of such goods, wares 
and merchandise, whether the same are proposed to be sold from stock in possession or from 
stock in possession and by sample; at auction; by direct sale or by direct sale and by taking 
orders for future delivery; whether goods or property proposed to be sold are manufactured or 
produced and where such goods or products are located at the time said application is filed; 
(f)	Whether or not the person or persons having the management or supervision of the applicant's 
business have been convicted of a crime, misdemeanor or the violation of any municipal 
ordinance, the nature of such offense and the punishment assessed therefor; 
(g)	Credentials from the person, firm or corporation for which the applicant proposes to do 
business, authorizing an applicant to act as such representative; and 
(h)	Such other reasonable information as to the identity or character of the person or persons 
having the management or supervision of applicant's business, the method or plan of doing 
such business, and any other information as the city clerk may deem necessary and proper to 
fulfill the purpose of this chapter or to protect the public health, safety and welfare. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 3, 2-23-1981; Ord. No. 774, § 1, 6-14-1982) 


Sec. 19A-4. - Same-Investigation of applicant; issuance. 
    Upon receipt of such application, the city clerk shall cause such investigation of such person or 
person's business responsibility or moral character to be made as he deems necessary to protect the 
public welfare and good. If, as a result of such investigation, the applicant's character and business 
responsibility are found to be unsatisfactory, the application shall be denied. If, as a result of the 
investigation, the character and business reputation appear to be satisfactory, the city clerk shall so 
certify in writing and a permit shall be issued by the city clerk. The city clerk shall keep a full record in his 
office of all permits issued. Such permits shall contain the date the same is issued, the nature of the 
business authorized to be carried on, the expiration date of said license, the place where said business 
may be carried on under said license, the name or names of the person or persons authorized to carry on 
the same, and a certification by the clerk that all statewide and local privilege taxes have been paid in full. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 4, 2-23-1981) 


Sec. 19A-5. - Bond. 
    Before any permit as provided by this chapter shall be issued for engaging in a transient or itinerant 
business, as defined in section 19A-1 of this chapter, such applicant shall file with the city clerk a bond 
running to the City of Clarksdale in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) executed by the 
applicant as principal and two (2) sureties upon which service of process may be made in the State of 
Mississippi; said bond to be approved by the city clerk conditioned that said applicants shall comply fully 
with all of the provisions of the ordinances of the city and the statutes of the state regulating and 
considering the sale of goods, wares and merchandise, and will pay all judgments rendered against said 
applicant for any violation of said ordinances or statutes, or any of them, together with all judgments and 
costs that may be recovered against him by any person or persons for damage growing out of any 
misrepresentation or deception practiced on any person transacting such business with such applicant, 
whether said misrepresentations or deceptions were made or practiced by the owners or by their 
servants, agents or employees, either at the time of the making of the sale or through any advertisement 
of any character whatsoever printed or circulated with reference to the goods, wares and merchandise 
sold or any part thereof. Said bond is to be in full force and effect for a period of one (1) year from the 
date thereof. Provided, however, that the provisions of this section shall not apply to applicants who are 
bona fide resident citizens of Coahoma County, Mississippi, and have been such for more than six (6) 
months prior to the date of applications, if the city clerk is satisfied as to the good character and business 
responsibility of such applicant. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 5, 2-23-1981; Ord. No. 774, § 2, 6-14-1982) 


Sec. 19A-6. - Service of process. 
    Before any permit as herein provided shall be issued for engaging in business as an itinerant 
merchant, as herein defined, in the city such applicant shall file with the city clerk an instrument 
nominating and appointing the city clerk, or the person or persons performing the duties of such position, 
his true and lawful agent with full power and authority to acknowledge service of notice of process for and 
on behalf of said applicant in respect to any matters connected with or arising out of the business 
transacted under said permit, and the bond given as required by section 19A-5 of this chapter, or for the 
performance of the conditions of said bond or for any breach thereof, which said instrument shall also 
contain recitals to the effect that said applicant for said permit consents and agrees that service of any 
notice of process may be made upon said agent and when so made shall be taken and held to be as valid 
as if personally served upon the person or persons applying for the said permit under this chapter 
according to the law of this or any other state, and waiving all claim or right or error by reason of such 
acknowledgement of service or manner of service. Immediate upon service of process upon the city clerk, 
as herein provided, the city clerk shall send to the permittee at his last known address, by registered mail, 
a copy of said process. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 6, 2-23-1981) 


Sec. 19A-7. - Exhibition of permit. 
    The permit issued under this chapter shall be posted conspicuously in the place of business named 
therein. In the event that such person or persons applying for said permit shall desire to do business in 
more than one place within the city, separate permits may be issued for each place of business and shall 
be posted conspicuously in each place of business. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 7, 2-23-1981) 


Sec. 19A-8. - Transfer of permit. 
    No permit shall be transferred without written consent from the city clerk as evidenced by an 
endorsement on the face of the permit by the city clerk showing to whom the permit is transferred and the 
date of the transfer. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 9, 2-23-1981) 


Sec. 19A-9. - Enforcement by police. 
    It shall be the duty of the police officers of the city to examine all places of business and persons in 
their respective territories subject to the provisions of this chapter to determine if this chapter has been 
complied with and to enforce the provisions of this chapter against any person found to be violating the 
same. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 10, 2-23-1981) 


Sec. 19A-10. - Record of complaints and violations to be maintained by police department. 
    The city clerk shall deposit the record of fingerprints of licensee, if given, with the chief of police. The 
chief of police shall report to the city clerk any complaints against person permitted under the provisions 
of this chapter and any conviction for violation of this chapter. The city clerk shall keep a record of all such 
permits and of such complaints and violations. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 11, 2-23-1981) 


Sec. 19A-11. - Revocation of permit. 
    The permits issued pursuant to this chapter may be revoked by the city clerk for the following 
causes: 
(a)	Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for permit; 
(b)	Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in connection with the selling of goods, 
wares or merchandise; 
(c)	Any violation of this chapter or the statutes of the State of Mississippi; 
(d)	Conviction of the permittee of any felony or of a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; or 
conducting the business permitted under this chapter in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to 
constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the 
public. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 12, 2-23-1981) 


Sec. 19A-12. - Appeals. 
    Any person aggrieved by the decision of the city clerk in regard to the denial of application for permit, 
as provided for in section 19A-4, or in connection with the revocation of a license, as provided for in 
section 19A-11, shall have the right to appeal to the board of mayor and commissioners of the city. Such 
appeal may be taken by filing with the board, within five (5) days after notice of the decision by the city 
clerk, a written statement setting forth the grounds for the appeal. The board shall set the time and place 
for a hearing on such appeal upon proper notice to the permittee. The order of the board on such appeal 
shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 13, 2-23-1981) 


Sec. 19A-13. - Expiration of permit. 
    All permits issued under the provisions of this chapter shall expire one (1) year after the date of 
issuance thereof or on the date of expiration of the privilege license issued to such permittee by Coahoma 
County, Mississippi, whichever shall occur first. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 14, 2-23-1981; Ord. No. 761, § 2, 4-13-1981) 


Sec. 19A-14. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction 
thereof, be punished by a fine not to exceed three hundred dollars ($300.00), or by imprisonment not to 
exceed ninety (90) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 758, § 15, 2-23-1981) 


Chapter 20 - UTILITY SYSTEMS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 854, adopted July 20, 1989, transferred certain powers regarding 
management of the city utility systems from the board of mayor and commissioners to the public utilities 
commission. See the editor's note-to Art. III of this chapter. 
Cross reference- Buildings, Ch. 6; electricity, Ch. 7; electric poles and transmission wires, § 7-49 et 
seq.; plumbing, Ch. 16. 


ARTICLE I. - WATER AND ELECTRICITY 


Sec. 20-1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Former § 20-1 has been deleted at the discretion of the editor as superseded by 
the provisions of Ord. No. 854, §§ 1-5, adopted July 20, 1989, included herein as Ch. 20, Art. 
III. Section 20-1 formerly pertained to management of the city waterworks and electric power 
system by the board of mayor and commissioners and derived from Ord. No. 521, § 10, adopted 
July 12, 1961. 


Sec. 20-1.1. - Application for electric service required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to consume or otherwise use electricity, electric current or power 
of the Clarksdale Public Utilities Commission or to connect to any electrical circuit, service line or meter of 
the Clarksdale Public Utilities Commission unless such person is duly authorized to do so by the said 
Clarksdale Public Utilities Commission. Any person or persons desiring to use or consume electricity, 
electric current or power of the Clarksdale Public Utilities Commission, or desiring to connect to any 
electrical circuit, service line or meter of the Clarksdale Public Utilities Commission shall make application 
for such use, consumption or connection with the Clarksdale Public Utilities Commission and shall pay 
such charges, fees, deposits and/or rates and shall comply with such policies, ordinances, rules and/or 
regulations that may be from time to time adopted, designated, promulgated or established by the 
Clarksdale Public Utilities Commission. 
(Ord. No. 674, § 1, 4-23-1973; Ord. No. 893, § 6, 11-23-1992) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 674, § 1 did not specifically amend this Code hence inclusion herein 
as § 20-1.1 was at the discretion of the editor. 


Sec. 20-2. - Utilities commission to fix rates for electrical service and water service. 
    The rates to be charges by the city for electricity or electrical service, and for water or water service, 
shall be fixed from time to time by the Clarksdale Public Utilities Commission, by resolution or otherwise 
in accordance with Miss. Code Ann. § 21-27-11 et seq. (1972) as now or hereafter amended. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 1, 11-23-1992) 


Sec. 20-3. - When water, electric and sewer bills payable. 
    The time for payment of all sums due the city for water, sewer or electric current furnished by the city 
to consumers of the city shall be as designated and fixed by the Clarksdale Public Utilities Commission. 
(Ord. No. 275, § 1, 8-9-1932; Ord. No. 617, § 1, 9-14-1970; Ord. No. 893, § 2, 11-23-1992) 


Sec. 20-4. - When water, electric and sewer bills delinquent; discontinuing service authorized. 
    Any and all bills for electric current, water or sewage collection and treatment furnished by the city 
which are not paid by the due date designated by the Clarksdale Public Utilities Commission shall be 
delinquent, and service to delinquent customers may be disconnected and discontinued in accordance 
with rules and regulations promulgated by the Clarksdale Public Utilities Commission. 
(Ord. No. 405, § 1, 2-15-1949; Ord. No. 617, § 2, 9-14-1970; Ord. No. 884, § 1, 3-9-1992; Ord. 
No. 893, § 3, 11-23-1992) 


Sec. 20-5. - Suspension of service, removal of meters. 
    Any customer and consumer of utility services furnished by the Clarksdale Public Utilities
