Commission, who is delinquent for twenty (20) days in the payment of his bill, as the same may be finally 
extended by the Clarksdale Public Utilities Commission pursuant to policies and procedures adopted by 
said Commission shall be suspended from any further water, electric current, or other utility service and 
the water and electric meters shall be disconnected from the premises of the customer. 
(Ord. No. 275, § 4, 8-9-1932; Ord. No. 884, § 2, 3-9-1992) 


Sec. 20-6. - Electric meters required; permit required to change system using city current. 
    All wiring connections for the use and consumption of electricity purchased from the city shall lead 
from a meter installed by the city in a separate building or compartment originally installed for that 
purpose. No changes in the electrical wiring for the use and consumption of electricity purchased from the 
city may be made without a permit in writing secured from the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 284, § 1, 8-1-1933) 


Sec. 20-7. - Unauthorized connections to electric meters prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person using and consuming electrical current purchased from the city to 
make wiring connections leading from any other meter than the meter originally installed by the city for 
the purpose of measuring the consumption of said electrical current; provided however, that any person 
who uses or occupies an entire building in its several compartments may, after permission in writing of the 
light and water superintendent, receive and consume all the electric current used by him, the payment for 
which he is entirely responsible, through wiring leading from one meter. 
(Ord. No. 284, § 2, 8-1-1933) 


Sec. 20-8. - Permitting connection by suspended electricity customer prohibited. 
    When and if the delivery of electric current to any person is suspended by the city for the 
nonpayment for the previous consumption of the same, it shall be unlawful for any such person to permit 
any electrical wiring connection to be made with electrical wiring leading from his meter by the said 
suspended consumer. 
(Ord. No. 284, § 3, 8-1-1933) 
Cross reference- For provision requiring inspection, approval before reconnecting 
discontinued service, see § 7-12. 


Sec. 20-9. - Penalty for unlawful use of electricity. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of sections 20-6 through 20-8 shall be fined in a sum not 
less than five dollars ($5.00), nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each separate offense, 
and every day's use or consumption of electrical current in violation of the terms of said sections shall be 
a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 284, § 5, 8-1-1933) 


Sec. 20-10. - Installation, location of electric meters. 
    All electric meters installed in the city shall be installed under the direction of the Clarksdale Public 
Utilities Commission, and shall be placed in a manner as to be accessible at all times for examination or 
reading by any agent or employee of the city charged with the duty of inspecting or reading such meters. 
All meters shall be encased in a box, the size and construction of which shall be determined by the said 
Commission which shall be furnished to protect the meter from rain or other moisture. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 6, 11-23-1992) 
Cross reference- For requirements regarding service, meter wiring, §§ 7-37, 7-38, 7-39. 
State Law reference- For authority to inspect meters, see 1942 Miss. Code, § 3374-141. 


Sec. 20-11. - Authority to remove improperly installed electric meters, discontinue service. 
    Any meter hereafter installed in a manner contrary to the provisions set forth in the preceding 
section, or in a manner not approved by the Clarksdale Public Utilities Commission may be removed by 
the said Commission, unless the installation thereof be made to conform to aid provisions and 
specifications upon request of the Commission, and the city may refuse to furnish current to any building 
in which any meter is hereafter installed in a manner contrary to the preceding section. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 6, 11-23-1992) 


Sec. 20-12. - Damage or destruction of electric meters. 
    Any owner of real property, or any lessee of real property in the event said real property is leased, 
shall be responsible financially for any damage to or destruction of any electric meter of the City of 
Clarksdale, Mississippi, located on said property. 
    In the event the owner or lessee of said property as referred to in subsection (a) hereof, does not pay 
the City of Clarksdale within ten (10) days for the damage or destruction of meters referred to in 
subsection (a) hereof, then said electric services from the City of Clarksdale shall be discontinued. 
(Ord. No. 601, §§ 1, 2, 7-15-1968) 
Editor's note- Section 20-12 is derived from Ord. No. 601, §§ 1, 2. This ordinance, 
nonamendatory of this Code, was codified as said section in the discretion of the editors. 


Secs. 20-13-20-16. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE II. - SEWERS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 735, §§ 1-13, passed Feb. 19, 1979, amended Art. II to read as herein set out in 
§§ 20-17-20-69. Sections 20-70 and 20-11 of said ordinance, repealer and effective date provisions, 
respectively, were omitted at the editor's discretion. Superseded §§ 20-17-20-28 which formerly 
comprised Art. II were derived from Code 1922, §§ 208, 209; Ord. No. 233, §§ 1, 2, passed July 31, 1928; 
Ord. No. 499, §§ 1-7, passed Jan. 6, 1959; Ord. No. 630, § 1, passed May 24, 1971; and Ord. No. 701, 
§§ 1, 2, passed Sept. 8, 1975. 
State Law reference- General authority of municipalities concerning sewers, 1942 Miss. Code, §§ 
3374-112 and 3374-129. 


Sec. 20-17. - Definitions. 
    Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms used in Chapter 20, Article 
II, entitled "Sewers," of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi, shall be as follows: 
    Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) shall mean the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical 
oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five (5) days at twenty (20) degrees 
centigrade, expressed in milligrams per liter. 
    Building drain shall mean that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which 
receives the discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and 
conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five (5) feet (1.5 meters) outside the inner face of the building 
wall. 
    Building sewer shall mean the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of 
disposal, also called house connection. 
    Combined sewer shall mean a sewer intended to receive both wastewater and storm or surface 
water. 
    Easement shall mean an acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others. 
    Floatable oil is oil, fat or grease in a physical state such that it will separate by gravity from 
wastewater by treatment in an approved pretreatment facility. A wastewater shall be considered free of 
floatable fat if it is properly pretreated and the wastewater does not interfere with the collection system. 
    Garbage shall mean the animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, 
cooking, and serving of foods. 
    Industrial wastes shall mean the wastewater from industrial processes, trade, or business as distinct 
from domestic or sanitary wastes. 
    May is permissive (see "shall"). 
    Natural outlet shall mean any outlet, including storm sewers and combined sewer overflows, into a 
watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface water or groundwater. 
    Person shall mean any individual, firm, company, association, society, corporation or group. 
    pH shall mean the logarithm of the reciprocal of the hydrogen-ion concentration. The concentration is 
the weight of hydrogen ions, in grams, per liter of solution. Neutral water, for example, has a pH value of 
7 and a hydrogen-ion concentration of 10-7. 
    Plumbing official is the individual, official, board, department or agency established and authorized 
by the city to administer and enforce the provisions of the plumbing code as adopted or amended in 
section 16-2 hereof. 
    Properly shredded garbage shall mean the wastes from the preparation, cooking, and dispensing of 
food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow 
conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half (1/2) inch (1.27 
centimeters) in any dimension. 
    Public sewer shall mean a common sewer controlled by a governmental agency or public utility. 
    Sanitary sewer shall mean a sewer that carries liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, 
commercial buildings, industrial plants and institutions together with minor quantities of ground, storm and 
surface waters that are not admitted intentionally. 
    Sewage is the spent water of a community. The preferred term is "wastewater." 
    Sewer shall mean a pipe or conduit that carries wastewater or drainage water. 
    Shall is mandatory. 
    Slug shall mean any discharge of water or wastewater which in concentration of any given 
constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer than fifteen (15) minutes more 
than five (5) times the average twenty-four-hour concentration or flows during normal operation and shall 
adversely affect the collection system and/or performance of the wastewater treatment works. 
    Storm drain (sometimes termed "storm sewer") shall mean a drain or sewer for conveying water, 
groundwater, subsurface water, or unpolluted water from any source. 
    Superintendent shall mean the superintendent of wastewater facilities, and/or of wastewater 
treatment works, and/or of water pollution control of the city, or his authorized deputy, agent or 
representative. 
    Suspended solids shall mean total suspended matter that either floats on the surface of, or is in 
suspension in, water, wastewater or other liquids, and that is removable by laboratory filtering as 
prescribed in "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater" and referred to as 
nonfilterable residue. 
    Unpolluted water is water of quality equal to or better than the effluent criteria in effect or water that 
would not cause violation of receiving water quality standards and would not be benefited by discharge to 
the sanitary sewer and wastewater treatment facilities provided. 
    Wastewater shall mean the spent water of a community. From the standpoint of source, it may be a 
combination of the liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial 
plants and institutions, together with any groundwater, surface water and stormwater that may be present. 
    Wastewater facilities shall mean the structures, equipment, and processes required to collect, carry 
away and treat domestic and industrial wastes and dispose of the effluent. 
    Wastewater treatment works shall mean an arrangement of devices and structures for treating 
wastewater, industrial wastes, and sludge. Sometimes used as synonymous with "waste treatment plant" 
or "wastewater treatment plant" or "water pollution control plant." 
    Watercourse shall mean a natural or artificial channel for the passage of water either continuously or 
intermittently. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 1, 2-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-18. - Disposal of waste-Regulated. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary 
manner on public or private property within the city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of said city, any 
human or animal excrement, garbage or objectionable waste. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 2, 2-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-19. - Same-Discharge into natural outlet within city prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the city, or in any area under the 
jurisdiction of said city, any wastewater or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has 
been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 3, 2-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-20. - Privies, privy vaults, septic tanks, cesspools, etc., prohibited; exception. 
    Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, 
septic tank, cesspool or other facility intended or used for the disposal of wastewater. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 4, 2-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-21. - Facilities required; duty of property owner to provide; sewer connections required. 
    The owner(s) of all houses, buildings or properties used for human occupancy, employment, 
recreation, or other purposes, situated within the city and abutting on any street, alley, or right-of-way in 
which there is now located or may in the future be located a public sanitary or combined sewer of the city, 
is hereby required at the expense of the owner(s) to install suitable toilet facilities therein, and to connect 
such facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this article, within 
ninety (90) days after the date of official notice to do so, provided that said public sewer is within one 
hundred (100) feet (30.5 meters) of the property line. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 5, 2-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-22. - Private wastewater disposal system-Generally. 
    Where a public sanitary or combined sewer is not available under the provisions of section 20-21 
hereof, the building sewer shall be connected to a private wastewater disposal system complying with the 
provisions of sections 20-23 through 20-28 hereof. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 6, 2-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-23. - Same-Permit required before construction; application for permit. 
    Before commencement of construction of a private wastewater disposal system the owner(s) shall 
first obtain a written permit signed by the plumbing official. The application for such permit shall be made 
on a form furnished by the city, which the applicant shall supplement by any plans, specifications and 
other information as are deemed necessary by the plumbing official. A permit and inspection fee as 
provided in chapter 16 hereof in compliance with the Standard Plumbing Code shall be paid to the city at 
the time the application is filed. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 7, 2-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-24. - Same-Compliance and inspection. 
    A permit for a private wastewater disposal system shall not become effective until the installation is 
completed to the satisfaction of the plumbing official. The plumbing official shall be allowed to inspect the 
work at any stage of construction, and, in any event, the applicant for the permit shall notify the plumbing 
official when the work is ready for final inspection and before any underground portions are covered. The 
inspection shall be made within two (2) working days after the receipt of notice by the plumbing official. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 8, 2-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-25. - Same-Compliance with state agency recommendations and Standard Plumbing Code; 
prohibited discharge. 
    The type, capacities, location, and layout of a private wastewater disposal system shall comply with 
all recommendations of the department of public health of the State of Mississippi, and the Mississippi Air 
and Water Pollution Control Commission, and with the provisions of the Standard Plumbing Code as 
provided in section 16-2 hereof. No septic tank or cesspool shall be permitted to discharge to any natural 
outlet. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 9, 2-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-26. - Same-Sewer connection required; compliance. 
    At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served by a private wastewater 
disposal system, as provided in section 20-21 hereof, a direct connection shall be made to the public 
sewer within sixty (60) days in compliance with this article, and any septic tanks, cesspools, and similar 
private wastewater disposal facilities shall be cleaned of sludge and filled with suitable material. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 10, 2-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-27. - Same-Owner to maintain. 
    The owner(s) shall operate and maintain the private wastewater disposal facilities in a sanitary 
manner at all times, at no expense to the city. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 11, 2-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-28. - Same-Additional requirements of health officer. 
    No statement contained in sections 20-22 through 20-27 shall be construed to interfere with any 
additional requirements that may be imposed by the health officer of the city or by any state or federal 
health officer. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 12, 2-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-29. - Privilege license-Required for cleaning, etc., unpolluted water or wastewater from private 
wastewater disposal facilities, etc.; exceptions. 
    No person(s) shall engage in the business of cleaning, removing, transporting, or disposing of any 
unpolluted water or wastewater from any private wastewater disposal facilities or other source which is 
not a part of the public wastewater facilities of the city, nor operate or maintain anywhere in the city any 
vehicle used or in connection with the cleaning, transporting or disposing of any unpolluted water or 
wastewater from any private wastewater disposal facilities or other source which is not a part of the public 
wastewater facilities of the city without first, before commencing the same, applying for, paying for, and 
procuring from the city tax collector, a privilege license. 
    Notwithstanding the foregoing, no such license shall be required where: 
(a)	Any such previously described vehicle is operated from a business location, office or 
headquarters located outside the city, and is transporting any unpolluted water or wastewater to 
a location within the city to be discharged at a location and in a manner that does not violate 
any of the provisions of this article; or 
(b)	Any such previously described vehicle is rendering assistance to the public wastewater facilities 
of the city at the request of the board of mayor and commissioners or the superintendent in 
case of a major disaster or emergency. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 2-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-30. - Same-Cash deposit. 
    Before a privilege license as provided herein is issued or renewed, the applicant shall deposit with 
the city clerk an advance fee in such amount as the plumbing official shall find reasonably necessary to 
insure payment of the rates set forth herein, subject to appeal to the board of mayor and commissioners. 
Any advance deposit fee remaining at the end of each licensing period after payment of all fees, charges, 
fines and rates shall be either refunded or credited to the advance fee in such amount as the plumbing 
official shall 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 2-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-31. - Same-Regulations; insurance required. 
    Prior to the commencement of business hereunder and at all times thereafter, license holders shall 
carry and maintain adequate public liability insurance and other such insurance as may be required by 
the plumbing official, subject to appeal to the board of mayor and commissioners, maintain suitable 
equipment in good repair with such tags and/or discernible markings as prescribed by the plumbing 
official, and also follow such methods of operation as are prescribed by regulations prepared by the 
plumbing official. A license from the Coahoma County Health Department or other health department or 
governmental agency having jurisdiction may be required by the plumbing official as a condition 
precedent to the issuance of a license as required by section 20-29. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 2-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-31.1. - Same-Required before discharging contents of vehicle. 
    Each tank truck or other vehicle shall be so equipped as to permit emptying the contents of the tank 
truck or other vehicle into the wastewater facilities of the city through a hose submerged at the end 
through the opening of a public sanitary sewer of the city, and no person shall empty a tank truck or other 
vehicle into the wastewater facilities of the city in any other manner unless permitted or required by the 
plumbing official. The plumbing official may also specify the particular location where such contents of 
such tank truck or other vehicle may be emptied into the wastewater facilities of the city. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 2-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-32. - Building sewers and connections-Unauthorized connections, etc. prohibited. 
    No unauthorized person(s) shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter or 
disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the plumbing 
official. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 2-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-33. - Same-Permits; inspections; fees. 
    There shall be two (2) classes of building sewer permits: 
(a)	For residential and commercial services; and 
(b)	For service to establishments producing industrial wastes. 
    In either case, the owner(s) or his agent shall make application on a special form furnished by the 
city. The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications or other information 
considered pertinent in the judgment of the plumbing official. 
    A permit and inspection fee in the amount as set forth in Chapter 16 of the Code of Ordinances of 
the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi, shall be paid to the city at the time the application is filed. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 2-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-34. - Same-Costs borne by owner(s); indemnification of city. 
    All costs and expenses incidental to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be 
borne by the owner(s). The owner(s) shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or 
indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 2-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-35. - Same-Separate sewer for each building. 
    A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building; except where one 
building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be 
constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard or driveway, the [building sewer of 
the] front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one building sewer, 
but the city does not and will not assume any obligation or responsibility for damage caused by or 
resulting from any such single connection aforementioned. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 2-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-36. - Same-When old sewers may be used. 
    Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on 
examination and test by the plumbing official to meet all requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 2-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-37. - Same-Must conform to codes; etc. 
    The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building sewer, and the methods to be used 
in excavating, placing of the pipe, jointing, testing and backfilling the trench shall all conform to the 
requirements of the building and plumbing codes or other applicable rules and regulations of the city. In 
the absence of code provisions or in amplification thereof, the materials and procedures set forth in 
appropriate specifications of the ASTM and WPCF Manual of Practice No. 9 shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 12-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-38. - Same-Elevation of sewer to be below basement floor or sewage lifted. 
    Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the 
basement floor. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public 
sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such building drain shall be lifted by an approved means and 
discharged to the building sewer. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 12-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-39. - Same-Connection with storm drain not permitted. 
    No person(s) shall make connection of roof downspouts, foundation drains, areaway drains, or other 
sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected 
directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer unless such connection is approved by the plumbing official 
for purposes of disposal of polluted surface drainage. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 12-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-40. - Same-Connection of building sewer to public sewer to conform to codes; etc. 
    The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of the 
building and plumbing codes or other applicable rules and regulations of the city, or the procedures set 
forth in appropriate specifications of the ASTM and the WPCF Manual of Practice No. 9. All such 
connections shall be made gastight and watertight and verified by proper testing. Any deviation from the 
prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the plumbing official before installation. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 12-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-41. - Same-Applicant to give notice for inspection and connection. 
    The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the plumbing official when the building sewer 
is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection and testing shall be made 
under the supervision of the plumbing official or his representative. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 12-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-42. - Same-Protection of public; restoration of public property. 
    All excavations for building sewer installations shall be adequately guarded with barricades and 
lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property 
disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 12-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-43. - Use of the public sewers-Discharge of unpolluted water into sanitary sewers not 
permitted; exception. 
    No person(s) shall discharge or cause to be discharged any unpolluted waters such as storm water, 
groundwater, roof run-off, subsurface drainage or cooling water to any sewer, except storm water runoff 
from limited areas, which storm water may be polluted at times, may be discharged to the sanitary sewer 
by permission of the plumbing official. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 12-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-44. - Same-Unpolluted water to be discharged into storm or combined sewer or natural outlet. 
    Storm water other than that exempted under section 20-43, and all other unpolluted drainage shall 
be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as combined sewers or storm sewers or to a 
natural outlet approved by the plumbing official and other regulatory agencies. Unpolluted industrial 
cooling water or process waters may be discharged, on approval of the plumbing official, to a storm 
sewer, combined sewer, or natural outlet. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 12-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-45. - Same-Inadmissible wastes. 
    No person(s) shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following described waters or 
wastes to any public sewers: 
(a)	Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas. 
(b)	Any waters containing toxic or poisonous solids, liquids or gases in sufficient quantity, either 
singly or by interaction with other wastes, to injure or interfere with any waste treatment 
process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, create a public nuisance or create any 
hazard in the receiving waters of the wastewater treatment plant 
(c)	Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.5, or having any other corrosive property 
capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment and personnel of the wastewater 
works. 
(d)	Solid or viscous substances in quantities or of such size capable of causing obstruction to the 
flow in sewers, or other interference with the proper operation of the wastewater facilities such 
as, but not limited to, ashes, bones, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, 
feathers, tar, plastics, wood, unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure, hair and 
fleshings, entrails and paper dishes, cups, milk containers, etc., either whole or ground by 
garbage grinders. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 12-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-46. - Same-Limited admissible wastes. 
    The following described substances, materials, waters or waste shall be limited in discharges to 
municipal systems to concentrations or quantities which will not harm either the sewers, wastewater 
treatment process or equipment, will not have an adverse effect on the receiving stream, or will not 
otherwise endanger lives, limb or public property or constitute a nuisance. The plumbing official may set 
limitations lower than the limitations established in the regulations below if in his opinion such more 
severe limitations are necessary to meet the above objectives. In forming his opinion as to the 
acceptability, the plumbing official will give consideration to such factors as the quantity of subject waste 
in relation to flows and velocities in the sewers, materials of construction of the sewers, the wastewater 
treatment process employed, capacity of the wastewater treatment plant, degree of treatability of the 
waste in the wastewater treatment plant and other pertinent factors. The limitations or restrictions on 
materials or characteristics of waste or wastewaters discharged to the sanitary sewer which shall not be 
violated without approval of the plumbing official are as follows: 
(a)	Wastewater having a temperature higher than one hundred fifty (150) degrees Fahrenheit (65° 
Celsius). 
(b)	Wastewater containing more than twenty-five (25) milligrams per liter of petroleum oil, 
nonbiodegradable cutting oils or products of mineral oil origin. 
(c)	Wastewater from industrial plants containing floatable oils, fat or grease. 
(d)	Any garbage that has not been properly shredded (see section 20-17). Garbage grinders may 
be connected to sanitary sewers from homes, hotels, institutions, restaurants, hospitals, 
catering establishments or similar places where garbage originates from the preparation of food 
in kitchens for the purpose of consumption on the premises or when served by caterers. 
(e)	Any waters or wastes containing iron, chromium, copper, zinc and similar objectionable or toxic 
substances to such degree that any such material received in the composite wastewater at the 
wastewater treatment works exceeds the limits established by the plumbing official for such 
materials. 
(f)	Any waters or wastes containing odor-producing substances exceeding limits which may be 
established by the plumbing official. 
(g)	Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or concentration as may exceed limits 
established by the plumbing official in compliance with applicable state or federal regulations. 
(h)	Quantities of flow, concentrations or both which constitute a "slug" as defined herein. 
(i)	Waters or wastes containing substances which are not amenable to treatment or reduction by 
the wastewater treatment process employed, or are amenable to treatment only to such degree 
that the wastewater treatment plant effluent cannot meet the requirements of other agencies 
having jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving waters. 
(j)	Any water or wastes which, by interaction with other water or wastes in the public sewer 
system, release obnoxious gases, form suspended solids which interfere with the collection 
system or create a condition deleterious to structures and treatment processes. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 12-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-47. - Same-Limited admissible wastes, powers of plumbing official with respect to. 
    If any waters or wastes are discharged or are proposed to be discharged to the public sewers, which 
waters contain the substances or possess the characteristics enumerated in section 20-46, and which in 
the judgment of the plumbing official may have a deleterious effect upon the wastewater facilities, 
processes, equipment or receiving waters, or which otherwise create a hazard to life or constitute a public 
nuisance, the plumbing official may: 
(a)	Reject the wastes; 
(b)	Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the public sewers; 
(c)	Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge; and/or 
(d)	Require payment to cover added cost of handling and treating the wastes not covered by 
existing taxes or sewer charges under the provisions of this article. 
    When considering the above alternatives, the plumbing official shall give consideration to the 
economic impact of each alternative on the discharger. If the plumbing official permits the pretreatment or 
equalization of waste flows, the design and installation of the plants and equipment shall be subject to the 
review and approval of the plumbing official. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 12-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-48. - Same-Interceptors may be required. 
    Grease, oil, and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the plumbing official, 
they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing floatable grease in excessive 
amounts, as specified in section 20-46(c), or any flammable wastes, sand or other harmful ingredients; 
except that such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All 
interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the plumbing official, and shall be located as to 
be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. In the maintaining of these interceptors the 
owner(s) shall be responsible for the proper removal and disposal by appropriate means of the captured 
material and shall maintain records of the dates, and means of disposal which are subject to review by 
the plumbing official, Any removal and hauling of the collected materials not performed by personnel of 
the owner(s) must be performed by currently licensed waste disposal firms. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 12-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-49. - Same-Owners to maintain pretreatment or flow-equalizing facilities. 
    Where pretreatment or flow-equalizing facilities are provided or required for any waters or wastes, 
they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner(s) at his 
expense. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 12-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-50. - Same-Owners to furnish facilities to measure flow of industrial wastes. 
    When required by the plumbing official, the owner of any property serviced by a building sewer 
carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable structure together with such necessary meters and other 
appurtenances in the building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling and measurement of the wastes. 
Such structure, when required, shall be accessibly and safely located and shall be constructed in 
accordance with plans approved by the plumbing official. The structure shall be installed by the owner at 
his expense and shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and accessible at all times. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 12-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-51. - Same-User to furnish certain information if requested. 
    The plumbing official may require a user of sewer services to provide information needed to 
determine compliance with this article. These requirements may include: 
(a)	Wastewaters discharge peak rate and volume over a specified time period. 
(b)	Chemical analyses of wastewaters. 
(c)	Information on raw materials, processes, and products affecting wastewater volume and quality. 
(d)	Quantity and disposition of specific liquid, sludge, oil, solvent or other materials important to 
sewer use control. 
(e)	A plot plan of sewers of the user's property showing sewer and pretreatment facility location. 
(f)	Details of wastewater pretreatment facilities. 
(g)	Details of systems to prevent and control the losses of materials through spills to the municipal 
sewer. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 12-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-52. - Same-Standards for analysis of samples. 
    All measurements, tests, and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which 
reference is made in this article shall be determined in accordance with the latest edition of "Standard 
Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater," published by the American Public Health 
Association. Sampling methods, location, times, durations and frequencies are to be determined on an 
individual basis subject to approval by the plumbing official. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 12-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-53. - Same-Special agreements between city and industrial concerns. 
    No statement contained in this article shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or 
arrangement between the city and any industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength 
or character may be accepted by the city for treatment. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 12-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-54. - Destruction of public property. 
    No person(s) shall maliciously or willfully, break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with 
any structure, appurtenance or equipment which is a part of the wastewater facilities. Any person(s) 
violating this provision shall be subject to immediate arrest under charge of malicious mischief. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 12-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-55. - Powers and authority of inspectors-Permitted to enter all properties for certain purposes. 
    The plumbing official and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and 
identification shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, 
measurement, sampling and testing pertinent to discharge to the community system in accordance with 
the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 12-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-56. - Same-To obtain information concerning industrial processes which affect wastewater 
system. 
    The plumbing official or other duly authorized employees are authorized to obtain information 
concerning industrial processes which have a direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge to the 
wastewater collection system. The industry may withhold information considered confidential. The 
industry must establish that the revelation to the public of the information in question might result in an 
advantage to competitors. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 12-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-57. - Same-To observe all safety rules; indemnification of company; exception. 
    While performing the necessary work on private properties referred to in section 20-55, above, the 
plumbing official or duly authorized employees of the city shall observe all safety rules applicable to the 
premises established by the company, and the company shall be held harmless for injury or death to the 
city employees, and the city shall indemnify the company against loss or damage to its property by city 
employees and against liability claims and demands for personal injury or property damage assessed 
against the company and growing out of the gauging and sampling operation, except as such may be 
caused by negligence or failure of the company to maintain safe conditions as required in Section 20-50. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 12-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-58. - Same-Permitted to enter easements for certain purposes. 
    The plumbing official and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and 
identification shall be permitted to enter all private properties through which the city holds a duly 
negotiated easement for the purposes of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement, 
sampling, repair and maintenance of any portion of the wastewater facilities lying within said easement. 
All entry and subsequent work, if any, on said easement shall be done in full accordance with the terms of 
the duly negotiated easement pertaining to the private property involved. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13,12-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-59. - Service charges-"Dwelling unit" defined. 
    For the purpose of this article, the term "dwelling unit," when used herein, shall mean any living 
quarters with bath and/or kitchen facilities which is furnished water by the city, whether served by an 
individual meter or not. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 12-19-1979; Ord. No. 755, § 1, 10-6-1980; Ord. No. 760, § 1, 4-13-1981; 
Ord. No. 831, § 1, 4-1-1987) 


Sec. 20-60. - Utilities commission to fix rates for sewer service. 
    The rates to be charged for sewerage collection, treatment and disposal and sewer service shall be 
fixed from time to time by the Clarksdale Public Utilities Commission by resolution or otherwise in 
accordance with Miss. Code Ann. section 21-27-11 et seq. as now or hereafter amended. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 12-19-1979; Ord. No. 765, § 1, 8-31-1981; Ord. No. 802, § 1, 9-24-1984; 
Ord. No. 824, § 1, 4-21-1986; Ord. No. 831, § 2, 4-1-1987; Ord. No. 893, § 4, 11-23-1992) 


Sec. 20-61. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 893, § 5, adopted Nov. 23, 1992, amended this Code by repealing § 
20-61, pertaining to service charges for sewer rates for commercial and small industrial 
customers, as derived from Ord. No. 735, § 13, adopted Dec. 19, 1979; Ord. No. 766, § 1, 
adopted Aug. 31, 1981; Ord. No. 802, § 2, adopted Sept. 24, 1984; and Ord. No. 831, § 3, 
adopted April 1, 1987. 


Sec. 20-62. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 893, § 5, adopted Nov. 23, 1992, amended this Code by repealing § 
20-62, pertaining to service charges for sewer rates for municipal sewer customers, as derived 
from Ord. No. 735, § 13, adopted Dec. 19, 1979; Ord. No. 767, § 1, adopted Aug. 31, 1981; Ord. 
No. 802, § 3, adopted Sept. 24, 1984; and Ord. No. 834, § 1, adopted Oct. 26, 1987. 


Sec. 20-63. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 893, § 5, adopted Nov. 23, 1992, amended this Code by repealing § 
20-63, pertaining to service charges for sewer rates for large industrial customers, as derived 
from Ord. No. 735, § 13, adopted Dec. 19, 1979; Ord. No. 802, § 4, adopted Sept. 24, 1984; Ord. 
No. 831, § 4, adopted April 1, 1987; and Ord. No. 834, § 2, adopted Oct. 26, 1987. 


Sec. 20-64. - Same-Manner of collection of sewer rates. 
    The charges herein imposed shall be collected by the Clarksdale Public Utilities Commission and 
shall be included with the water bills of each customer, and failure to pay the same within the time 
provided for by the rules and regulations of the Clarksdale Public Utilities Commission shall result in 
discontinuance of water service at the time provided in said rules and regulations, after proper notice for 
the opportunity of a due process hearing. Service shall be resumed thereafter only on payment of the 
accumulated fees for the period of service and the period of nonservice, plus a penalty of fifteen dollars 
($15.00) unless the Clarksdale Public Utilities Commission specifically directs otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 12-19-1979; Ord. No. 831, § 5, 4-1-1987; Ord. No. 893, § 6, 11-23-1992) 


Sec. 20-65. - Same-Discontinuance of sewer service for failure to pay water or sewer charges. 
    Any person who is delinquent in payment for water or sewer service shall be disconnected from the 
city sewers and no longer entitled to use said sewers. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 12-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-66. - Sewer improvement fund-Service charge collections to be paid into. 
    The Clarksdale Public Utilities Commission shall, after collection charges have been deducted, pay 
each month into a fund, to be known as the sewer improvement fund, the amount of sewer service 
charges collected during the previous month. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 12-19-1979; Ord. No. 893, § 6, 11-23-1992) 


Sec. 20-67. - Same-Use. 
    The moneys paid into the sewer improvement fund shall be used for the purpose of paying for the 
improvement, enlargement and construction of the sewage system of the city, and the planning, 
designing, construction and operation of a sewage disposal system for the city. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 12-19-1979) 


Sec. 20-68. - Penalties. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor 
and upon conviction thereof shall be fined in an amount not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) or 
be imprisoned in the city jail for a period not exceeding ninety (90) days or be both so fined and 
imprisoned. Each day such violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate 
offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 12-19-1979; Ord. No. 831, § 6, 4-1-1987) 


Sec. 20-69. - Separability. 
    If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase or portion of this article is for any reason held 
invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a 
separate, distinct, and independent provision and such holding shall not affect the validity of the 
remaining portions hereof. 
(Ord. No. 735, § 13, 12-19-1979) 


Secs. 20-70-20-80. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE III. - PUBLIC UTILITIES COMMISSION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Inclusion of Ord. No. 854, §§ 1-5, adopted July 20, 1989, as Ch. 20, Art. III, §§ 20-81-
20-85, was at the discretion of the editor, the ordinance not being specifically amendatory of the Code. 
 Section 8 of Ord. No. 854 provided as follows "... any prior ordinance, resolution, or order of the Board 
of Mayor and Commissioners affecting any system as defined in Article I hereinabove which refers to the 
exercise of a right or power or performance of a duty by said Board of Mayor and Commissioners shall, to 
the extent said power or duty is not reserved herein to said Board of Mayor and Commissioners, be and 
the same is hereby amended to refer to the Clarksdale Public Utilities Commission." 


Sec. 20-81. - Purpose of article. 
    The purpose and intent of the board of mayor and commissioners is to provide for the city all benefits 
resulting from the creation of a commission to control, manage, and operate the utility systems of the city, 
and to exercise all powers extended to municipalities by section 21-27-11 et seq., Mississippi Code 1972 
Annotated. 
(Ord. No. 854, § 1, 7-20-1989) 


Sec. 20-82. - Formation of commission. 
(a)	Creation. There is hereby created effective with the effective date of this article a commission 
pursuant to section 21-27-13, Mississippi Code 1972 Annotated, as now or hereafter amended, to 
control, manage, and operate the following utility systems owned and operated by the city: the 
waterworks system, water supply system, sewage system, sewage disposal system, and any 
combination thereof, and the electric generating, transmission, and distribution system, and any part 
or combination thereof, and all parts and appurtenances thereof, as defined by section 21-27-11, 
Mississippi Code 1972 Annotated (Supp. 1988), together with such other systems which the board of 
mayor and commissioners may hereafter by ordinance delegate the control, management, and 
operation of to said commission. 
(b)	Name. The commission shall be known as the Clarksdale Public Utilities Commission and may 
conduct all of its business and affairs under said name, and all references herein to "the 
commission" shall mean the Clarksdale Public Utilities Commission. 
(c)	Initial date of operation. The commission hereby created shall assume the control, management, and 
operation of said systems on October 1, 1989. 
(Ord. No. 854, § 2, 7-20-1989) 


Sec. 20-83. - Commissioners. 
(a)	Number of commissioners. The commission shall consist of five (5) commissioners, each to be 
elected by the board of mayor and commissioners. 
(b)	Posts and terms. Each commissioner shall be elected to a designated post, which post shall be 
referred to by number, to wit: post 1, post 2, post 3, post 4, and post 5, with each commissioner to 
serve a term of five (5) years or until his successor is elected and qualified; provided, however, that 
the initial term of the first commissioner elected to post 1 shall be one year; the initial term of the first 
commissioner elected to post 2 shall be two (2) years; the initial term of the first commissioner 
elected to post 3 shall be three (3) years; and the initial term of the first commissioner elected to post 
4 shall be four (4) years, so that thereafter the term of office of one commissioner shall expire each 
year. 
(c)	Qualifications. Each commissioner shall at all times during his term be a qualified elector of the city, 
and shall not hold any other municipal office for honor or profit. 
(d)	Compensation. Each commissioner shall receive compensation in the amount of five hundred dollars 
($500.00) per month, together with reasonable and necessary expenses incurred by said 
commissioner in the performance of his duties. The compensation of said commissioners may be 
modified from time to time by order of the board of mayor and commissioners. 
(e)	Performance bond. Each commissioner shall, before entering upon his duties, furnish bond for the 
faithful performance of his duties in the penal sum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00), the 
premiums of which shall be payable from the funds of the systems. 
(f)	Removal. The board of mayor and commissioners shall have and retain the power to remove any 
member of said commission for inefficiency, incompetency, or any other cause. 
(Ord. No. 854, § 3, 7-20-1989; Ord. No. 948, § 1, 12-1-1997; Ord. No. 1012, § 1, 8-22-2005) 


Sec. 20-84. - Powers and duties. 
(a)	General grant of powers and duties. 
(1)	The commission created herein shall have and is hereby delegated by the board of mayor and 
commissioners all powers, authorities, and duties vested in, permitted to be exercised by, or 
imposed upon the commission contemplated by sections 21-27-11 through 21-27-103, section 
77-5-701 et seq. (the Joint Municipal Electric Power and Energy Law), and any other law, 
statute, or ordinance authorizing or permitting the exercise by the city of a power or right with 
respect to a system as defined in section 20-81, together with all powers and duties heretofore 
exercised or performed by or imposed upon the board of mayor and commissioners with 
respect to said systems, exclusive, however, of those powers and duties specifically reserved 
by applicable law to be exercised or performed only by the board of mayor and commissioners 
whether by a law or statute of the United States of America or the state or the ordinances, 
orders, and resolutions heretofore adopted and promulgated by the city, including but not limited 
to this Code, the bond resolution issuing the $3,785,000.00 Electric System Revenue Refunding 
Bond, Series 1978, dated June 6, 1978, and the bond resolution issuing the $6,130,000.00 
Sewer Revenue Bonds, Series 1987, dated December 1, 1987. 
(2)	It is the intent of this section that, except for those powers and duties which as a result of 
statutes, regulations, ordinances, or contracts, or this article, are specifically reserved to be 
exercised or performed only by the board of mayor and commissioners and [which] may not be 
delegated to the commission herein created, said commission is hereby delegated and shall 
exercise and perform all powers and all duties of the city with respect to its systems as defined 
in section 20-81 hereinabove. 
(b)	Reports to board of mayor and commissioners. Without limiting the foregoing delegation and grant of 
authority, the commission shall report quarterly to the board of mayor and commissioners on all of its 
actions and transactions of every kind whatsoever, which report shall also contain a complete 
statement of the financial condition of each system as defined in section 20-81 above. Further, the 
commission shall annually make a detailed statement to the board of mayor and commissioners 
concerning the entire management and operation of said systems. 
(c)	Budget and transfer of funds. Further, without limiting the foregoing delegation and grant of authority, 
the commission shall, on or prior to September 1 of each year, deliver to the board of mayor and 
commissioners its budget for the operation and management of the systems for the ensuing fiscal 
year, which budget shall provide for the transfer to the board of mayor and commissioners for 
distribution to various municipal funds such amounts of the surplus revenue, if any, of the systems as 
requested by the board of commissioners, all as set forth in sections 21-27-19 and 21-27-57, 
Mississippi Code 1972 Annotated, as now or hereafter amended. Further, nothing herein contained 
shall be construed to limit or otherwise alter the discretion of the commission to lend available funds 
of the systems to various other municipal funds to be repaid upon reasonable terms and conditions, 
including reasonable interest. 
(Ord. No. 854, § 4, 7-20-1989) 


Sec. 20-85. - Abolition. 
    The commission herein created shall not be abolished nor shall the powers herein granted be 
diminished except in accordance with section 21-27-15, Mississippi Code 1972 Annotated, as now or 
hereafter amended. 
(Ord. No. 854, § 5, 7-20-1989) 


Sec. 20-86. - Trespass. 
    No person other than officers of the Clarksdale Public Utilities Commission and of the city, and their 
duly authorized and designated employees, agents, and independent contractors shall enter or be upon 
any facility, structure, or equipment used in the transmission or distribution of water or electric current by 
the Clarksdale Public Utilities Commission, or upon the wastewater facilities as defined by section 20-17 
of the Code of Ordinance of the City of Clarksdale, Mississippi, or upon the real property upon which such 
facilities, structures, equipment, or wastewater facilities are located. Entry upon such facilities, structures, 
equipment, or wastewater facilities by an unauthorized person shall constitute a trespass and, upon 
conviction thereof, such person shall be fined in an amount not exceeding one thousand dollars 
($1,000.00) or be imprisoned for a period not exceeding ninety (90) days, or be both so fined and 
imprisoned. 
(Ord. No. 883, § 1, 3-9-1992) 
Editor's note- Inasmuch as Ord. No. 883, § 1, adopted Mar. 9, 1992, did not specify manner of 
codification, inclusion herein as § 20-86 was at the editor's discretion. 


Secs. 20-87-20-90. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE IV. - CROSS-CONNECTION CONTROL[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 970, §§ 1-5, adopted September 7, 1999, enacted provisions which were not 
specifically amendatory of the Code. At the editor's discretion, and for purposes of classification, these 
provisions have been included herein as a new Art. IV, §§ 20-91-20-95. 


Sec. 20-91. - Definitions. 
    Back pressure backflow means backflow caused by a lower pressure in the potable supply than at 
the point of delivery. 
    Back siphonage backflow means backflow caused by a negative pressure in the potable supply line. 
    Backflow means the reversal of normal flow direction where water flows from the intended point of 
delivery towards the supply. 
    Contaminant means any physical, chemical, biological, or radiological substance or matter in water. 
    Cross-connection means any direct interconnection between the water system and other water 
source which may result in the contamination of the drinking water provided by the water system, and 
shall include any arrangement of piping where a potable water line is connected to non-potable water, 
including but not limited to a pipe-to-pipe connection where potable and non-potable water lines are 
directly connected, or a pipe-to-water connection where the potable water outlet is submerged in non-
potable water. A cross-connection shall be deemed to exist wherever a potable and a non-potable source 
are separated by gate valves, check valves or devices other than the appropriate backflow preventer as 
provided by this policy/article. By-pass arrangements, jumper connections, swivel or change over 
assemblies, or other temporary or permanent assemblies through which, or because of which, backflow 
may occur shall be deemed to be cross-connections. 
    Health hazard, (high hazard) means contamination with the potential to endanger the health and well 
being of the consumer. 
    Non-health hazard, (low hazard) means contamination that will not endanger the health of the 
consumer, but does not meet established water quality standards for public water systems. 
    Non-potable water means water not acceptable for human consumption or of unknown quality. 
    Owner means the person shown on the metering and billing records of Clarksdale Public Utilities to 
be the user of water utility services. 
    Person means any individual, firm, company, association, society, corporation, or group. 
    Potable water means water that is acceptable for human consumption. 
    Water system means the public water works and water supply system of the City of Clarksdale, 
Mississippi, operated and managed by the Clarksdale Public Utilities Commission. 
(Ord. No. 970, § 1, 9-7-1999) 


Sec. 20-92. - Backflow prevention assembly requirement. 
(a)	Elimination and protection of cross-connections. It shall be unlawful for any person to permit, 
construct, or maintain a cross-connection with the water system unless the same is protected by an 
appropriate backflow preventer in accordance with section 20-94 of this article. 
(b)	Connections to sewer. Direct connections, permanent or temporary, between the water system and a 
sanitary or storm sewer are prohibited. 
(c)	Home wells. Connection to any source of water other than that provided by the water system, 
including home wells, is prohibited unless a backflow preventer approved in accordance with section 
20-94(a) is installed. 
(Ord. No. 970, § 2, 9-7-1999) 


Sec. 20-93. - Right of entry and inspection of consumer facilities. 
(a)	Right of entry. The Clarksdale Public Utilities, acting through its authorized employee or other agent, 
shall have the right to enter any nonresidential building, during reasonable hours, to inspect the 
plumbing system installed in any subject building or premises upon notification to the owner thereof. 
Nothing herein contained shall be construed to authorize the entry of the Clarksdale Public Utilities 
employee or agent in any single family dwelling without first obtaining the consent of the owner. 
(b)	Elimination or protection of cross-connections. If, upon inspection, a connection is found which is a 
high hazard cross-connection, the owner of the connection shall be notified in writing within ten (10) 
days that the cross-connection must be eliminated or protected by the installation of a backflow 
preventer approved by the water system within ninety (90) days of notification. If a low hazard cross-
connection is found upon inspection, the owner of the connection shall be notified in writing within 
ten (10) days that the connection shall be eliminated or protected by a backflow preventer approved 
by the water system within one (1) year of notification. 
(Ord. No. 970, § 3, 9-7-1999) 


Sec. 20-94. - Approval and testing of backflow prevention devices. 
(a)	Approved backflow prevention assemblies. No backflow preventer shall be installed by the owner at 
any cross-connection except the type of backflow preventer determined by the Clarksdale Public 
Utilities and no backflow preventer shall be installed at a location other than that determined by 
Clarksdale Public Utilities, the determination of the type of backflow preventer and the required 
installation location to be in accordance with guidelines published by the Mississippi State 
Department of Health. 
(b)	Installation requirements. All reduced pressure principle assemblies, double check valve assemblies, 
and pressure vacuum breakers shall be installed in such a manner and in such a location that 1) 
provides adequate access for testing and repair of the assembly, 2) is not subject to possible 
flooding, and 3) is not installed in a pit or enclosure below ground level. 
(c)	Tests required. Each reduced-pressure principle backflow prevention assembly, double-check valve 
assembly, and pressure vacuum breaker installed on the water system shall be tested after 
installation, after repairs of any kind, and annually. Any backflow preventer found to be non-
functional shall be repaired and re-tested within fourteen (14) days of the initial test. 
(d)	Certified testers. Only backflow preventer testers certified by the Mississippi state department of 
health shall test backflow preventers located in the water system. 
(e)	Notification. The water system shall notify the owner of each backflow preventer sixty (60) days prior 
to the date that the backflow preventer is scheduled to be tested. 
(f)	Existing backflow prevention assemblies. All provisions of this article shall apply to any backflow 
prevention device or assembly installed on the water system prior to the adoption of this article. 
(Ord. No. 970, § 4, 9-7-1999) 


Sec. 20-95. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)	Refusal of inspection. If the owner refuses to let the authorized agent of the water system perform 
the necessary inspections to determine if a cross-connection exists, the water system shall install at 
the owner's expense a reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly at that service 
connection, the cost of which shall be added to the first invoice for utility services rendered 
subsequent to the date of the completion of the installation of the backflow prevention assembly. 
(b)	Maintaining a cross-connection. If the owner, after having been informed that a cross-connection 
exists at his property, refuses to eliminate or protect the cross-connection through the use of the 
appropriate backflow preventer, water service to the connection shall be terminated until such time 
as the owner complies with Mississippi State Department of Health regulations, the applicable 
policies of the Clarksdale Public Utilities Commission and this article. 
(c)	Penalty. Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a 
misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined in an amount not exceeding five hundred 
dollars ($500.00) or be imprisoned for a period not exceeding ninety (90) days or be both so fined 
and imprisoned. Each day such a violation is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a 
separate offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 970, § 5, 9-7-1999) 


Chapter 21 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- For privilege tax on operation of vehicles for hire, see privilege tax code, adopted in § 
13-1; provisions requiring operators of vehicles for hire to furnish certain reports regarding moving 
household goods, see § 14-21. 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to regulate, 1942 Miss. Code, § 3495; to fix rates, § 3374-
143. 


Sec. 21-1. - Operators to obtain licenses. 
    It shall be unlawful to drive or operate a taxicab or public dray or conveyance upon the streets of the 
city without having obtained a license therefor from the board of mayor and commissioners, which license 
shall be issued upon the advice and recommendation of the chief of police to said board that the same be 
done. 
(Ord. No. 332, § 1, 4-26-1938) 


Sec. 21-2. - Chief of police to issue license to operator. 
    The chief of police of the city, upon direction of the board of mayor and commissioners, shall issue a 
license to all drivers of taxicabs and of public drays and vehicles who apply therefor and who shall furnish 
to the board of mayor and commissioners satisfactory proof that they are of good moral character, are 
law-abiding and trustworthy. 
(Ord. No. 332, § 2, 4-26-1938) 


Sec. 21-3. - License forms to be provided; posting required. 
    The board of mayor and commissioners shall provide suitable license forms printed on cardboard or 
otherwise, duly licensing the person named therein to drive a taxi or public conveyance over and along 
the streets of the city, which said license shall be posted conspicuously in the vehicle so driven. 
(Ord. No. 332, § 4, 4-26-1938) 
Cross reference- For requirement that privilege license be posted in conspicuous place, § 13-4. 


Sec. 21-4. - Duty of licensees to register; police department to provide records. 
    It shall be the duty of all of those to whom licenses are issued to sign identification cards and to 
register their fingerprints with the police department. It shall be the duty of the police department to 
provide suitable files for said records which shall be open to the inspection of any person interested. 
(Ord. No. 332, § 5, 4-26-1938) 


Sec. 21-5. - Forfeit of license. 
    Any person who has been licensed pursuant to section 21-1, who shall be convicted of any violation 
of the criminal ordinances of the city or the criminal laws of the State of Mississippi, shall forfeit his license 
and all right to act as the driver and operator of the vehicles set forth in section 21-1, and it shall be the 
duty of the chief of police upon information of such judgment of conviction and verification thereof, to 
strike the name of the person so convicted from the list or roll of licensed drivers. 
(Ord. No. 332, § 7, 4-26-1938) 
State Law reference- For authority to revoke or suspend permit, see 1942 Miss. Code, § 3497. 


Sec. 21-6. - Penalty for violation of license provisions. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of sections 21-1 through 21-5 hereof shall be fined not 
less than one dollar ($1.00) or more than fifty dollars ($50.00), or confined in the city jail not longer than 
thirty days, or both such fine and imprisonment may be imposed. 
(Ord. No. 332, § 8, 4-26-1938) 
State Law reference- For similar provision of state law, see 1942 Miss. Code, § 3500. 


Sec. 21-7. - Bond of operators required to insure compliance with law; penalty; cancellation. 
(a)	Bond required; conditions. All operators of taxicabs and public conveyances of passengers for hire in 
the city shall be required to enter into bond in the sum of five hundred dollars ($500.00) with some 
surety company qualified to transact business in the State of Mississippi as surety, conditioned to the 
following effect: 
"That whereas, the applicant desires to operate a motor vehicle under the provisions of 1942 
Mississippi Code, Section 3495, if the said principal shall faithfully comply with and observe all the 
provisions of the law in that behalf applicable, and in addition shall observe all rules and regulations 
which may be prescribed by the City of Clarksdale and shall do all other things of him by law 
required, then this obligation shall be void, otherwise to remain in full force and effect." 
(b)	Penalty for noncompliance. Any driver of a taxicab or motor vehicle for the carrying of passengers for 
hire, who shall not give bond as required herein shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be 
subject to a fine of not more than fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(c)	Cancellation. The corporate surety on said bond shall have the right and privilege to cancel any bond 
upon which it may become surety as herein provided upon giving ten days' written notice to the chief 
of police or clerk of the city. 
(Ord. No. 338, 12-19-1939) 
State Law reference- For municipal authority to require a bond, see 1942 Miss. Code, § 3495. 


Sec. 21-8. - Liability insurance or bond to protect public-Required; amount. 
    No certificate or permit shall be issued by the city to the owner or operator of any motor vehicle 
owned or operated for hire in the city, and no such owner or operator now holding such permit shall allow 
or cause any such motor vehicle to be so operated unless and until such owner or operator shall have 
filed with, and the same has been approved by, the board of mayor and commissioners of the city an 
insurance policy or certificate of insurance in lieu thereof, issued by some insurance company authorized 
to transact business in this state, or bond or bonds to be approved by said board of mayor and 
commissioners in an amount not less than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for death or injury to any 
one person, and subject to said limit for one person, not less than twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) 
for total public liability for any one accident, and not less than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for 
property damage, conditioned to pay any final judgment against said owner or operator for personal 
injuries or property damages resulting from or arising out of the use, maintenance or operation of said 
motor vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 490, § 1, 7-1-1958) 
State Law reference- For state law requiring owners or operators of motor vehicles for hire to 
obtain liability insurance, or a bond in lieu thereof, and specifying the extent of coverage, see 
1942 Miss. Code, § 3495.5. 


Sec. 21-9. - Same-Notice required for cancellation. 
    The insurance policy or bond filed with the clerk of the city as required by section 21-8 of this chapter 
shall contain a provision or endorsement to the effect that the same shall not be cancelled for any cause 
by either party thereto unless and until twenty days' written notice shall have been given to the city. 
(Ord. No. 490, § 2, 7-1-1958) 
State Law reference- For state law requiring notice, see 1942 Miss. Code, § 3495.5. 


Sec. 21-10. - Same-Liability of insurer or obligor; when suit against insured not required. 
    The insurer, insurance company or obligor in any policy of insurance or bond filed in compliance with 
section 21-8 of this chapter shall be obligated to pay any final judgment obtained against such owner or 
operator regardless of solvency or insolvency, bankruptcy or receivership of said owner or operator; 
provided, that in the event the insured shall abandon his permit and leave the state a claimant asserting 
his claim within the provisions of said insurance policy or bond may file suit against the insurer or 
insurance company or obligor issuing such insurance policy or executing such bond in a court of 
competent jurisdiction without the necessity of making the insured a party to said suit. 
(Ord. No. 490, § 3, 7-1-1958) 
State Law reference- For similar requirement of state law, see 1942 Miss. Code, § 3495.5. 


Sec. 21-11. - Same-Penalty for noncompliance. 
    Failure of any owner or operator to comply with any of the requirements of section 21-8 of this 
chapter shall be cause for the revocation or suspension of his permit, or a fine not to exceed one hundred 
dollars ($100.00), or both. 
(Ord. No. 490, § 4, 7-1-1958) 


Sec. 21-12. - Signs to be placed on vehicles; time for compliance; penalty. 
(a)	Signs required. The owner or operator of a motor vehicle operated for hire in the city shall paint or 
place a sign in at least two conspicuous places on said vehicle indicating that it is being operated for 
hire, said signs to be at least four inches in height. 
(b)	Time for compliance. Subsection (a) of this section shall be complied with by all owners or operators 
of motor vehicles for hire prior to the commencement of said operations. 
(c)	Penalty. The failure of any owner or operator of motor vehicles for hire, as herein provided, to comply 
with the requirements of subsection (a) hereof shall constitute a penal offense punishable by 
revocation or suspension of permit to operate said vehicle in the city or a fine not to exceed one 
hundred dollars ($100.00) or both. 
(Ord. No. 492, §§ 1-3, 7-8-1958) 


Sec. 21-13. - Duty of police department to inspect vehicles. 
    It shall be the duty of the police department, by and through the chief of police and police officers, to 
inspect taxicabs and public conveyances to see that they are properly equipped, are safe to be driven 
and are being lawfully used, and upon demand of any police officer of the city, it shall be the duty of any 
person driving any of said vehicles under license as provided in section 21-1 to permit the inspection and 
investigation by such officer of the taxicab or vehicle driven by him. 
(Ord. No. 332, § 6, 4-26-1938) 
State Law reference- For requirement that vehicles for hire be registered, see 1942 Miss. 
Code, § 3498. 


Chapter 21A - VEGETATION 


ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 


Secs. 21A-1-21A-20. - Reserved. 


ARTICLE II. - TREES AND SHRUBS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 906, adopted March 21, 1994, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, 
codification herein as Ch. 21A, Art. II, §§ 21A-21-21A-38 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 17. 


Sec. 21A-21. - Scope and definitions. 
(a)	This article will apply to all trees in the City of Clarksdale, including trees on public rights-of-way and, 
to the extent applicable, trees on private property. This article will apply to trees presently in 
existence and trees to be planted in the future. 
(b)	As used in this article, the following words and phrases will have the following meanings: 
(1)	City: The City of Clarksdale, Mississippi. 
(2)	Private land: Any land not owned by the city, including lands owned by individuals, partnerships, 
corporations or other entities, as well as lands owned by other public agencies. 
(3)	Public land: Any land owned by the city, including street rights-of-way, parks, yards around 
public buildings and the like. 
(4)	Tree: Any woody plant which normally grows to be ten (10) feet tall or taller, regardless of the 
size of the plant when it is first put in place. 
(Ord. No. 906, § 1, 3-21-1994) 


Sec. 21A-22. - Existing trees. 
    It is the policy of the city to preserve the existing trees as shown on the tree plan and inventory, 
jointly prepared by the public works department and the department of culture and recreation: parks and 
gardens. Only trees that are considered desirable to be preserved are shown on the plan. The city will, to 
the greatest extend possible, preserve the trees on public land shown on the tree plan. The city will 
encourage owners of trees on private land to preserve, to the greatest extent possible, the trees on 
private land. If any trees shown on the tree plan on public land should die, the city will, at its earliest 
convenience, replace the trees, either with the same variety or with another variety of tree approved for 
use in the city under the tree plan. The replacement tree may be younger and smaller than the original 
tree. If any such tree on private land shown on the tree plan should die, the director of culture and 
recreation: parks and gardens will notify the owner of the land that it is the policy of the city to recommend 
replacement of that tree, and will notify the owner of the land of the types of trees approved for 
replacement under the tree plan. 
(Ord. No. 906, § 2, 3-21-1994) 


Sec. 21A-23. - Additional trees on public land. 
    Whenever the tree plan shows a proposed tree on public land, it is the policy of the city to plant a 
tree at that location. No tree will be planted at such a time and such a location that it will be destroyed in 
the course of anticipated future construction. Trees shown on a city plan are trees to be added to public 
lands and may be planted, from time to time, as funds are available and as conditions warrant. 
(Ord. No. 906, § 3, 3-21-1994) 


Sec. 21A-24. - New subdivisions. 
    Owners of private lands being developed as new subdivisions will provide trees shown on the tree 
plan in all areas to be dedicated to the city as public streets or other public lands. The subdivider will be 
encouraged by the city to provide the tree on private lands in the subdivision in accordance with the tree 
plan. 
(Ord. No. 906, § 4, 3-21-1994) 


Sec. 21A-25. - Other private lands. 
    The city will encourage owners of all private lands in the city, except for lands covered in the 
provisions referring to new subdivisions, to plant trees in accordance with the city tree plan. 
(Ord. No. 906, § 5, 3-21-1994) 


Sec. 21A-26. - Pamphlet. 
    The director of culture and recreation: parks and gardens, will, with the assistance of the Mississippi 
Forestry Service and the Coahoma County Forester, prepare and distribute a pamphlet for the use of the 
public, without charge to all persons requesting the same and delivered to each person proposing to 
subdivide land inside the city. The pamphlet shall be in such form as may finally be approved by the 
board of mayor and commissioners of the city. 
(Ord. No. 906, § 6, 3-21-1994) 


Sec. 21A-27. - Tree plan adopted. 
    The tree survey on file in the office of the city clerk, and incorporated herein by reference as though 
fully set forth herein, together with the text of this article, shall be and become the official tree plan of the 
city. The tree survey is hereby made a part of the official plan of the city. The details on the tree survey, 
including, but not limited to, locations of existing trees to be preserved, types of trees approved to be 
planted, and locations of proposed additional trees are hereby approved. 
(Ord. No. 906, § 7, 3-21-1994) 


Sec. 21A-28. - Tree trimming on streets. 
    No person shall trim or cut any tree located on any public street right-of-way or on public lands 
unless such work is done by or at the direction of the city, and it shall be unlawful for any person from a 
corporation to cut or fell any tree located on any street, alley, or sidewalk easement within the city without 
a permit from the board of mayor and commissioners of the city. 
(Ord. No. 906, § 8, 3-21-1994) 


Sec. 21A-29. - Request for tree trimming. 
    Any person who wishes to have a tree in any street right-of-way or other public land cut or trimmed 
shall first make a written request to the city clerk to have said work done. The director of culture and 
recreation: parks and gardens shall make a visual inspection of the tree and, if the city determines that 
the tree needs to be trimmed for safety or visual purposes, the city clerk shall issue a permit to the person 
so requested to have the work performed. In the event that said permit is granted, the cutting and felling 
of said tree shall not be allowed to obstruct nor interfere with normal traffic on any of the streets or 
sidewalks of the city, except under conditions set forth in the permit. 
(Ord. No. 906, § 9, 3-21-1994) 


Sec. 21A-30. - Planting. 
    It shall be unlawful to plant any tree or shrub in any public street or parkway or other public place 
without having first secured a permit therefore. Applications for such permits shall be made to the city 
clerk and shall be referred to the director of culture and recreation: parks and gardens for final 
recommendation to the board of mayor and commissioners. No shrubs shall be planted, maintained, or
